text: Smell of yeast, caramel, date, roasted malt. Come in black dark brown with thin cream crown. Taste of balanced sour yeast and sweet bitter malt, with some raisins. Close to Belgium quadruple beer but with less spice for commoners like us. Could experiment more on that. Overall its very good beer.

750mL. Im not gonna bore you with the same details everyone else already posted on this. I will say that given expectations (and given that I generally like the brewer) this one was a bit of a letdown. So many better Quads. Who knows. Maybe its an old bottle. Oh and... fuck the Penguins.

Rami Rami is drinking a La Terrible by Unibroue at Powiśle

Suszone owoce, ciemne owoce, przyprawowosc (pieprz? Gozdziki?ciut kolendry?), melasa, karmel, nieco syropowe, raczej slodkawe w odbiorze [..
Rami Rami: [...] zajebiscie ukryte alko (ciut grzeje i nic ponad to). Sporo CO2. Generalnie klasa piwo, dla mnie ewidentnie najlepsze z Unibroue
Rami Rami: Zaskakujaco lekkie w odbiorze, jak dubbel niejeden
Rami Rami: Nadruk na butelce A09171345Q - ktos umie to odcyfrowac? ;)

Rami Rami: Z takich nutek delikatniejszych, w tle, to jeszcze chleb i banan. Rami Rami: nie napisalem o rodzynkach? duzo rodzynek.

Bottle shared. Pours a clear, deep brown with a full 2 fingers of foam. Big nose of red currants, dates, plum and toffee. Booze is hidden really well with a complex bit of oaky wood and dark, late summer fruit. Smooth and finishes with more fruit and light booze. Very nice.

Its almost inconceivable to me that La Terrible was not brewed inside the walls of an abbey. Its not only completely convincing as a Belgian Abt, its one of the softest-drinking and most cohesive beers Ive tried. Textbook brown-colored pour. Malty and fruity aromas with subtle spices. Taste profile consists of chocolate, prune, plum, raisin, molasses, and dessert wine. The booze is completely hidden away. My bottle had well over a year of age on it, and this brew seemed to be in prime condition.

Unibroue can do it up all right. La Terrible only continues that. A locally obtained 750 ml slice of delight. A wire and cork opening, be sure it is not aimed at anyone after the cage comes off. The good news, I did not lose any product. With a pour I call it inky darkness, you can put any color you want on it. A large, just short of white, finely bubbled head, very nice lacing. The scent is a walk through the orchard. It gives up red plum and maybe fig, red cough drops. The taste, oh my, a yeasty ripe fruit start leading to maltiness, spice and a slight bitterness finishing. The alcohol is looking around the corner at me. Well done.Trois Pistoles may be slightly better. I will gladly take either one.

Bottle.

A- Tart cherry, dark fruits, oak.

A- Dark mahogany color, dark liquid, tan head.

T- Raisins, plums, dark fruits, subtle booze.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, smooth finish.

O- Pretty smooth, granted it had years of age on it and loaded with a variety of dark fruits I cant quite bit a finger on.

Bottled at Clubhouse BFD event. Pours black, tan head, creamy. Aroma is lots of dark fruit, fig, lime, Belgian esters, spice. Flavor is fig, Belgian spice, cinnamon, some nutmeg, lots of raisin. Solid.

750 mL bottle shared by ebone1988 for the stupid book. The pour is a light black with a thick pillowy white head and a pretty soapy lace left behind. The aroma is a little metallic but pretty good overall. There is a Belgian malt and a sweet metallic finish to it. There is a spiciness about it and its just well balanced beyond the metal. The flavor is a little more complex. There is the metallic malts and a nice caramel and dark fruit with the spicy malt and some interesting sweetness on the back end. The mouth feel is light and a little watery with a brighter carbonation and a lingeringly fruity and caramel malts on the back end. Its decent overall, but definitely not my favorite thing.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. For the book. Aroma is raisins, wood, dark fruit, molasses, roasted, good. Appearance is dark dark brown, light brown head, opaque. Taste is dark fruit, woody, raisins, metallic, yeast, dry, slight booze, good. Mouthfeel is medium body, light bubbly carbonation, slightly metallic woody raisin aftertaste. Overall, its pretty good.

Bomber. Pours an opaque coffee color with a dense bubbly and lasting khaki head. Malty aromas of nuts, prunes, cream, oats, and sweet dark bread. Very nice dark cherry, raisin, light chocolate, and clove flavor with a bit of leather. Medium body, medium carbonation. Silky creamy mouthfeel. Somewhat spicy finish. Alcohol is detectible but well hidden. Really, really nice beer. Opposite of the name and all that.

341ml bottle part of a taster pack. Pours an opaque deep brown colour with a small lasting head. Complex aroma with a dark fruit backbone with notes of figs, raisins, prunes, dark cherries, and licorice. Taste matches the aroma with some nutmeg and clove notes. Full-bodied with medium carbonation. It has a nice peppery finish from the booze, the alcohol is there, but its balanced against the flavours. Excellent quad.
From bottle. Aroma of candied fruit and caramel. Pours almost black with tan head. Taste is medium bitter. Full bodied with a thick texture and a slightly bitter finish. Excellent beer.

Bottle from BevMo! in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is dark sweet fruits (figs, prunes), mild chocolate, mild herbal aperitif, burnt sugar. Taste is figs, black cherries...but not quite leathery dried fruit (somehow both juicy and dry). Very rich dark fruit notes and then mildly herbal / bitter. Mouthfeel is pristine...great balance of fizzy and creamy. This beer is definitely on another level. Supremely classic.

Smell of wood, licorice, maple, dense chocolate fruit, leather, and dark basement. Taste is licorice, maple, chocolate cookie, sweet fruitiness, and balanced well. In the glass it looks awesome, still black with a giant thick head that retains. If this doesnt get a perfect score I dunno what does
Pours a dark brown color. Aroma is cloves and spices. Taste has some dried fruit, spices and yeast. Very good
Bottle pours brown with a off white head. This is a very good beer, enjoyed every drop.

Pours a very dark brown with a medium beige head that leaves awesome lacing. Nose is of dark fruits, dark sugar and alcohol. Taste is not quite sweet and offers raisins, figs and candi sugar. Body is medium, carbonation moderate and mouthfeel while a little syrupy is never heavy. Overall a solid quadrupel but the mouthfeel is not even close to Rocheforts really and dark fruits flavors could be more upfront.

Bottle. Dark brown, nearly opaque pour with a rich tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, spices, Belgian yeast, rich and complex, some fruitcake and candy notes, but also slightly roasty. Taste is fairly rich for the style, some chocolate up front, sweet dark fruit and fruitcake spices, raisin, lots going on here but very tasty and nicely balanced.
Dark brown in color with twoish fingers of head. Rich and creamy without being overly thick. Medium mouthful. Cherry notes and great subtle booze warmth in the finish. Really impressive.

Apparence : Brune très foncée, reflets cuivres, trouble, léger col brun foncé ayant une bonne rétention et une belle dentelle, plutôt crémeux, carbonatation semble moyenne. 
Nez : Levure Unibroue, épices, malt. 
Goût : Toasté, malt grillé, notes brûlées rappelant le café, très léger caramel avec une trame de fond épicée non-négligeable de la levure typique de la maison. 
Sensation : Effervescence moyenne-plus (ou seraient-ce les épices?), corps moyen tout comme la longueur en bouche. 
Bref : Je dois dire dentrée de jeu que je mattendais à plus. Javais été quelque peu déçu par leurs autre offrandes foncées et je voulais plus de celle-ci. Dabord, juste au nez, je ne crois pas que jaurais su que javais affaire à une Unibroue que je navais pas goûtée. Leur levure est omniprésente. Ensuite, lentrée en bouche est trop effervescente à mon goût et le corps un peu trop mince. Au goût, cest bien, sans plus. On finit le verre en jasant, mais on nanticipe pas avec excitation la gorgée suivante.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2016 Pours 2 thick fingers of foam, that shrinks to a pillowy beige layer of head. Smell is sweet and bready, some vanilla. Taste is dates, stone fruit, peppery Belgian yeast, Carmel, light vanilla, cola. Palate is medium bodied, with above average carbonation starts sweet finishes dry and peppery. Some alcohol warmth, not overwhelming. Overall- A delicious and complex Quad

Pours extremely dark brown, effectively black... creamy tan head is fizzy at first, but a mocha layer lingers for a long time. Aroma is sweet - toffee, dark berries, currant, gingerbread spice; slight overripe fruit note. Taste is cherry, currant, fig, spice. Some roasty malts, slightly tart finish. Flavours are just a touch thin for my liking. Impressively creamy mouthfeel, both rich and lively. Excellent, but a couple minor flaws keep it from top-tier status.

2015 BJCP Category: 26D Belgian Dark Strong Ale 
AROMA: Rich strong dark malt presence. Very sweet aroma with notes of dark and dried fruits plus peppery phenols and a hint of citrus peel. Alcohol is moderate, but not distracting and complements the bouquet. 11/12APPEARANCE: Deep shade of murky maroon/burgundy/brown proper. Slight highlights. Large, tan, moussy foam mostly dissipates. 2/3FLAVOR: Robust and complex palette. Spicy black pepper sensation up front. Rich sweet dark malt presence with bread and fruitcake flavors throughout. Dried and stone fruit flavor preside from beginning to end. Faint orangepeel in the background. Alcohol imparts a lightly sweet vanilla-like taste. Perceived bitterness is medium-low as is hop flavor (spicy/earthy). Aftertaste is akin to Coca-Cola. 19/20MOUTHFEEL: Medium-full body; highly carbonated but not sharp (but not smooth, either). Finishes surprisingly clean with a sweet vanilla sensation. Alcohol creates for minor, tolerable warmth. Quite drinkable for 10.5% 4/5OVERALL IMPRESSION: Pretty much a perfect beer. To-spec in every way; delicious; drinkable. Cant believe Ive never review this before! 10/10TOTAL SCORE: 46/50DISCLAIMER: The author is not a certified BJCP judge; therefore, this score sheet is not necessarily indicative of proper BJCP judging techniques and protocol. The author is grading to 2015 BJCP Guidelines in order to prepare for examination.

Vieillie 4 ans. Il en reste très peu de carbonatation ni deffervescence. Au nez, les levures belges prennent la vedette. En bouche, trois goûts ressortent clairement du lot - caramel, raisins rouges et alcool. Les raisins rouges (ou même le jus de raisins) dominent beaucoup, avec un profil malté super intéressant.
Pours dark mahogany with a billowy light brown head that holds well; aromas of fruitcake dipped in port; off dry spicy palate; nice soothing finish.

Si on veut une bière de style belge au Québec, il ne faut pas chercher loin, dans tous les épiceries et dépanneurs on peut trouver les produits Unibroue, on ne sait pas quelle chance quon a. Cette quadruple est au top de son style, un tour de force. Le nom et lapparence sombre de la bouteille sont trompeurs, cest loin dêtre terrible et il ny a pas la lourdeur dune bière noire typique. Au nez, lalcool transporte des cerises et des fruits rouges pétillant, un peu comme un Rhum & Coke ( en bien mieux bien sûre). Unibroue ont la recette magique pour rendre autant de saveur concentré en bouche aussi légère et facile à boire, sans résidus sucrés collant. Le côté épicés, un peu poivré, est équilibré à la perfection. La finale est longue et douce. Elle remplace à coup sûre les meilleur vins pendant un souper. Je continue à la déguster :)
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown. Aroma and taste are dark fruits, brown sugar, and some molasses.

Bouteille 750ml, 2012, gracieuseté de SebD lors du CanBIF Spring 2016, Thanks Sébastien! Couleur brune très foncée opaque, mousse moka laissant un anneau sur les parois du verre et une dentelle éparse. Arôme de cerise noire, malt, madérisation, sherry. Goût de malt caramélisé, café, fruits confits, légère amertume, sucré. Carbonatation moyenne-faible, corps moyen-dense.
Dark brown pour with minimal head. Aroma is Apple and raisin. Taste brings raisin and molassus forward. This is a young 2015 terrible. I have a second bottle.stored for future tasting.

750ml bottle at 10.5% means that this guy sat in the cellar while more approachable bottles were cracked open first. And boy did it sit. For at least 3+ years. Im pretty sure it has been down there since the autumn of 2012. (Note, I needed pliers to yank the cork out.) Pours a dark, dark reddish brown with a tan head. On the nose, pressed apple cider, apple tart, raisin, brown sugar, faint woodiness and a light molasses note. Sweet, and lightly acidic with faint woody notes, dark dried fruits, some alcohol burn, faint molasses, and faint tart apple that heads into more of the dark dried fruit notes, with more apple, a light green vegetable taste, and woody molasses notes. This is good. Very good.

Pours darkest brown to black with a nice sized khaki head of tight-bubbled foam that hangs out and leaves ropes and waves of lace. Nose involves red grape, toasty hay, bubblegum, candy sugar, plum, and cocoa. Quite sweet, somewhat tart, somewhat bitter. Lighter bodied considering the size, fairly active, slippery and slick, with a long toasted grain, yeasty, and roasty finish. Really well done, lots of character and complexity, but holding on to some drinkability thanks to the effervescence and body.

750mL bottle poured into a goblet. A potent, medium high intense, aroma is initially a fading dough followed by wood, Cabernet wine grapes, licorice, nuts, mild molasses and caramel, and sweet dates. The effervescent, dark cola brown hued beer is topped by fluffy, creamy fizz, beige head that has mild retention and great, puffy lace. The taste is high sweet cut with a sharp, medium bitter. The thick, smooth, and viscous texture is emphasized by an abundant, creamy body. The medium full body has a wood and licorice flavor up front with brown sugar and grape sweetness. It finishes zippy with alcohol warmth and flavors of licorice and clean, mild clove with cherry pie like notes. The aftertaste is like a full bodied, red wine with pie crust and light molasses.

Bottle from LCBO. In the cellar for at least a year. This is one of the best Unibroue has to offer. Very fond of the others, but this one is just lovely. Very dark reddish brown. Aromas of raisins, grape bubblegum and smells very strongly of port. Similar flavours, with lingering port aftertaste. Very smooth.

2016/02/19 - 2012 vintage bottle. Pours a dark brown (almost black) colour with a fizzy, khaki coloured head that immediately reduces to a patchy, lingering surface film. Aroma is vinous (port like), doughy yeast, brown sugar, dark fruits, grapes, sour notes and light licorice. Taste is dough, notes of port, slightly sour dark grapes, brown sugar and light anise. Mouthfeel is medium To full with effervescent carbonation and a sweet, mildly warming finish. Really enjoy that trademark Unibroue carbonation in this beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Got a smell of brown sugar and wine (dark fruit or port type smell). Appearance is very dark brown, almost black (in the lighting I am in). There is spotty lacing that lasts for the whole time. I am getting Belgium yeast in taste (but didnt get it in the smell), a bit of sourness, brown sugar and malt. The after taste has a huge clove-like feel to it. Very high carbonation - which was too much for my liking. I let it sit for a while and it felt a bit creamier, but carbonation was still there. Felt the alcohol

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2016 Bouteille datée daoût 2012, bue après 52 mois. Robe brune-cuivrée trouble avec un mince col de mousse blanchâtre et laiteux. Arômes de raisin sec, mûre, caramel, confiture de baies, liqueur de fruits, tarte aux bleuets. En bouche, cest une confiture de baies qui assaille le palais. Une tonne de fraises saupoudrées de sucre, datte, mûre, eau dérable, framboise. Finale très axée sur le raisin sec. Haut taux dalcool imperceptible. Texture veloutée et liquoreuse, corps rond. Une bière qui vieillie à merveille.

The cork really popped out of this bottle and the head was huge, so it took me a while to get a good pour. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of malts and years. Flavor is sweet and malty with ripe fruit. No alcohol flavor for such a high alcohol beer, which is nice. Also pretty light and smooth in the mouth.

Bottle. A least a few years old. Appearance is dark black with dense white head. Good lacing and retention. Aroma is anise, some light sourness, mixed in with brown sugar and clove. Taste is stoned fruit, clove, mixed in with a hint of tartness. Really nice beer, had this fresh once and remember it tasting a lot stronger. Tasting really great right now though.

Bottle; pours dark brown with a tan head; aroma of dark fruits, molasses, spice, and a hint of malt; taste is sweet with molasses, dark fruits, and some spice and yeast notes; finish is sweet with some alcohol warming; very nice

Medium aroma with plum and bourbon. Amber color with minimal white head and hazy liquid. Strong taste of cherry, plum and bourbon. Alcohol comes trough clearly. Balanced with medium taste spectrum and long cherry aftertaste. Strong/medium body with low/medium carbonation. Overall, superbly stylish and bold, still balanced product. Could have more aroma.

As with others from this brewery it has the same slight sourness to the aroma that I dont like. Otherwise, this pours a nice dark brown with big, lasting, dense tan head. Aroma has some malt and sour fruit. Flavor is quite different thankfully. Nice balance of malty sweetness and ripe dark fruit. A little light body, like their other similar offerings.
Dark pour, large pillowy head. Aroma and taste of yeast, wheat, cherry, lighter spice notes, molasses. Sticky mouthfeel.

Pours dark red brown with a big light brown head. Nose is strong and sweet with cherry, cake, and a touch of sour. Flavor is similarly potent and malt driven. High carbonation and alcohol presence. Very good.

Shared 750 ml. bottle. Dark brown with creamy tan head. Nice lacing which clings to the glass and slides downward. Aroma is slightly vinous, malt, yeast, hints of cherry. Taste similar to aroma. Marginally sweet. Highly carbonated, creamy, and smooth. A soothing warmth in the finish.

Aroma: can smell alcohol with some fruity and malty undertones; otherwise, not very fragrant; Appearance: almost black with tan head that quickly dissipates; Taste: too wheaty/yeasty for my taste; some complexity but a bit disappointing; Palate: thick, creamy and satisfying; Overall: just cant go over a 12 for a yeasty beer.

Bottle, 750ml. A dark beer with a red hue and a small brown head. Sour aroma with citrics and belgian yeast. Taste is bittersweet with a mild alcoholic finish. Faint carbonation and some astringency. Medium bodied with a sweet aftertaste typical of a Quadrupel.

Bottle, 75cl. Opaque dark ruby with a frothy brown head. Wheaty, sour aroma, with hints of clove, spices, green apples. Moderate to fizzy carbonation. Sweet with low bitterness. Fruity, earthy character, with a fiery, but controlled alcohol finish. Very nice.

Bottle @ The Baroness. Pours dark brown with small foamy beige head, faint caramel aroma, high carbonation, taste starts with sweet molasses and roasted malt flavors, followed by medium bitterness, long syrupy finish. A tad too sticky sweet but still nice.

750 ml bottle. Enjoyed at Los Angeles, CA. Pours a dark brown colour with a small foamy head. Aroma of toasted malts, syrup, plums and some earthiness. Flavour of heavy sweet maltiness, syrup, booze, raisins and some spiciness (ginger at least). Full bodied. Alcohol dominates. A dessert.

75 cl bottle @ hotel room, Los Angeles. BBE 15.04.2015.
Pours clear dark mahogany color with a small head. Sweet ripe fruits on the nose, wood, some caramel mail, mild yeast and spices. Sweet caramel, ripe fruits, licorice, yeast, some spices and subtle dark berries. Complex, nicely aged Quad. Nice. 
6335

750ml bottle
BBE 04-15-2015 - 
Pours dark brown, with a smooth head. Aroma of raisins, sweet syrup, caramel, toffee, ripe fruits and berries. Taste is sweet, heavy and raisiny with loads of sweet syrup, berries and brown sugar. Finish is sweet, smooth and complex with loads of raisins, ripe berries and licorice. Heavy.

75 cl bottle @ hotel room, Los Angeles. BBE 15.04.2015. Aroma has raisins, some ripe fruits and sweet malt. Flavour has raisins, some mild salmiac and licorice. Finishes with warming alcohol Somewhat foamy palate. Like ultrabrune with salmiac added.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2015 Bottle to glass. Aroma is brown sugar, cinnamon, brown bread. Dark brown, foamy, creamy, tan head.Tastes like a Bahamian spiced rum cake. Yummy and thick.Alcohol is present, but not offensive.Feel is thick and creamy, but bubbly as well.Really nice. Trois Pistoles on crack.
Pour from bomber, frothy, carbonation on the heavy end. Nose is malty and raisiny. Taste is toasty, raisin, caramel, surprisingly smooth. Well done brew.
Corked bottle pours dark brown with lots of head. Fruity and toasty. Taste is earthy and umami. Smooth.

Shared at Kyoto Brewings launch party in Kyoto. A deep reddish brown with a beige head. 10.5% a nose of sweet fruity cherries with a soft light silky body. A sweet chocolatey cherry flavor. Tasty and smooth.
Draft. Dark cola pour with a thick tan head. Somewhat overwhelming yeast profile with a little chocolate and dark fruit. Kind of weird.
Dark pour, thin tan head. Nose is dark, soft fruit. More sweet than bitter. Middle is tobacco, plums, and a hint of pepper. Finish is sweet and long. ABV hidden quite well. Try this.

Pour on tap, dark black pour with creamy tan head, aroma brought big notes of dark fruit, caramelized sugars, toffee, molasses into some spice, clove, some slight vanilla into a bit of cocoa. Taste was a mix of earth, cocoa, yeast into a bit of caramel, molasses, lots of raisin, plum, touch of spice, finishing sweet.

Pours an opaque chestnut with garnet highlights, and a big fluffy tan head that persists as significant lacing and decorative skim.
Nose is sweet malt, roast nuts, dark fruits, ginger. On the palate, the major notes include caramelized banana, grapes and raisins and a spunky spiciness that mixes ginger with coriander and orange zest. Theres a bit of alcohol burn on the end along with bitter cola, but its more of a suggestion than a serious misstep.

Pours a dark brown, fluffy tan head that pillows up and recedes into fine lacing. Aromas are of subtle spices...ginger, cinnamon and some clove. Light roasted malt creeps in along with some alcohol. Taste has a nice crisp edge to it. Spices dance across the palate on a medium-to-high carbonation...which counterbalances the big malt bill nicely. Plenty of dark fruit tang along with earthiness and light roast. Finishes with a bit of alcohol sting, but its pretty well masked. Solid.

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark brown with a offwhite head. Aroma of malt, yeast, dark fruits, spice. Flavor is light sweet, malty, yeast, dates, spice, coriands. Thin to medium body, average carbonation. 300810

Pours a deep brown almost black color. Aroma is of ripened prunes mixed with a sweet toffee. Taste is full flavored with strong alcohol mixed with ripened sweet fruit. A simple malt flavor which is overpowered by the alcohol content but very well balanced. Another good beer from a great brewery.

Bomber shared by KyotoLefty. Dark fruit nose, some breadiness, and stale cake. Dark trnaslucent brown. Deep pruney initial, goes to fizzy raisins, some small bit of oxidation, with a mild sweet finish.Medium-heavy body, a little slick. Mildly tasty, a bit too sweet. Very malty. Okay.

Bottle from Hegedorns. Fruity nose, grapes, chocolate, caramel, coriander maybe. Quite fruity, citrus, grape, cherry. Flavor like a spicy brownie, with tangy fruits. A bit too much spice, and the body rather thin. I was really excited about this, but although nice enough it came nowhere close to my expectations.

Im so thrilled to have got the chance of grabbing a bottle of this refined brew after waiting for like 2 years! Very enjoyable pour of a deep brown shade of high opacity topped by a sustantial tanned head finely structured and letting guess a creamy feel. Retention is excellent and lacing is verry god, too. The nose is dense wih sweet banana, roasted malts, yeasts and a sweet/bitter spicy presence I couldnt identify. This ale is sweet, spicy and nutty with again candied banana and a great harmony between the hops and yeasts giving it lots of depth. I found the bitterness just right, giving kick to the taste but without overpowering anything. The mouthfeel can be described as dense, vapory and creamy bearing a slight sharpness at first hand. The downer is a mild aftertaste but no ale is perfect.This brew evolves as it heats so serve it cold and let it reach 10 - 12 degrees to release more boldness. Overall the best features of this ale (besides its name) were its depth, density and originality compared to other brews offered by Unibroue. Very happy I can say I tried it!

Aromas of candy sugar and spice. All malt and spice; not much hops. Some dough. Lots of spice- clove, all spice.

Appearance is dark brown; even at the edges though a bit of dark red at the edges. Moderate sized quite light tan head.

Taste has a little sweetness, probably mostly from the alcohol. Not much real bitterness.

Body is pretty full. Texture is kind of interesting with a bit of oil and a touch of creaminess; a little towards the thick side.

Finish is carbonation and spice; pretty long.

Overall its pretty good. Not complex enough to rate higher, dominated by candy sugar and spice.
Dry white grape aromas with some meaty undertones. Bone colored head and dark brown body. Earthy belgian yeast and veggie flavor with some rootyness. Smooth.
Wonderful aroma, dried fruits, yeast, slightly herbal. Taste brings more of the same, earthy, rich, vibrant. Dark brown \ ruby body, small airy head, finish could be longer.
2.5 years old but not in the best conditions. Fresh yeast in aroma.round brown sugar in aroma. Dominated by dark malts but sourness appears later. Maybe to simple.
Burnt raisin, sweet, subtle toasted malt and tart fruity aroma. Subtle champagne-like yeast. Raisiny flavor; dark fruit, sweet. Sour apple-sh fruit. Earthy yeast. Sweeter in the finish.

on tap @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Clear, very dark brown color, good light beige head, dots and spots of lace. Taste is malt and dark fruit and loamy fresh turned earth, but mostly, it is the warmth of alcohol, which is more of a distraction than a positive quality. Good, not great.
Bomber shared with my pal josh at club w... very dark pour wih big head, arouma is sour fruit, taste is incredible, very smooth, some grape, love it
Bomber. Deep brown with a beige head. Sour raisin aroma. Grape and candi flavors.

750 ml caged and corked bottle, back of bottle says best before 04-15-2015. Served in a chalice, the beer pours very dark brown with about an inch tan head that stuck around for a little while. Theres also a decent amount of lacing. I like the aroma, the brew smells like dark fruit, brown sugar, chocolate, caramel, dark bread and a sweet spiciness. For the most part I think the taste is just like the aroma, but theres also some earthiness and a bit of tart cherries noticeable. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its smooth, a bit coating, and has a good amount of soft carbonation. Overall I liked this, certainly worth picking up if youve never had it before!
Not bad but better in small doses. Has a really strong flavor that sits in the mouth a little long.

Draft at Ale Marys. Pours extremely dark brown with a very thin tan head. Tastes very smooth, like raisin, caramel, earth, light alcohol, malty. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like raisin, nutty, caramel, earth.

On tap it is very dark brown with a red tint and modest beige head. Taste is malt with fruit and spice in some complexity. Very smooth with great mouthfeel. There is a faint hint of alcohol but it is along the lines present in a good port or sherry, It all works nicely and is a very good beer.

Sampled at Northgate Tasting. Worth a second look since my rating was quick and much lower than the average... but this was darker with a dirtier taste, and I just wasnt feeling the love here. Still want a second look at this one.

not sure of the age on mine, but man, is it "refined" like the brewers descriptions says. I had hopes for this one, but I gotta say, I think this brewery is overated and a little rough around the edges usualy. But then comes Terrible, a fantastic dark, roasted, subtly spiced belgian strong ale that made me rethink what Unibroue is capable of. Some similar flavors (dark fruit, yeast, spices) that other belgians have had, but more elegant and restrained here, with a choclatey aspect as well as wine-like complexity. Full bodied, full flavored, expertly balanced. Easily their best beer, and one of my favorite Canadian beers of any kind. "

It has a very dark brown colored body that is nearly opaque. A tall tan head of big soft bubbles slowly settles down to a finger of thick and creamy foam. Lacing is thick, sticky and coats the glass. The aroma is light and delicate. I get modest hints of sweet bready and mildly funky yeast with some fruity notes of dark cherries. There are fruity/estery notes with hints of sweet-tart black cherries, dry yeast and bready maltiness. This is balanced by a very light herbal leafy hop presence that also adds a light bitterness and a slight mineral or metallic touch. The palate feels smooth and creamy with mellow yet very active carbonation and a good solid medium to full body.

Bottle served in a tulip. Past its drink by date by almost a year. Pours near black with a short beige head. Almost no lacing. Nose has heavy bleu cheese, malt and background prune. Mild sweet with a hint of sour. Medium body, sticky texture, decent carbonation and a moderately dry, light bitter finish. The alcohol is well hidden. This would likely rate better if it were fresh.

750 ml bottle. I purchased this at Market Basket, I always walked past it thinking it was mediocre. Well yet again I am wrong. The thing I love about beer is it can alway surprise you, this beer did just that. Dark brown with amber hues, thick white head. severed in a chalice. Aroma is plums, raisins, anise, light red grapes and Belgian yeast. Spilt 3 ways with family and friends. 
More complex and real surprising for a brew you can find in a super market! Flavor is a myriad of malty flavors with yeasty notes. Prunes, figs, dates, English toffee. The yeast gives the malt some balance and complexity. Fruity yeasty flavors, cherries, red grapes giving a mild port wine flavor. This brew is sweet but still works. The texture is smooth with a medium body with a mild sugary finish. Could be the best brew I purchased at a super market!

Pours a dark semi translucent chocolate with tan fluffy head. Subtle roasty nose with funky yeast . Taste is a flash of sweet malt then bubbly effervescent bitter vegetal spicy yeast. I think I just dont care for Unibroues yeast.

Sweet Belgian yeast, strong malt (medium roast), dark fruit focused. Some alcohol on the finish. Sweet, yet not overly sweet or syrupy. Long finish boasts lots of plum and raisin. Hints of earth and anise. Mild spices arent overpowering, yet adds to the balance. Well made brew.

Pours jet black with off-white head. Frothy head, substantial lacing. Sweet citrus, yeast on the nose. Dark fruit (dates, figs, plums), Belgian yeast, hints of caramel and vanilla, with a touch of bitterness on the back of the tongue. A delightful dark ale.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2017 Bière noire présentant quelques subtils reflets rouges brunâtres, parfaitement opaque, effervescence difficile à observer mais qui semble assez élevée, et surmontée dun col couleur moka très dense, très mousseux, presque crémeux, et bien persistant. Arôme de levure belge (typiquement Unibroue!), avec tout de même pas mal de petits fruits foncés (mûre, raisin, cerise noire, prune), voire confits (pruneau), du pain grillé, de la pâtisserie (gâteau aux dattes!) et des sucres foncés (caramel foncé, mélasse, chocolat brun). On note également certains effluves dalcool, ainsi que des nuances et de malt fumé (bonne tendance charcuterie, viande fumée) et dherbes fraîches (gazon, feuille verte, herbes aromatiques). Nez fort agréable, complexité et intensité bien élevées. En bouche, pétillement assez élevé sur la langue, onctuosité intéressante au palais, cest rond, moelleux et velouté. Au goût, entrée en bouche pas mal sucrée (caramel, mélasse, chocolat brun), avec beaucoup de petit fruits foncés voire confits (surtout raisin, cerise noire et prune/pruneau). Aussi, saveur de pain grillé, nuances de malt fumé, avec levure belge bien présente en bouche (esters fruités, poire surtout, et phénols épicés et herbacés), mais tout de même moins dominante quau nez. Lalcool est également présent, mais cest très bien intégré. La fin de bouche apporte une certaine amertume aux accents subtils de houblon floral et herbacé, qui accompagne à merveille une finale surtout alcoolisée, chocolatée et fumée. Excellente intégration des différentes saveurs entre elles, complexité et intensité en bouche très élevées. Excellente bière! ///// Jai déjà bu une Terrible vieille de 4 ans et demi, et ce fut une dégustation fort intéressante. Explosion de caramel et de fruits foncés confits! Mais pas nécessairement une amélioration globale du produit

Poured from 750mL bottle (best before 01-18-2018, saved for a year). Light black with tan head. Aroma has lots of sweet raisin, fig, and plum, a little unibroue belgian yeast and citrus notes. Taste similar, but the alcohol comes through and gives it a little kick.

Poured in to a tulip. This beer pours a very black with a head of toasted caramel that reaches 1.5 fingers and doesnt let go. the scent and taste go hand in hand with coffee and earthy nutty flavor. This is a awesome ale brewed to perfection and gives the best taste aroma I have had yet

Decent, but it doesnt taste like a real Belgian to me. Unibroues yeast isnt particularly interesting, and this beer is overly sweet. All I am getting is molasses, brown sugar, dark candi sugar, and a little plum/fig/date flavor. Next time Ill stick with Trois Pistoles, a much better beer.

Pours earthy chestnut brown with a massive foaming bubbly tan-white head. Leaves wet lacing and fades to a rim and light coating. Aroma is strong with Belgian yeast, slightly smoky malt and mild notes of darkfruit. Taste is rich and malty with a sweet finish. Plenty of flavors - caramel, prunes, cherries and a yeasty echo. Just a touch of alcohol evident. Very good; a touch too sweet for excellence.

Bottle at home from backlog notes 07. Pours a hazy darker brown color with a medium plus sized beige head. The aroma and flavor have caramel, brown sugar, raisins, spices, the typical Unibroue yeast, this was one of the early bigbbeers for me and I still enjoy many of the Unibroue lineup.

Dark brown with lasting thin tan head; aroma is slightly smoky malty and sweet Belgian yeast; Flava is richly malty with considerable tangy/tart fruity (cherry?) notes with malty sugary backbone; feels a bit light but fizzy and zingy; finishes sweet malty tangy

750 ml bottle from La Vista Liquor. Pours coffee black with a thin khaki head that doesnt retain, little lacing. Aroma of figs, plums, sweet cherries, black grapes, alcohol, and caramel malt. Has vinous and port-like qualities in the aroma and flavor. Earthy notes, not too sweet due to the dry yeast influence and high attenuation. Very little bitterness, more fruity, sweet, and vinous. Alcohol is apparent but not too much, still smooth to drink.

Transfer from BA review on 5-12-12- 
Served in a 10 oz chalice glass

Appearance  Served a deep brownish-red, nearly black color with a tiny off white head. The head faded fast to give only a little bit of lacing.

Smell  The aromas are big and bold of dark fruit. Cherries and plum are quite big and when mixed with a lighter alcohol, yeast, and sweet fig aroma give a very nice fruity smell.

Taste  The taste follows the nose very nicely. A cherry sweetness starts out the taste. There is a lighter tasting dark bread flavor mixed with the cherry. These flavors are soon met with some other darker fruit flavors that come to the tongue. The fig and plum that were present in the nose, as well as some lighter flavors of molasses and yeast mix with the cherry and bread. At the end these flavors mingle with a light warming alcohol flavor, that all in all, leave a very pleasant sweet and warming aftertaste on the tongue.

Mouthfeel The mouthfeel is a bit above normal in thickness for the average brew, but light for a beer of this high abv. The carbonation level is quite average and very appropriate for matching the body and the flavors. 

Overall  This was one very nice and tasty brew. It had some great dark fruit flavors with just the right hint of warming alcohol to make it very easy to sit back and sip with enjoyment.

Dark brown color. Touch of head. The aroma and flavors are prunes, bready yeast funk, touch of raspberry. Supremely yeast-heavy. Sour cherry and a dank cellar. Smooth but dry feel. This beer is no joke but its delicious, my mom says it has "too much flavor!"
750ml ($12.49) First time Ive ever had this. This is a flavored beer. kinda wine tasting beer too. Not my favorite at all. high strength but its got a taste like pruno.

This is the second time Ive had this beer and the second time I believe its pretty over rated.
The date I see is a best before 1/18/2018 stamped on the back of the bottle.
I poured this into a chalice.
The appearance was a decent looking dark color with a half finger white foamy head that rises a tad and eventually lowers leaving a decent coating of a lacing gracing the sides of the glass.
The smell was once again just like the last time, too vinous, with some light plums and Belgian spices.
The taste was sweet but vinous over taking the Belgian spices that wanted to come out but never did. There was a vinous-like plum sweet aftertaste with a long dry finish.
On the palate, it sat about a medium with a pummeling dry-ing like effect putting my tongue into submission. The carbonation is decent for the style and to me. Its vinous and harsh and dry.
Overall, Belgian Strong ale, well, I guess it is, but theres too much vinous qualities in this one. This is the second time Ive had this and probably the last time.
750ml bottle. Poured an opaque black with a frothy tan top with amazing lacing and head retention. Taste of Belgian yeast, plum, fig, with a quite boozy finish. High carbonation, medium body.
Poured a dark reddish brown from a 750 ml bottle. Long lasting head with a sweet fruity aroma. Flavor was malty, fruity, with a strong sweetness. Was ok but just not my type.
My least favorite of the Unibrue regulars. Very malty, not much head. Lots of fruit.

A dark dark ruby color pour. I hard a very hard time opening this bottle. The top of the cork broke off and left me with a flat top cork flush against the opening of the bottle. A corkscrew did not work because of the protruding shape of the cork and I was forced to carve away at it until I can push it into the bottle. Finally I can drink it and it is well worth the wait! Dark fruits and spices everywhere in this beer! Aroma of funk, stone fruit, alcohol, red wine and something else...possibly tree bark or leaves? The fruit is wine and plum I think. Flavor has a musky overtone to it...or that is the cork I dont know. So good it tastes pure even though I know it isnt quite.
I prefer Unibroues Trois Pistoles, however, apart from a slight odd taste that I cant pinpoint, La Terrible is a good choice.

Pours a dark coffee with medium tan head which has high retention. Smells like dark fruit and port wine. Tastes like port, dried black cherry, tart dark fruit with an earthy balance. Medium carbonation with a really smooth drinkability. One of my favorites!

Bomber share thanks to Matt. Appearance: three fingers of khaki head, dark red-brown color, clear. Aroma: lemon, brett, basement yeasty, light raisin, plum. Palate: medium body, dry finish, light carbonation. Taste: super sweet-light fruity tartness. Overal, great balance, unique beer. My new favorite from Unibroue

On tap at the hollywood gardens. Odd mild perfumy aroma. Yes, first taste is strong and spicey. However, you would never think this stuff was near 11%, way to civilized for that. Yes, hides alky well. Not much co2 and finish is quite medicinal. I think Im getting dizzy half way thru this glass.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Opened a bottle from 2011 which was pure heaven. The pour is a dark viscous burgundy with a fizzy tan head that en cloaks the glass with sticky lacing. The nose is rich and sweet with dessert like fruit and toffee aromas, mild prune and raisins blend well with a dusting of cocoa and heaps of molten toffee and caramel. Delicious mid palate with heaps of fruit and sweet malts. Delicious warmth on the finish with delactable cherries, raisin and prunes. Great brew

Bomber with 1yr age into a big glass mug. Has a really dark root beer brown color. Opaque. Large tan head that fizzles quick. Nose is of bread, yeasts and fruits. Smells like a belgian. Lots of fruit flavors, and yeast bread flavors. Good mouthfeel. Not too bitter, and not too malty. Pretty nice Belgian.

Poured into a tulip glass. Pours an inky black, with a large rocky brown head which slowly dissipates and leaves good lacing. Nose is chocolate and coffee. taste is chocolate, coffee, and dark fruit. Delicious. Another winner from Unibroue.

one year old 750 ml Bottle.. Ive had this beer quite a few times and never had the chance to review it.. Nice thick layer of dark foamy head (a whippet I like to call ha ha ) very delicate beer for a quad smells like dark chocolate, good cofee, very grainy smell, wow... the taste is even better cofee and figs a small hoppy aftertaste, some other spices very crisp when aged mix with Unibroues one of a kind yeast.... it doesnt get any better than this !!! in my top 10 if not my top 5
Nice malty spiced aroma (rum?) Dark chocolate color with a thin but creamy head. Strong but smooth taste. Sweet finish. Excellent for the class. Excellent drinkability for the class also!
Complex aroma, dried fruit, rum, dates, dried figs flavors, vanilla, burnt sugar. Light/medium body.

Aromas of clove and other spicy phenols, and dried dark berry fruit, roasted malt, and subtle banana. Very dark, almost black, with ruby-bronze highlights, head is minimal but long-lasting. Dry and spicy, with a savory earthiness, herbaceous, bitterness redolent of citrus fruit rind. Medium bodied, refreshingly carbonated, finishes with lingering fruity esters and earthy bitterness.
Tap at devils advocate. Tulip. Dark plum Color. White head. Sour dark fruit smell. Dark fruit and sour taste with nice finish. Mouthfeel works for me. Definitely not terrible.

Tap pour at Devils Advocate. Tulip glass with a deep plum color. This one is definitely in the Belgian sour vein. Aroma is really good. Taste is dark fruit and sugar prevalent. The end is slightly bitter but overall quite easy to drink. Not sure more than one in a night is recommended.
Just catching up on some old ratings from Untappd -- First rated on 16 May 2011 thanks to a bottle share with some buddies!
Draft at craft ale house. Pours deep mahogany with with large tan head. The aroma is fruity with some brown sugar. The taste is sweet dark fruit and a booziness . Ok

Draft at Khyber Pass. Walking into this beer completely blind. Poured way darker than expected. Good amount of tiny tan bubbles on top. Sweet, dark and complex. Burnt wood tea. Dark fruit: Raisins. Prunes. Bing cherries. Dark vegetables: Rotted celery, kale and artichokes. Dark malty spice: Chocolate covered espresso beans. Cigars. Black peppercorns. Nutmeg. Ultimately feels a bit watery but the palate is very broad and deep. Worth sipping and enjoying.

This beer has flavor throughout it. Great nose, earthy nutty, anise, vanilla that smells tasty and tastes tasty, but the lack of carbonation in this 750ml corked bottle was extremely disappointing and I would of expected more. Might be bad or oxidized beer.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2014 This was interesting. Poured into tasting glass a dark brown. Cloudy with small head. I expected this one to be a big beer but it is simpler. Aroma was yeast, wine, malt. Taste had a wine note, dark fruits, light yeast. Nice malt balance. Warming, sticky. This for me is a stand alone, after dinner beer. Not at all terrible and very easy to drink for a higher ABV. This is another Unibroue with well hidden alcohols. SECOND TRY FROM AGED BOTTLE, I had a bottle stored for about a year that was aged by store but no dates on it I could see so not sure of true age. It gets less yeasty and more fruity. Dark fruits, figs, plums. Alcohol hidden. Even better cellered.

Very easy to drink, or should I say dangerously easy to drink. No booze burn which isnt easy when your over double digits abv. Went extremely well with the spicy Indian dish for dinner, and used their recommendation for an after dinner drink. Dark fruit, mulled wine flavor, nice easy carbonation, smooth like velvet.
Wow la surprise elle vaut le prix très réconfortant et à boire avec modération elle cogne

Bouteille 750ml de noire avec une belle mousse bien dense. Arôme de cerise, de réglisse, de cassonade. Arôme complexe et enivrante. Au goût on retrouve des notes de cerise, un peu dacidité et damertume avec une présence dalcool. Elle est assez douce malgré tout et un peu sucré. Très bon produit.
Aroma of malt and sour mash, dark ebony colour with a creamy head. Taste of malt with a hint of caramel and peppery palate.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2014 Poured from a room temperature bottle. Dark brown color, medium off white head. Medium mash and malt aroma. medium caramel malt with pepper accents and a light finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Its sad to say but I finally am not wowed by a brew from Unibroue. Everytime I pass a bottle of the Maudite I salivate. I tried this one. Dark caramel color. No head. High carbonation. Welchs grapejuice, Sunday communion sensiblity. Lacks body. Seems too simplistic, like some first draft of a brew or first batch gome awry. Floral, fruity but lacking the booziness. But then again every brewery is entitled to at least one brew you are not thrilled about.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2014 Très "banane" comme bière. Avec ce taux de sucre/alcool, ça tombe prèsque sur le coeur... Je croyais à une "mauvaise bouteille" au début mais ça cest confirmé à la longue. Je peux comprendre que certains aiment, mais ce nest définitivement pas mon genre.

Dark brown pour with small tan head. Chocolate malty smell, caramel toffee and burnt sugar and a hidden alcoholic nose. Mildly sweet and a pretty huge alcoholic warmth. Chocolate and dark roasted coffee beans and some apple/pear like aftertaste. Medium bodied with quite the carbo bubbels. Really really love it! From a trade with Alehunter, thanks a lot for this brew Dominic. My first Canadian beer.

Aroma: Pleasant fruity aroma 

Taste: Rich fruity taste paired greatly with a dark maltiness, finishes with warm smooth alcohol finish

Appearance: Dark clear amber with thin white bubbly head

(750mL from the LCBO, aged 1 year) Pours a very deep brown with mahogany highlights, like a strong cup of coffee, with a big pale tan head of fine bubbles, lots of lace. Aroma is dark fruit (seems figgy), dark candy sugar, very bready yeast, a bit of cherry note and maybe slight toast in there too. On the palate there is dark grape juice, candy sugar, some other misc. dark fruit character, slightly toasty/nutty but not very much. Yeast character throughout the sip. There is some currant/grape character in the middle and a definite dry/bitter character to the finish with persistent yeast/fruit. There is decent concentration of flavour, but its not shockingly intense. There is a fair amount of alcohol warmth in the finish, but probably not enough to match the ABV. The palate is medium full and would be slightly sticky without the high, prickly carbonation. I like this, its a good Belgian strong dark, but maybe just lacks the complexity to kick it into that top rank.

This has been in my fridge forever. There was a time when I loved unibroue, now it takes a lot to get me to want to open one up as they all taste and feel the same, and not in a favorable way to me. Dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of liquid bread with toasted malt, yeast and light fruit. Taste of strong bready yeast, brown sugar, mild dark fruit and some sweet malt. Finishes up a bit boozy and so uninspiring. I promptly filled my spot in the fridge with Unibland 17, wonder how long that will sit there.

Dark with an effervescent but quickly disappearing head. Light fig and date sweetness followed by a moderately liquorice aftertaste. Lighter body than the color suggests and highly carbonated. Can't believe the ABV quoted until you drink the whole bomber. Luverly!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The aroma is Belgian yeast, earthy. Pours dark brown, the head is light brown, frothy, fully diminishing with excellent lacing. The taste is a light sour with some bitterness. The body is medium/full, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish a long bitter/sour. A good beer. Always been a Canadian fan, since we have to go south to get there! And Unibroue is one of the best!

Pours a deep mahogany that has sublte hues of cola and dark caramel brown. Impeccable clarity even though it is almost completely opaque. If you turn you attention to the bottom of the glass you can clearly see the tiny champagne like bubbles rising furtively to the top. The head is tan and creamy. Its slow to fall and it constantly refreshes with each turn of the glass leaving a pretty thick layer on top. Sheets of lace to look at as they slid back down into the beer as you drink. 

Nose is belgian yeast, earthy and woody. Te vibrant scent of ripe cherries. A dark fruit quality overall but nothing you can pinpoint and call raisin or fig or prune. The malt is perfectly roasted with an earthy depth of its own. It seems to come right to the edge of all the dark roast scents like chocolate or coffee but stops right at the edge of the yeast. That is terribly exciting as its grain promises a smooth and rich earth all its own with only a hint at sweetness on the nose that isnt from fruit. Its a touch nutty as ti warms. There is some clove to round out the nose. 

The taste is pure delight. It has the tart and lively cherry, the earthy dryness of the belgian yeast, the depth of the roasted malt. The malt is as smooth and delicate as such a dark roast could possibly be. The clove and spice add a bit more complexity. The carbonation is ticklish and tiny bubbles that add to the lightness of the body. The drink is just a touch boozy and to your delight. It is only a faint warmth as you swallow and the carbonation lightens that as well. 

Add this one to the beers you must have by unibroue. Expressive in the glass from its stately appearance to its sumptuous flavors. This beer is vigorous and bewitching.

Gosh, this is a very very very good beer. Let town by a lack of head, despite its very effervescence pour, Cherry and liqueur aromas fade to a more familiar belgium type, but this is to behold. The slight entrance of bitter does it no harm ,and there is a lot to enjoy. Easy easy draining, would go out of my way to get another.

Beautiful dark (almost black) colour, completely opaque. Aroma caramel, toffee & dark fruits. Taste is sweet dried fruits, hazelnuts, roasted malts, dark chocolate & just a hint of sour cherry. Very full bodied. Really nice beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

8 nov 2013, bottle. Dark brown. Nose is malty, grapes, alcohol. Med body, a tad fizzy, a tad syrupy. Grape jelly, black currants, alcohol. Decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft to taster. Looks good; a cloudy darker brown with off-white lacing. Smells of dark fruit, Belgian yeast, and spices with a rich semi-sweet backbone. Tastes like it smells with a pleasant, mouth-watering mouthfeel. Good beer.

Dark, nearly opaque with a tan head that had wonderful lacing. Aroma was promient with dried raspberries and lite chocolate notes. Flavor was boozy, yeasty, and juicy with a mild bitterness and a bright, hot finish that lasted. Groovy beer.

Refrigerated corked and capped 75 cl brown bottle poured into a trappist glass. Pours dark brown with chestnut brown highlights with small beige head. Aroma dark candy sugar, low/medium carbonation, very little lacing, and medium body. Taste is dark candy sugar, some dark fruit, and hint of alcohol.

Good beer for my 600th rating, pours dark brown with a light tan head. Aromas of spiced dark fruit and yeast. Flavor is similar, lots of rich and complex flavors. No hint of the 10.5% abv at all. Finish is long and smooth. So good. This is one of the best Unibroue beers I have had to date.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 At Red Lion. Really this was fantastic. Chewy, spiced, yeasty and strong. Dried boozy fruit flavors. I love that they knew the beer was so good that they didnt even change the name of the English speaking market. Serving: Bottle
Dark black beer. Has a fruity smell and taste, perhaps spiced fig. A very unique flavor, and one I enjoyed a lot.

Brune, presque noire, avec des reflets rougeâtres avec une mousse beige-crème. Nez danis, de bonbons et un petit quelque chose dépicé. Au goût, cest encore lanis, les épices et le sucré des friandises qui prennent place, en plus de lalcool et le caramélisé, on retrouve une petite sensation de cerise qui rappelle les vins fortifiés. La finale est ronde et douce.
Bottle - Vintage 2011 - Raisin, dark sugars and lots of yeast. Cloudy jet brown with a beige full head. Raisin, fig, dark molasses a little alcohol. Well balanced and very nice, alcohol is in check.

03-03-2011. 750ml bottle, poured into a snifter.

A- Deep, dark ruby, almost completely opaque. Topped with a thin, sticky beige head.

S- Dark fruits and alcohol, some bready malt in the background.

T-BIG dark fruits, figs and dates come to mind. You can pick up on some malts in the background just like in the aroma. Alcohol is prickly and complex but not overwhelming. Light spices. 

M- Smooth, medium body. Good carbonation.

D-Could sip at this all night, very drinkable for 10.5% ABV

This brew is easily my favorite of Unibroues Dark Belgians, the complexity makes for a very enjoyable experience. Must try.
Poured from a bottle, San Diego. Powerful aroma of fruit and sweet, rich malts. Deep brown-black, lively head but not creamy. Not too yeasty, but a rich fruitiness on the acidic side. Great beer.

Portion of a 750ml bottle into a Duvel tulip. From two day old notes.

A: Pours a dark ruby color. A two finger khaki-colored head is formed, and retains itself nicely. Minimal lacing.

S: I notice a bit of earthy, bready yeast, which slowly builds into dark fruits. Chocolate even pops up at times. The person I drank with found this to have a funky aroma. I wouldnt say funky, but I would say complex.

T: The fruit esters on the opening really make themselves known immediately. Not just with stewed dark fruits (raisins, plums, figs, etc...), but with a strong cherry note, also. Actually, this is ridiculously cherry forward. Slight chocolate touches give way to a bready finish. Just a really balanced, likable BSDA.

M: This has a good thickness, a creamy feel, solid carbonation, and a dry finish all at the same time. When I was sipping it, I half-thought it was a well-hidden 8%...when I found out it was really 10.5%, I nearly fell on my face. One of the more dangerous brews Ive encountered in terms of drinkability.

O: I really enjoyed this one. Like I said before, dangerous is the key word here - this could perhaps be chugged. Theres enough flavor and complexity to make one want to sit and savor this instead...and last time I checked, thats the hallmark of a great beer.

750 ml bottle. Pours a darker brown to black with a beige head of foam. Aroma is caramel, vanilla ice cream, and vanilla beans. Taste is fairly sweet and spicy. Lots of esters. Overall, nice, bit could take some more flavor. Pretty good.

Solid dark brown with a good sized beige head. Aroma is brown sugar, plums, yeast, raisins, caramel, fig. Full bodied, sweet on the palate with a slight syrup character. Taste is dates, raisins, plums, brown sugar. Think I like this more than most Unibroue beers.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Total Wine Sterling. It pours a cloudy dark brown with a nice tan head. The nose has notes of dried dates, fresh figs, light caramel, stone fruit, and a little spice. Lighter on the tongue with a nice effervescence. Sweet at first then drier on the back end. Belgian candy sugar, light spiced cake, dates, and fig. Very nice indeed.
Darkish murkiness. Aroma is grain and mild raisin. Taste is booze, raisin, winey quality, candi sugar. Overall one of the best belgian strong dark ales.

Pours a dark brown that lets a little light through and a big rocky tan head that slowly settles. Aroma is dark candied sugar, figs, raisins, plums, malty sweetness, light alcohol, and some caramel notes. Flavour is well balanced alcohol, raisins, figs, plums, malty sweetness, burnt candied sugar, light bitterness, and spicy Belgian yeast with a dry finish.

Pours a clear dark brown with a red tinge a d a nice frothy brown head. Aroma of dark dried fruits, grapes, red wine and some caramel. Taste is sweet caramel, red grapes, figs, dates and then finishes semi dry with a red wine after taste. Medium high carbonation really brings a full body and full blend of flavors on the palate. Excellent Belgian dark strong.

2010. Brune. Beau collet. Nez: épice. Figue. Caramel. Banane. Levure. Sucre candi. Raisin. Porto. Rhum. Bouche: très sucré. Anis. Chocolat. Fruité. Datte figue. Caramel salé. Madérisé. Cerise. Pain au banane. Bonbon. Un chef d'oeuvre québécois.

Quite impressive. It has a very unique and immediate alcohol/fruit aftertaste which I really enjoyed and found very distinctive from other Belgian strongs. I would definitely be back for me. The aroma was brilliantly rich, but since Im not skilled enough to say what I detected, Ill leave the specifics to the other raters. Bravo

Very nice and leans a little into Quad territory. Nice malty aroma with a touch of plum and dates. Dark reddish brown color with a very small head. This had been in storage for over a year and like most of their beers, it held up well. The palate was heavy and oily with good carbonation. The flavors are rich and complex with bready malts, alcohol, Belgian yeast and dark fruits. This was well balanced.

Delicious to the very last drop olive this beer with my heart and soul. So good. Delicious. Aromatic. Changed my opinion of what a beer could be. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer is a very, very dark reddish brown with a medium off-white head, and the aroma combines the scents of sour (wine-like) fruits and cloves with an effervescent sweetness. The taste is mildly sweet and mildly sour with a superb balance of the two, and the palate combines a lively carbonation, thin and slick texture, medium body, and a long dry finish.

750ml bottle poured a deep brown hue w/ a large frothy tan head mostly diminishing to a small cap w/ excellent lacing. Big dark fruit aromas plus pear, molasses, and bubblegum. Initial flavor is heavy sweet w/ a light acidic finish. Tastes are raisin, prune, fig, plum, pear, molasses, bubblegum, dark bread, chocolate, and dough. Medium to full bodied, creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation, and a moderate alcoholic feel in the finish.
Bottle from backlog. Pours dark brown. Nose and taste of plum, fig, dark fruit, bready chocolate, vanilla and some grape. Full bodied.

750 ml bottle into signature tulip glass, best before 11/15/2016.  Pours fairly crystal clear dark reddish brown color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy khaki head with incredible retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Nice dense soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a ton of streaming carbonation retaining the thick head.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, fig, plum, apple, pear, molasses, toast, dark candi sugar, bread, clove, light pepper, bubblegum, and yeast earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of yeast ester notes with a good dark malt balance; and good strength.  Taste of big raisin, prune, fig, plum, pear, molasses, toast, clove, pepper, bubblegum, dark bread, chocolate, dark candi sugar, and yeast earthiness.  Slight fruity tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of light and dark fruits, molasses, dark candi sugar, toast, dark bread, clove, light pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic complexity and balance of fruity ester flavors with a big dark malt backbone; and zero cloying sweetness after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a slick, creamy, and slightly syrupy mouthfeel that is great.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic Belgian strong dark ale.  Great complexity and balance of fruity ester and malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the gravity.  A highly enjoyable offering as expected.
Big red wine nose.  Some dark fruit and grape flavors.  Really boozy and strong finish.  Solid

750ml bottle. Black/brown with fizzy head. Yeast, champagne, oak, plum, citrus, vanilla, chocolate. Slight sour taste; rich and complex. Medium-bodied, and well-carbonated. Long, dry finish. Some of the usual Unibroue flavours but enhanced and given an interesting twist. Very good beer.

Aggressive pour.  Lots of head, strawberry foam with tight bubbles.  Aroma is full of fig, alcohol, and red grape. Light lacing and goes away quickly.  Flavor is quite shallow with none of the flavors from the aroma on the palate.  Dry finish with little aftertaste.  Wouldja - No

A: Pours a rather gross slidgy brown color. A bit of lacing.
S: Lots of fruit. Plum, currant, raisin, alcohol in there as well.
T: Tastes great. Smooth. Huge fruit notes with only a subtle tinge of the belgian mustiness which really works well in this beer. Alcohol is present in the finish but not offputting. Maybe a little too sweet.
P: very nice on the palate. Alcohol cuts though a bit much.

Overall this is a really great beer. It has lots of fruit notes but is balanced out with some more earthy must notes in just the correct proportion. One of the best belgians Ive had. Unibroue does not seem to disappoint.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2013 Dark beer with an interesting aroma of fruits and sour berries. A little overly carbonated but a lot of taste, specifically, cherries, sour berries, and possibly plums or figs. Very tasty, hides the alcohol very well.

pours a dark brown with strong aromas of hay and fruit.  mouthfeel is surprisingly light.  lots of fruit: banana, sour berries and some candy.  finishes with some light chocolate and similar fruit flavours.

Pours dark brown / red with a coarse tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt, cherries, hint of banana bread.  Taste is sweet caramel, raisin, date, cherry.  Sweet malt finish. Great mouth feel, lively carbonation.
Appearance brown with a tan head aroma floral taste dried dark red cherries  and long on the palate with a sweet taste
From a 75 cl bottle shared at home.  Pours a cola brown with a tan head.  Malty aroma.  Flavors of caramel, dark red cherries, and candy sugar.  Nice.

Corked and caged, best before 11-15-2016.  Sweet nose with a mix of dark pitted and rotting fruit.  Light chocolate, stronger figs, dates, berries, cherry, plums, toffee, caramel, earth, oak, spice and yeast.  Dark mahogany body with coke and ruby highlights, eventually flattens out, with a noisy tan cola head.  Taste is sweet to very sweet (candis added to all the listed fruit) -- but not too sweet -- and has a wonderful slow-burn alcohol, not hot or charring on the organs, but very subtly and slowly increasing in the chest and belly, a masterful act of taming from the kennelmaster.  Fruit is still there and strong bu the spice is backed off; yeast is still there at the end, Belgian as ever, with a bit of vanilla.  Low bitterness a touch under balancing.  Medium body with slick malt and the depth of a good quad, very spirit-like.  This is a young bottle but my, how classy and pleasant it is already!

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, & molasses; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel/syrup, rich dark fruit (notably plums & figs), raisons, and spice; Nicely balanced; The alcohol is well hidden; Overall, very tasty but just a little flat - dangerously drinkable though.

During spl spring party der friend and netcafe owner, Ali bring this Terrible beer to boat of my cousin Ahmad for full boost party at Durrat Al-Arus area of tourist and much fun. We open this like sweet champagne and pour in nice glass for much drinking and fun. I am not see this purple colour as other reviewer state... I see dark choco like beauty woman or even dirt from garden area or field planting crop. Glorious head like bath of many bubble and delish flavour. Telling from my heart, I love this beer.

bottle. Pours deep purple/black, bubbly one finger head in trappist glass. Aroma is mostly dark fruit, raisin, fig, also some lighter unibroue yeast. Taste can be almost wine-like, a little acidity on top of the sweet fruits. Pretty good.

On tap at Ridgewood (Raleigh)

Dark and cloudy. A fruity aroma that just doesn't go anything for me, with a taste that matches.  I believe it is the fig that is coming through....

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750ml->Trappist.  Dark nrown with medium offwhite head.  Aroma: dark friit, yeast, spice.  Taste is same, some booze.  High carbonation.  Decent.
Fruity yeasty aroma. Very dark brown with thick light tan head. Plum, fig, hints of spice. Medium bodied. Smooth finish with a gradual warmth.

A - Pours completely opaque with a rocky 2 finger tan head. Retains very well.

S - Green apple skins, dusty yeast, clove, pinot grapes,

T - Apples and dark fruits off the top- figs, prunes, raisins and some melon. The yeast is there but doesnt come out and try to bully through the flavors. There is a pinot grape like acidity creating a vinous character. The roasted malts are weaved with molasses, licorice, clove, and pepper. Banana is pronounced when warm. Finishes tangy and slightly acidic.

M - Moderate carbonation, fizzy, medium to full body.

The bright white grape character was unexpected but melded perfect. All the flavors seem so balanced that nothing sticks out. The drinkability is very high for the style. Alcohol is hidden well.

Serving type: bottle

01-22-2011

750ml bottle, 2011 vintage, aged almost 2 years. Dark brown with a little red, creamy, hazy. Large sponge toffee head. Lots of lacing. Aroma has cloves, raisins, dates, brown sugar, musty yeast. Slight sour crept into the taste, but otherwise much like the aroma. Letting the beer breath for a few minutes and the sour dropped off some. Slight alcohol burn but just how it should be. Overall, this was really good. My third favourite Unibroue, which is hard in such a competitive field.

Des arômes épicées émanent de ce liquide brun très foncé, garni dune mousse épaisse, se résorbant lentement en laissant une fine dentelle à mesure quon la déguste. Son goût est tout aussi épicé. En sy remettant au nez, les fruits secs et la salsepareille la parfume, tandis quon détecte des senteurs de coriandre. Texture soyeuse. Alcool discret et réconfortant. Je devrais men faire des provisions. (H2812/1036/Q)(550-020313)

Bottle sample at a tasting at the new Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks kerenmk. Pours brown hazy opaque with a nice head, aroma of dried fruits, vanilla, fruit acidity, flavor of fruits, light acidity, very sweet and buzzy, medium bodied

Draft. Wow this is pretty dang good. The yeast is awesome. An amazing balance of hops yeast and malt.  Not to sweet. Nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours an extremely dark brown color with a moderately thick frothy tan head. Nose has some slightly sweet dark fruit elements that are somewhat reminiscent of a quad. Taste is slightly sour, but with a robust fruity element to it that makes for a remarkably easy drink. It combines a lot of elements I frequently dont like, but it ends up being amazing. Very happy with this choice.
Tastes like every other unibroue.  Belgian yeast and dark fruit.  Not my thing.

Bottle shared at a tasting at the new Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks Excellent Little Brother for the delivery! Pours black, opaque, with a quick dissolving off-white head. Smells sweet, nutella chocolate, somewhat spiced. Spicy, sweet, and light-fruity taste. full body, heavy, very sweet finish. For dessert.
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2013 Pours dark red-brown with a thin white head. Smells strongly like peppercorn. Tastes peppery and sweet with mild fruits. I swear I smell pepperonis. Pretty good.

750ml bottle. A dark cola brown body, huge mocha head with excellent retention. Aroma of Unibroue yeast, raisins, prunes, herbal hops, slightly roasted malts and peppercorn. Taste is unexpectedly light and refreshing: yeast, raisins, prunes, light spices, herbal hops and a nice woodiness in the background. Alcohol very well hidden.

Bottle. Belgium yeast, vinous prune, cherry, vanilla, brown sugar, and light alcohol aroma. Deep mahogany with a moderate beige head. Sweet cherry, brown sugar, Belgian yeast flavor, and very light anise in the finish. Medium body, soft carbonation, light alcohol burn.

Bottle.  Cherry, prune, yeast, and vanilla toffee malt aroma - exquisite.  Dark brown with moderate head.   Sweet cherry, prune, and strong brown sugar malt flavor.  Hint of alcohol in the finish but doesnt seem anywhere near 10.5%.  Delicious.

On tap at reuben?s. Pours a very dark brown with a finger of off-white head.  Settles in minutes with minimal lacing. Aroma is sweet, fruity, stone fruits, plum. Flavor is fruity up front, stone fruits, plum, with a malty caramel finish. Incredible masking of alcohol. Moderate carbonation, medium body, and mildly dry finish. An impressive, fruity, strong belgian ale.

Pours deep black with tones of dark ruby. Head is off white, lively, large bubbles. Aroma is dark fruit (grape, plum, raisin). Taste is similar to port wine, grapes, alcohol, and sweet-tart. Palate is alcohol, grape. Perfect dessert beer, a la port wine. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle refermented dark ale on lees ale brewed with spice  10.5% 750ml bold dark pour with creamy head
Feuity, Sweet, slightly sticky. A little caramel. Darkish red and brown. Lots of Malts. Overall sweet and thick

Bottle sample at a tasting at the new Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks kerenmk. Hazy dark reddish brown. Aroma of malt, dark fruits, yeast and alcohol. Sweetish alcoholic flavor with dark fruits, some brown sugar, molasses notes and alcohol. Medium-bodied.

Thanks jbruner! Almost black pour with a frothy tan head. Lots of dark fruit, prunes, raisins, light roasted aroma and hints of powdery cocoa, touch of acid. Licorice up front with grape notes and touches of sweet cocoa, subtle roast and dark fruit for the finish. Not bad big unmemorable.

Pours an opaque brownish black from the bottle with bubbly tan head that dissipates to leave good lacing. Aroma of Belgian yeast, leaving fruity esters of plum and banana, slight wheat. Taste follows, slightly bittersweet mouth with bubbly feel. Good stuff, but expecting more.
Really good beer. Pitch black color. Sweet candied fruit aroma. Flavor follows with really rich malt and fruit.
Pours deep brown with very thick white head. I really shouldve started this review before I nearly finished the bottle. Anyhow, its good.

A - Dark black with a bit of brown mixed in a finger of frothy tan-khaki head. Fades fairly slowly.

S - Sweet dark caramel malts, cherries, raisin, plum, dates, other dark fruits, Belgian yeast, clove, and other spices, a bit of sourness, and some booze.

T - Sweet dark caramel malts, black cherries, raisin, plum, dates, and other dark fruits, Belgian yeasts, clove, other spices, some sourness, some residual sugars, and some booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet, warming, and slightly sour finish.

D - Great BSDA. Great overall balance and complexity.

750 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in a snifter. Pours hazy deep ruby-chestnut with a moderate tan head that slowly fades to a thin cover and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are huge notes of Belgian yeast, along with dark fruit, wine, fig, banana, clove and a touch of hops. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout, with a subtle bitter accent towards the end. Fruity notes are dominant, but accompanied by toasted malts, wine and spice. The finish is long and malty with a touch of spice. Alcohol is very well hidden. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice dark abbey-style ale with loads of fruit and that Unibroue signature yeast bouquet. Tasty, but not as complex as Unibroue 17. 2012-12-22

d un brun assez fonce avec col blanc elle beaucup de saveur qui se melanger tres complexe un malt torrifier avec touche de caramel avec petit fruits a un gout sucre melanger a une forte taux d alcool tres bonne assez costaude (rate 53)
The color is dark brown with a medium light brown head. I smell yeast, dark fruits and banana. I taste all of the same with raisins and sweet malt.

Mörkt brun öl med ett livligt, ljusbrunt skum som lägger sig som vispad äggvita. Doft av jäst, jästa frukter, kryddor. Kryddighet även i smaken. Fikon, rostade toner och alkoholsötma. Även viss beska i smak och eftersmak.

Best before October 15, 2014.
Appearance: The beer appears a dark chestnut on the pour and light is only visible through the edges, exposing a clear chestnut body. The head tan and dense, but rather thin with average retention. The head settles into a full coating.
Aroma: Dark fruits are the strongest with grapes and raspberries that come to mind. Toffee and brown sugar underlie the fruits with a hint of cocoa.
Taste: The flavor is strong with a medicinal grape flavor coming through hugely with a sweet toffee flavor that comes in towards the end of the taste with a lingering spice.
Palate: Thick and slightly syrupy, fizzy carbonation.
Overall: This is a great alternative to a port wine. This is a bold beer with lots of fruity flavors with a spice to it that gives it a medicinal flavor. Its not overly complex, but its interesting.

Couleur brun foncé avec de petits reflets rouges, odeurs vinées et de levure belge typique dUnibroue. Au goût, elle rappelle beaucoup la Trois-Pistoles, avec un soupçon de Maudite. Assez goûteuse, lalcool est bien contrôlé, et les grains maltés, à défaut doffrir des flaveurs torréfiées, viennent arrondir la finale. Une très bonne bière, malheureusement la trop forte signature Unibroue et les inévitables comparaisons avec quelques-unes de ses soeurs (moins dispendieuses) la rendent un peu moins éclatante que prévu.

Ténébreuse  brune foncée tirant sur le noir  avec un bon col de mousse qui largue une fine dentelle au passage. Nez danis et de confiseries avec une touche de vanille. Cest toutefois en bouche que la magie opère; cest Terrible dans le bon sens du mot! Les épices et lalcool (10.5%) enveloppent totalement la langue et lengourdissent presque. La signature de la levure Unibroue se fait aussi sentir, mais elle se fond parfaitement dans le mélange. Une finale en caramel doux ferme la danse avec classe. Le deuxième meilleur produit dUnibroue, pas très loin derrière la 17 Grande Réserve.

Tight, cream colored bubbles started immediately on the pour. Very deep brown/ox blood color. Strong nose of figs, sweet bread, alcohol. Taste is more caramel, raisin, syrup. A beautiful beer but just a bit too sweet, due mostly to the huge 10.5% ABV, of course.

Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a thick, tan head; aromas are minimal; significant carbonationbetter after it rests a while in a glass; spices are surprisingly less pronounced than expected.  A smooth, almost slick, mouthfeel.  Flavors of fig, vanilla, black pepper, and a subtle hint of currants.  Less boozy than some of the other Belgian Strongs Ive had.  Overall, a solid example of a Belgian Strong Dark Ale.  Id definitely have this one again.

It pours dark mahogany with ruby highlights; the head is bone and mousse-like. The aroma has notes of: cardamom, cloves, yeast funk, hay, figs, and alcohol. The taste is dry that finishes light bitter; there are notes of: cloves, figs, a tiny bit of burnt coffee, and lots of alcohol. The palate is full bodied, slick, medium carbonation, and a long finish. Overall, when this is young its very closed - definitely needs a couple of years to perk up.

Pours deep brown/black with an airy, tan head. Aroma is of yeast, bubblegum, and fruit. The taste is of fruit, molasses, yeast, and a bit of toast on the finish. No noticable hops. Medium-heavy body and pretty sweet. ABV is noticeable after the finish fades, leaving plenty of warmth.

750ml bottle from steve
Pours a dark ruby with a big frothy off white head
Aroma of bubble gum banana 
Awesome belgian trappist flavouf very good
Bottle. Aroma is dark fruit, toast, and a bit of citrus hops. Appearance is very dark brown with a thin khaki head. Good lacing. Taste is fruity esters, plum, raisin, and sweet malt. Medium body.

Bottle from the LCBO. Pours a dark black-brown with a fair amount of tan foamy head. Smell is quite roasty with some bright citrus hoppiness and a hint of dark fruit. Palate is medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation and a bit of an oily mouthfeel. Taste is sweet at first but then gets a bit more fruity and a bit bitter. The aftertaste is a bit sweet and has a nice warming sensation deep in your throat letting you know about the alcohol content. Quite nice, would be interesting aged.

La Terrible dUnibroue, à 10.5% dalcool, a une couleur brun foncé qui tire vers le noir. Attention toutefois, elle na rien à voir avec les noires Stout, ni par larôme, ni par le goût. Au nez, elle offre des parfums subtils dépices, de sucre et de fruits confits. Belle effervescence. Cette bière créée en 2002 a un goût de porto, de sucre brun, et de petits fruits telle la cerise noire. Idéalement, laissez tempérer cette bière avant de la déguster ; les aromates seront plus évidents et lexpérience, enrichie. La finale nest pas amère ; elle laisse place aux sucres et donne un bel équilibre. Jaime beaucoup les produits Unibroue en général. Cette bière étant plus chère que ses frères et soeurs, je ne penserais pas la racheter toutefois. Pour moi, les produits standard comme la Fin du Monde et la Trois-Pistoles sont plus intéressants au niveau qualité-prix.
