En revanche, cette bière mérite dêtre dégustée au moins une fois si vous aimez ce porte-étendard de la microbrasserie au Québec, ce pilier, qui plus est, cette tête de proue de la vraie bière de lAmérique du Nord. Par ailleurs, Unibroue a un excellent site Internet dans lequel vous aurez un foule dinformations sur leurs bières de même que des capsules de leur sommelier en bières. Bonne dégstation. Cheers!

Cola color with huge head and good lacing.   Spicy dark fruit smell and taste.  Raisin and dark fruit taste with brown sugar.   Very carbonated.  Fizzy mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Spice smell and taste.  Highly carbonated. Sweet. Okay.       ,$!:!;!!/;;!,"" via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A good beer, but it doesnt really taste that much different from most of Unibroues other main titles. Tastes like halfway between Maudite and Fin du Monde. Floral aroma with that signature beer on lees Unibroue taste. Pours black with good initial head. Taste is sweet and bitter with nice perfumed finish. Very good, but didnt quite live up to expectations. Perhaps it was just too long in the coming. Bottle.
Tasted very similar to Trois Pistoles to me. Very good beer. dough, cheese in the asfter taste, raisin, and other fruity notes. Very enjoyable Belgian Strong Ale indeed.
(bottle) clear very dark reddish brown; medium tall brown head; aroma of bread, wheat; strong, sweet, complex flavour; long light bitter finish ; better than many belgians from Belgium
A powerfully flavoured bouquet of forest friuits, licorice, and tobacco. Pours a thick, black. Smells strongly of fruits and polish. Overwhelming, intoxicating, but just not enjoyable.

Pours a midnight black, and a thick tan head. The aroma is thick, like fresh minced meat pies are baking in the oven. Lots of fruits, yeast, banana, and coffee are packed into the aroma. The initial taste is a blast of black liquorice, followed by some coffee, raisin, and plum. The body of this beer is very thick, and almost feels like you are drinking a fruit cake! Excellent beer, and a fine example of Unibroues excellence in crafting fine beers!

10.5% a/v, 750ml bottle. Loving the cork and cage seal as well. 

Pours a remarkably opaque black colour, with a nice tan head. Looks pretty impressive. Aroma is dark stone fruit, a bit of toasted barley, and espresso. The taste is just phenomenal, and remarkably complex. Again, lots of dark stone fruit, but that comes in after some espresso and deep dark chocolate taste. After mellowing on the tongue for awhile, you get the deep roasted espresso flavor and smokey richness. 10.5 percent on the label but doesnt seem like more than 6-7% on the tongue. This beer is far from Terrible, another winner from Unibroue.
Un marron très foncé. Une mousse lèger. Le nez et peut-être du cola et rasin. Le goût et du rasin et cola. Il y a un peu damertume a la fin. Très bonne.

Very dark brown with red highlights.  Sweet fruity malt on the nose.  Sweet, rich malt...candied sugar, caramel, toffee, dark fruit and some warming alcohol.  Reminds me of Gulden Draak. Nice flavor but a bit cloyingly sweet.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Caramely, dough, raisin, "unibroue" aroma. Dark brown, hard to see through, lasting brown head. Medium sweetness, light sourness, no bitterness. Full bodied, creamy with average carbonation. A pretty good and well balanced one for its style.

Deep, dark mahogany in color with a persistent off-beige head. The aroma evokes raisins, bananas, chocolate cake, licorice, prunes, old furniture, some wine, and tart yeast esters. The taste is initially yeasty, follows up with dark fruits, and ends with banana. Tart all the way through. Mouthfeel is medium with fizzy carbonation. Balanced and tasty.
Bottle and Draught.  This is not my favorite offering from Unibroue but it is good none the less.  Sweet, warm, and straight forward - bog standard Belgian style ale at a good price.

This ale poured a deep brown colour with a big, creamy, tan coloured head. Light lacing.  Scents include smoke, weiner water, caramel, malt, spice(Allspice?) and a little cocoa. First sip was very creamy with light carbonation. Fairly sweet with flavours of yeast, malt and spice. Finish is thick and sweet with almost a mollassass palate.
Bouteille de 750ml, robe noire opaque, arôme de fruits et de levure, goût de fruits confis et porto, superbe bière!

Dec 6 2012. 750ml bottle pours black with an inch tan bubbly head. Head settles to ring. Leaves slight lacing. Aroma is yeasty, alcohol with some dark fruit, plums and fig. First sip is sweet dark fruit which quickly turns sour with bready yeast and strong alcohol. Over duration of bottle the alcohol settles in behind the rich fruit flavour of plums and figs and becomes part of the dryness in finish. Palate is superb. Dry and slightly bitter finish with a warming mouthfeel much like a fine merlot.

One finger of light tan head. Body is black as can be.
Smell is musty grain with dry chocolate milk and dried fruit. It smells like Swiss Miss powder!
Taste is alcohol, a slice of bread and dry dark fruits. Its fruit cake.
Thick body with low carbonation... smooth.
Strong body and taste and enjoyable all-around.

750 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a cloudy, very dark brown with large, thick tan head with some lacing.  Aroma is full of dark fruit, slightly roasty caramel and fairly spicy.  Flavour is raisin, plum, cherry, clove, pepper, caramel and an underlying roastiness.  Fairly big body.  Nice.
750ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a brown head. Aroma of malt, yeast (but not as much as other Unibroue beers). some dark fruits. flavour is sweet. Slightly sour.

750 ml bottle. Terrible...C'est magnifique!! Served at 5 degrees Celsius in chalice glass (as recommended). Pours a vivacious, fizzy tan head. Aroma is very strong and pleasant - prunes, raisins, dates. Bubbly lace around glass. Black brew (Lovibond 40). Amazingly powerful yet not overwhelming flavours of raisins and plums. Red wine palate and warmth. What a brute of a beer! Great! Nice carbonation! Just.. BUY THIS

0.75l bottle from the LCBO, served in a tulip. Appearance: Opaque black, with a large frothy brown head. Aroma: Weird mix here, and several smells that I cant place. Notes of raisins, chocolate, grass, cheese, leather. Palate: Thick bodied, fizzy, slightly oily, long dry finish. Taste: Fairly sweet. Lessens in the finish. Alcohol isnt as prominent as one would think. An interesting beer.

Pours a murky dark brown with a 3-4 finger head that lingers. Raisin cherry. Mildly sweet and tart, but finishes bitter. Medium body. Moderately fizzy. Medium finish. A touch boozy but moderately drinkable. I like it.
Thisis a fabulous beer. Delicious and beautifully balanced. 10.5% and you can t tell. Candian beer making at its best. Wonderful.

750 to Chimay glass...

Aroma: Subdued but theres the definite Unibroue signature aroma. Dark fruits, spice cupboard, slight hotness but that you have to sniff for, marzipan, dark chocolate, coffee...if I didnt know this was a beer, Id swear it would be some sort of christmas cake or something along those lines. Is this gonna be a flavour sucker punch?

Appearance: Very dark brown with a brow head that leaves nice lacing. No turbidity which is making me wonder if I should have turned the bottle a few times before opening. 

Taste: Wow, quite something! Quite assertive with strong malts, much sweetness, and a slight sour/bitter finish. This is a savoury beer for sure!

Palate: Thick, chewy, slight prickly CO2, somewhat creamy and the complexity is up there. Very drinkable...pace yourself! Oh and the alcohol? Be careful, you feel it more than taste it....

Overall: Cheap and amazing which doesnt happen often. Quite a big beer and nice to drink during the colder months to warm your bones.

750 ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown with medium persistent head. Aromas of dates, raisins, spice (yes mincemeat), yeast, and a bit of white pepper. Sharp and acidic. Flavors of cinnamon and nutmeg, roasted malts, tobacco and plums.

750 mL bottle.  Pours a dark cola like almost black color, with a foamy tan head, lots of lacing and slow dissipation.  Heady perfumed aroma of fig, molasses, vanilla and oak.  Taste is amazingly balanced for such a big beer, sweet, with a bitter midpalate and sour finish, you can taste layers of dark fruits, bready yeast, mushroomy earth and a distinct meat flavor. Smooth and full bodied coating mouthfeel but not cloying. A great big beer, and another landmark from unibroue.
Pours dark with frothy beige head from bottle.  Aroma is light and fruity.  Taste starts out mild and ends strong-sweet.

750ml bottle. Not usually a fan of dark ales but was prompted to buy it after hearing good things. Pours very dark brown with ample foamy head. Spicy, dark fruit, malty aroma. Absolutely delicious. Flavour is bold and lingers invitingly. Does not drink like a 10.5%! Not too dry, not too sweet. Will definitely be stocking up on this one!

This is delicious.
The aroma is spicy and great,
the appearance was dark, but the head was soapy seeming.
The taste was yumyum but boozy, maybe Im just not into the boozy beers.
The palate was decent but burned a little.  Again maybe I am just not the best person to rate this.
Overall, yum yum I will buy this again but also may pass it by until I can try new things.
I love the bottle and had it suggested to me more than once at my job, so - good on them!

Aroma; has fantastic malt, cloves, hint of banana esters. No hops
Appearance; Up to the light, it dark brown but clear, with a persistent head that cling to the glass of tiny cream colored bubbles
Taste; fantastic, the malt is very apparent, with the cloves and slight sweet chocolate nuttiness. Flavours keep going long after sipping. 
Body; despite 10.5% it has very light body. Very drinkable, balanced sweetness as its not too dry or sweet. No astringency. The sweetness balances out any bitterness that it might have.
Best beer I have had in awhile. I didnt give it full marks, only because I dont believe in perfection. 
I would recommend this beer to anyone.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours black (very dark brown) with low beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of fruits (dark), malt, lots of yeast, alcohol. Taste is of dark fruits, malt (ligthly rosted), some warming alcohol (but well hidden for %), caramel, yeast Unibroue classic). Palate: medium-high body. Near-sparkling carbonation. Overall: Easily drinkable. Blatant Unibroue signature. Quite complex, very good.Oh! And a pleasant alternative to coffee? Doesnt really makes sense to me, but whatever...

Bouteille 750 ml. Robe brun foncé surmontée dun collet beige. Arôme de levures, de malt et de fruits noirs. Goût semblable et excellent équilibre. On discerne la touche caractéristique dune Unibroue. Ronde en bouche.

A  very pleasing yet complex aroma. Spice, dark fruit (plums, figs, raisins), Belgian yeast, and mince meat. Pours a dark brown with a mostly diminishing off-white head and no lacing. The taste is medium sweet. Like the nose, cloves, raisins, sugar candy, cherries. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Overall, an excellent beer to savor. While sweet, it was not cloy. Would be enjoyable after a large meal.

750 mL Bottle. Dark brown body with a foamy beige head that shows good tenacity and leaving ample lace. Sweet combined bouquet of sweet malts, yeast, that signature Unibroue cookie dough, notes of cloves and nutmeg, and hints of prune, black mission figs, raisins, and molasses. Very bold, very intense flavor although quite sharp-sweet for my liking. Sweet dark malts, cloves, ginger, nutmeg, and figs and other dark fruits sting all over the tongue and then ask for forgiveness in the lingering finish of a combination of prunes, black mission figs, raisins, and subtle hint of molasses. Have an open mind and this beer could really grow on you. Definitely a sipping beer. A cigar aficionado might find an experience with this beer to be quite likeable.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2013 One which is terrible conjures up a vision of wrong and bad but this is but a fine beer, much like Louis Prima and glorious butt cheeks and other fantastic portions of divine areas!!! This is a special  beerso very special that I wish to drink until I have morals that are thrown into garbage and I go on rampage of lust and devotion to many women who welcome my advances. This is truly a delicious beer that should be coveted and nurtured like virgin area of grass or even farmland that is ready for planting and growth. I would certainly dedicate cycle of farm growth to this special beer for hops and envy.

intense sweet malt, cinnamon, cloves with some grape and prunes and toasted bread to the nose.  the drink pours a very dark brown / black with a beige head of one finger and is very bubbly.  flavor is sweet, malty, heavy caramel with notes of spice.  very fizzy with a long lasting malt / alcohol aftertaste.  im sure its a great beer for its style but Im not a big fan of the style in particular.

750 ML bottle
11/11/13 BB

Dark brown, bordering on black color. half finger of light tan head. Spotty lacing. 

Brilliant nose. white and red grapes, malt, banana, pear, and apple. Alcohol is very restrained in the nose. 

More malt, grape and pear in the taste. quite robust taste and no noticeable ABV. 

Feels lighter than what it is. Very well developed and balanced. 

Super beer

Aroma: intense powerful aroma, it almost feels like you can taste the beer when you smell it, grapes, malts, alcohol, very impressive. Appearance: beautiful, dark character, intense light tan head with medium lacing. Taste: gorgeous taste, but I have to ask where the difference between this and a chimay blue is, where do we draw the line here? Nonetheless, delicious Trappist. Palate:  nice, goes down smooth and really has no drawbacks, little burning at the end. Overall: extremely impressive, but it tastes almost exactly like a regular Trappist, so bizarrely nothing special. Trois pistoles is better and more unique
This is a dark ruby-brown ale, with a white soft head.  The flavors are dark cherry, dark molasses, and dark plum.  It is soft on the palate and quite complex.  Its a solid beer.

Heavy gray head over a deep dark yet relatively thin appearing pour. Smells of a nice blend of dark red fruits and heavily roasted malts. I would prefer a bit lighter malt selection as it takes a bit away from the wonderful fruit notes produced by the Belgium yeast. Tastes mostly sweet and sour. Hop flavor and aroma is floral but minimal. The low point for me is the palate. High alcohol and carbonation is a bit numbing and harshly sharp. The maltiness doesn?t help as it dries out the mouth. Finish is much the same. Lots of nice points but could be more balanced.

Aroma is full of Belgian yeast with some spicy undercurrent. Pours a nice dark brown almost black. Very slight head that does not really fade. The taste is mostly the Belgian yeast. Strongly carbonated.

Pours a dark reddish brown color with a thick head that lingers a bit.  Aroma is dominated by Belgian yeast.  Getting little hints of dark fruit and anise too.  Taste is overpowering Belgian yeast flavor and I dont like.  I cant really taste anything else.  Finish is rough and highly carbonated.  I really dont like this beer.  Ironic that its named Terrible.

Notes of black currant, leather, & anise. Nutty & dark fruit, with some nice earthy notes as well. A little bit woody in the finish. A lot going on, but all in a very impressive balance. Creamy, medium-full bodied. Robust carbonation. Incredibly smooth.

Malty belgium sweetness. On the nose with a Clovy cinnamon spice. Amazing mouthfeel with monolithic malt structure. The yeast esters linger for days. I'm on the radio talking about I gotta go. 

---That dog will hunt!

From Notes, 4/28/12:

Poured a 750ml bottle into a Duvel snifter. Taken out of the fridge and rested for about 40 minutes to bring to serving temp. Best by date of 04-15-15. Poured carefully as to not disturb yeast sediment.

A: Nearly opaque dark brown. Light beige head that dissipates slowly.

S: Took a quick whiff of the cork and got green apple peel. Dark fruits, raisins, figs. Caramel and brown sugar there as well. Also a spiciness Im assuming is from the alcohol.

T: Outstanding. Raisins and brown sugar more pronounced. Caramel and chocolate in the middle. The green apple seems to reappear very faintly in the finish. Peppery alcohol. Mild hop bitterness there for balance.

M: Lush and full. Carbonation is just a little high, alcohol bite noticable; probably didnt let this one sit long enough; I dont apologize.

O: Complexity is great on this one. This may surpass Maudite as my favorite. As has become my habit, I love mixing the yeast sediment in my second glass when it comes to Unibroue brews. It did not disappoint.

Very carbonated, medium brown good head. Smell of prunes and other dark fruits. Like a Belgian mixed a darker ale. Some spice in there can't quite peg it. Nice sweet taste no after taste. Bubbly. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 at home in a Bordeaux glass at cellar temp (60F). Best before 10-15-2014.  Poured a dark brown to black. No head at all, nice whisp cork pop on the opening. This smells wonderful. Tons of candied sugar, lots of dark fruits, hint of grapes and citrus. it has this sort of fernet branca taste. Like a dessert liquor. Burn in the chest. Raisins, figs and mint. Hint of peaches and plums. Very nice!!!

Aroma interesante y algo complejo. Las principales notas son a maltas tostadas, flores y principalmente frutas del campo.

A la vista es particularmente obscura, con notas color rojizo. Corona de espuma que se dilute rápidamente, carbonatación de ligera a media. Cuerpo ligero.

En boca es una cerveza interesante. Lo primero que destaca es su suavidad y cremosidad y ligero amargor.

Al paladar denota su interesante y complejo aroma. De extraorinaria forma como casi en ninguna cerveza, se mezclan las notas amargas y dulces. El dulzor suavemente en un principio y el ligero amargor al término. Es una cerveza de un final largo haciendo sentir su potencia alcohólica!

En general es una cerveza muy buena. Desde un principio al destapar el corcho, hasta terminar la última gota, pero como casi todas las Strong Ale, se deben degustar con tranquilidad.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2014 A great caramel taste.  Important not to drink too cold.  It is a great beer to share with friends

Deep, dark mahogany in color with a persistent off-beige head. The aroma evokes raisins, bananas, chocolate cake, licorice, prunes, old furniture, some wine, and tart yeast esters. The taste is initially yeasty, follows up with dark fruits, and ends with banana. Tart all the way through. Mouthfeel is medium with fizzy carbonation. Balanced and tasty.

Les malts brunâtres dominent avec laide de la levure propre à Unibroue. Petits fruits confits, chocolat dans une corpulence bien soutenu et une buvabilité effrayante. Certains éléments dune quad et dune stout dans la même bière.

Another beer I have looked forward to in a while. Dark, cola colored beer, with red hues and an off-white head. Aromas of dark fruit, and some molasses. Tastes of candy sugar, molasses, some toffee, even hints of dark chocolate. My favorite flavor mixed in this one was of tart cherries, mixing with the hints of chocolate this was great. Oily mouth feel, and a bit cloying. I should have had this a bit colder, but I think the flavors came out more at just a chilled temperature. Sweet, dark fruits in the finish. Extremely tasty brew to share with friends.
Reminds me of a Trappist ale.  Strong but not overwhelming.  Dark with a nice head.  Excellent beer.  Definite recommend for the price.

750 ML bottle purchased at BevMo in redding, CA. THE POUR / APPEARANCE: Pours a very dark brown, almost "stout" dark with a nice tan colored head that collapses somewhat quick. AROMA / BOUQUET: Cherries, cherries, cherries! Has a Godiva / Cacao aroma. TASTE: Cherries / Cacao, beautiful fizzy carbonation on the front and on the back of the tongue. Almost has a bitter Bosco chocolate finish. PALATE: Fills the enitre mouth with a lovely creaminess, cocoa bitterness, and dark cherries all at once. OVERALL: This is a wonderful dessert beer, or one just to assalt the olfactory senses. Praise the Lord Jesus for this one!

look: Very dark dense ruby shade of brown. Nice Two finger off white foamy head. Alcohol legs are apparent. Smell: Spicy yeast, faint dark fruits maybe cherries. Some metalic, faint alcohol. Taste: Same in the aroma but throw in some cocoa nibs and coriander. Feel: Carbonation is on point to style. The body is medium built. Overall there is alot going on in this brew, yet it comes together nicely. One of my personal favorite BSDA on this side of the globe. Unibroue keep em coming.

750ml bottle poured into a tulip glass. Deep brown color with a 1" white head. Nose is dried fruit, rich, Trappist style beer. Taste is very similar. A little bit thinner than other beers of this style. Alcohol is well hidden. A very well done beer

Poured from a 750 ml bottle, formerly corked and caged, into a Unibroue branded short stemmed tulip glass. 

Pours a dark molasses colored brown with one and a half finger off-white head that resembles sea foam in consistency that dissipates quickly. No visible lacing. Dark fruit especially notes of black cherry and fig, a bit of spice, and light phenol alcohol on the nose. Opens with the flavor of black cherries and bit of date and fig that combines with hints of almond and spice. Finishes clean and fairly dry with some alcohol warmth. On the lighter side of medium bodied, fizzy champagne-like carbonation, slick on the palate. A very solid brew. Theres nothing necessarily novel about this brew, however a good solid representation of the style.
This beer has a nice foamy head. Mostly due to its age. Very fizzy. A tad bitter, and a basic belgian ale taste. Nothing too special. Worth a try, but not something to go out of your way for.
Pours dark reddish brown with a lot of tan head. Aroma is fruity, spicy dusty, oats and caramel. Tate follows aroma with some alcohol and banana a well. Just the right amount of sweetness

750ml bottle 
10.5% ABV 
I shared a bottle of this with fellow BeerPal Sassy on July 11, 2012 at "Bar Volo" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a coca-cola brown colour with a thin tan creamy head into the Unibroue tulip.  The aroma was dark fruit, molasses, roasted malt, and sugar.  The mouthfeel was full bodied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was blackberries, molasses, some applish and anise notes.  Alcohol was completely hidden.  A great beer.

Yeasty sour grape nose, plenty of dark fruit and decadence.  Some bittersweet chocolate in there too.  Palate is well balanced with sweet and sour notes, with thick creamy feel, but undercut with some tartness.  Appearance is clear, dark red, thick head that stays, thick retention.   Really good, will have to try this one again, and try it aged too.

Pours dark,dark brown with a tall, steady tan head.
Aroma is roasted malt, raisins, dark heavy fruit.
Taste is yeasty, malty,....sugary dark fruits.
The slightest trace of alcohol is present.
A bit of spice.....Sweet with the barest hint of tartness.
Another fantastic offering from Unibroue.
Bottled sample from MLCC.  Dark brown in colour.  Great malt/raisin/hop taste.  Loved thsi beer.  Would get it again and again

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2012 On tap 5 oz. sample at Judges Bench in Ellicott City, MD. Clear, nearly black mahogany with small head and very good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and dark fruit, especially raisins with Belgian yeast. Taste of sweet raisins, dark stone fruit, brown sugar and roasted malt with Belgian yeast and spice. Sweet and spicy. Medium/full and light carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark amber ale. Fruity aroma and taste. Thick but small head. Hints of apples, berries, other fruits. Very rich but with a nice finish. A pleasant finish.

Fantastic! Molasses appearance and even somewhat palate. The alcohol is very low key despite the amount of it.  Perfect balance in all direction. Perhaps a bit watery for the style, but nearly perfect.

From 750 ml corked bottle. Very dark, somewhat translucent. A decent beige head, it disappears quickly. Nose is fruity. Taste is of caramelized fruits and rich malts. Somewhat sweet and very satisfying!
everytime I have a long day at work, I grab my skateboard and some tasty jams, and cruise to my local Ralphs, just to skate back drinking this beer. Love it! Would love to try it on tap!

Terrible pours an opaque brown color which comes to look deep and murky once in the glass. Reds and Browns peek from the edges but very little light peeks through the beer. A two finger head of light beige takes its time disappearing. Lacing is very prevalant.

The first thing on the nose is the faint scent of apples, quickly overtaken by raisins, figs and a general dark fruit scent. An extremely sweet smelling malt makes up the center and faint alcohol peeks it;s head out. Theres a Belgian yeast here that sits inside all of the other aromas giving things a spicy note and making it quite interesting. The nose is complex and very promising.

Raisins, figs and cherries are up front on the tongue and help to produce a light tartness on the first splash. The middle is characterized by a sweet, faintly roasty malt flavor accompanied by the spicy Belgian yeast. It fits together wonderfully. The yeast carries to the end where fruity esters start to show and the only hint of alcohol in this 10.5% brew is noticed.

Theres a slight oily quality in the mouth but you can definitely feel the low attenuation here. The natural carbonation helps though and carries this flavor exceptionally well.

Awesome. Unibroue has yet to let me down and with Terrible, theyve set the bar even higher for themselves. Sweet, yeasty with a slight malt background. Definitely a must try for any Belgian fan.

Very dark, almost black colour with deep ruby hints when held up to the light. Dark and dried fruts in the aroma; raisin, prune and dark cherries. Very complex flavour. Lots of sweetness and tons of dark fruits. A tiny bit of heat on the end from the alcohol. Full bodied with a touch of carbonation. Tasty.

Ale Brewed with Spice. Bottle Refermented. Dark Ale on Lees. 10.5% 750ml 1pt 9.4 fl oz Unibroue Chambly Québec Canada
Great Beer :)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a goblet. Best before 01-30-2016.

4.0 A: Black color. Two fingers of frothy, faint tan colored head. Retention is solid for the ABV, but no lacing is left.

4.0 S: Pleasant mixture of dark maltiness and dark fruitiness. Light supple roast, lots of chocolate, some caramel and molasses. Fruits including lots of fig and lesser amounts of plum, date, and raisin. Clove spiciness from the yeast with hints of pepper. A touch of candi sugar.

4.5 T: Very tasty and well balanced. Again theres lots of chocolate followed by a light roast with caramel and molasses. Fig heavy fruitiness with plum, date, and raisin. Clove and pepper spiciness. Candi sugar. A lot of fine Belgian brews are delicious, but often too subtle and require that the drinker concentrate to get the full experience. This is not one of those beers. The flavors are intense by Belgian standards and mesh extremely well together.

4.5 M: Unibroue yeast is awesome for creating wonderful, spritzy mouthfeels and this is no different. Light to lighter medium body. Good spritzy carbonation. Super smooth with just the right amount of creaminess.

4.5 D: Very good beer. Its been a long time since I had a Belgian style beer this good. Solid all around.  Dont pay attention to the label, this is anything but terrible.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-11-2012 22:57:57

Pours a very dark brown with a small beige head. The aroma is spicy, fresh bread, and yeast and some tartness. The taste is slightly tart, spicy Belgian yeast, and a dry finish. Good stuff.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours almost black - great head.  Smell: spicy phenol, peppery, woody from the bottle.  After pour - plums, raisins, potent purple fruits, yeast, tad roasty.  Taste - not too dissimilar to La fin du Monde.  Little less tart and more complex.  Quite similar to the smell profile - good woody character, nice malt and fruit after-flavors.  Still a bit too much citric acid and tart than Id like.  Tasted this side by side with Chimay Grande Réserve, and as nice as this one is, it wasnt even close.  Still, try out if you like the Belgian Strong Ales - its still quite top of the line for the style.
Really nice beer. Dark with about a half inch of white head. Very fruity and fairly strong. More of a sipping beer than a steady drinker.

This beer is pretty good and  I would buy it again. Not too sweet and the hops stand out. Slight bitterness. Spicy and earthy are there but the body isnt. No head is bad. Flavor is good with burnt dark fruits. Spices are dry on the palette. I paid 10 bucks.
Pours black with a couple fingers off white head. Smell is rich belgium yeast, sugary, maybe some light fruit. Taste is crisp, maybe a tiny bit tart, red fruit, very rich, caramel. Pretty good.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2013 Poured into a 10oz glass with a nice white head that does not last long and leaves minimal lacing.  Smells of molasses raisin,  bananna and a decent undertone of alcohol but not too strong.  Tastes of bananna,  spice of some sort and a bitter aftertaste of alcohol but it hides it well.  Medium body and  not too carbonated.  Overall a delicious beer.
My nose is off. depending on jakebra for that. Lovely dark murky color. Perfect balance of dark malts and hops, delightful! Smooth velvety palate. Probably the low point of this beer.

A: Poured a deep brown with a nice dirty white head

S: Vinous grape and slight alcohol aroma and molasses 

T: A sweet refreshing kick characteristic of champagne initially. Delicious molasses undertones mesh beautifully with the vinous taste. Hints of blackberries, plums and strawberries. Leaves with a slightly sour/bitter aftertaste. Abv is detectable, but not dominant. 

M: Absolutely amazing. This beer has a ridiculously low viscosity, yet it moves in my mouth like a thicker beer would. It is astoundingly smooth and incredibly refreshing. 

O: Great. It is soothing and delicious, very easy to finish.

Well, with a name like Terrible, they had to be pretty sure of their product. Mostly dark brown with big khaki head and some lacing. Smells of booze, cotton candy, and herbs. Sweet then dry. Fairly lively mouthfeel. Warming quality. Not too much lingering sweetness.
From the bottle came a dark amber brew with a thick, fine head. Floral aromas mixed with malt and bubble gum. Flavors pretty much the same. Medium bodied and very tasty.

Dark as night, but what an amazing beer. Spicy, flavorful and smooth with just the right about of bite. I'm a huge fan of this brewery, they never fail to impress. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Malty aroma with a smooth taste. Rather carbonated for my liking, but the flavor is very good.

Roasted malts on the nose. Some coffee, raisin, oats and vanilla. Very dark purple in color with a very thin foam at the head. Very smooth with flavors citrus and orange upfront followed by creamy malts. Light carbonation and a heavy alcohol filled body. Overall, a fantastically flavored brew that has great drinkability. Id give this an B+ rating.

Total Wine & More, Fairfax 750ml ($10): Pours a dark brown with a beige head type thing. Aroma is winy, with a whole bunch of yeast and a bunch of fruitiness mingled up in there. Taste is complex. The fruitiness is in some sense unique, with a bunch of different flavors acting up. Pretty easy drinking considering the rather high alcohol content. Quite a nice beer, but a little terrible.

Bottle 750 ml [2010]. Appearance: Pours very dark brown (almost black) with a small brown head. Aroma: Heavy aroma. Very strong notes of dark fruits (blackberry), wood, raisins, alcohol, malt and yeast. Taste: Dark fruits, vinous, raisins, underlying sourness, spices, alcohol, malt. Warming alcohol leave the palate dry. Overall: Way more fruity now than when it was fresh, yeast aroma almost completely disapeared. A really good beer from Unibroue.

From the swanky bottle to the beautiful, black pour, this beer is wonderfully presented.  There are bananas, clove, biscuit, and prominent Belgian yeast smells going on.  Smells milder than expected, but very pleasant.  Spicy, lightly boozy taste mixes well with the dark fruits, and a mellow creaminess and mild carbonation make this beer well-rounded.  Yum!

Poured from a bottle, black with a small tan-brown head which leaves no lacing.  Aroma of dark fruit, oak, roasted malt and ether.  Taste follows odors, with a dominance of dark fruit and cherry.  A bit boozy, but well-rounded and finishes short.  Medium body with a high ABV.   My friends and I enjoyed this one, would recommend you give it a go.  Definitely interested in trying other selections from this brewer.

Almost ten years ago I got my hands on my first Unibroue Terrible and, for basically a brand new beer, it hit all the high notes that the traditional Abbey beers in Belgium had spent centuries perfecting.  The fact that such a new beer could match such excellence should have been a sign.  The world of the top 1% beers has changed.  Its no longer dominated by these Abbey beers.  

The upcoming Anglo-Saxon beers of Brew Dog, Oskar blues, and numerous upstart American brewers are changing the face of beers.  More so even than the rise of Napa changed wine.

I have to admit I have a nostalgia for  La Terrible due to many great times had with this beer, but objectively it cannot compete with the newer concoctions dominated by imperials.
Poured a near black with a big light tan head that faded to ring. Aroma is yeast and some sour apple. Taste is cherry, spices, yeast, and malt. Pretty lively on the palate. Really good.

S: almost black, slight brown around the edges, surprising white head, not much lacing, small bubbles

A: almost sweet, sour apple, Belgian, a little bitter, some malt comes thru, but is overpowered

T: taste follows the nose, sweet start, tart-dry end, short finish, powerful taste, but quick, not complex

O: decent beer, good, but I'm not a Belgian fan & this is the definition of a Belgian strong ale, it's pretty good, but I'm not a huge fan

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From tap to a tulip. Black as night with a thin off white head. Malty aromatics and a full bodied palate. Loads of dark malt and anise lead into a brooding finish. Excellent.

aroma, sutle fire maltness, coupled with belguim fruitness,color, HA I had during a thunderstrom all power out so in the lighting stikes 
I could see, medium hue, powerful white head bubbly, tastse, blew me away, so sulte belguim fruitness, and maltness mingled with old funk!, awesome, overall, great beer love it! only when the lightstrikes will I drink again!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Far from terrible. Pours a very darl brown. High carbonation like all uniboues. Tastes of cherry, grape and burnt sugar. That typically unibroue yeastiness found in la fin and trois is not there but this is a kick ass brew from a kick ass brewer.

2012.02.25 - 750ml bottle in Chimay glass.  Pours dark brown, average head dissipates quickly leaving ring with little lacing.  Aroma was yeasty and bready at first, but turns more toward malty sweetness as it warms up.   Taste is good, hints at the spiciness of Trois Pistoles but doesnt quite follow through, then a bit of fruitiness like cherry that isnt quite there.  Mouthfeel is fairly light, not really that carbonated but the head that remains gets a bit frothy.   Not much of a bite at all, pretty smooth for 10.5% abv.    Pretty good overall.

Bread in the nose, but nothing else. Lively head and carbonation, with a dark purple-burgundy color. Aroma wise, very one dimensional. The flavor is rich with sweet, dark malt and finishes with a slightly fruity, very briar fruit like, and cloys with yeast esters. I found it to be very enjoyable and plan on purchasing again. The fruity characteristics definetly have captured the moment.
light bread,brown, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bread finish.

sampled on tap pours a dark brown with a light brown head.  Aromas of sour malts brown sugar yeast candied sugar and funky bread dough .  Flavor is slightly sour and bitter earthy and different.  body is medium and finish leaves a slight sour flavor
Amazingly  vinous...like a rich dark port (but better). I could imagine smoking a fine cigar while sipping on this (without the cigar).
user_location: Peoples Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: The "lowlight" of a recent tasting.  Compared to the other beers I had that night, it lived up to its name... terrible.  But really, not THAT bad.  It somewhat reminded me of a sour ale, though not quite as sour.

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours very dark brown with a thick, lacy, light tan head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, chocolate and caramel and slightly roasted malts, dark fruits, and floral hops to balance it out.  Flavor really strong of everything.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer.

Amazing, simply put. Big sweet presence up front. Light espresso, some molasses, dark fruit. Finish is also quite sweet with a light bitter aftertaste that lasts. Pours a very dark, coffee like with a small head. Very cream in the mouth with medium carbonation. Amazing.
If you have pabst Dont drink this. Weak, lighter than dark beer. Might give you a light buzz.
Shared bottle. Dark colour, nice head. Hints of oak and berries in the aroma. Not Terrible at all

Shared by OmegaX - thanks! Poured a nice deep brown with a frothy head. Smelled plentiful of dark fruits, yeast and alcohol - quite floral and thick. The taste is of yeast, cherries smooth malts and had a warm finish. Of course by the time I got to this brew I wasnt spelling correctly... hopefully I get to try it again soon.

Pours dark brown, with a decent tan head. Aroma is malty, with a little carmelized sugar. Taste is malty and sweet, a cross between Belgian and brown flavors. Fairly smooth and drinkable, thumbs up on this interesting brew.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with medium creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of licorice and chocolate.

An amazing beer.
Aromas of oak barrel (reminds me of Duchesse de Burgundy)
Very balanced taste with dark fruits and yeast.
Really enjoyable, you dont get the high alcohol at all.

Draught sample.  Pour is deep brown with no head.  Aromas are dark fruit and some spice.  Taste is dark fruit and a hefeweizen maltiness, with some hint of mint.  Overall, an OK beer, but not one I would seek out.

This is my favorite Unibroue. Red berries, red wine, plums, chocolate and torrefied notes. Very yeasty character. This a kind of beer that mixes flavors not meant to be together but with a fantastic result.

Great ale flavor but the fruity tones just dominate the palate after the first sip. Pours fantastic, tight white head with a dark mahogany body and isnt thick and syrupy. The aroma is reminiscent of a red wine or almost like dates, but the flavor just wasnt for me too sweet. Not a "must try" but definitely worth trying.
Dark pour with thin tan head. Sweet/fruity taste up front which persists. Over all, pretty nice.

750 ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a thin beige head. Very subtle roasted grain aroma. Tastes very fruity - black cherries, blackberries maybe. Weak bitterness in the finish reminds me of green grapes or some red wines. Typical Unibroue acidity is present. Overall, very reminiscent of many good belgian brown ales, especially some doubles, but it may be a tad bit expensive for the tasting experience it provides...

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Re-rate: amazing brew...one of my favourites. Pours a cola colour. Dark dried fruits in the nose and on the tongue...notes of bubblegum with a boozy finish. Wow..this is smooth and so delicious.

I seem to be going against the grain judging from other views but for me this was a bit of a disappointing effort from one of the best breweries for strong Belgian style ales. Unibroue is usually good at hiding the high alcohol content of their beers but this fully tastes like a 10.5% beer. At that percentage it is not possible to mask the alcohol but it need not be overwhelming either like it is here. This beer lacks the subtlety of many of Unibroues other beers. A sweet syrupy/wine-like taste that is strongly of burnt malt and caramel. Not a bad beer but nowhere near the standard or complexity of Maudite or La Fin du Monde.
Dark brown with a red tint.  Aroma is cherries and dark fruit.  taste is sweet and malty.  Syrupy moutfeel.  Very good.

Bottle thanks to soulpolisher. Pours a deep ruby brown with a small creamy light beige head. Aroma is nicely earthy and fruity lots of black cherry and some raspberry picking up some light cocoa and spice. Flavor starts with a crisp cherry black cherry sweet earthy fruit before picking up some of the subtle cocoa and light herbal note. Finishes clean and sweet. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Nice beer

Bottle. Pours a very dark red clear red with an offwhite head. Smells of a strong fruity scent, with some wood and alcohol. Tastes of a heavy sweetness with some sour fruit to counter it. Medium to heavy carbonation. Oily texture. Ends with a fruity slightly acidic finish.A superb beer.
#1027 bottle; Nose is mediumsweet roasted malt, cake, mediumsweet alcohol, rotten fruit, free is medium, carb is medium, taste is sweets, velvet malt, red apple, port, cedar, late weak cough syrup
Bottle. Dark with thin tan head. Fruit, oak, alcohol aroma. Berries, alcohol.

Bottle.  A dark opaque cola-brown beer with a thin fading off-white head.  Big malty, fruity aromas, some sourness.  Taste is very sweet, mild bitter.  I only get a very very faint sourness.  Medium-full bodied, well carbonated, with a dry finish.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. The darkest beer Ive tasted (in colour.) The taste is moderately sweet. I approve of this beer - it is not terrible at all.
Bottle in tulip glass. Dark brown, almost black colour with off-white head. Nice lively fragrant fruity aroma. Taste is sweet malty, fruit. A damn good Belgian style ale.

On tap @ Judges Bench-Ellicott City, Md-Cloudy mahogany pour w/a moderate tan head. Sweet, sticky aroma. Flavors of dark fruit, raisens, caramel, toffee, figs, very sweet & smooth. Great before/after dinner sipper, after would be better as it packs quite a punch, alcohol is quite evedent. Long, sweet finish, another winner from these folks, Ive got to remember to look for their stuff more often, the few Ive had from them have been quite good.
Good stuff.  Pours a deep reddish brown with very little head.  Nice aroma filled with fruit and sweet candi yeast.  So smooth across the tongue, very quick, yet sticky finish.  Keeper!
750mL bottle from Broue Ha Ha.  Pours dark brown with a good head.  Smooth fruity malty taste, and suprisingly not very sweet for a > 10% ABV beer.  Really good, wish Id picked up another bottle.
I drank this beer and I got pretty good and plowed. Good beer. When I was drinking it I was like, "This is pretty good." So I drank more. Thats how I got drunk.

Very floral with fruity esters, some sourness borderline rotten fruit, citrus, banana, almost chalkiness character.  The Pour was very dark, and plenty of carbonation, almost too much if you ask me.  Plenty of creamy head.  Taste - um, ok, this is fantastic.  You have the floral notes as mentioned in the smell, man sized banana, some alcohol burn and warming of the stomach.  Slightly sweet, but just enough to give it depth, finishes dry and hoppy.  As with other world class Belgians, they end up being too sweet this one strikes an excellent balance for me.  So good it will make you cry.  This one has been sitting around for probably a year.  Enjoyability 5/5.
Medium brown pour with a tan head.  Sweetness of plums and raisins abounds.  Taste of alcohol and caramel also present.  (9/1/2008)

It is right up there as a contender for my favourite beer of all time. Dark, velevety pour with a lovely off white tinge to the head. Aroma is amazing, with raisins, plums, a sort of caramel malt smell almost a little reminiscent of a fruit cake. Taste is just like what you smell but more  intense. At its absolute best when taken out of the fridge about half an hour before you drink. As it warms, it just gets smoother and smoother. Like drinking silk and it is a tragedy of epic proportions that for now we can no longer get it in this part of the world. Still, with a bottle in the cellar I guess Im luckier than some

Very dark  color with amber notes.  Aroma and taste are of cherries and black plum.  Sweet notes on the finish like a port.  It has a sticky consistency in the mouth and the flavor lingers well after the sip.  Very well balanced and the carbonation is subdued for unibroue which is a welcome trait, as I usually find their stuff overcarbonated.  I am a fan of this beer.  While thee may be better out there I would be happy to have this again.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a dark opaque brown.  Aroma is wine, coriander, honeysuckle, bubblegum, cherry.  Flavor is bubblegum, wine, coriander, pepper, citrus, dried cherries, plum.  Extremely flavorful beer and aromatic.

WOW what a beer! Dark cola colored pour with medium sized off white head. Aroma is amazing, with raisins, plums, caramel and a fruit bomb of intense ripe fruit. Taste is what you smell but so complex and interesting that this is just amazing. Only one thing is that this beers carbonation was slightly fizzy at colder temperatures but smoothed out and became creamy at warmer temps, dont drink this too cold, as it is amazing just cooler than room temp. One of the best beers I have ever had, and have heard it is a westy 12 clone, which I am more than dying to try now! Bravo!!

Pours a lovely dark brown/black with thick beige head when poured into a tulip glass. The aroma is of yeast, maple, cherries, and spice notes of cinnamon and nutmeg. The taste is of brown sugar, dried fruit, and subtle yet persistent warm cinnamon notes. Very good beer, especially on a cold winter night by the fire, like it is currently being enjoyed!

Bottle. Dark cola colour, thin creamy head. Fruity yeasty nose: banana, cloves, ripe prunes, dates, strawberries and dark candy. Some spiciness, maybe anise. Malty, raisiny sweet flavor finishes drier, slightly bittersweet candy finish with a hint of hops and chocolate. Smooth, very soft and pleasantly warm palate. Very pleasant beer.

Sampled at an esbls tadting.  Dark opaque with a big  tan head.  Acfruity nose with malt.  The flavorvis also fruity with yeast and Belgian influences.  This has brown sugar for sweetener.  Very good.

Tasted from large bottle at a bonfire party into glass tumbler. Poured a cloudy dark brown with massive beige foam, lasting with good lace. Aromas of rising dough, baking bread, aged fruitcake, some apricot and plum. Malty, nutty sweetness balanced by refined hops bitterness. Complex flavors of toast, cereal flakes, roasted barley, caramel, toffee, dark coffee and chocolate. Cream and slick mouthfeel, lingering aftertaste. Exquisite carbonation from bottle fermentation. Spritzy and refreshing, no one would believe this contains 10.5% alcohol by volume. A masterful big brown ale.

750cl bottle in a pint glass - pours opaque brown with excessive beige head and leaves some lacing.  Nose is yeast.  Aroma is crimson fruit, ether, hay, resin and just short of brandy.  Taste is sweet and borders sour.  Dry finish with medium body.  Id love it so much more if it has different fruit flavors.  Enjoyable.
From my Asheville, NC, beer log: On tap, Dark as night, super dark fruity taste and strong. Soft carbonation which I feel is unusual from Unibroue. Full bodied as hell. Thick, creamy, and delicious.

These brews from Unibroue continue to amaze! This is definitely one of the more complex brews that I have enjoyed in quite a long time! This brew is definitely a sipper as there are just so many intriguing flavors. This brew really came across muck like a fine port wine more than a beer. With these dark ales I prefer to open them up and take a quick sip and then let it sit at room temperature for roughly an hour and then pour and savor. Doing this lets the flavors intensify! While enjoying this brew I noticed the best before date was 01-30-2016!!! Time to go get several bottles and let them age!!

Bottle. Nice deep dark midnight color with  a subtle off white head. Deep caramel and toasted almonds aroma. Sweet caramel flavor with a light bitterness. Complex and deep in flavor. Very light hints of roasted malt and coffee bitterness layered into the creamy smoothness.

750mL bottle.  Pours dark brown with loud & dynamic fizzy off-white head.  Fairly weak aroma: slight yeasty doughy, sour apple, dark fruit, and an almost anise-like spiciness.  Flavor is caramel and other sweet notes with some yeast and spice and a bit of alcohol at the end.  Slight carbonation but not overwhelmingly so.
Sample. Dark brown but not opaque. Nose is spicy with some cinamon and maltiness. Taste is a bit sweet but not cloying with some spiciness and roastiness. Body is medium.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 13, 2011 From the bottle, pours black with a frothy tan head. Apple, black raspberry, and sour cherries. Full carbonation and big flavor of apple, fruit, and spice. Very dry finish. This is an enjoyable beer, but I feel like I need some water to wash it down.

750ml from Westroads poured into my Chimay Trappist glass. Bottle says best before 4/15/2015. Pours a dark black with a minimal amount of head. Aroma of apple and fermented fruit. Almost smells like a nice, dry merlot wine. Taste is lightly sweet. Slightly citrus, slightly spicy, and heavily apple tasting. Medium bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Explosive carbonation with a very long, alcoholic finish. Overall, very good. Definitely something Ill drink again.
pours a dark brown with a lively tan head.  Smells of wet leaves, coffee.  Taste is sweet and strong, a little tangy.
Pours brown with a khaki head. Aroma is malty, dark fruit, wood, and yeast. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, raisin, cherries, lingering finish.

Bottle "Best before 06-05-2011."  Aroma:  Burnt/roasted caramel, malt, hint of coffee, candy sugar and yeast.
Palate:  Soft mouth feel; fills whole mouth.
Flavor:  Caramel, candy sugar, baking spices--nutmeg, and light ginger.
Comment:  Above flavors linger on a soft finish.

Deep brown pour with an orange hue thin off white head .... aroma of dark fruity yeast, roasted malts and some candi syrup .... taste is of dark fruits (plums, raisins and figs) with some candi syrup, roasted malts and some dark bitter chocolate ... finishes with a light bitter dry hop and roasted malt .... mouthfeel is thick and syrupy little oily .... well done abv is only slightly there but more so as it warms good stuff

Pours dark but not oily with a good frothy head. Nice lacing. Tastes like a combo of the Unibroue Maudite and their Le Fin Du Monde. It really hides the 10.5% alcohol very well - incredibly well, actually. It is a truly well-balanced beer with great complexity - notes of soy, citrus and roasted malt throughout. Very well done, Unibroue!

Had this a couple times...close to a quad but different yeast  I guess.  Pours dark purple, almost opaque.  Its dark fruit all over...strong delicious flavor of plum, cherry, etc.  Description is accurate, perfect alternative to port or any digestive drink.  Very tasty...just dont try to put down a bomber of it, its a little too rich for that.
Aroma of belgian yeast, apple, orange and spices. Flavour profile is almost reminiscent of a wine with a slightly cidery edge. Complex and delicious. This is a great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 02.15.2015.  Draft at Rosamune with Erica. The below largely applies, I would add that there are big-time Belgian yeast notes in there. Agree with overall rating.  

08.14.2011. Bottle on our balcony courtesy of James, shared with Andy, Streets and James. Really cool pour - close to black with a big head that consists of zillions of little bubbles as opposed to a consistent froth. I enjoyed looking at it. Aroma was somewhat tart, and taste was apple and maybe some other fruits. Apple is the one I noticed specifically.

Pours dark brown w/ a large head. Lacing not noticeable. For a 10+% Abv beer it was very well received. Not too far forward with no burn. Fruity notes of plum on the palette with some caramel and malt characteristics following closely behind. Great Unibroue beer!

Bottle pours dark reddish-brown with large fluff light tan head.  Aroma dark fruit and slight belgian yeast.  Taste grapes, dark fruits, candi sugar and Belgian yeasts.  Brief finish of dark fruits.  Alcohol well disguised.  Palate rich, thick, not sticky or syrupy.
Really a sweet well balanced beer.  I would call it a quad, and a good one.
Thin head and dark reddish brown color with heavy lacing.  Strong root beer aromas and spices on nose following through to flavor.  Medium light body and upfront palate.

Rating #300.  Big Bottle from Chips @ OBX.  Poured a murkey brown color with a full head that slowly diminished.  Aromas of sweet belgium candy, honey, orange, and some spice.  Taste is Med/heavy sweetness with a tiny sourness.  Med body, creamier texture, ave carbonation.  Alcohol comes through a bit.  A sipper.  Complex.  Good one to try.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and served to a snifter with a dark, mahogany color, modest, off white/light tan foam that produced just a thin ring and a light layer of film, with negligible lacing. The aroma was a touch of yeast, dark plum and prune, and smooth, sweet maltiness. Lightly vinous with a pleasant alcohol presence, the body was medium to full, with nice complexity, and an altogether delicious nature!  The next encounter was a shared, 750 ml. bottle, served to snifters. Additional aroma notes were dark cherry and light spice. with sweetness in the flavor that was brown sugar-like. Equally impressive on tap or bottled!

Bottle; black brown with small tan head; aroma- plums, cherries, red wine/grapes, yeast, alcohol; tastelight sweetness,fruity, lightly bitter, acidic and warming. Not my favorite Unibroue but nice and complex.

Wow! Fantastic beer! Poured into my trappist glass. Nice dark colour. Thin head. Aroma is fruity. Flavor is pleasant. This is a phenomenal beer, and from Canada no less! Way to go! Love the after dinner digestant, or a substitute to coffee, this would be great first thing in the morning! LOL!

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a solid black/brown with a small this lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, alcohol, yeast, red wine. Flavour of dark fruits such as plums, some pleasant but not cloying sweetness, yeast and red wine. Medium body and acidity.

Bière limpide couleur de mélasse et coiffée dun col chamoix laissant une large dentelle au verre.  Des arômes boisés de fruits confits, de mûres.  Légèrement amère avec une pointe dacidité et un peu de sucre résiduel...  Elle aurait peut-être mérité un peu de vieillissement...  Bière généreuse et onctueuse laissant une fin arômatique et légèrement astringente.  Mondail de la bière 2011.

Dark deep mahogany brown with medium tan head.  Aroma red and dark fruits, caramel, cocoa.  Full body, sweet, alcohol there but not overwhelming.  All kinds of interesting flavors, cherries, coffee, licorice, yeast.  Maybe a little sweeter than I would like but complex and worth having again.

On tap at the Mondial. Dark brown/mahogany pour with a short head that sticks around and coats the glass. Very fruity and nutty with a little roasted edge on the nose. Quite sweet on the palate with pronounced caramel.

Pours a deep, dark brown with a lasting off-white head. Explosive, rich & sweet malty aroma with cocoa, subtle cherry notes, candied fruit, spices, raisins, yeast. In the mouth its full-bodied and slightly viscous, but not too weighty; palate-coating, rich, layers of flavor, complex, no heat from the alcohol. Finish lingers, just the right amount of malty sweetness; a superb effort.

750 mL bottle, aged approximately two years. Pours thick, opaque brownish-black with almost no head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits, raisin, plum, brown sugar, maybe a hint of yeastiness. Flavor follows along pretty well, being perhaps more sweet and a bit less interesting than the aroma. Palate is very heavy, with little carbonation. Decent Belgian style ale, if a little less interesting and complex than the best of the type.
Crystal malt.. very dark.  Yeasty, dark fruits, alcohol presence.  Coffee,  roasty.
Poured dark brown with a thin white head smelled yeasty and fruitty. Tasted the same with weak aftertaste good

Draft.  Pours a dark mahogany with a light tan head.  Aroma and flavor are sweet malt, some brown sugar, fruits (cherry, peach, raisins), a bit of spice, and a subtle yeasty/earthy quality.  This is clearly a Belgian style, but those elements are not overly assertive.  The alcohol is there, but muted, particularly for 10.5%.  Medium mouthfeel; nice carbonation.

This poured a very dark red with a beige head. Aroma was lots of yeast, some sweet caramel and dark fruits. Flavor was very typical of all Unibroue beers, somewhat sweet, lots of yeast, and lots of booze.

Nice dark brown color with a medium nearly tan head.  Aroma of fruit, banana, yeast, candy and alcohol.  Flavor follows suit with the typical Unibroue carbonation you would expect.  Wonderfully sweet but not overly so.  Warms nicely.

(750ml bottle thanks to Dixonian) cloudy dark brown, medium tan head, decent lacing. Nose of cherry, dark candi sugar, banana, anise, mild chocolate, and Belgian yeast. Complex. Taste of big time cherry syrup, ripe banana, dry and crackery, a bit too sweet and syrupy in the end. A good beer but not without its flaws. Quite good though.

pours black with a strong off white head and a little lacing.  aroma is yeast, plums and apples.  taste is licorice, yeast an raisins.  finish is dry and boozy.  an excellent, warming beer.  delicious.

750ml bottle from the latest batch that was finally released in Quebec. Full disclosure - had a bottle last year from 2002 and it was one of my favourite beers. Now rating a comparatively fresh bottle (3-6 months) and this is definitely a bottle that gets better with age...lots of age :) Anyways...pours a cloudy brown with almost no head, nice tan lacing. Aroma you come to expect from Unibroue - "darker" belgian yeast, with some fruit and alcohol. Nice carbonation, full bodied belgian and yeasty, bit of bitterness/hops in the finish but balanced with a nice sweetness. A good beer but one that improves significantly with age.
A very good Belgian brown... nice malt, good balanced sweetness, some fruit and raisin. Super drinkable at 10.5 % and quite enjoyable... one of the better Unibroue brews I have had.

strong sweet rich fruity belgian yeast aroma, pineapply mango plum  grap raisny slightly vanilla like, smells awesome sits at a dark brown with a small white head, noticed quite a bit of carbonation when I poured, and definately something I have associated with not so good thick belgian beers, but we will see, first taste is sweet tart like grape/raisin vanilla like flavor pretty damn good, and the carbonation adds a very nice balancing lightness to the deep sweet flavors in the beer, definately one of the better belgian strong ales I have had

On tap at Rustico - Alexandria (feels weird to have to specify the city now!) Reviewed from notes. 

Pours a nice dark brown with a light tan head. Some lace as it falls down my glass. Nose brings a touch of booze along with some light dark fruits and some dark candy sugar. The taste adds in a bit of darkened sugar or caramel...maybe some molasses. Good dark fruits with a bit of sweetness. Medium feel with good carbonation. This is a nice example of the style, and it seems like it would age quite well.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-24-2010

Pours a tawny brown with very little head. Sampled from tap. Faint notes of spice. Taste was strong being difficult to differentiate the different flavor sensations. I think part of the problem was the beer was served at too cold a temperature. A beer like this needed to be served at 50 degrees as opposed to the 36-38 that this one was served at. Had a nice finish to it. It definitely felt like a strong ale with a big and lingering finish. Id like to try this one again but at home.

(Sample Date: 11/24/2010   Source:Other)   Bottle from Kroger. Spicy fruity yeast character. Sugary. Almost black with fluffy off white head. Sweet, fruity, and spicy. Light peach pear flavor with candi sugar and cocoa notes. Medium body and mouth. Sweet finish.
Bottle. Color dark brown with big head. Aroma vanilla, fruit, bread.Taste dark fruit, sugar, alcohol. apple.

750ml bottle, best before Oct 15, 2014.  Served at cellar temperature.  Pours dark brown with red highlights and a large foamy/bubbly tan head that holds a very persistent cap and leaves some spots of lacing.  Aroma is chock full of dark fruit notes, raisins, cherries, plums, figs, belgian yeast and candi sugar, bread, hints of chocolate, caramel and coffee.  Excellent strength.  Flavor follows suit with more dark fruits, candi/brown sugar, toffee, caramel, dark bread/toast, yeast, a bit of chocolate, some spice, mild alcohol, very nice.  Mouthfeel is foamy, medium bodied, a bit fizzy.  A fantastic BSDA, and another winner from Unibroue!  Seems very similar to Trois Pistoles, would have to do a side-by-side to really notice any differences.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits. Unibroue is one of my favorite breweries so far and this one just reinforced that fact. The aroma was full of spice and fruity character, with a little yeast/malt sneaking in the mix. Poured nice and dark. Taste was apple & cinnamon with nice malts. Sweetness and maltiness are well balanced. Excelente!

Bomber shared with a dear friend. Pours dark brown with a off white head that just stays and lingers this beer looks awesome! This smells amazing! I pick up on raisin, slight booziness and vanilla. The vanilla really comes through with plums and raisin. There is also a hint cherry and the finish is nice and clean. This beer very good and would love to have again.

Very dark, near brown black. surging beige head.  Very yeasty, fruit forward aroma, kind of a funky currant/passion fruit feel with spice, some bready malt.  Tastes a bit bready/toasty with more of that fruitiness, dark dried fruit with some bright, lightly tart tropical notes, a little leather, soft earthy hoppiness.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 750ml bottle into a tulip glass. This bottle is labeled "Best Before 02-26-2012".

Appearance: It has a very dark brown colored body that is nearly opaque. A tall tan head of big soft bubbles slowly settles down to a finger of thick and creamy foam. Lacing is thick, sticky and coats the glass.

Smell: The aroma is light and delicate. I get modest hints of sweet bready and mildly funky yeast with some fruity notes of dark cherries.

Taste/Palate: There are fruity/estery notes with hints of sweet-tart black cherries, dry yeast and bready maltiness. This is balanced by a very light herbal leafy hop presence that also adds a light bitterness and a slight mineral or metallic touch. The palate feels smooth and creamy with mellow yet very active carbonation and a good solid medium to full body.

Notes: Overall this is a very well made beer from a solid brewery.

Bottle, as pictured.  Pours a deep, dark mahogany-brown with nice long lasting foamy head.  Smells of plum, cinnamon, raisin, nutmeg.  Taste is similar, with a nice creamy taste to it.  Extremely impressive.
The most dangerous thing about this beer is the fact that you can have a glass, and another glass, and keep wanting more.
Deep brown in the glass.  Aroma of dried fruits, roasted malt, and spice from the yeast.  Rich malty palate.  Alcohol comes through a little hot.

Bottle. Pours a black with a mocha head. Rich nose smells slightly wine, dark sugars, and a little booze. Taste is very light and complex. Dark Belgian sugar is complimented with dried figs. Lots of carbonation give it a quick and clean finish for ten and a half percent. Very nice.

11.02.20 bottle shared with seb after a long there it is. black fizzy lasting beige head with nice lacing. A : spicy, roastiness, some dark caramel. F: thin body finish is sweet and medium long. O: Nice but not extra... for memory the older version had more brown sugar.
I dont believe how well hidden the alcohol is, 10.5% and it doesnt taste alcoholic, an amazing achievement.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2011 Smell of dark fruits and a wine like tartness. Taste is a mix of belgian yeast, toffee, chocolate malt and tart dark fruits. Very, very good. Extremely drinkable, Im just downing this.

750 ml bottle from Broue Ha Ha, served cool in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a nice, creamy, tan head.
  
Aroma:  Signature Unibroue yeast, wet bread dough, some bright fruitiness (berries, raspberry leaves?), a fair bit of dark, dried fruitiness, sweet brown sugar and rich malts, some minty herbal notes and some decent esters, something that reminds me of a little funkiness, rich, sweet and lovely.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, full, velvety, elegant effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Certainly a hint of Saison funk, then a big hit of rich malts, fruitiness, yeast and bread dough, minty herbals, very nice; sweet with sufficient bitterness and brightness for balance, a rich malty finish with a hint of alcohol.

Loin de terrible

Big, richly flavoured beer. Lots of dried fruits and some alcohol notes on the aroma. Quite darkish brown in colour. The palate is rich and full, warming alcohol with a quite Belgian character to it as well.

Pours a deep murky brown with a pillowy light tan head.  Aroma is an inviting blend of heavy malt and dark fruit notes, complimented with a mild woody and boozy undertone.  Nice sweetness up front that is quickly muted by the sharpness from the alcohol, flavors of prunes and damp wood linger on the tongue.  Quite airy on the palate, high carbonation level makes this a surprisingly drinkable brew despite its strength.  I would very much like to accent this beer with a fine cigar.

(Gorgeous bottle shared with my beautiful Flemish wife who is now half drunk!)  Le liquide a une couleur brune très foncée.  La tête mousseuse est fugace et se transforme rapidement en anneau.  Au nez, des arômes de cerises et de prunes en compote sont fortement touchés par un fin et judicieux mélange dépices dominé par un clou de girofle capiteux.  Lalcool qui me semble bien camouflé est insidieux et aime bien se manifester à travers ce léger souffle poivré et cette belle brise florale.  Le goût est collé aux arômes avec des fruits épicés qui, à retardement, exhibent un côté doucement suret.  La bouche est remplie de pur bonheur belge, avec une effervescence juste et une texture légère et caressante.  La finale se fait sur des notes alcoolisées chaudes, amères et surettes avec une magnifique touche poivrée.  En résumé, encore meilleur que dans mes souvenirs les plus lointains.
A great Belgian dark ale, just great dark fruits in it all around and gives the originators a run for their money.

Welp, the nose on this one is pretty nice, getting some sour cherry, figs, and some sweetness, and a bit of booze. On the palate the flavours are similar, cherries, candy, booze, and a little bit phenolic. A nice beer and happy I could finally try it (thanks Tyler). A little bit flat but really the only negative in it. Glad this is back in Canada.

750 ml bottle shared with friends pours a dark brown with a moderate head. Aromas of ripened fruits and spices. A different more full bodied palate than the famous La Fin Du Monde. Tastes the malt sweetness mixed with the spicy clove and yeasts. Finishes less dry than other strong Belgium ales. Good balance of tastes. Great beer!

Great nose! Dark fruit, plum.

Pours a nicetan head with a dark opaque body.

Sweet and malty, fruit esters.

An excellent beer!

Lovely deep brown color; large tan head that lasts a surprisingly long time. Spicy: cloves dissipating into bitter chocolate. For us non-Francophones, the missing article on the label suggests a regrettable false cognate: theres nothing terrible about this beer... unless you count the deceptively high alcohol content.

Pours deep dark brown that is still translucent and bright (like a dense root beer), fine tan head.  Aroma is generally fruity and not very distinguishable from other Unibrou aromas (particularly the Chambley Noire I just had a week ago), but as your nose gets just close enough, to the point where you think it might touch the liquid, one realizes that there are a slew of flavors hidden in the liquid.  The flavor contains dark fruit, but not dates and raisins as in other BDSAs, rather black currants and prunes.  It tastes like fermented fruits too, making it almost wine-like (as opposed to fresh fruit).  Delightful, a great beer to share.  It becomes tempting to drink this at an accelerated rate as the bottle empties.
(bottle)  Mahogany colored, disapating head, no lacing.  Deeply flavored of raisons, prune and alcohol well hidden.  Sweet and delicious to sip.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2013 pours dark murky brown with a dark beige head, belgium yeast fizzyness and spicyness. figs, raisins, ripened dark fruits, chocolate. semi-sweet  great balance with the hops, grassy and citrusy. lively carbonation, medium body, nice grassy-spicy earthy finish. excellent!
A little bit dissapointing not what i would call a pretty beer, Very good none the less.

Bouteille de 750ml, avec bouchon de liège. Bière brune foncée avec une mince mousse beige. Nez sur les épices, les fruits et la levure. En bouche la bière ne fait pas ces 10,5%, elle a de bons goûts de fruits secs, raisins, épices. La finale est longue et enveloppante, avec une plaisante chaleur.

750ml bottle sample purchased at Consumers Beverages. Pours a very dark almost purple brown, with not much head to speak of. Some minor lacing. Aroma I didnt find very strong at all. Taste is of dark fruit such as grapes and dates, and some alcohol in the finish. This really is quite an awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2011 Bouteille 750 ml. 10,5%. Couleur brune très foncé, presque noire. Mousse beige pâle mince. Arôme de levures, malt, blé. Goût de levures, agrumes, malt, fruits mûrs. Finale sèche et pas très amère.
Black pour, big brown head. Aroma is sour fruit (grapes, plums), yeast and some nuts. Flavor has a sour, vinous bite, plums and a big yeast character balanced by sweet nutty malt/ dried fruit.
Extremely smooth and drinkable at over 10% AVB.  Nice dark fruit flavours.  Once again, Uniboue did not disappoint!
amazing! cant believe its not from belgium! I am seriosuly amazed...
750ml bottle... poors very dark brown with a tan head. Decently fizzy and very light tasting for having such a dark color.

Listening to my bud Mitch tear up the airwaves. Thx to Glouglouburp for the brew so I could give it to a fat friend. Ultra dark brown brew with a fair sized bubbly brown cap with some spots. Wicked aroma! Burnt sugar, sweetness, raisins, dull cherry... or is it raspberry? Light nut and vanilla, caramel, very light yeast, grapes... excellent. The taste is more mellow and simplified but still a total treat. Smooth melted caramel, molasses, hint of chocolate, light alc burn, dark crusts, brown sugar, moderate yeast spice follows up and finishes the taste. Smooth and soft, medium bodied and more. Soft finish. Sometimes you dont need to go over the top for goodness...
Bottle, thx Nick. Pours black with an off-white head. Flavor is sweet, raisins, dark fruits, yeasty. Surprisingly light for such a dark appearance. This is a winner.

Super dark color with a fluffy, bubbly head. Aroma of dark fruits, plums and raisins. Sweet flavor, touches of fruit and malts, a little bit of sugar as well. Medium mouth feel, nothing too heavy. Enjoyable with a big dinner.

This is a beautiful beer with wonderful body. But the aroma is pungently sweet and the sensation of the sugars in my mouth is overwhelming.  Will try this again in the future and hope to discover better balance.

Bottle best by 5 Jun 2011. Poured a dark brown with a quick off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits and roasted malts. The flavor found fruits (cherry mainly standing out) and roasted malt. Light hints of spices. Medium body and sweet.

Pours a dark brown with almost no head.  Aroma is strong; wine, chocolate, prunes, raisins, cherries, solvent. Taste is chocolate, cherries, red wine. Packs a kick. Good but not one that I couldd rink everyday.

bottle.  Poured into trappist glass, very very dark brown, pretty much black, with nice layer of creme colored off white froth, bubbly and fizzy.  Aroma lighter than expected, of classic belgian spices, soft chocolate, dark fruit, perhaps plum, raisin, prune.  Full bodied, soft mouthfeel with some noticeable carbonation, bubbly and yeasty.  Flavor is at first light cocoa with lots of spices, and then moves to an almost sour prune aspect, to a very long finish which displays notes of raisin, plum, light chocolate.  This is quite a nice beer, 10.5% entirely masked, very enjoyable.

Bottle. Moderate to heavy malt notes of toasted and molasses, light to moderate perfume and resin for the hops, light soap for the yeast, and background notes of prune, tawny port, nutmeg, licorice and cola, and alcohol, Head is small, fizzy, light tan with some slippery lacing and and good legs, and is almost fully diminishing. Color is clear dark brown. flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly bittersweet and acidic. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, oily, with a lively carbonation and a moderately alcoholic finish. Nicely balanced flavors and spicy, but not too spicy, aromas makes this a very enjoyable Belgian strong Ale. Definitely worth taking your time with.
Bottle. Poured black with beige head.  Much lacing.  Aroma is fruit, roast, caramel. Caramel and fruity full body.  Doesnt taste as strong as it is.  Spice, brown sugar and plum finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: The beer pours a dark reddish-brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is strong dark fruit with some Belgian candy sugar, roasted malt, molasses, chocolate and caramel malt mixed in. The flavor is just as nice. I get a ton of dark fruit - cherries, grapes, plums - as well as roasted malt, brown sugar and caramel. The alcohol is well hidden for a beer of this alcohol amount. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

750 ml bottle. Pours almost black with a nice tan head. Nose is belgian yeast, dried apricot, cocoa. An almost full body that is smooth and somewhat creamy. The taste is heavy on overripe fruit, grape, but more tart than sweet, with a bit of spiciness, some roasty kind of coffee notes. Juicy, jammy and tart like a big red wine, but still a beer with its roasty and yeasty profile.

Very dark pour with a light tan head. Good carbonation. Smells of some spices and fruit, almost cider like. On the tongue you notice the carbonation followed by some some different sweet tones, not so much of fruit but more of caramel. Palate is very typical of a Belgian strong ale with a unique and enjoyable taste.

Bottle from my Ontario cellar that moved west. Pours a very dark brown, with smaller tan head that dies rather quickly. Aromas of Chocolate, light coffee, yeast, faint hints of malt and fruits. Flavour is nice, sweet, and smooth. Hints of raisins and malt come through, with other dark fruits and caramel. Finish is nice, fizzy, but smooth. Seems to have aged well but not remarkably.
comes across to me like a belgian abbey dubbel, with more roasted and chocolate malt character, and a bit more alcohol. decent, but not great.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2010 Tasted from a 750 mL bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Very dark black appearance.  Fairly fruity (dark fruits) sweet aroma.  Dark malts and pretty sugary Belgian ale flavor.  More alcoholic than some of the other Unibroue beers.  Pretty good but not spectacular.

22 oz bottle pours to a deep brown with a thin off white head that dissipates quickly. Taste is sweet and sour with a hint of spice. Lively carbonation with a medium body. Its a Belgium with a dark side. Overall pretty good, spicy and good tasting.

Aroma of dark, hot cider, candy sugar, very oud bruin like. Appearance is dark brown but the head is off pink. Flavor is very different from the aroma, more caramel and chocolate, still fairly sweet and very boozy. Palate is creamy. Interesting brew.
My current favorite beer, this guy strays from my normal lighter fare. It is so complex I cant wait to have another and find more reasons to love it.

Very dark brown and not much head.  Aroma has tons of plum, prune, and fig going on, and that runs right into the taste too.  Theres some sweetness and more dark fruit flavor in the finish too.  A good for everyone to try.
had over Thanksgiving - will have to try again to remember all the details; verrry good though - seemed like it started as a stout and finished as a belgian ale; very good combo.  will try again

Quite simply a dark beauty... ive let one age a bit for over a year and it developped port like caracter but still a dark roast and dark chocolate taste remained.  Surprisingly light for a 10% alcohol beer.  I wouldnt know how to categorize this beer, but without a doubt its in a league with very few others.

750ml bottle. Dark as night with a deep tan head and spiced fruit aromas that remind you of Grandmas christmas pudding. Plums and stone fruit in the aroma with a thick and creamy mouthfeel that hits all parts of the mouth. Strong flavour of spiced fruit thta has been soaked in alcohol.
I dont think Ive ever seen a blacker beer, the the ehad was very foamy. Great carbonation with a sweet aftertaste.

Bottle. Dark brown with a thin head. Aroma is yeast, coriander, spices, alcohol, sweet malt and dark fruits. Flavor is yeast, mildly spicy, sweet belgian malt, raisins, coriander and alcohol. Medium to full body with above average carbonation. A very good strong belgian ale. Its a shame that this one is not available in Québec anymore.

Appearance:  opaque dark brown with a light brown creamy head that slowly shrinks (I left the 2nd glass for an hour and it was still there), thick collar, tons of lace.  Aroma:  didnt care for the aroma fresh and cold out of the bottle:  very tangy, sour and musty; after it sat in the trappist glass for awhile it was quite nice:  dark toasty malts, cloves, cinnamon, yeast.  Taste:  yeast, cloves, cinnamon, spices, tangy and sourish dark fruits (plums, prunes, cherries), toasted brown bread with a little brown sugar and chocolate.  Finish:  medium in length, tingly and a little sour.  Notes:  As usual, a very good ale from these guys.
