Palate was a delight; rich and creamy yet somehow light enough to have a whole huge bottle all to myself.  Flavors were rich, malty, yeasty and full of spice.  Not my favorite of theirs, but its pretty good.  Better as it warms.

One of the best and most complete beers Ive ever had.  Smooth all the way through, which is a common boast many beers have but La Terrible really comes through.  Beautiful color with not too much head.  I had it in a Trappist glass which really allowed the beer to show off all it had.  I would suggest this beer to anyone that likes drink beer and stray from the big labels in the states.

Sample, during the Mondial de la bière, savoured June 2 2010; eye: dark brown, opaque, tiny ring of beige head; nose: yeast, fresh, medicinal, malt, floral, perfumy, light coriander; mouth: yeast, fresh, medicinal, malt, floral, perfumy, light coriander, perfumy finale with presence of malt, medium-full body, good carbonation, mildly bitter, slick texture; overall: quite likable

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, lors du Mondial de la bière, savourée le 2 juin 2010; il : brune foncée, opaque, petit anneau de mousse beige; nez : levure, « frais », « médicinal », malt, floral, parfumée, léger coriandre; bouche : levure, « frais », « médicinal », malt, floral, parfumée, léger coriandre, finale parfumée avec présence de malt, corps moyen-corsé, bonne carbonatation, moyennement amère, texture coulante; en résumé : bien aimé

750ml bottle shared at a party last night.  I logged onto RB and realized, holy crap, I havent ticked La Terrible yet!  For shame!  This is a nice beer from Unibroue.  Dark brown in color with a lasting light tan head and good lacing.  The aroma is rich caramel malts, chocolate, brown sugar, dark fruits, and banana-like esters.  Smells great, and really complex.  The flavor is very authentic Belgian and tasty.  Sweet caramel and toffee malts, raisin and fig, spiced notes, fruitcake, and brown sugar.  Smooth and medium-full on the palate with great soft carbonation, evidence of bottle conditioning.  Overall a very well-done Belgian Strong Ale.  Big fan, tickd717 is.

Pours dark brown/black with copper edges. Aroma of Belgian yeast- banana, clove, and dark fruits and a touch of graham cracker. There is a good amount of malt in the aroma but it is dominated by yeasty esters. Taste is very nice, not overly sweet and syrupy like a lot of Belgians, great balance of fruit, yeast and malt flavors. Very drinkable for such a strong, rich beer. Alcohol is minimally noticeable on the finish. Medium body, carbonation is true to style being slightly high. There is also some bitterness on the finish. A very good beer. I have had the chance to buy this before but passed it over several times since Im not a huge fan of Belgian Strongs, Im glad to have finally bought it because its great.

Jet black with a nice tan head that lingers around.  aroma of fruit and toffee.  smooth and sweet on the palate.  This beer is very rich with a steady increase in the alcohol level as the beer warms.  Finishes sweet and chewey.  Not bad at all, but as suggested use an aperitif or for substance for a Monk.

Big beige head. Nearly opaque black body goes dark brown body. Sugary papery caramelly aroma with oily toffee notes. Dry-sweet oily banana alcohol taste with soy sauce notes. Fullish body. Hot mouthfeel. Dryish spicy mealy roasty aftertaste with banana and cardamom notes. Quite nice, but not great. Unusual. (0.75l bottle, Fish & Beer, Copenhagen.)

Pours near black with just a touch of light brown head. Nose is very sweet with a lot of brown sugary and raisin-laden malt. Flavor is typical for the abbey quad style: rich and sugary with a touch of dark chocolate, raisins, and roastiness and low hops. Finish is very sticky and sweet. Not exceptional but it does the style well, ergo making a damn good ale.

Dark brown with a good sized light brown head.  Malty, fruit aroma with caramel with cheery like.  Big aroma.  Taste is of bits of chocolate, fruit, caramel, malt, and finishes strong with some warming alcohol.

(750 ml bottle, best before 4/15/15) Pours dark brown with a thin, soft tan head - nice looking beer. Aroma of chocolate, sour dark fruits, light yeast - surprisingly a little off-putting and not too complex. Mouthfeel soft and lightly fizzy - nice palate. Nice, strong, weepy rings of lacing around the inside of my Trappist glass. Flavor of dark chocolate, sour dark fruit and light yeast. The sourish tinge didnt add much to this beer IMO but still quite bold and tasty. ABV well-integrated.

Dark chocolate color -- deep and beautiful; good bubbles, too. Aroma is red fruit, some raisins, caramel; taste is quite sweet, some creamy red fruits -- sour cherries, too. This one is a bit too hot for me, too, but really nice. Maybe some more time back in the fridge would have helped. Quite nice -- worth revisiting, too.

A deep enigmatic pour with a deep black ruth featuring a mocha brown whispy top.  Easy to sip with a touch of apple infused caramel forced bittering brandyish sweep.  Not too bad but lacks a certain folksy whimsical woddsyness that transcends normal tasting nomenclature
Bottled. Pours dark brown with a nice tight head. It smell of alcohol and brown sugar. The palate is extra fizzy, almost like a sparkling wine. Finish is shorter than i was expecting.
Lively is the first good term that describes this beer.  La Terrible has a finish of mellow and abrupt with but an even better body full and heavy.  Unibroue never  disappoints.

750 mL bottle.  (2008 vintage).  Dark - darker than any Unibroue cept Chambly Noire.  Certainly a darker head.  Trois Pistole-ish aroma, only less sharp, and a little buttery (in a good way).  Yeasty, (dark) fruity flavour, with some candi sweetness.  On the sweet side.  Alcohol lends a touch of flavour, but is unobtrusive.  Low carbonation for Unibroue.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Very dark cola brown, almost black, with a bit of a dark cherry walnut hue on the edge. Pretty large, light, fluffy, cloudy, stick, foamy, off-white head. Pretty good retention with a nice sticky, foamy layer of lace.

S - Nice dark fruit with a good plum, fig, and raisin flavors. A touch of dark cherry. Some bubble gum aroma as well. A lot of Belgian yeast and candi sugar as well. Has a full jamy aroma. A pretty good amount of spice and fairly sweet.

T - Get a lot of rum soaked dark fruit (similar to the nose) giving it a bit of a vinous/plumy flavor. Some dark bread/malt and a touch of burnt brown sugar is in the background. Fair amount of bubblegum and phenol flavors come in and out. Belgian spiciness and yeast and the candi sugar are pretty up front, definitely taste like a Belgian style beer. Alcohol is present through out the sip, but not overly strong.

M - Medium body with plenty of carbonation. A little light/thin feeling for the style/ABV. A bit of a zesty feel with a sticky and drying finish.

D - Definitely a sipper with some strong, bold flavors. With a lot of spice, sweetness, and alcohol heat no one flavor overpowers, but it is a little much to drink a lot in one night.

Notes: A good offering from Unibroue, that definitely had a Belgian taste. Pretty bold, strong flavors gave it a feel that it wasnt perfectly balanced, but it didnt really seem out of balance. Overall it is an enjoyable beer that would be nice to have every once in awhile.
UPDATED: SEP 20, 2010 Very dark brown, almost black, with puffy head. Yeasty and fruity. Very thick on the palate. Good stuff.

Bottle, 2006 edition thx to Gnoff, 2010-09-04
AP: dark brown, wee beige head
AR: sprity, caramel, fudge, ww vionos, wee choclate
F: some sort of spicyness perhaps black pepper + se AR above. I guess it didnt develope so much as wanted...
Very good beer, reminds me of the flavour of Westmalle dubbel with a slightly heavier body and more booze. Smooth, and very Belgian. Ripe fruit galore.

Bottle. Pours cola brown, foamy off-white/pale tan head, very ropey lacing. Nose is dense, fruity, and bready, cherries-tobacco. Mercifully the "raped by Unibroue" yeast character has been tamed and toned down by time and age. Flavours runto fruit and acid. Nice rich bread notes also. Rather boozy.
Pours a cloudy brown with fizy soda head. Nose is belgian yeast spice, taste is ok, very dry, overcarbonated, mild all around on the flavor.
Bottle. Very dark bown pour with a strong tan head. Strong malty scent with some fruits and yeast. Smooth tasty drinking her and I have had a few. Malty flavor with some dark fruit and spice.

Smells... in between, like the boatman. Its kind of malty and kind of hoppy, but then theres like a void, and then the darkness of the malts hit, and the blankness inbetween is like the void... Its dark and clearish, some head and lacing.... sweet, darkish, mostly the sweet though shines through, its very clean, just a hint of dextrose at the end. The sweet ness last out, but it fades quickly. Not too bad, but its definatley an apertife, as it says, for cleansing the palate. The blue cheese Im eating for belgian night is fading out fast.

Bottle. Fantastic warming aperitif.. not too sweet, but rich and decadent. Christmas pudding / raisin pie with dark roasted malts perambulating throughout the mouth. The richness and the high alcohol makes this one a drink to split on a cold winters night

(Bottle, a couple of years old) Pours dark brown to black with beige head. The aroma holds typical Unibroue yeasty notes - spicy (mild white pepper, cinnamon and cardamom), doughy and fruity esters. Undertones of dark berries, over ripe dark berries, candi sugar, some chocolate, cork and light oxidation. The flavour is medium sweet, light bitter and light acidic. Spicy, fruity, yeasty, earthy, sugary and light cork. The mouthfeel is soft yet light sticky with a lively carbonation. Dark sugary, yeasty and earthy finish. Medium bodied.

(bottle at Seans Unibroue tasting).  Pours dark brown with off-white head.  Aroma of caramel and some smoke.  Taste is sourish and sweet.  Light bodied and thin.  The beer had and oily mouthfeel.  Terrible has a nice caramel flavor.  Would drink again.

I love unibroue 75cl corked and caged bottles. Opens with a big pang, but never foams over or gushes. Great!!.  clear dark brown, smooth light brown head.
tart fruity and dark caramelly aroma. flavor is caramel, alc. bite. lots of alc. bite. faint flowery. faint toffee. way too much alc. for my taste, considering there is not much flavor in the brew.

750 caged and corked bottle EDT:10-15-14- Pours black with reddish brown highlights at the bottom of the glass, the head is thin and creamy off white. Aroma is tart and fruity. The flavor is Belgian yeast, bread, cocoa, a very bright (yeah, I know its a dark ale) fruity and easy to drink Belgian ale.
A huge dark, full bodied beer. Big in alcohol. Big head. Heaps of dark fruits and malt on the nose and equally matched in flavor. Really enjoyable after dinner treat.

Aroma: bread, toast, dough, alcohol, soy sauce.
Appearance: brown, black, cloudy, sparkling, white foam, tan foam.
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter.
Palate: medium body, creamy, fizzy.
Overall: This is an exquisite Belgian ale with a complex flavor profile. It is rich and malty, with hints of caramel and chocolate, but without tasting like a stout. This elegant beer, with a 10.5% alcohol content is perfect for special occasions.
alcohol, banana, clove, vanilla, woody, smoke, dough, dark, black,medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, creamy, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter, astringent,

Poured from a 750 ml. caged and corked with a freshness date of 10-15-2014.

Pours a murky dark cocoa brown with cola highlights. Head is three finger and sticks impressively stays around a while.

Aroma is powerful! Dark roasted malt with a hefty dose of fruity yeastiness. Fruitiness in the middle from the yeast there is also a burnt toast aroma from the malt. Finishes with band aid and tropical fruit yeast with a dose of dark chocolate.

Flavor opens with dark fruit. Yeast takes the top of the profile with bready dark roasted malt following. Middle brings banana and bubble gum with a shot of warming alcohol. Bitterness in the finish from the roast, nost any hop flavor can really be detected. Finishes sweet with a warming of booze down the gullet.

Carbonation is higher than I would think for a bottle conditioned beer, but this works to cut the sweetness some. The only suffer to the drinkability is the higher ABV.

Nice, split the bomber with someone.

Reviewed 07/11/2010

Bottle thanks once again to Danny. Pours a dark brown with dense coffee coloured head. Aromas of sweet dark fruits, dark malts and doughy yeast. Flavour wise pretty much the same. Very sweet with lots of candi showing through. Sweetness also comes through from the dark fruit. Slightly bitter finish thanks to the raosted malt. Nig mouthfeel. Nice

750 ml bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a dark brown with plum tints and a huge, foamy beige head that lasts and sticks all over the glass.  Aroma of raisins, booze, caramel malts, cherries, dust, Belgian yeast, and spices.  Flavor of raisins, caramel malts, alcohol, plums, cherries, Belgian yeast, spices (clove, coriander), licorice, and a musky note that holds it back from truly being awesome.  Alcohol and spice combine for a spicy kick, even though this one has mellowed over the past few years- 2007 vintage.  Still a complex, satisfying beer shared after dinner.

Very dark currant colour with beige head that dissapears quickly. Currant or beery notes in the aroma, very nice. Beautiful smooth taste, definete fruit hints. Leaves a lovely warm sensation going down. Exceptional beer.

Bottle 2004 Vintage thanks to JohnGault1. Pours out a brown with some red highlights topped with a tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, maple syrup, and pit fruits. Taste more of the sweetness takes over and a little spice helps pull it together. A very tasty Belgian Strong Ale. Thanks Toby
tried this at the Beer & Brewer Expo in Melbourne.  Very nice, quite thick and creamy. rather sweet with a hint of cinnamon, with a light bitterness to finish it off. Liked this one a lot!

Bottle 750ml. Masterpiece. Aromas of caramel, butterscotch, dough, and chocolate. Taste is sweet, with bitter notes, and long lasting. Palate is syrupy, and full bodied. Black, with a frothy white head.

Great pour! creamy, dense lasting head. Smell: very similar to leffe Brune with added metalicness and slight cherry. Taste: spice of corriander and clove followed by bitterness of spicey alcohol drenched licorice...slight sweet prune and raisen appear then quickly disappear! finishes with a little tart cherry and dominant amounts of coriander spice...palate is left coated with a licorice like texture. Overall, a little firery and unbalanced for the style...the dominant spice overides and makes the beer quites one dimensional.

Poyurs a dark amber chocolate brown with frothy cream colored head. Aroma is a mix of raosated matls, some peat and nuts. Flavor is earthy malt with an underlying sweetness almost little cherry/raisin. Body is light yet creamy mild carbonation.
Almost black of color with a beige head. An aroma of spice, sweets and prunes. A flavor of prunes, sweets, spice and a bit of alcohol.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2011 tasted at the mondiale de la bière in Montréal. pours dark brown with a foamy tanned head that leaves some gorgeous lacing. HUGE fruity, yeasty nose. taste is dark fruits, spices and belgian yeast. some caramel, but im not getting any of the advertised coffee, nor do i see how this could be a coffee replacement. slight alcohol burn on the way down. mouthfeel is more carbonated than what i expected. this is a delicious dark BIG belgian styled ale.

Extremely dark brown pour with a foamy tan head that settles creamy and lasts. Mild Belgian candy sugar up front, cinnamon and dark chocolate malt and bready yeast. Taste is mocha and rich plum jam and raisin. Hides alcohol fully, though has a warming ending. Rich and deep.

Bottle at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2010.
Dark fruit, malt, dry hoppiness. Prunes. Nice and complex beer.

Bottle aged for 1 year at cellar temperature.

Appearance: Dark brown / black body with a nice 2 finger grey brown crown. Decent retention and some lacing.

Smell: Muddled and uninspired. Dark fruits (figs), toffee / hazelnut notes. Some belgian style yeast.

Taste: A touch better than the nose. Nice hazelnut meets figs flavor. Finish rides the line btw dry and sweet.

Mouthfeel: Ample carbonation and a medium to medium thin body.

Drinkability: This one doesnt show its strength.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-26-2009

Pours very dark with an off white fluffy full thick foamy top.  The head is incredible!  It just doesnt want to go anywhere giving this beer a decadent appearance!  Aromas of raisins, plums, browned sugar, and a bit of a metalic aroma coming through as well.  There are some noticeable spices from the yeasts that were used.  The yeasts also give this a bit of a bread-y aroma that is really nice.  The flavor is predominately about the spices.  Clove and coriander really seem to be in charge here permitting some of the darker fruits to come forth.  The darker fruits really are more subdued and their sweetness comes in a distant second to the spices.  As the beer warms, the spices seem to not be near as strong and some of the softer flavors like sweet browned sugar, a bit of molasses, and sweet plums seem to become a little more bold in flavor.  The finish is long and rather spicey throughout the glass.

Served from tap into a Unibroue tulip.  Pours a nice dark brown that is almost black with a nice three-finger tan head that lingers.  There was minimal lacing evident throughout.  The aroma was comprised of sweet malt with a hint of nuts.  The flavor was sweet with bitter notes and alcohol.  There is also a bitter aftertaste upon swallowing.  It was medium on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this was a very nice brew.  It is definitely the best one I have had from Canada thus far.  The flavor was similar to a Chimay (Blue) only the flavors were a little more potent and also had the nice alcohol flavor.

750ml bottle into a Duvel tulip glass. Pours dark but not oily with a good frothy head. Nice lacing. Tastes like a combo of the Unibroue Maudite and their Le Fin Du Monde. It really hides the 10.5% alcohol very well - incredibly well, actually. It is a truly well-balanced beer with great complexity - notes of soy, citrus and roasted malt throughout. Very well done, Unibroue!

Oh yeah... very smoooth ! This fine Unibroue product pours a very dark brown colour with red highlights. A thick creamy tanned head erects and stays for a long time. Lacing is left on the side, uniform, and a 3mm layer coats the brew. The aroma is very mild, but berries are present with notes of nuts. Roasted malts are also there at first pour. Mouthfeel is smooooth and creamy. The taste is mostly berries. Cherries at the start, and then the tart kicks in. Long tarty lingering aftertaste. Raspberries, blueberries, plums are fruits that come to mind. Slight nut in the finish. A very good brew, hard hitting and like said... smooooth.

Cant believe I had to go to NYC to get this beer from Quebec!   Pours a black syrup with an off-white head, good retention.  Aroma of purple fruit, malt and yeast.  Taste is of a great belgian, sweet malt, yeast, raisins with light tannins.  Such a nice sipping beer.  Sit back with a book and enjoy.
Almost black of color with a beige head. An aroma of spice, sweets and prunes. A flavor of prunes, sweets, spice and a bit of alcohol.

750ml bottle, 14C (better as it warmed), BB 2013. Very dark brown with a small light tan head. Nose of dark fruits and earth. Tastes lightly sweet with mysterious dank and peppery/ leafy spices. Complex fruity taste includes apples as well as red berries and sour oranges. Less Porty and more spicy than Troi Pistoles. Prickling carbonation. Noticeably boozy but not raw. Fruity but dry finish. Elegant and full of character. Less approachable than other strong beers Ive tried from this brewer. Likely to keep well for a while, but good now.

750ml caged&corked bottle. Pours very dark brown and a little cloudy with a medium-thick but short-lived light tan very smooth tightly-beaded head that leaves many dots and long streaks of lace on the glass. The aroma is rich - lots of fruit like figs, mild acidity, hints of cherry, sweet with molasses, touches of milk chocolate, etc. Flavor is similarly rich, though more straight-forward and less complex -- starts malty and sweet with touches of caramel and maple, light amount of spice, and hints of tropical fruit (pineapple and cherry). At mid-palate, light touches of balancing hops, growing fruitiness (subtle hint of bubble gum, apple cider), and some alcohol. Warm and very dry finish with more fruit and crisp molasses cakey malts. Mouthfeel is very bubbly and airy that turns frothy, rich, and medium-full-bodied as the carbonation is released in the mouth. Mild astringency on the sides and back of tongue from alcohol. Overall, a very nice beer - rich, sweet, and decadent.

Dark brown to black, light tan head, good lace. Aroma is sweet milk chocolate and strong vanilla, light roast, earthy hops. Taste is taste chocolate licorice with lighter caramel and Belgian yeastiness. Boozy burn in finish that is very pleasing.

Pours a deep dark brown, head holds well-did have off tap. Smells of sweet malt, candy sugar and dark fruits. Taste is candy, raisin, caramel and a bitter zip in the aftermath. Very good, but not  a favorite.

Poured into a small wine glass. deep brwon that boarders on black. The aroma was a candy sugar and caramel but with a fruit tartness and a light chocolate like bitter in the end. The taste was very suble sweetness and slight bitter with a nice creamy texture. A good beer to enjoy slowly.

750 ml bottle poured into my Trappist glass. Dark brown with a thick foamy beige head that lasts a long time. Aroma of earthy musty Belgian yeast, burnt caramel and some dark fruit. Flavor of sour yeast, lots of sugary dark fruit and malt and some bitter chocolate. Mouth feel is nice and dry with a full body and a active carbonation that lightens it up a bit and enhances the drinkablity. This is an outstanding beer, more of a dark strong or quad, but very nice whatever you call it.

Served on draught into a Unibroue tulip glass. Dark, black and opaque color. Nice 1 inch head. Some dark fruit aromas with a bit of licorice.
Malty fruit flavors including plums, raisins with some licorice and chocolate. As the beer warms, I pick up more of the cocoa flavor.
Medium bodied and good carbonation. This would go great with a grilled steak or chunk of roast beef. It would make a great desert beer or complex enough to be drunk on its own.

Corked and wired 750ml bottle into Trappist glass. Pours opaque dark brown with a small beige head. Strong port wine-like alcoholic notes on the nose with caramel, candy sugar, dark fruits, liquorice and faint aniseed. Taste is not as sweet as the nose suggests with a spicy warming alcoholic finish and low bitterness. The palate is rich and full bodied with an oily texture and low carbonation. It is a fine sipping beer that, like the blurb states, is ideally served before or after a nice evening meal.
pours a dark reddish brown smells of dark fruit and port wine taste is of brown sugar and plums very nice finish feel the warmin of alcohol that is well hidden in the flavor
On Tap at Capones. Light banana, licorice aroma.  Black body with white head.  Flavor is sweet and spicy, banana with hints of anise.  Sweet finish. An excellent strong ale

Tasted at Griffen Distribor show.  Dark brown with a thin but lasting head. smells of dark berries and malt. taste is of rich dark fruit, dark sugars, and some spice. finish is clean and warming due to the alcohol content. very interesting and another great beer from Unibroue!

Pours a dark brown, almost black, with ruby highlights.  Thick, foamy tan head with good retention and lacing.  Nice strong aroma of dried cherries and raisins.  Flavor is similar, with dark malts, brown suger and dried fruits.  Just enough hoppiness to keep the sweet flavors in check.  Warm, earthy finish and a clean aftertaste.  Outstanding beer.

Im pretty sure this is an Abt/Quad. Pours a very dark, opaque brown with ruby edges and a tan head that hangs around awhile. Full aroma of figs, grapes, candied sugar, yeast, toffee, and caramel. Similar flavor with some alcohol heat on the finish. Rich, full mouthfeel with soft, fizzy carbonation. My new favorite from Unibroue.

750mL bottle. The beer pours a dark brown almost black, like coca cola. Some dark head, lots of carbonation - a staple attribute of any unibroue brew. The aroma is some fruit, towards the end I can begin to sniff some strong alcohol. However, this alcohol is completely absent from the taste

2003 bottle shared by footbalm, thanks man 
Appearance: Pours dark brown, almost black with a small tan head. 
Aroma: Dark fruits, caramel 
Taste: Dark fruits, caramel, roasted malts <br.
Silky and smooth mouthfeel, very nice.

Unibroue
Terrible
Pours dark brown with a dense creamy head and good retention. Slight reddish tinge. Sweet aroma of cloves and grapefruit with some alcohol on the nose. Smells nice. Flavor is malty and boozy with some cloves and a slightly sour finish due to a citrus flavor. Mouthfeel is bubbly and crisp. Good brew

From the 750 ml. bottle with an expiration date of 11-11-2013.  I had trouble with the cork to this one and ultimately had to use a corkscrew, which always makes me worried about getting cork in the beer.  Fortunately it was a smooth uncorking after that.  It poured brown with two fingers of puffy, beige head.  The aroma has some light hops, cereal malts, and comes across as a tad alcoholic but still tolerable.  The mouthfeel is decent, heavy, and thick. The taste has some bitterness, mile hops, but it is smooth overall.  An excellent beer.
On tap at Capones.  Dark brown (almost a hint of purple) with a coffee head.  Taste is very complex with hints of vanilla and caramel. Very impressive beer but the ABV hits you quickly.

Unibroue makes some good beers.  This one is no different.  Pours a dark chocolate color. Has an aroma of grapefruit and caramel.  The alcholor comes through on the nose.  Has a taste of sweet maltiness with a slight sourness that really balances the beer out well.  Lighter body but creamy still.  Complex, but working together.  Love it.

The invigorating aroma of a sweet brown spicy ale characterizes this brew with hints of vanilla. The deep dark chestnut brown color is paired with a beautiful creamy coffee head. The sweet abbey dubbel/ brown ale flavors complement each other so well. It runs smooth and sweet throughout the palate.

Opaque brown with tan head. Berry, and black licorice aromas. Heavy sweet, medium bitter, medium-heavy sour. Soft carbonation, medium bodied, heavy sweet into long medium sweet finish. Quite rich, but a great experience nevertheless.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2011 750mL bottle, pours a very dark brown with a reddish tinge. Aroma is predominantly yeast, with raisin and caramel. Flavour is yeast, raisin or grape, slightly chocolately malty and various other dark fruits, as well as a dry vinous quality. My favourite from Unibroue.

This is a bottle probably from 2008. From my collection. The aroma is raisin, caramel, and slight chocolate. Appearance is a perfect brown mahogany with a lasting tan head. Taste is of caramel and raisin with a lively carbonation, also malt with no hop bitterness. Overall this is a great beer. The alcohol on this aged bottle is nonexistent.

A Drunkard Tasting   A rocky, frothy head with a dark brown color. Cherry, Almond And Vanilla. Not overly sweet, finishes with a touch of bitterness. Apples up front, then moves to Cherry. Feathery in texture.  In fact, just Too light. Expected More from this Ale.

750 ml. from Jax in Cumming, GA. I was fairly surprised that they had this there. Nice dark cola appearance. Nice off-white fluffy head. Looks pretty damn good to me. Pungent aroma, even though it is quite cold. Light spice and dark fruit aroma. A nice yeast aroma as well. Dark fruits consist of: raisins, light plum, light grape, and maybe some fig in there as well. As said, nice pungent aroma. Damn this is a very sweet/fruity flavor. Warming characteristics are present due to the alcohol. Tastes like grape juice . The fruit characteristic just cuts right through everything and smashes the taste buds with flavor .Alcohol is well-hidden. Light cinnamon and other spices are hitting my taste buds. Very nice Belgian with a great spice and fruit complexity.

26th October 2008. Very dark brown beer with a cream head. Mild and smooth but quite dry. Subtle milk chocolate and subtle cherry. Dry finish. Hides the alcohol very well but overall the beer feels a little tired.

It pours dark brown with a slight amount of light shining through and an off-white head that actually lasts quite a long time. The smell is quite normal for a strong ale and consists of caramel and dark malts, licorice, and bitter dark chocolate. I was hoping for the same type of taste as I found with the smell but it was somewhat lacking. It was much more watery and alcohol tasting than I would have liked, although it went down relatively smooth.

Finally got around to drinking this 75cl traded bottle at Codys birthday party. Pours a very dark brown with a towering, foamy, khaki head. Tons of lacing as well. The head beats down some of the aroma but there is dark fruit, yeast and chocolate. Surprisingly lighter palate that includes vanilla, raisons, and caramel malt. Quick finish. Well done.
Pours out a dark reddish brown with a rocky tan head that lingers for a little bit. Smell is fruity and malty and the taste is the same. Overall delicious, and my favorite from Unibroue.
Smells metallic - but otherwise incredible. Hides alcohol better than anything. Tastes like slightly sour sweet raisins with wood and nice yeastiness. Dark and toasty. Yum.

Tap @ cloverleaf. Pours dark with tan head. Aroma is sweet ,  and of dark fruits. Belgian sugar, dark malt, dark fruits, etoh, strong belgian(well canadian) beer that is complex and nice in 8-12 oz pours.

Impressive beer.  The darkness caught me totally by suprise and as a dark beer lover, I welcomed it.  The cherry tone made for a unique, enjoyable experience.  It poured with a lot of head for me - more than any beer Ive poured prior.
This thing pours dark. A small beige head appears and slowly disappears. The nose is raisins, fig, caramel, and some chocolate. The taste is similar with a dark fruit finish. A great Belgian Strong.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 A beer that poured so dark it gave me nightmares.  Upon opening the bottle and pouring I was struck by a cherry smell, this was unanticipated.  Taste was initially bitter at first and sweet towards the finish.  Felt Terrible had a full and thick feel to it. My first taste left me unimpressed but subsequent sips changed my mind and at the end I really enjoyed it.
Bottle (in NZ). What a beer to bring in the new year with.  Was everything but "terrible". Velvety, didnt come across anything like 10.5%. Would have happily drunk it until the next new years...

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a laced beige head. Aroma and flavour of raisniny malt, figs, caramel, chocolate and pepper. Fantastic balance all round with a welcomed complexity and easy to drink considering the high abv. Sweet fruity finish. A well brewed Belgian style strong ale.

750mL bottle.  Pours a translucent dark red with a small light brown head that leaves no lacing.  Immediately upon opening there is a complex aroma reminiscent of a sweet red wine.  In the glass there are also aromas of yeast, caramel, cherries, citrus and dried fruit.  The flavour is very sweet (possibly excessively so), slightly spicy with some tartness and almost no hop character at all.  The alcohol is noticeable but not overt.  Medium to full bodied, tingles pleasantly on the lips and tongue like a sparkling red but is not excessively carbonated, and is otherwise quite smooth with a sweet and slightly sour finish.

Big and spicy - If you like the unibroue yeast you will love this beer. I could go either way depending on the day, but this is on par with most really good belgium beers. Dark fruit, raisins, spice. There is a lot going on and may be a bit much for some, but I quite enjoyed it. Cheers to volcanicbeat for this beauty.

Almost black body with a rather bubbly but small caramel colored head.  Aroma is tangy with a slight barnyard smell and notes of hay and grass.  Flavors of cherry, malt, some vanilla, and some grass.  Mouth feel is light especially for such a complex beer.  Bitter finish that has strong staying power.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brune body with a tan head.  Vinous notes, caramel, dates, a dark fruity ester y warming, with a sweet flavor.  Toffee, some butterscotch, more caramel and a modest warming.  Love it.

Draft at High Street Grill. Poured a deep dark black body with a smaller frothy head. Aroma of dark fruit, cherries, yeast and strong alcohol notes mixed in as well. The alcohol on this one isnt hidden at all and is easily tasted mixed in with the yeast and malts. Flavors of cherry alcohol and grains dominate. Interesting but the alcohol needs to be more balanced.

What a plesant suprise to find this on tap at Stone.  Dark like a stout with no head by the time the server brought it to the table.  Lotsa seriously tart deep sweetness and sourness.  No pucker however.  Darker and deeper in the mouth.  Lotsa malt hiding in there.  Cherries and vinegar.  Yumminess.  I need Weeheavy to explain this one to me.

the best Unibrou ive had so far. it made it all the way to NZ without tasting old and musty. nice esters and phenols on a firm malty backbone with some restrainted roastiness. very enjoyable the only thing I would fault this one for is that it was a bit too sweet and Im not sure I would have enjoyed the entire bottle.

750ml bottle in glass. Deep redish-brown with two-fingers of head. Aroma raisons and cherries, a bit of yeast. Starts strong with fruit and berries, primarily cherry.  Nice unfiltered yeast in the middle, and finishes smooth again with the the berries and roasted malts. Almost devoid of hoppy bite; instead, the smoothness and rich flavors mask the high alcohol. Dangerously drinkable. Quite lovely.

Large, four-finger head.  A touch of tan to the froth.   Deep, dark ruby brown color.  Light only shines through on the sides of the glass.

Sweet cherry smell.  Some raspberry, too.  Reminds me of a framboise, but without the sourness.

Rich sherry-like flavors: strong alcohol, sweet berry.  Rich body with a warming swallow.  If there are hops, they are hidden.  I would consider this to be an after-dinner drink, IF you havent had too much to drink already.  This is a very tasty sipping beer.

Poured dark brown and slightly cloudy.  An almost creamy, light tan head formed.  The aroma was a hint of cherry and then raisin, malts and a touch of yeast.  The flavor too had a bit of cherry with dark malts and raisin becoming more prevalent as it warmed.  A touch of alcohol towards the finish.  Medium bodied with tight carbonation.  Not bad.

Pours a very dark brownish black color with a nice big head and plenty of lace. The aroma  is plum cherry and alcohol with plenty of floral and estery aromas. The flavor is fruity and lightly roasty with some apple and cherry and plenty of spice. The flavor displays just a slight hint of warming alcohol note and just a faint tartness. The palate is creamy and full. I could easily believe that this beer is half its strength. Smooth and drinkable without negating flavor or texture.
Pours dark brown color with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits, candy sugar and dough. Flavor of raisins and figs, dough and molasses. Medium body with lively carbonation. Very nice.

Dark reddish brown, big chunky tan head. Aroma was very fruity. Closely resembles Juicy Juice. Lots of cherry aroma and flavor. Little bit of sourness. 10.5% alcohol was totally hidden. Im not sure if thats really a good or a bad thing.

750 ml bottle at Cest What? in Toronto.
Opaque black with a large tan head.
Hints of pine and licorice.
Creamy chocolate mousse flavor with an edge of slight smoke. Finish of cocoa and milk chocolate. Alcohol shows through, otherwise Id give it a 4.5 for taste.
Great body.
Definitely to be sought out.

750-ml bottle Marcellos Lafayette, LA - Aroma: chocolate, raisin-, plum-like dried fruit, vanilla (malt); Appearance: dark-brown to black color, tan head (fades quickly), some laces; Flavor: sweet, salty, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, raisin-, plum-like dried fruit (malt), bitter (malt/hop), sourness (yeast); Mouthfeel: medium to heavy bodied, high carbonation, creamy texture, dry finish; Overall: a gorgeous black colored Belgian style beer with restrained bitterness, and amazing aroma and flavor of chocolate and dried fruit which finishes a little sour or tart and hidden alcohol content.

Ive sampled Unibroue beers in the past, but this is my favorite from the Unibroue family. Fairly strong alcohol content of 10.5 %. Nice taste. Very rich and complex. I will be purchasing more of this brew in the future. A must try!

On tap at local pub. Dark with creamy head. Raisin and plum aroma. Sweet and smooth. Medium body. Little carbonation. Truly a unique beer. Had I drank it blindfolded, I could have been convinced that this was wine. Very pleasant.

Pleasantly surprised with this. Strong sweet-yeast nose like most Unibroue beers but with a lot more character on the dark, evil end. Mouthfeel is stout and smooth with all manner of spice and tasty sweets. Molasses, coffee and raisins. Dark but not purely black pour with a bubbly tanned head that has stayed around for awhile. Alc does come in, but rather perfectly. A bit sticky finish with a rush of malts. Nice and impressive, but not top-shelf.

This is terribly good. A reddish-black beer with a nice fluffy disappearing head. The aroma is very fruity as is the taste with a lot of flavor going down rather smoothly. The 10.5% ABV is totally hidden more than any other 10 - 11% beer so much it is pretty amazing. This seems like wine drinkers could like this & I like the fancy gothic bottle.

Bottle. Deep brown with a thin tan head. The aroma is slightly fruity but mostly yeasty. The taste reflects more of the Unibroue yeast and dark malts, perhaps a little raisin. Probably my favorite by this brewery.
Dark brown opaque colour with tall foamy tan head, nice lacing. Nice malty aroma, almost molasass. Slight carbonation, sweet malt flavour with noticeable alcohol. Nice lingering aftertaste
Dark with a soft white head.  Fruity aroma.  The flavor is definately Unibroue, raisins, figs, some sour.  Medium finish.  I likey.
Dark brown color.  Small head with good lacing.  Tried out of bottle.  I really enjoyed this beer.  More like a stout than a strong ale.
I like the Belgian strong ales they do but they all blend together to me.  Big, alcoholic warmth, plum notes. I prefer the Ephemere and lighter offerings for some reason.

Pours like root beer from the 750ml. bottle: An infused nose of plum, grape, and alcohol pairs with a sweet malted, spiced, doughy, smooth carbonated flavor and body. Unibroues signature yeast flavors dominate. Drinkability: Its enjoyable just how complex this beer is. Rebuy: Yes. #177 on 31102009 "BOO", DG.

My 1000th rathing - 2007 Bottle from my very first trade, thanks douglas88! - Pours thin and dark brown with a medium beige head...aroma is inviting, cocoa, plum, apple, sweet malt and Unibroue yeast...flavour is similar, fruity and doughy, spice, dk malt, roast, raisin and creme...pleasant carbonation and not even the slightest abv burn...easily my favorite of their offerings so far...

Corked and caged Bomber via Bonster.  Understated and gentle is where I must start with this on all fronts.  Pours dark with some nice brown tinges at the edge of the glass.  Nose is whispy and ephemeral but strikes of stonefruit and wet bark.  Body is unassuming and gentle.  Malts (not radios) appear as body progresses.  This beer glides up on you and gently hits you like a bag of wet cement.

Draft at International Beer Garten (Lutz, FL).  Pours a deep, dark brown with a ruby hue along the edges and a nice tan head.  Has the characteristic Unibroue yeast aroma with the addition of dried fruit and grapes.  The flavor includes more of the grape notes along with malt and yeast.  Quite nice and the 10.5 is well hidden and not at all overpowering.
 Reminds me a little of their Trois Pistoles.

You think if the beer name was 
"Terrible" the brewer would try their best to make it taste good.  Actually, is not great, its not terrible, is just okay.  The to me the style was not so much as a belguim strong but an imperial stout with weak hops.  The flavors come from dark malts
2003 bottle.  Pours a dark brown with an aroma of dark fruit, caramel, and spice.  Flavor of caramel, spice, dark fruit, and cocoa.  Decent carbonation.  Very nice!

very dark, deep black color, shades of red and brown shine slightly through when held up to the light. smells faintly of cloves, plums; that character of the yeast i smelled in the trois pistoles. tastes the same, clove, plum, raisin, with a sour note that comes in later. I taste a little coriander, but much more in balance than the coriander bomb that was la fin du monde (for me). hidden alcohol that warms the throat slightly. overall a very good beer, something i wouldnt mind buying again.

Bottle. Appearance: black with a soapy off White head. Aroma: smells like unibroue. Yeast, malt, caramel, lemon and spice. Flavour: spicy malt, hop, alcohol, slightly sour, sweet and with a bitter finish. Nice.

Leos South Point, OH - What do you get when you brew a dark beer in the Belgian style? Something La Terrible...but really tasty. A plum, grape, and alcohol infused nose rises from a Cherry Coke color body giving the beer a smooth, yeasty, and nicely carbonated flavor and body. For a "Dark Belgian," this beer doesnt disappoint.
Poured very dark brown,  dark fruits, caramel, nutty, spice, alcohol, little granny smith apple, little yeasty, little roasted malts.

Rerate after 4 years in the cellar: Pours a dark opaque brown almost black. Puffy mocha colored cap.

Raisins, spice, cake, earthyness in the complex aroma.

Rich buttery mouthfeel, Big bundt cake like malts in front go to a rich complexity of dark fruits, cocoa, nuts, roastiness, herbs, spice, grape skins and licorice. Rich long finish punctuated by the malts not a wisper of fusil alcohol.

Still this brewers best offering.
This is a pretty darn good beer and hands down the best Ive had in this style.  But I must admit Im not a huge fan of the style, but still a good beer.
Rotten aroma, sour taste, aftertaste is okay. Come on, Unibroue. I really want you to make a good beer...

Appearance:  Pours a dark reddish brown, letting no light get through. It pours with a big foamy head that subsides to a collection of froth at the top.

Aroma:  Raisins, spice (clove and nutmeg?), and sweet red grapes.

Taste:  Dark fruits, licorice, cocoa, red grapes, and spicy hops.

Mouthfeel: Really fizzy and medium bodied.

Overall: Another winner from Unibroue.

Bottle. Pours extremely dark brown, nearly black, with a tremendous, creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, walnuts, and hints of pepper. Very full body, with a pronounced, slow-burning finish. Excellent Belgian strong from Unibroue.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dun fût, dégusté au Festival Bières et Saveurs 2009 (Chambly, QC). Arôme: Légère odeur de chocolat et de prunes avec une pointe dépices. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de chocolat et de caramel légèrement fruité avec une pointe de vanille et dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de mélasse en arrière goût. (Rating #2659)

Pours an opaque sable, nearly black, with a thick and fine-bubbled beige head. Aroma is malty with a nutty undertone and quite tempting. Flavor is malty, a little nutty and slightly sweet with a hint of caramel. Smooth, tingly texture leaves a nutty and malty finish.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Bottle, 5 years old. Dark, dark pour almost black brown. Aroma is pretty complexe lots of mushrooms, woodsy and kind of fishy (fish not strange, a seashore smell) and of course the classic dates, plums, grapes and cherries. It smells fresh for its age. Mouthfeel is sparkling and bold. Taste is red fruits, alcohol still quite present (the bottle was VERY well sealed) and cola. Well done long finale.

Dark reddish brown pour with a big tan head. Dried fruit and malt aroma with a little alcohol.
Taste is huge with the dried fruit, a little spicy, and the alcohol is only slightly present as it warms. 
Not my favorite style, but still great brew.

Bottle 750ml. Aged 9 months piror to tasting. Poured dark brown with a large, tight, foamy, lightly tanned head which was fully lasting.  A complex aroma with notes of sweet milk chocolate, coco powder, yeasty malts, plums, blueberries, dried apricots, allspice, light notes of coffee and a dash of brandy. Flavor was smooth with virtually no bitterness, yeasty malts, chocolate, prunes, blackberries, sultanas and a touch of vanilla & cinnamon. Very well masked alcohol content. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, a somewhat syrupy texture and a good length finish.

Poured from big bottle.  Aroma is cocoa, dried fruit, oak.   Quite dark - Ive seen lighter stouts - this tan head persists.  Cocoa, fig, some kind of tart fruit, brown sugar, in flavor.  Alcohol hits big in back of throat, sinuses, even in stomach.  Got a bit mellower toward the finish, but still felt a bit more like a brandy than a beer.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of Fratto.  Dark dark rouge pour. Aroma is sweet upfront with heavy notes. Also has sour notes of vinegar. Has small sweet tastes with soured malts. I was rather disappointed in this. Meh.

Bomber, corked & caged, from 2002, thanks brother-in-law John. Zero pop from the cork, and minimal head, but there is some decent self carbonation in the body.  Rich aroma similar to a Flemmish red blended with toasty caramel. Nice lacing when you swirl the glass. Oak, dark fruits, malt, floral hops, smoke. Finishes a bit dry. Nice Belgian style dark ale.
TAP: jet black pour, medium head. Dark fruit nose. Malt, fruit on taste, some molasses.

Dark, ruby brown; linkering small amber head. Rich, nutty caramel aroma. Big flavor of dark roasted malts, molassas, carob, pepper, poppy seeds, alcohol, prunes and kumquat with a lingering aftertaste of smoke
This is my favorite of all the unibroues I have tried. Love the look, smell, taste, and attitude of this one.

Bottle. Very aromatic with licorice, roasted malt, chocolate and cherries. Very dark brown colour with soft beige head. Sweet flavour with English licorice and alcohol.. I somehow understand the name of the brew - its a nasty thing just like candy. You just want more of it.
Im beginning to think that Unibroues beers are generally over carbonated.  Carbonation aside, this is a very tasty beer that packs a dangerous punch.
Pours very dark brown with a thick foamy tan head.  Strong dark fruit and sweet malty candy flavor.

This was hard to place, for me, stylistically.  It certainly had belgian notes to it, a dark fruityness, a candy sweetness, carbonated mouthfeel.  But it was also dark and malty.  10.5 is miles away.  I thought this was quite good and special.

Shared this with MereLikesBeer, I originally purchased this as a potential for my 300th rating, but went with the Uninbroue 17. HOWEVER, this stuff is equally as epic. Its a dark Belgian style beer, with tons of prune and raisin, and a hint of clove on the finish. It  truly is an epic beer, equal to the task of pairing with a good steak, as well as creme brulee.. Cheers!

Oh Unibroue.  So, I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617 - who else...  And well, it was epic, as usual...Good choice BeerBaron617 (as it was his purchase).  Definitely not what I expected upon pouring it.  It poured an opaque black brown color with a fluffy light tan head.  Has a strong aroma of dried dark fruits and alcohol, sweet, and slightly malty.  Taste, epic.  It has a great amount of carbonation, typical of Unibroue.  It has a great alcohol warming, and all of the aroma notes translate to the palate.  Very tasty, I would love to get another bottle of this and crack it for a special occasion.
Got this to drink in a hotel in Chicago and lost my tasting notes, so I just jotted down the number the next day.

[2345-20090103] 650mL bottle. Sweet dark fruity malt aroma is roasty. Dark dark brown body with a medium-lasting creamy light tan head. Sweet roasted malt flavour has lots of sugary fruit and a long aftertaste. Full body. Wonderfully malty and lingering sugary finish, Formidable!
(c/o DuctTape, w/ him, jerc)
Pours deep brown/black and has the aroma of dark candi sugar.  Dark malt and belgian yeast give this one its uniqueness.

750ml bottle. Yes indeed. This is another amazing beer from Unibroue. Pours almost black, but if held up to the light it is really a dark ruby colour, with a light tan head that lasts. Sour cherry and port wine feature strongly on the nose. They also both feature in the mouth along with molasses, blackberries and sherry. This is a fantastic beer that I can only imagine would develop even more complex and delicious flavours over time.

750ml bottle - $8.48 at Sherlocks in Marietta, Georgia. Best Before: 2-26-2012.

Appearance: Pours an opaque, walnut brown body with an appropriately tall, foamy, light tan head.

Smell: Sweet-scented, malty nose coming across as a plated up Shoofly Pie for dessert along with some secondary notes of dark fruits and spice.

Taste: Dark, not-quite-roasty maltiness with flavors of molasses, dark brown sugar, dark candi sugar, and sweetened cocoa-flavored coffee. Burst of black cherry, sour cherry, and cooked raisin fruitiness. Earthy spiciness with a hint of black pepper and ground cardamom. Small touch of alcohol warmth, though, as it warms somewhat, it becomes a moderate pinch of alcohol warmth. Finishes dry but also malty with a taste of, well, again, Id say Shoofly Pie, but I feel that reference would be entirely lost on most.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Well carbonated with a tingly, altogether bubbly mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Paired remarkably well with the movie "Casino". Id pair the last third with some food to see how it goes, but I only have yogurt and ramen, so... Easily one of the better Unibroue brews Ive had, but, sadly, not one I often see around in Georgia. Ah well, such is life. Drinks surprisingly easy for purportedly being above 10%.

Bottle from about a year ago enjoyed July 09.  Pours a murky darker but thin brown with a thin sudsy light tan frothy head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity, oxidized, sugary, one-note straightforward, Unibroue yeast of course, very sweet, slightly dark and rich.  Flavor of dark raisins, toasted, almost burnt, brown sugar, very sweet, one dimensional, some Unibroue yeast but not as much as other offerings, flat dull raisins, sugar.  Thin bodied, a bit sugary, nice carbonation though, sharp larger and fluffy.   Okay.

Terrible in name only, this is a fabulous beer.  The colour is very dark, almost black and the off-white head is VERY carbonated witghout being fizzy.  The aroma and taste have lots of things going on, with various fruits and malt.  The high alcohol content makes itself known without being overpowering.  More, please!

Her cork lets loose with a brilliant pop and his, freeing a billowing white mist that broils and eeks over the rim of the bottle. As she roils into my large, bulbous chalice, she melts into an array of deep ambers, garnets, rubies, and brown-black tigers eye. It should come as no surprise that she quickly sports a rising head of large bubbles; fading just as quickly, she cuts a discernable trail of lace on her way down to her final destination. Her haze and head dissipated, she gives free reign to a rich nose that oozes moist prunes, plums, dates, raisins, and licorice root atop warm dark breads drizzled with melted brown sugars and cinnamon. A crisp apply presence cuts through her thick, sweeter side to reveal hand-picked crunchy red apples and pears just in season that leads into a sweet nip of alcohol warmth. Lips wet with anticipation, I dive into her awaiting depths, only to be met with an explosion of bubbly effervescence and vivaciousness that lifts both body and soul. Concentrated sugar sweetness hits first in all her succulent dark fruits glory even as burgeoning warmth makes her presence known. Cinnamon sticks and spice tingle on top of my tongue and compliment her warmth which lingers in my breath. There is a surprising presence of tartness which also nips and plays with my senses while crisp crunchy apples contrast chewy warm dark breads that seem to ooze rum, spices, and molasses. As she warms, her body remains effervescent and pleasantly light which helps La Terrible maintain her refreshing palate. Once more, Unibroue steps up to my plate and hits a home-run on all accounts. Now to just sit back, sup, and savor the last of my La Terrible. No notes allowed.


Oh Unibroue, how I love thee, let me count the ways


Seriously, dont think, dont doubt. Find your nearest liquor store and take home as much Unibroue as you can. They have about 10 year round beers that are available either in large 750ml bottles or 4packs. They have best-buy dates on the back which are usually within a 2-3 year range depending on the beer. Freshness need not apply because we are talking natural, quality ingredients and brewing. Long live Unibroue.
750ml bottle best before 11/11/13. Pours dark brown with a nice head. Aroma is nice with  a cherry, malty scent.  Taste is simalar to aroma. Excellent beer, highly recommended.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 750 ml. bottle. Best before date of 2/26/12. Pours a happy mocha head, over a slightly cloudy, dark brown (SRM 28) body.....nose is heavy with dried fruit, cherry, raisin, prune, also banana, bubblegum drift in along with slight molasses, add a bit of yeasty bread....taste is very similar, with many dried fruit tones, cherry, prune, raisin, fig, somewhat sweet throughout, but finishes fairly dry....mouth feel is thick, but surprisingly light, carbonation is medium. A lovely thing, not too heavy, the alcohol which lightens it is hidden by the thick esthers and light phenols. Re enjoyed 12/1/11. Bottle dated best before 1/30/16. This bottle met all of the previous comments. Balance is superb, aroma and flavor complexity are enormous. This, despite its youth, is a great beer. BJCP 9/3/16/4/8

2004 bottle.  Aroma is woody, fruity, subtle malt, and light cherries.  Flavor is spicy, minty, lightly malty, and very very clean.  This may be the cleanest 5 year old beer I have ever had.  Its so crisp and clean.  Alcohol is very well hidden, really very good.  A sneaker.
Very aromatic with fall-ish fruits...figs, raisins, plums. A bit thinner than expected and the high alcohol content is a little too up front but it is very, very good beer.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2011 very dark and viscous pour.
aroma is roasted malt plus deep dark fruit, figs and raisins and alcohol. similar flavor, fairly sweet with some maltiness and vanilla.
smooth texture, fairly full bodied.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2011 Re-rate after many, many years.... of all the beers Ive found over the years, this one stood out as a re-rate. I barely remembered it the first time, one of the first monster beers Id tried, so it was certainly high on my list should I encounter it again. It appeared in Vancouver, and I obliged to take on the monster bottle. This pours pitch-dark with a huge smooth head. The aroma is of oak and cherries, some yeast and citrus. The flavour is a huge and smooth morass of molasses, yeast, sugary esters and barley. Wet finish. After years and years of rating so many different beers, this remains one of my favourites. Worth every penny to re-connect with an old classic and its great that Unibroue is still making it.

-------& rating 7/1/2009
Probably the best way to get knocked out.... a dark brew, very smooth, but by the time youre halfway through this monster bottle youll have forgotten anything about what the beer was when it started. Not like thats a bad thing, though. 8/5/9/4/16
Another great beer.  Dark brown color with nice head.  Tastes of malt is very nice.  A little thin on the palate compared to the very top belgian strong ales but pretty doggone tasty.

Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle in a chalice.  The beer pours a deep brown with a lively just-off-white head.  Aromas of banana, Belgian character malts, toffee, prunes, and raisons sneak through.  The initial taste is a touch on the grainy side, and the overall palate is a little less full than offerings such as St. Bernardus Abt 12 and Het Ankor Grand Cru of the Emperor.  The middle to end of the palate brings sweet flavors of slightly burnt caramel and some yeast-derived esters.  The yeast seems to be a cross between the fruity Chimay variety and the "darker fruity" and more restrained Westmalle type.  Overall, a great Belgian syle from North Americas Belgian brewery

draft at The Porter.  arrived a dark brown with no head.  wonderful dark fruit and slight Belgian yeast aromas.  some spice up front with big raisin, plum and other dark fruit notes coating the palate.  nice medium body which is quite smooth and well rounded.  good strong finish which doesnt overpower the mouth with alcohol, but leaves a lingering sting with more dark fruit notes through the back.  excellent BSA.

750 ml. bottle from Buffalohead. Black/brown pour, nearly opaque with some ruby highlights, and a rather small light brown head. Aroma is dominated by fruit esters, black current, raisins,dates, etc. - vinous in nature. Medium to full body, light carbonation, some stickiness on the palate, but a satisfying richness. decidedly sweet flavor profile extends into the finish, with just the softest bitter accent that prevents it from being cloying. Alcohol not really apparent, but this is a slow sipper in any case.

I had been eyeballing this beer for a while at the store but just wouldnt pick it up. Tried it for the first time the other night at the malt house and it was a delight! Pours a dark dark brownish black colour with a hint of red coming through once the smoke clears. Big fluffy brown head. Rich and toasty with plenty of spice, dark fruits and chocolate malts. Aroma is toasty with alittle bit of a prune scent. Totally worth it, check this one out!
Black fizzy head. Aroma is yeast and raisins. Carbonation is quite intense and very fizzy. Taste is sweet dark fruits. Body feels thin.
Bottle, Mondial 2009. Black fizzy head. Aroma is yeast and raisins. Carbonation is quite intense and very fizzy. Taste is sweet dark fruits. Body feels thin. Among my top Unibroues (with the 17) !
Bottle. Drank from a trappist glass. Pours dark brown with a creamy beige head. Aroma of dark fruits and spice. Tastes of plum, licorice, and alcohol present. Very easy to drink despite the high abv.

Finaly a non belgian, belgian styled quality ale. Dark brown look with a decent light brown head. Fruity aroma of raisins and nuts with dark sugers and alchohl. Smooth palate, with a nice toffee sweetness again with some nutty notes and full alchohol.

Amazing beer.....Its been a long while since i drank it but its better then i remembered. The beer pours very dark with a thick creamy head. The aroma hits you hard with heavy red wine like characteristics. Despite the strong alc. content it flows down your throat very easily, witch can land you in trouble for example the last time i drank this brew at this local pub i go to "Gully House, a home for drunken fools" i ended up wearing 12 pairs of underwear rainbow toe socks and scaring a bunch of female patrons up stairs when i ran by with darts in my hand, but i digress. This strong ale is truly a great beer and i would recommend it to any one (except Wyan i hate that f**k)
I do like this brewery.  Deep, dark, fruity and flavorful, and a killer ABV... cream colored head lingers slightly, but the full body of this beer is great. Deserves the cork.

Pours dark molasses with a residual creamy tan head. Aromas of spice, a little dark fruit(cherries and raisin), and yeast. The flavor is of raisin, bread, dark fruit, and spice. A little on the carbonated side and the alcohol comes through a little much.

Pours dark brown and bubbly.  Full of flavor and aroma.  Some dark fruit flavor and aroma.  This beer has a very malty flavor that is is well balanced with the fruit flavors and alcohol flavors in the beer.  Slight sugary flavors yet well balanced.  Very nice beer.  I wish I could find this year round.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2011 750ml bottle at our KW group tasting thanks to Jan Primus, thanks Jan! Pours a dark brown with a large white head. Smells awesome, Unibroue yeast, very malty and the fruit esters are great, cherry, mellon, green apples, and some booze, with a somewhat creamy quality to it. Flavour is a perfect reflection of the aroma, with a mild boozy touch that is well in check. So well integrated, the medley of flavours come in delicious waves. Yeasty as one would expect from Unibroue, and theres a minor hint of roasty malts in there. This is definitely the best Unibroue product Ive had so far, so well done. Why the hell cant we get this without going to Buffalo? Or Gatineau?

Draft at Flying Saucer, Raleigh. Dark maroon with a nice white head. Rich nose of molasses, yeast, and wood. Rich prune flavors, some jerky, and pumpernickel bread. Yeah, its a little unusual, but nicely balanced. Not my favorite, but solid and really interesting.

Holy smokes, this is good! Poured deep dark brown, almost black, with ruby and orange highlights when raised to the light. Thick, pebbly, tan head with wonderful lacing and a patchy film that stayed strong throughout. Wonderful Belgian aromas of figs, raisins, plums. Hints of dark malts, bread, and brown sugar suggest something special once I get around to drinking this. And the flavor profile does not disappoint. The dark fruits lay the foundation up front, then a generous helping of hops and a clear earthy yeastiness follow right behind. The finish features a rich, bread-like maltiness that was promised on the nose. Full bodied, lively carbonation, and a clean aftertaste. This is why I prefer beer to wine.

deep brown almost black under a large tan head.  lots of carbonation bubbles.  a pretty typical unibroue aroma with lots of brown sugar and spicy yeast.  flavors of dark fruits, caramel, yeast, brown sugar and plenty of dessert-ish spices.  palate is also very unibroue with TONS of carbonation and a medium-full body. overall...not very unique.  tastes like countless other unique-ibroues ive samples over the years.  time for something new
Dark brown body with a thin tan head.  Aroma is very strong yeast and raisins.  The carbonation is high--big turn off.  The flavor is alcohol and tons of yeast and raisins.  Not my bag.

2004 bottle, aged 5 years, courtesy TheCheeseMan. Pours and extremely dark mahogany color with a violet tint. A small, foamy, khaki colored head settles to a thin blanket, leaving minimal spotting behind. The nose is heavy on raisin, dark fig and caramel lending further sweet malt. Earthen spices include nutmeg and clove, with hints of molasses and candied orange peel lnding nice complexity. Flavors follow suit, big dark raisin and hints of cocoa are accompanied by brown sugar, burnt caramel, and various winter spices. That  signature, bready, ethereal Unibroue yeast is there throughout. The palate is big and full, sweet but never cloying, with a nice, semi-dry finish. Very good brew. You can tell it has benefited from some bottle aging.
2004 vintage, thanks to Cheeseman.  Pours a dark brown.  Aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar and black licorice.  Flavors follow, with a mellow sweetness to balance everything well.

750ml corked bottle.
Near black opaque body, dense thick beige head that hangs around.
Plenty of bready, doughy yeast on the nose. Lots of spice; pepper, clove, vanilla, slight citrus hopiness, subtle dark fruits.
Suprisingly lean bodied for the strength, spritzy carbonation, bit of creaminess about the texture. Ends with an odd sharpness.
Yeast seems to dominate the palate. Lots of spicy phenolics; pepper, unripe plums, prunes, the odd bit of oxidised dried fruit. Finishes mildly bitter, slight roasted astrigency.
Bit disappointing. Quite similiar to other Unibroue beer, Trios Pistoles particularly, but not as well balanced or complex.

Abosuletly loved this beer Poured a ruby/black with a fat two-tone beige/brown head that deminished to a very tiny cap. The nose was nice and complex with black cherry, ripe peach and a malty spiciness. The taste started with black licorice, plums, raisins and toffee surrounding a huge malty caramel flavor. The finish was slightly bitter in the back of the throut. A nice warming ale with a very complex flavor profile. Very nice

dark brown with a thin but lasting head. smells of dark berries and malt. taste is of rich dark fruit, dark sugars, and some spice. finish is clean and warming due to the alcohol content. very interesting and another great beer from Unibroue!

Dark body with a nice light brown head. Aroma of raisins, yeast, sweetbread, plums. Very nice nose! Flavor of yeast, cinnamon, bread. Very enjoyable brew. Hides alcohol well. Syrupy mouthfeel. Id go out right now to buy another, but Im too drunk.

A dark pour with a roasted hops aroma.  The taste was wickedly smooth and really a continuation of the roasted hop smell.  The finish was full-bodied and only improved as the beer warmed in the glass.  This is a wonderfully complex beer by one of the Canadian breweries that really knows what they are doing.  Awesome.  Cheers.

Sample at the Unibroue tasting at Blacklick Wine and Spirits on 4.10.09.  Dark brown color with a big tan head.  Yeasty and malty aroma with plenty of sugary sweetness.  Grain and sweet malt flavor.  Not a whole lot of yeast, so tastes more like a barley wine.

In 2009, it is impossible (I think) to find that beer in Québec, even though it is brewed here, in Chambly!  Since I usually like Unibroues products, I asked my brother that lives in the US to by me two bottles.  8,99$ for 750 ml.  Best before 11-11-2013.  Pretty low carbonation (I even thought it was flat at first), darker than most stouts, not much foam but constant thick lacing.  Sweet and spicy aroma (smells like a headache...).  Very sweet taste, with strong notes of licorice sourness and various spices, moderate bitterness, some astringency, also fruiy, all in all very complex and easily drinkable although it is a very heavy, very sweet beer.  Worth trying if you can get ahold of it.  I will let my other bottle age...  And ask my brother some more...  And share the next one Ill have... Héhéhé!
Notes of prunes, raisins, cherries, coffee. Slightly alcoholic taste.  Pretty good if youre in the mood for this kind of ale.
Bottle. Pours dark brown. Aroma contains notes of coffee, dark fruits, belgian yeast. Flavor is dark fruits, sweet yeast, and a little alcohol bite.

750mL bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar (Escondido, CA).  Pours a very dark and almost opaque brown, bordering on black.  Probably the darkest Belgian-style beer I have seen.  Two fingers of light brown head which doesnt stick around for long.  Aroma of malts, dark fruit, and chocolate.  More of the same in the flavor with the dark fruit and chocolate toward the finish.  The noticeable chocolate is interesting in a Belgian.  Less yeast than most Unibroue brews.  A little booze but generally the 10.5% is well hidden.  Rating #22.
UPDATED: JUN 15, 2009 Wow.  this beer was awesome.  This is a very pleasant alternative to coffee.  pours dark brown.  dark fruits.  caramel, some alcohol.  very smooth.
This is a nice and smooth Belgian with a good flavor. The taste consist on a mixture of grapes and tangerines, with just a slight hint of a milk chocolate.
Nice beer that compares favorably to many Belgian Quads. Fruity and well-balanced. Alcohol is hidden well.

Pours a dark dark brown with a thin tan cover.  Some apparent alcohol, a plum fruitiness.  Taste is a heavy dark malt sweetness, with berries over top, and less abrasive alcohol.  Nice warming sensation.

I had tried others from Unibroue, and I knew what to expect from this one. Deep brown/purple color, fruity aroma, mostly berries and dark toasted sugar, and impressive in palate. Its almost a licquor. Its a completely different experience than your average beer.

Bottle. The aroma is light fruity, a little bit of yeast, also light sweet and creamy, overall rather mild. The brown creamy head is medium large, she stays long. The body is black. The taste is light bitter, very soft alcoholic, reminds me a little bit of wine, A creamy body which gets silky in the finish. Not much carbonation, the body is light to medium. A nice soft beer.

750ml bottle from Willow Bend Liquors in Lutz, FL. Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a small beige head. Aroma is alot of caramel, some cocoa, some plum, and a good amount of alcohol. Flavor is cocoa, plum, caramel, and a good amount of alcohol. Good flavor, but too much alcohol for my liking. Medium, sticky mouthfeel. But a nice alcohol burn. This is good...but again, a bit too much alcohol for me.

750ml Bottle shared with Pyrozoid and French Tickler.  Dark brown reddish apperancewith minimal brown creamy head.  Aroma:brown sugar, caramel, dark malts, apples, meringue, lactose, alcohol and toffe.  Flavor: alcohol, cloves, banana, light peppery taste, caramel anf light taste of apples.  Palate: full body, well balance carbonation with a peppery alcohol finish.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Dégusté avec french tickler et Agaguk. Bière de couleur brune très foncé avec un moyen collet collant. Odeur très très semblable à la trois pistole, prunes, sucre, alcool, oranges, citron et un peu poivré. Saveur de cerises, sucre alcool, fruits en général,

Very dark pour with big tan head. Yeasty, oaky aroma. Flavor is a bit vinous, sour cherries, plums, yeast, bread, lots of pleasant frutiness. Nice, typical unibroue bubble mouthfeel. Been looking for it ever since the dude said it wasnt "terrible", and I am impressed.

This is a good, solid beer.  Its scent is somewhat sweet, and has an oaky sort of personality to it.  The first drink is a bit sweet, and just about as thick and creamy, almost bready, as I typically like in a heavier dark beer.  Overall, its a pleasant beer to drink--but please share its hugeness with a couple other people.  750 mL in one go was a bit much for me, as I didnt have a good way to re-seal the bottle, and wasnt drinking with friends at the time.  Theres much to be said for planning.

Black amber with thick, rich foamed top. Vein of sweet malt taps the nose, hints of wood, touch of sourness, and sweet yeastiness round out the bouquet. Pleasant medley of medium, sweet, and toasted malts, moderate yeastiness, caramel, and swell breadiness endow this brew with a rich, easy-going complexity that belies its potency.

Absolute beauty of a beer; deep chestnut in color with a true meringue head with stiff peaks and valleys.  Milky clumps of suds cling tightly to the inside of the glass.  Aroma is fairly subtle, with not a lot in the nose but sweet malt and Belgian yeast.  Flavor also isnt aggressive but the alcohol is invisible.  Roasted malt, caramel, and toffee...not Terrible but not terrific either.
Roasted malt smell. Black and thick. Nice head. Highly drinkable with a malty finish. Very smooth. The malty flavor stays for a bit, its nice.
bottle, opaque but visible brown color, excellent tan foam, has the consistency of a coke float, aroma is the same spicy vanillas, flavor is vanilla, coca cola, cashew butter and lots of carbonation

Poured fifth.  Beautiful deep, dark ass brown with nice brown head(slowly vanisehes).  Very nice fruity aroma, sugar plummy.  Full bodied.  Malty flavor, raisin notes.  Drawn out alcohol finishes vanilla-y.  Not too bad at all....
Bomber at Lees.  Very dark brown.  Dark fruits in the aroma, along with the bitter chocolate smell.  Alcohol is definitely present.  Really liked this one.

Bottle. Pours a cola-like color, with a tan head. fizzy. Aroma is very sweet - grapes, and chocolate, but the taste is kind of bitter. black licorice and alcohol. Dark malts. medium body, thin feel, not much on the palate. Not a bad beer. I bought it just cause it was called "terrible", its anything but.

Dark Brown in color. Sweet and extremely rich of flavor. Other than the richness, I was looking for something else to stand out in flavor. It was very smooth but just seemed to be lacking in complexity. Very good but not great.
scura schiuma media disreta persistenza niote tostatew liquorose futta secca in bocca lieve etilico discte tostaure frutta secca pouittosto bilancioata
Dark brown body, with a light brown head, sweet aroma and flavor, but not overpoweringly so.  A little on the anise flavor, very well-balanced, and a warm  companion on a cold day.
Bottle with da boys. Vintage 2004. Pours a clearish dark brown. Quite sweet with mellow caramel aromas. Aromas of dried fruits. Quite sugary. High carbonation. Medium to full bodied.

Bottle with Butters and sixfootsix.  Pours a tan head with a very dark brown body.  Smells of anise, clove, yeast, and some chocolate.  Tastes of yeast, lightly roasted, chocolate, apple, and a hint of tin.  Doesnt sound good but it was delicious.
bottle split with butters and barrios. Very dark pour near black has a anise nose and taste but very balanced. didnt want this beer to end.

Bottle split with Barrios courtesy of sixfootsix.  Pours a magnificent near black with large sustainable off-white head.  Nose is a near perfect blend of black licorice and alcohol.  Anise, raisin, dark malts, cordials,  and tons of alcohol.  This bottle definitely had mellowed some, but there is still a lot of heat.  Awesome name for an awesome beer.

Very dark opaque brown pour with a thick off-white head. Aromas of Belgian yeast and dark fruit. Flavor is dark fruit (figs, perhaps) with some black licorice and a liberal dose of alcohol. Fruity, sharply bittersweet. Very good.

bottle BB 2-26-2012

yellowy tinted dark woody brown with a huge fluffy beige head. it leaves behind an enormous amount of spotty lacing... almost unreal!

very fruity aroma though i cant attempt to single one particular smell out... vanilla, chocolate, cinnamon, rich earthy yeast and its bitterness and something like a nicely oxidized white burgundy.

theres more fruit in the flavor along with hints of vanilla, raisins, chocolate cream,  flowers, brown sugar-y malt, yeast and light warm spice on the finish. the body is medium. relatively thin mouth feel given the abv% and the amount of flavor packed in but its quite smooth.

no sign of the of the alcohol! incredibly easy to finish the bottle!
8/4.5/8/3.5/17/4.1

Sweetness.  Huge thanks to Keith, kp, for bringing this.  Another beer Ive been wanting to try, but I have been to cheap and had too many other beers Ive been trying to taste first.  Black tan med/small bubble head.  Sweetish.  A hint of caramel.  Some malty hints in the aroma.  Pretty nice.  I wish I had some cheese to eat with this.

Dégusté le 25 septembre 2006 avec frenc tickler. Bière dun brun foncé avec une mousse qui a disparu peu de temps après le service. Aromes de noisette, malts, mélasses,toffee, vanille française. Mûres, cerise et le sucre brun place cette petite beauté sur une ascension de saveurs fantastiques. Bouteille de 2005 qui pourrais vieillir un autre 10 ans...
pours with a vibrant head but after pouring, a dark prune head. The aroma is of dark fruit spices with a blended dark cherry and traditional spices.
Sampled at St Pete Creative Loafing Beerfest.  Definitely in the Belgian Strong Ale style.  Lots of pitted fruits and slightly spicy.

bomber from grape and gourmet, poured into a snifter. pours a very dark ruby color with a bright white head and great lacing. aroma was excellent. very bright with cherries, plums, raisons, and some sweetness. i can best describe the flavor as gourmet cherry cola. hints of chocolate, brown sugar, and a slight hint of alcohol come through as well. very lively mouthfeel with good carbonation. an excellent and unique beer.
Pours very dark. Nice head. Very good dark beer with lots of flavor. Nice aroma especially for a dark brew. Recommended beer.

A very complex and imaginitive brew. Has a nice variety of dark, sweet flavors including dark fruits (like plum), and molasses, as well as an authentic Belgian bread taste. I might add that it also looks amazing and very inviting as you catch you first glimpse of it out of the bottle. Overall, excellent.

750 ml bottle split in Duvel glass.  Dark reddish brown with lasting head and lace.  Pungent fruit, port wine, caramel and wood aroma.  Brown sugar, dark fruit, raisins, prunes, wood, earth, hint of smoke and lingering sweetness.  Medium-full body and medium carbo.  Nice mouthfeel.  Wow.  Extremely complex and delicious.  I prefer golden straw-colored peppery Belgian styles but this is really really tasty.  Cheers!

Bottle@home - 2007 vintage

Apperance: Massibe black with a decent head and some residual lacing.

Aroma: Belgian yeast, Dark fruit, Port wine, Spices.

Flavor: Molasses, Ripe fruit, Hint of alcohol, Dark caramel, Spices, Yeast. Very unibroueish in character.

Palate: Plenty of carbonation. Initialt hit of spices and some bitterness and a nice end dose of sweetness (caramel/toffee) at the end. Great!

Another good beer from one of my favourite canadian brewers. This beer was great fresh but even better with some age on it. Recommended!

I have been wanting to try this for a long time.  Very dark brown pour. Very fluffy tan head with some lacing.  Aroma is really a molasses bomb with some good malts, fruit and a barely perceptible hint of hops.  Flavor is creamy and has that signature yeasty Unibroue flavor.  Hops aren’t really noticeable, but some great fruity malts and chocolate with molasses are.  NIce stuff!

Dark brown/red. Pretty high carbonation on a tan head.  Nose of molasses and raisons.  Some special B malt and crystal presence, also some dark candi sugar.  Some hop  bitterness present, and a dry finish.  The  yeast provides some esters, not overbearing.  Some definite alcoholic warmth at the end.  A flavorful brew, but I am not sure all the flavors mesh perfectly.  This maybe could have been aged more, a little fresh.  Probably a mistake to drink this so early  Unibroue makes high quality Belgian-style beer and although I havent tasted many side-by-side, they seem to make a lot of similar styles; a ton of Belgian dark strong ales.  Not that they are bad, but maybe they could have some more variety
