Pours a purple-black (a lot like Trois Pistoles).  Aroma is dark fruit, port, sherry, cherry, plum, depth, and spice.  Flavor is similar with hints of earth, some hops, and a slightly awkward bitterness in finish.

Bottle shared.  Poured dark brown/amber with a small tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, yeast, malt.  Flavor is very nice, lots of fruit, yeast, oak, somewhat vinous.  Mouth is pretty carbonated.  Finish is smooth and malty.  Another solid brew from Unibroue.

750ml Bottle: Aroma is sweet and vinous.  Smells of dark ripe fruits, raisins, grapes, slight tobacco, yeast, and an unidentified spice.  Poured dark brown with a hint of red in color and a small, fizzy, brown head that disappeared quickly but was reconstituted as a small film by the carbonation.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of dark ripe fruits, raisins, grapes, yeast, tar, tobacco, Madeira, and wood.  Medium to full body.  Thick, tingly, coating texture.  Lively carbonation.  Woody, tar and resin, lightly dry finish.  Much more drinkable than many of the Unibroue brews I have had.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 Bottled 75cl. It pours a very dark beer with an average beige head. The nose has all the typical Unibroue characteristics. Yeasty. A bit metallic. Vitamin tablets, berries, mince pies and oak showing up. The taste is a bit dissapointing. Slightly sour with hints of le parfait. Very fruity with vitamin tablets, cherries, wood, nutmeg and pumpernickel appearing. Full bodied. Some lacework. The alcohol is quite present. Some coffee, fruits and fish?! in the finish. Not all that good. Additional comment: A lot of cork in the nose. Strange yeasty finish. Overly sweet. A lot of crystal sugar added to this beer probably. Definetely dissapointing. My rating stays at 3.1

750 ml bottle shared at a beer tasting / monopoly game with my girlfriend and close friends. Poured a nice dark brown murky hazed hue with a nice light brown/tannish head that sticks around, in a decent amount. Aromas are chocolate and dark fruits, more somber belgian yeastiness. Taste is similar up front, mixing chocolate and sweetness into darker, dried fruits. My friend caught hints of coffee, but I did not. Raisins and plums mixed with the subtle cocoa. Yum. A nice bit of a bitter finish that has died a bit with aging. Still, a very yummy brew.

750 mL bottle. Pours a cloudy, deep ruby with a generous, dark tan head. Lively carbonation. Nose is strong on the alcohol and yeast with additions of raisins, black cherries, and raspberry. Taste is a cataclysm of different flavors:  dark fruits, Belgian candies, sweet malt, yeast, spices. Finish is quick, dry, and hoppy. Another top notch Unibroue creation.
[Bottle] Pours a deep hazy gold with a large tan head of large bubbles. Aroma is alcohol and raisins with some candi sugar sweetness as well. Flavor matches. Sharp, well carbonated palate.

Courtesy of Tony at OTH.
Pours black with brownish head.
Aroma light dark fruits (cherry).
Taste, medium carbonation with light hops.
Some roastiness and dark fruits (cherry), malty with plenty of Belgian candi sugar.

2003:
Slight fruit aroma. All berries and sugar sweetness. Strawberries, raspberries, elder, cherry, blue, black, and some apple. 
Pours a dark cola brown, patchy head. 
Candy fruit flavor, actually more like a liquor fruit flavor. Fruit preserve:strawberry jam. Palate is sharp with fruit and caramel.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2009 Pours a dark, dark brown with a tan head.  NOT what I expected from Unibroue!!  Aroma of wine, earth, plum and grapes.  Flavor is a jumble of varied things, which include but are not limited to chocolate, cherry, dates, and malt.  All of this complemented by the trademark Unibroue prickly carbonation.  La Terrible finishes spicy with cinnamon, and with more than a tickle of alcohol to let you know it isnt screwing around.  re-rated 12/6/09:  I seemed to have missed the very forward spiced element of this brew!  At a private tasting, I got pronounced dark candi sugar, allpsice, and cardomum.  Always a bold blend, this beer is good but short of great, with flavors just missing a sublime harmony.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Thanks!
Pours a muddy dark brown with a light beige head.  Smell is yeasty, almost cherry and gummy like, with raisins.  Taste is creamy dark malt with raisins, dark fruity, belgian yeast, spices and bananas.  Medium body and light carbonation.  Almost a touch skunk in the flavor, somehow.  Not bad, but not a favorite of mine.

Bottle. Pours deep ruby with a beige head. The aroma is fruity, like sweet apples, anso spices and yeast. The flavor is also sweet, but more along the lines of plums. Also spices, yeast and a bit bready. The finish is a bit dry. Very good.
Every beer from this brewer is top notch. This one is no different. Beautiful dark ruby red. Nice head persists. Very complex flavor with a lot going on. Very nice after taste. Bring me more.

Shining mahogany body with a white ring around the rim of the glass. Moderate aroma of orange shells. Rich and exciting flavours of grapes, sweet berries, prunes and brown sugar ending up with a suitable bitter touch, added a little alcohol tingle. Soft carbonation. Worth repeating in larges quantum than the 100ml taster I had on EBF (Copenhagen, 14.09.2008).

Pours a deep deep red.  Basically black.  Aroma disappoints.  Really not a very strong nose.  Smells of chocolate, deep molasses.  Head starts alright, quickly receds into a ring.  Flavor is rich.  Lots of different things going on.  Mouthfeel is like wine, very present and lasting.  Quick burst of warming alcohol.  Great brew, needs more smell though.

Had this as part of a Unibroue tasting dinner.  Poured a deep black/brown color with a thick, robust head.  Roasted, fruit, and chocolate tones.  Reminds me of the Chambly Noire, but with more body and a more complex palate.

Dark brown in colour with spritzy carbonation. Aromas of figs, caramel, prunes, and a bit of booze. Loads of complexity on the palate, with elements of stewed fruit, more caramel, chocolate, berries, licorice, red berries, citrus peel, and allspice. It’s medium weight body makes it surprisingly drinkable. Well done.

Pours Black with nice tan head.  Aroma is  not too strong but there’s some slight ripe fruit.  Flavor is not as complex as I had hoped - basically just roasted malt and dark fruit.  Has the trademark Unibroue high levels of alcohol and carbonation, which I like, and helps the overall effect.  High drinkability and nice dry finish.

Brown to black pour with a thick creamy brown head.  Yeasty dark fruit aroma.  Sweet taste on a moderate body, maybe a thinner one than I had expected.  Dark fruits from prunes to figs in the taste with a lot of malt.  Good, but not great.  Lacks finesse. A long cloying fruit and malt finish.  Perhaps aging would help this.

Deep mahogany hue with a large beige head and little lacing.  Arresting array of aromas, from the trademark Unibroue yeastiness, to the dark, malty fruits, to the dessert wine qualities.  More dark fruit greets the taste buds, along with toffee, soy sauce, seasonal spices, chocolate - all adding to the complexity.  Surprizingly, not too thick on the palate, with lively carbonation.  Full bodied mouthfeel; warms the gut before the buzz sets in.  Long lasting, enduring finish.
Dark brown pour with thick brown head. Moderately carbonated with a spicy aroma. Flavor is slightly alcoholic with notable hints of orange zest, fig, yeast and nutmeg.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2008 Pour is very dark, almost black with a frothy, aromatic head of fruits, oak and spices. Flavor was very overwhelming. A heavy mass of malt, spiced plums and fruits. Had the smoothness of coffee on the finish which was nice. A little too tangy and "biting" on the palate but otherwise an excellent effort from Unibroue.
Smells like a damp forest and drinks like a barrel of cement.  I respect this beer, but it took me down.  Truly fearsome.

Light creamy head tinge of brown ,good carbonation,darkest ale aroma fruit spice herb,malt orange peel,clove lemon.Flavour fig,hoppy malt,orange peel,yeasty smooth almost creamy,nutmeg.Head has remained nice and creamy,says a lot for the drink.Eyes light up when I see this brewers items,they are always pretty good.10%alcohol well hidden,finish bright flavours dry.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2011 750mL bottle. The beer pours a dark brown almost black, like coca cola. Some dark head, lots of carbonation - a staple attribute of any unibroue brew. The aroma is some fruit, towards the end I can begin to sniff some strong alcohol. However, this alcohol is completely absent from the taste - which is uber as f**k.
This is an amazing beer. Thanks to bman1113vr for buying me a bottle!

750 ml bottle from premier gourmet. pours dark brown with a mis tan head. aromas of dark fruit, chocolate, unibroue yeast. flavours are sweet malts with dark fruit up front and a sweet berry finish. the unibroue yeast is also very noticable in the palate. very easy drinking and enjoyable. i wish this was one of the locally avalible unibroue products.

Pours an opaque black with only a hint of dark brown on the edges. The coca-cola head was long lasting and quite a bit of lacing.

 The aromas are strongly Belgian, sweet and warm with alcohol.

 Sweet at first with a nice touch of carbonation. Strong grape undertones, almost if you reduced a cup of grape juice down by half. The alcohol was surprisingly not over powering at all. Yeasty at the end with a nice warmth.

 Very balanced. Excellently crafted.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2013 750 from Whole Foods, Durham. Deep dark pour, almost black with some gleaming brown in there. Big ass head. Yeah, its a Unibroue beer. This ones slightly distinct from some of the other offerings, insofar as theres a more pronounced fruity presence in both the nose and in the taste itself. Sweet malts are in there, with enough hops to keep things crisp and lively. But its the fruits that dominate, and it ends up being just a tad below some of the other solid offerings from these folks.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2010 Bottle Ive had in my cellar waiting for some time. Bought at the Utah state store. Pours a dark brown, almost black hue with a medium off-white head. The aroma is wonderful; tons of rich fruits, yeast, sweet candies and alcohol. The taste was similar; dark fruit; plum and grapes, a ton of yeast, and a sweet candy aspect that is nice and not overpowering. Strong, but not in any way too much. Awesome. Re-rate: had a 2003 edition in 2010. The seven years have mellowed this beer considerably, reduced the fruitiness and added a musty nutty, malt. Very nice and interesting.

Bottle. Very dark ruby with little beige head. Not a lot of aroma - maybe tangy, possibly meaty. Medium body and carbonation. Intense and rich flavour, obviously of a Belgian strong ale style, but was not interesting or complex enough. Caramel and apples in the foretaste with abitter finish. It’s a good beer, but I was disappointed. It lacks finesse.

Unibroue La Terrible is an opaque, almost black ale.  It seems to be an obscure berry hue.  The head is the color of burlap, thick and foamy with oily bubbles.  It exhibits excellent retention and lacing.  The aroma has notes of molasses, plum, raisin, peach and chocolate.  It has a smooth medium body that seems a little syrupy.  It has a vinous flavor, with notes of prunes, chocolate, raisins and other dried fruit.  It is smooth and a bit sweet.  The alcohol is well hidden.  This is a complex one.  The aftertaste is of leather and coffee.  This is one of my favorites; I’m glad I finally got around to reviewing it.

Dark brown/black in color with a small, off white head with decent lacing.  The aroma is of oats and apples with a hint of white wine.  The flavor is of apples and spices- tastes like a hefferwizen!  The palate is syrupy.  Overall i’d say its a unique beer with a unique taste which I didn’t expect from a beer so dark.  A good beer, but not my style.

Bottle.  Color of molasses with a light tan head and almost zero lacing.  Aroma has a lot of dark fruit and caramel malt but I can still sense the alcohol.  Flavor is mostly sweet, alcohol and the dark fruit.  Very drinkable with less carbonation than most of the others by Unibroue.  Impressive

Wow, this is very dark, and very bold.  I’m also getting dark fruit, and the alcohol is very well hidden.  Except that it’s getting me drunk.  Right now, the crew is in Amsterdam going crazy, so I drink to them.

Pours an almost opaque black with an off white head that settles down to a thin, but creamy layer. Somewhat fruity (as in raisin/plum/fig) scent and taste, with a touch of bitterness, but overall very drinkable. A hint of the 10.5%, but not overwhelming. Medium mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Like a good double/abt. I hope that I can find this again.

Wow...  pours a dark brown with hints of red... thick tan head.  Aroma is similar to other Unibroue beers... yeasty, with the dark fruits you would expect.  the flavor is so much better in this one than others from the brewery though.  The strong alcohol and the sweetness keep fighting with each other...  dark fruit flavors, raisins, dates, quite a bit of malt as well.  The finish is dry with a tingle of alcohol.  I’m a fan of this one.

Bottle pours a dark brown nearly black with a tall tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, dried dark fuits, and chocolate. Taste starts with sweet roasted malts followed by the bitter coffee and dried dark fuits like prunes, dates, figs. Still a somewhat thin palate for all the things going on here.

This is a big ol’ bevy.  It’s aroma is complex with a bit of dark fruit, dark malts, and some aromatic caffienes.  The appearance is a very dark flat black-brown, with a light tan, full head.  It’s flavor is complex, with a bit of dark fruit, notably sultanas, figs, and perhaps some spices, coriander.  It’s mats shine through, but there is also some oaky wooden flavors as well.  It’s alcohol burn is balanced, and it effects you nicely.  It’s very well balanced for such a big brew.  Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 Pours very dark brown with some lighter brown highlights. Substantial tan coloured head persists and laces very well. Aromas are typical of the unibroue range, sweet malt, hinting at carmel flavours, overipe banana and some darker fruits hiding in the background. Palate is rich with more banana coming through supported by dark fruit and spice. Again, trademark unibroue characters are evident. Finish is malty and rich.

Taste 8/8 Bottle. Black with a nice head. Lots of activity inside. Aroma: Banana, sweet dark fruit,sour yeast, a little roast and caramel. Taste: Very smooth and even. Finishes as it starts. Creamy, fruity, spice, good body. Nice foam and great hops spice at the tail end. By far, best "Unibrow" I’ve had.

pours black with a red tint, very large foamy tan head, good lacing.
smell is of dark fruits, alcohol is dominate, touch of cocoa, roasted nuts, some toffee, spice.
taste is strong, pepper, spice, ;sour malt, dark pitted fruits, touch of dark chocolate, ends slightly bitter and dry.

Dark brown pour, fizzy tan head.  Aromatic tones of alcohol, Prunes, Black cherries, toffee, sweet malts, and a bit yeasty.  Mouth feel is vinous.  Sweet black cherry fruits and sugary malts. alcohol is noticeable but not overpowering, especially for 10.5.  A dark resonant strong ale that would probably be excellent with food.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 Pours dark brown with a small 1/4" white head. Smells like sweet Belgian yeast and banana. Flavor is strong and sugary and yeasty. A bit of alcohol in the flavor too. Palate is full bodied and mild. Finish is lightly bitter, full, and has some hickory undertones.

2004, original batch.
WOW, WHAT A FREAKING TREAT.
Consumed 7/31/2008
Aroma is black cherry, oxidation/sherry, sweet malt, and Unibroue yeast.
Murky brown mahogany color.
Taste is musty and old with a lot of dust, cherry.  Taste is alcoholic, cherry.
A lot of alcohol, dust and slightly tart cherry.
Finishes tart and slightly alcoholic.
I like it, but it has probably just past its prime.
Black-brown color with fairly thick white head. Bready and yeast aroma. Hefeweizen type flavor with coriander and honey. Unfortunately for me this high yeastiness is not my cup of tea.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet with caramel, lemon, bubblegum, spices, toffee, and spices.  Flavor is sweet at first with toffee, caramel, dark fruits, bubblegum, spices, and lemon.  Finishes with a hint of chocolate with a lingering flavor.  There is a slight warming but it really isn’t that strong considering how hich the alcohol content is.

This beer pours very dark with a dark head that left the glass quickly.  It smelled very sweet and tasted much the same.  This beer is very unique in that it is very strong and doesn’t taste it at all.  Not only does it not taste 10.5%, it doesn’t taste above 4.5% I would say.  I have had other beers from this brewery and I hvae to say that I am most impressed by this one.  Great job guys
Definitely qualifies as one of my favorite beers.  Oh, this one is beautiful.  Pours black like the Saint of Killers’ soul, and just keeps getting better as you go along.  Absolutely fantastic.

Poured from a large sized bottle into a trappist glass.  The beer had a cloudy, dark brown to almost black color with a very dark tan, creamy head, that had modest retention and size, and clung to the edges of the glass.  The aroma was subtle but very pleasant, featuring some toffee and raisin tones, with perhaps some other fruits such as bananas, and a bit of caramel malt.  The taste is a sweet dense fruity and candy blend with a pleasant bitterness on the side.  Its mouthfeel was superb, a creamy, velvety texture with amazing smoothness and only a hint of the heavy alcohol content appearing.  The body was wet and full, with slightly below average levels of carbonation and fizz.  A truly quality beer, and although a little bit expensive, still a good value for the size and character.

Bottle at Århus Ølfestival 2008. Pours a dark brown with a small head. Aroma of roasted malt and raisins and other fruits and vinious. The flavour is nicely balanced roasted malt, raisins and other fruts and vinious.

The bottle poured coffee color with sort of ashy tan head, maintains a nice sheet on top. The aroma is heavily spiced and sweet; cardamom, ginger, candied cherries, alcohol. The flavor is similar; peppery burn on the tongue with that sweet, honey-like Belgian flavor. The palate softens as it warms. This is a big brew with balanced flavors, especially considering the content. A beautiful offering.
Bottle.  belgian ale with strong yeast flavor and light malt taste.  Carbonation is quickly noticed with hints of plums.  Very nice - very potent.  Good beer

Pours a dark brown color with an off-white head but left no lacing. Smell is full of dark fruits, caramel, etc. Definitely on the sweet side, but nice. Taste has qualities reminiscent of red wine; it’s also quite yeasty and has some different dark sugar flavors. Mouthfeel, the carbonation jumped on the tongue right away, seemed a little high paired with a medium body. A good beer definately worth trying, perhaps twice, but I wouldn’t throw a fit over not finding any.

Deep brown pour with a big foamy tan head that lasts throughout.  Big ripe dark fruit aroma, with hints of malt and alcohol.  Nice sweet fruit flavor with caramel and chocolate malts and yeast.  A bit heavy on the palate.  Nice warming alcohol on the finish.  Damn good brew.

potent aroma of belgian yeast and alcohol with a small hint of licorice (when cold). as the beer warms there are notes of raisins and plums. black bodied with faint tones of deep browns. the alcohol presence slightly numbs my tongue as the flavors announce themselves. these flavors include sweet malt, raisins, candi sugar and of course, some alcohol. smooth and pleasing.

Sampled during Cellars Wine & Spirits Wednesday evening tasting via Unibroue representative. Pours a near opaque dark brown brew with an average sized beige head that quickly dissipates to a thin ring. Aroma of dark fruits, a touch of red berries, chocolate and some caramel. Taste is medium to full bodied, some alcohol warmth with flavors of roasted caramel and chocolate malts, some light tart cherries, and sweet dates. Finish is semi-sweet with a mild yeast and roasted dark malt aftertaste.
Dark brown pour with a finger thick light tan head.  Aroma of unbuttered popcorn and a hint of sourness.  Sharp bitterness at the roof of the mouth.
Bottle at ÅBF08. Weak vinous aroma. Clear dark brown colour, very small light brown head. Yeasty aroma and flavour.

The beer pours a black brown with a nice off white almost grey head that dissipates quickly, there is no lacing. The nose is a sweet sourness mixed with light acidy, dark fruits and yeast. The mouth feel is highly carbonated and slightly sharp. The finish is clean and short. Overall a nice sour that would be good before a meal.

750ml, cork and cage.  Dark brown pour with red around the edges, fluffy off white head.  Round, belgian, very dubbel-esque aroma.  Balanced and sweet smelling, toasty with prunes.  Flavor is similar, heavy on the prunes and plums.  Vinous and silky finish.  Lightly bitter.  Dry finish.  Nicely done.

75cl bottle from Beer World (Largo, FL). Bottled in 2004. Pours a dark brown color with a thick tan head that dissipates quickly. Some lacing of the glass. Still very carbonated for its age. Aroma is intoxicating -- sweet ripe fruit, caramel, hints of chocolate, prunes and plums. Taste is very fruity and similar to the aroma with notes of malt and a faint sourness on finish. Medium-bodied ale. Alcohol tends to come through more as the beer warms. Aged very well.
750ml a gift from a friend from a few months ago.  Pours dark brown with a big 2 finger head.  Nose is sweet.  Taste is sweet with a bit of apples in the taste.
Pours thick and black. Good carbonation and nice head. Smells like a pile of over ripe fruit. The flavor is deep and rich somewhat malty and yeasty. Nice!

(Sample from June 15, 2007 Beer Club Meeting) Dark brown color.  Carbonated and bubbly.  Nose of fruit, malt, molasses I think.  Flavor of  chocolate, banana, spices something deep and dark very tasty, and the alcohol is well hidden.  Heavy on the mouth.  Great job on this!
Red brown beer with a small off-white head. Aroma has dark dried fruits like dates, lots of malt and Belgian yeast. Dry bready malt flavour with yeast and sherry notes.
Sample at Aarhus beerfestival. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are malt, hops and fruits. Bittersweet finish.

Pours a dark cola brown with a fizzy head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is strong ripe fruits (bananas and cherries), molasses and chocolate with just a hint of yeast and spices. Tastes drier and yeastier than the aroma lets on, with a bit of alcohol burn. Notes of port wine, cola (!) and chocolate accompany the fruits from the aroma. The mouthfeel is a bit harsh - this would be fantastic if it had a little less carbonation and the alcohol was a little more well-hidden. Very good overall, though, and probably the best Ive had from Unibroue.

Hello.  Surprising dark brown / black pour but easier on the palate than expected.  Kind of a punchy malt taste to it, which was different, but in a good way.  Random buy that will probably happen again.  I enjoyed it quite a bit for something different.

Bottle, pours a dark brown, with a nice head, lots of dark fruit, with a bit chocolate and banana, clove, and bisquits. Alcohol is not overwhelming  considering its above 10%. I enjoyed it quite a bit.

Pour is dark golden/brown with a very thick brown head.  Very carbonated.  Aroma is of dark fruit, molasses, malt, and spices.  Flavor is medium to full bodied with same taste as aroma.  Very good brew.  Would buy again.

750 mL bottle, pours a deep red-brown body with light brown, very bubbly head.  Aroma of dark fruits - mainly plum and raisin, along with carmel and malts.  Flavor is similar to the aroma with notes of banana, spice, and bread.  Slight alcohol burn to the finish.  Medium to heavy body with an oily, cloying mouthfeel.

Bottle in NO w/ Pete.  Random find!  Flavor is super sweet, yeasty, with some dark fruits intertwined w/in the sweetness.  Robust, full bodied, but a sugar plum bomb.  Not quite a mess, but this is nowhere near delicate, nor complex - and a tough one to drink.
Bottle. Low white head. Hazy very dark body. Caramel coffee aroma with vineous notes. Mild caramel sweet vineous flavor. Long aftertaste and low carbonation.

Pours dark unclear brown with a creamy white head. Lots of dark fruits, yeast, bread & sweet dark dried fruits. Oily, soft & filling palate. Long end. Great!
Bottle: Pours a hazy brown with an off white head. Aroma, dark fruits, plums, spices, yeast, sugars. Flavor, yeasty, bready, dark fruits, molasses, spices. Pretty solid.

Aroma has fruity notes.  Would almost be as bold as to say grapefruit.  Pours dark brown with beige head.  Nice head retention.  Flavor has some banana notes with some good spice.  Carbonation is medium.  Good time sampling this beer.  First Unibroue and looking forward to more.

Aroma is dark fruit, spice, yeast, and malt.  Deep mahogany hue with a large off-white head that left great lace and was mostly lasting.  Aroma of vino, yeast, fruits, and must.  Lively carbonation, medium bodied, and a little lingering.  A good one thats well above average.

bottle thanks to ericandersnavy, pours a dark brown w/beige head, aroma with alot of dark fruity notes...flavor is sweet malt, dark fruit, slight hints of bannana and clove with nice balanced alcohol spice...palate med. mouth feel, med. carbonation...good stuff.
Bottle: Dark brown w/ a light brown head. Smells like cereal w/ some yeast. Also a slight hint of clove. Flavor slaps me in the face w/ clove & a little grainy thing...blah,blah,blah...

Pours black with a thick tan looking head. Smells of alcohol and very malty with a hint of fruit and spice. Has a smooth fruity taste to start and then a real alcohol kick. Has an oily and fizzy finish.Unibroue scores again.

750 ml bottle...smoke billows from the pop cap and it seems like a never ending pour...dark brown body--pungent tan head...smells yeasty and wheaty...quite earth fulfilled and wholesome like all bran cereal--all twiggy like...mild cloves also....many layers that change so quickly its hard to extract and describe them individually (muddled)...some clove flavors and grains and yeast with an alcohol presence...maybe it needs aging...pounded it to get rid of it because a dont want to decipher it anymore
Corked and caged 750. Pours dark brown with a massive off-white head. Aroma of yeast, sour fruit, and spice. Flavor of sour fruit, spice, alcohol, and bread. Solid beer.

Pours an intense dark ruby black with a very tall foamy tan head. Strong Belgian yeast aroma of sour fruit, citrus, and bread. Very creamy body. Taste is very bready with a lot of yeast flavor that brings out some of the same soured fruit that you can smell. The finish is a little dry and leaves a light tartness on the tongue.

The pour is a pleasant deep blood reddish to almost black with an ample and quickly dispersing tan head.  The nose is a bit twangy with hints of sour cherry, dried apple, malt, yeast and a hint of nutmeg.  The flavor is complex like the nose adding caramel, hazelnut, cola, dried dark fruits and astringent alcohol into the mix.  Very Pleasant.

Poured a ruby/black with a fat two-tone beige/brown head that deminished to a very tiny cap. The nose was nice and complex with black cherry, ripe peach and a malty spiciness. The taste started with black licorice, plums, raisins and toffee surrounding a huge malty caramel flavor. The finish was slightly bitter in the back of the throut. A nice warming ale with a very complex flavor profile. Very nice.

Bottle @ Allen Street Hardware, Buffalo NY. Pours a dark sort of hazy brown. Aromas of sweet maltiness. dried fruit, some chocolate & caramel. Nice mouthfeel. Flavor of dried fruits, sweetness. Very well balanced & flavorful . Very good
Dark brown with medium off white head. Sweet vinious aroma with overripe fruits, caramel and roasted malt. Sweet flavor with roasted malt, caramel, overripe fruits, yeast and chocolate.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 one of the most amazing heads ive ever seen. simply would not go away. also nice lacing, beautiful almost black coloration. aroma is also excellent- dark fruit, some chocolate, and sweet alcohol. flavor of brown sugar, molasses, massive plum, raisin, fermented grapes. 10.5% ABV is definitely in the taste and mouthfeel, but the sharpness on the tongue is welcomed. absolutely incredible, again one of my favorites ever.

Pours extremely dark brown with huge head. I had to wait before pouring the whole thing. Typical unibroue yeast aroma with chocolate, plum, and citrus evident. Flavor was molasses, and caramel, wrought with residual sugar. Prickly mouthfeel, but unbelievable smoothness and full body. This is just so great.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 Liked it.   
Very excellent flavor of spicy alcoholic brown sugar, plums, raisins with pepper and sage and cloves. Very yeasty ale, but the sour burning of the alcohol content makes the yeastyness aggressive, complex like yeasty licorice more so than hefeweizen breadiness. Overall I was thoroughly impressed by this brew, unibroue didnt live up to my expectations several times before, but this one blew me away.

The cork popped with the release of a tremendous aroma -- fruity, spicy and yeasty, almost breadlike.  Flavor is the typical Unibroue profile with lots of spicy phenolics, some stone fruits and rum raisin.  Finishes appropriately dry.  Similar to their other strong darks, just more intense.  At 10.5% abv, its probably best to share the bottle with someone else.
Dark fruit and yeast aroma. Dark and cloudy with a medium white head. Moderate malt taste in the beginning with a fruity finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Not an overly thick palate.

Ale on Lees from a bottle purchased at Kenwood in Chicago Southside.A very dark ale - not black with a tan head that fades quickly. Aroma a sharp loam with licorice and scents of pollen, cherry and a hint of Pez. The first sip is sour with a bright spicyness and a shock of citric tartness - and again a little bit of Pez - held together with a deep malt center and a true hop-bitter finish. This beer compares very well with the best Belgian Abbey Ales. OORay! Quebec!!
Dark brown. Aroma light hoppy and very yeasty, small head which disappears quickly.  Flavor is  moderately bitter with an sweet finish. Full bodied with moderate alcohol.
Bottle. Pours deep brown with dark tan head that dissipates with some lacing. Strong malt cherry aroma. Flavours of cherry, malt, not overly sweet. Hides alcohol well.
Very unique flavor with a fruity and malty flavor. Chocolate, cherry, caramel. Very enjoyable.
Dark black pour with decent head.  Aroma and taste of cherries and malt and a hint of chocolate.

Completely opaque reddish-black with a bubbly tan head that dissipates quickly. Big aroma of hops, with hints of yeast, spices, and ripe fruit. Sweet taste, of hops, yeast, cherries, spices, and malt, with a bit of an alcohol bite. Nice carbonation and lingering sweet sharpness. Very tasty.

Pours a opaque black color, with a rather loose head. Smell is very floral, very aromatic, almost like a perfume. Taste is very smooth, almost perfect, a little bitter up front, then a big fruity/floral finish, with a nice sutble maltiness to balance it all out. Incredibly smooth, you wouldnt even know its abv is 10%+. Definitely one of the top 5 beers Ive ever had.

I consider myself to have a decent palate when rating a variety of beers. But seriously,  while Unibroues line of beverages is great, several in their product line are all incredibly similar in aroma, mouthfeel, complexity and finish. Terrible, Fin du Mode, and Trois Pistoles are all far more alike than dissimilar. Its enjoyable with that fruity carbonation and slight heat. I still prefer Trois Pistoles of those 3 however. Solid beer, but less of the caramel, nutty and happy zing that other strong belgian ales like Chimay Blue bring to the experience, for instance.

750ml bottle from BevMo.  Almost pitch black pour, a little scary at first, and not a very thick head. Aroma is outstanding, a lot of fruit, classic Unibroue, maybe a little chocolate on the nose. Highly carbonated, and pretty fruit forward, which contradicts the appearance. Perfect balance, more fruit on the finish, followed by smooth chocolate.

750 ml bottle from Hogtown Harry! Thanks for the great stuff! Nose of light funk, chocolate, toffee, and black cherries; Cloudy black with a big, long lasting, glass lacing, tan head; Flavor is tart plums, chocolate, with some contrasting sweetness; finish is very lightly bitter and fruity!

Pours a dark brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor is of roasted coffee, alcohol, and is slightly hopped.  Not overwhelming in any of the flavors.  Perhaps some dark fruit in there as well.

1 pt. 9.4 oz. bottle.
Full bodied but not creamy. Very dark yet still lets some light through the glass. My friends think that it tastes like a mild red wine, I dont see the resemblence.

Dark muddy brown, massive head. Yeasty and vaguely fruity aromas. As dark as this is, Im getting no chocolate/coffee flavours or aromas, so Im assuming there is no (or very little) roasted malt in here. Its all big bready yeast and dried fruits like raisins and prunes. Nice job once again Unibroue.

750 ml bottle, RBNAG07. Dark brown. Clear. Tall coarse coca-cola-like head that falls down quickly. Dry hops aroma. Mellow dark malt flavours mixed with Belgian yeast character. High carbonation level. Notes of bread and rye.
Deep brown, nearly black color with a dense tan head. Aromas of yeast, prune, and some caramel. Taste is of chocolate, mocha, dark cherries and prunes. Medium body...very smooth.
Lives up to its name! Very dark with a thin head. Sweetish and fruity aroma. I noticed a nice smooth medium body to it with malty/fruity taste. Not bad.

750 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville. Pours black with a medium sized head that lasts. Aroma of yeast and sour cherries. Aroma does not translate to the taste, which is smooth and malty. Goes down real nice. This beer thankfully does not live up to its name.

2005 vintage.  Deep brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is of mild tart cherries, molasses, spices, and yeast.  The cherries are also evident in the flavor with a nice malty, molasses backbone.  Mouth is fairly carbonated.  A pretty mellow flavor profile overall.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2008 mild scent that doesnt overpower.  pours dark brown with quickly disappearing head.  Has a taste of liquorice/prunes.  A very unique taste.  I was impressed with this beer.  it is very easy to drink and goes down very smooth.  I would certainly purchase this again.

This brew pours a dark brown with a tan foamy head consisting of tiny bubbles. The aroma iS a mix of what seems to be chocolate, coffee, and malts. The alcohol iS very well hidden making this a delight to drink. Terrible? Hardly...only terrible if you pass it up for a first try.

Attractive in the glass...pours dark brown, almost black, with ruby hints in front of light.  Aroma promises plums and chocolate, and flavor adds dark cherries to the profile.  Im going to pair this one with desserts.  Im thinking cherry pie.

Pours almost black with a one finger tan head that fades to a ring and leaves good lacing. Aroma of molasses, cherries, and that unforgetable Unibroue yeast. Taste is the same as aroma with a hint of roasted malt. Medium mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation and well hidden alcohol. Very good.

Pours dark chocolate brown with white head.  Aroma of plum, port, licorice, spice, and belgian yeast.  Flavor contains some nice malt complexity- some chocolate, licorice, dark fruit, dried cherries- and some nice spiciness and yeast.  Palate is, like all Unibroues Ive tried, fizzy as hell.  Another good one from a pretty reliable brewery.

750 mL bottle.  Pours like a glass of coke.  Dark brown color with a thin white head.  Thick malty aroma.  Fruity with cherry tones.  Little bit sour on the tongue.  Sweet and fruity with a bitter finish.  Chocolatey and spicy.  Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2008 Found this at a random liquor store i usually dont go into.  Hell of a find, i wanted to try this for a while.  Pour is near opal black with a tan head that dissipates.  Yeast, spice, & hints of licorice in the nose.  Mouth is the notoriously well balanced Unibroue spritzer fizz.  More bitter and spicy than most Belgian ales, yet the familiar yeast/clove are reminders that its incredibly drinkable.  It is warming but not alcoholic tasting.  Beautiful.

Dark brown to black in color.  I like the bottle.  Nice tan colored head.  Fruit and some different spices in the aroma.  I could not quite pick them all out.  Flavor is very rich and full with some strong alcohol presence that seems to enchance the flavors.  Again it has fruit and spices in the flavors.  Very good beer.

Pours very dark with a tan head and micro bubbles. Great lacing, medium carbonation. The smell is of yeast and that typical apple you get with this brewery. The taste is very malty with a slight bitterness thats quickly covered up by the sweet honey and floral finish. Great mouthfeel, like silk.

750ml.  Very dark brown pour that tends to black.  Graceful light brown head.  Aroma is mostly fruit, some sweet malt and the slightest touch of chocolate.  Body is similar with a fair yeast presence, sour malt and an awesome nuttiness on the finish.  Im a bit torn about the mouthfeel, it is fairly rich and viscous... soft with little to no carbonation, can come across as a bit flabby.  Still an excellent brew from north of the border.

What a beer. I have had several of Unibroues beers, but this one stands out. Lovely color and head, full aroma... But then the first sip stands out, with cinnamon, cherry? A nice sweetness stands out, with wonderful spices. the alcohol is evident, but it doesnt deter. This is one beer, that all beer lovers should have.

Spicy clove/cinnamon and fruity nose.  Reddish "cola" color.  Complex mix of flavors, might be a little boozy and hair thin, but an excellent unique beer.  Unibroue seems to consistently produce some great beers.

Aroma initially was rich sweet molasses and dried fruit with a slight hint of yeast. Dark brown pour with hints of ruby and a tan head. Flavor of dates with just the slightest hint of abv. A flavor that is semi sweet. Just a complex overall flavor. Mouthfeel and carbonation are very good. One of my favorite by this brewer. No over powering yeastiness to me just solid all round. If Ive rated one of their beers higher I will do a side by side and re-rate.

A bottle of La Terrible aged since 2004.  Incredibly smooth.  Amber Color.  Hoppy and spicy but with the drinkablility of an easy bock.  Anise, ginger, clove, vanilla, grainy, but still big.  Grainy flavors that balance the initial sweetness.  Sample with several friends, overall description is SMOOTH, with nice alcoholic finish.  4 years of anticipation were not disappointed.  Subtle but not to be missed.  Put it away as long as you can stand.  It keeps getting better and better.

Appearance: dark brown color. Big head with beige color, lasting and some rocky.
Aroma: sweet spicy smells with tones of toast-malts, aniseed and ginger. Too others grains smells, the vanilla, nutmeg and clove. Some aromatic reminiscence of stew-plums.
Flavor: toasty malty start, too the corn and wheat. Progress of the sweet-spicy present in the ingredients like aniseed, paprika and ginger; too other tones reminiscent of clove, nutmeg, cinnamon and vanilla. Candy dried fruits touches, figs, raisins, elderberries (similar to touch of the Ebulum beer) and (maybe) plums. Warming final that to make up the sweetness. Aftertaste with the wheats touch.
Palate: medium beer with silky texture. Medium carbonated.
Slightly unbalanced, with a conjunction of sweet-species that stamps a slight exotic touch. Nice alcoholic degree some hidden for the sweetness. I had major expectations of this beer.

Pours a dark brown with a fizzy white head.  The head seems quite cola like and fizzy as it disappears.  Aroma is yeasty and fruity.  The flavor is malty with a bit of raisin, banana, and chocolate.  Colalike follow through.  The first few sips were quite nice but it didnt hold up that well to me.   Good but not great.
A 750 ml bottle, best buy date on the back. The head and body are just like a cola in comparison. Malt and fruit flavors more than anything. Not bad.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, with medium white head.  Aroma is yeasty, with smoke, spice and cherries.  Flavor is yeasty, spicy, with a little caramel.  Tingly on the tongue, little bit of alcohol in aftertaste.  I hace to say, it is not at all what the label says.

Nice. Aroma is white wine, raisin, date, coriander, misc. spices along with pepper, pine hops and cookie malts. Appearence is dark monotone brown with a frothy brown head. Flavor is spicey and it goes down creamy smooth with a warming finish.
Pours a very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, raisins, and Belgian yeast. Nice flavor, slightly cloying.

bottle.  average fizzy tan (quickly and mostly dissapating) head into dark brown body.  decent lacing.  aromas of dark ripe fruit, light licorice, light chocolate, but not as strong in aroma department as expecting.  flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter.  alcohol warming was present but overall hidden well.  light to moderate mouth feel.  duration of finish was average.  Good Good Stuff
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 they should really think about changing the name of this...not really terrible at all!!
0.75 l bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007. Brown, almost black color. Honey and black currant in the aroma. Sweet honey, chocolate, perfume, rose and warming alcohol in the flavor.

Bottle:  Pours a color that is reminiscent of dirty chocolate syrup with a smaller beige head.  Aroma is light, but sweet and spicey with bits of Belgian yeast.  Flavor is rich with dark malts, candied fruits, caramel, hints of spice, and somewhat viney.  Very smooth, yet crisp and spicey finish.  On the negative side, maybe a bit overly fruity.  Still, very good.  Thanks to my secret santa for this treat.

Bottle, 75cl corked. (RBNAG 07) Pours an almost clear, deep brown body with some microfloaties. Beige head. Sweetish nose with some dried fruits, beef-stock notes and a wee hint of cellar. Flavorwise its dried fruits, brown sugar sweetness and nots of cellar. Theres alcohol too, but its far from overpowering. Full, slightly sweetish mouthfeel. Yet another beauty from Canada. (071103)

2004 bottling (aprox. 3 years old at rating). Malt ball like nose with the combination of chocolate and malted barley.  The mouthfeel is amazing, it is lush and silky with fine champagne like bubble that gushes out of the beer & fills the mouth like creamy cotton balls. Flavors have a bit of uncooked flour The finish is a bit rough with a raw, uncooked flour and sugar snap pea (vegetable) note.  Over all a very nice beer

black pour with a khaki head that doesnt last long.  dried fruit and malts on the nose immediately.  lots of carbonation and a slight alcohol burn (maybe that was all the carbonation).  overall it was a very drinkable beer.

O those crazy French Canadians, this isnt so terrible...  I was pretty surprised, as I am not a huge Unibroue fan but this was pretty tasty.  Very dark for a Belgian style, and not overly sweet.  I am starting to open up to the style but still am craving more hops.

750ml - Poured a very dark brown in color with  a small tan head ,  Malty and sweet on the aroma.  Flavor  is sweet and strong with plenty of malt, dark fruit and alcohol.  Plenty of brown sugar as it warms up.
Bottle at RBNAG 07. Red black colour with a tan head. Aroma is alcohol, dried fruits. Flavour is dry, sweet, alcohol, dried fruits. Nice beer.

this beer pours black with a small tan head.  The aromas are of mixed fruit and spices.  The flavors are belgian sugar, nutmeg, and cloves.  This beer really gets better as it warms up.  The alcohol becomes a little more prominent thgouhg.  This is a well crafted beer from a great brewer!  Cheers!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a ruby that is almost too dark to see through, small tan head.  Aroma of bread and maybe wine.  Initial taste is sour fruit and bread yeast.  Finishes with hops and is less sour, alcohol can be noted.  Light to medium body, light carbonation, some lacing.  Drinkable, but would try more before I buy it again.
Pours a dark red brown color with a fizzy bread like head. Smells of yeast and sourness. Tastes like dark fruits and yeast. Its good but its just not great. I expect more from a 98percentile.

The cork succumbs with a struggle and a muffled pop, and I decant a surprisingly inky, matte muddiness. Brilliant back-illumination produces only the dimmest ruby glow. A sand colored, rocky head crackles busily, throbbing with animation, yet apparently devouring its own lacy leavings.  I inhale the expected Unibroue nose of rummy caramelized sugar and plum, with welcomely novel whiffs of cocoa powder, cardamom-laced coffee, lemon, and pine. Warm pipe tobacco and pumpkin pie scents offer soft contrast, and actually dominate once the churning foam subsides. Syrupy and uberfruity flavors ensue: boysenberry jam and plum, unripe pineapple, tart cherry, bubblegum, and antique books and leather. A clipped finale follows; a grating conspiracy of Turkish coffee, sourdough yeastiness, balsawood shavings, and oiled metal. The overall soft palate is punctured by puppyteeth nips of lively, pinpoint carbonation, generating a rubbery and gritty effect. Our liquid sojourn concludes with a star anise and composting pear aftertaste, and cloying, clovey bittersweetness (skewed far more towards sweet.) In general, this ale offers scant complexity and jittery unbalance; a disappointing dud from a normally notable brewer.

Aroma is mild with roasted and fruit scents.  Color is a dark solid brown with a very tight tan little head.  Taste is light and sweet.  It has a medium body that goes down with a fizzy somewhat foamy feel.  Finish is mildly sweet with a light dried fruit taste, fruity Belgian yeast and very faint roasted flavors.  On the very end is a little bite and an alcohol feel.  Its surprising as to how light it feels for being such a dark brew at 10.5%. and yet its full with bold flavor.  Overall it a wonderful Belgian brew.

This beer pours a dark brown with a a thick head that fades quick and thins out. It also leaves some minor spotted laceing along the sides of the glass. The aroma is very vinus with some bready malt and a mild acidity. As you drink it there is an initial bitterness with somr hints of pitted fruits and bready malt. The palate is full of grape and it is very smooth and leaves a nice coating on the sidewalls of your mouth. There is also a mild fall spice at the back of your mouth.

Pours a deep brown colour with a medium creamy tan head. Nose of grapes, dark fruits, old pennies and spices. Initial taste begins creamy with dark fruits, light roasted malts and grape. Moving into a light hops. FInishing with cocoa and sweet malts. Dry finish. Medium Body.

McChouffe trappist glass. Pours an inpenetrable deep brown with a puffy tan head with good retention. Complex aroma of berries, buttery grape-like notes, pound cake, bubble-gum yeast, and fig. Sweet, dark malts, brown sugar, grapes, corriander, figs, bubble-gum yeast, cherry and cinnimon spice on the finish. This is insanely complex and the flavours are well supported by a full, creamy body that finishes aromatic. It is slightly chalky, but for some reason its not offensive for being so. Nice, soft micro-bubble carbonation. Unibroue does it again.

75cl bottle in a Duvel Glass.
Pours a rich full head which subsides without much lacing. A swirl of the glass responds with a renewed head. Aroma of berries, green grapes and current. The colour is that of a dark molasses which cant be seen through. Upon tasting I am met with a strong burnt malt flavour emanating with hints of caramel and toffee. Overall I am a bit dissapointed with  this bier considering its reputation but a substantial bier nonetheless. Satisfying but needs a bit more.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 Thanks Laura!  2004 bottle, says best by 2007.  Cola nut, prune, bright and sweet soft brown.  Oxidized and old, great leathery, velvety smooth character.  Love this.  Best by 2007?  Whatever.

Pours thick and consistent. There is a big head and dark fig like aroma here. First taste is that of prunes slathered in malt. The texture is chewy and fully coats my tongue. Long finish that is complex with fig, dark cherry, yeast and bread. At this hi alcohol content, its going to take me awhile to finish this puppy.

Copying from my tasting notes. Bottle. Dark pour with a small head. Nice aroma of red wine and some hops and malt sweetness. Nice smooth beer for the alcohol content. Quite warming toward the end. Very good
Poured with medium head and smelled of hops and wine.  Rich and smooth on the palate considering the high alcohol content.  No slouch on taste either.  Excellent beer!

Bread, coffee and moderate malty aroma. Large creamy, light brown initial apperance. Excellent lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Red brown body. Heavy sweet initial flavor with a light coffee touch. Medium to full palate.

750ml bottle @ RBNAG07. Clear, dark brown body with a small beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, liquorices and dry fruit. Flavor is rather sweet malt, some dry fruit and spices, brown sugar and warming alcohol. Big, strong and elegant.

Thin coarse beige head. Dark brown to near black body. Dry fruity and lightly toasted malt aroma. Notes of spices and yeast. Balanced and complex taste of dark fruits, light sweet dark malts, herbs and spices.  Mildly hopped with notes of milk-chocolate and dark bread. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium to full body. Vinous mouthfeel. Very nice and very elegant. (Bottle @ RBNAG07)

2004 Vintage.  Pours a dark black with a thin brown head.  The aroma is dark fruits, cherries, raisins, brown sugar and alchol.  The flavor is tremendous.  A bit of sweetness, brown sugar, plums, raisins.  Clean aftertaste.  Very well made beer, this might be the best Ive had from this brewery.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2007 750 oz. pour. Poufy, big light tan head which quickly diminishes. Aroma is malty, milky and somewhat caramel-nutty. Front palate of fruit and spice, with a malty middle and finish of coffee with some bitterness / dryness. Nice heavier beer for colder months.

75 cL bottle, thanks to Carsten for bringing me this from Boston. Pours deep brown with a huge light brown head, quickly diminishing. Aroma is malty, alcohol heavy wineous, notes of dried fruit and a slight yeasty spice note. Flavour is rather sweet caramel malty. Has notes of fruits and yeast in the flavour. The yeast holds some vague spices but no match to the Belgian rolemodels. Has a light acidity lingering. Ends slight herbal/spiced with a mild bitterness and medium dry.

Pours stout black.  Aroma is slightly fruity, with some yeast.  Flavor is very very mild for a beer of this magnitude.  I sense debittered black malt, but I could be wrong.  Mouthfeel is nice and thick.  Huge yeasty aftertaste.

Amazing nose, deep earthy tones. poors dark with a very large head. bubbles in the head are fairly big detracting from the head a bit. task is very bitter, dark and spicy. was surprised at how well it tasted and finished.

The color was dark chocolate coffee.  The head was thin, creamy, and medium beige.  The aroma was sweet malt, alcohol, dark fruit, and some spice.  The flavor was dark fruit, alcohol, ale, and aged.  The palate was lively.  The finish was warm.

Pours a dark brown that allows some light. The head is two fingers thick, tan, and creamy. The aroma is strong, alcohol, sweet, sweet chocolate, caramel, Belgian notes, fruits.  The flavor is strong, alcohol, Belgian, fruits, chocolate, sweet malts. The palate is soft carbonated and full, long lasting finish.

Pours near black with with a mostly maintained foamy mocha head.
Aroma of sweet cherries, plus, raisins, brown sugar, cotton candy. 
Tastes is sweet, estery with notes of brown sugar, plums, cherries, a
Mouthfeel is full bodied, lightly sweet with light alcohol burn. 
Very nice beer, I could see cellaring this.

Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. ABV was 10.5%. Dark brown colour. Moderately malty aroma, notes of brown bread and spices. Malty and moderately sweet flavour, some vinous notes, well rounded, moderate spices and oak, low bitterness.
75 cl bottle. Dark brown color. Beige head. Sweet, malty, caramell, dark fruits, vinous. Very nice. (RBNAG07 in Grimstad Nov. 3th.)

750 mL at room temperature. Drank on 2006/11/03 (aged 1 year). Dark brown opaque beer. Keeps a beige foam lacing. Medium carbonation. Strong wine and port aroma. Plum and caramelized malt. grapes. In mouth: sweet roasted malt taste with intense port and plum/black cherry flavors. Medium bitterness with some roasted coffee/black chocolate notes. Some spicy notes revealed at the end. A warming beer wtih its 10,5% Alc. Really great. Too bad Unibroue discontinued its production.
Very Nice.  A very dark dark brown.  Very strong and alot of dark fruits - figs, plums, and raisins etc.  Some tobacco as well and very smooth.

Oh man. What a treat this is going to be. 750ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head and light carbonation. Beautiful!!! The aroma was an instant blast of over ripened fruits (plum, cherry), malts, mild sourness. Every once and a while you know right away you are in for a treat just from the aroma. Flavor is tart boozy fruits, rich malts, maybe hints of black licorice. I can feel it starting to warm my gut. Flavor is so smooth you would never guess it is 10.5% alc. Served in a De Koninck glass. A truely beautiful beer.

750 mL bottle rating.  Pour is pitch black and opaque.  Thinner head than many belgians.  More stoutlike in appearance.  Dark candied fruits, namely raisin, fig, as well as some tobacco and spices.  Very strong and complex flavors.  This is a real treat and is my favorite Unibroue beer to date.

Naming your beer "Terrible" pretty much makes it critic proof, I guess. Murky brown, with a thin beige head. Pleasent aroma of figs and grape, some red wine notes, too. Rich fruity flavor - rasin and plum, rum, and brandy. Some alcohol heat, too.

From a prestegious 750ml 2004 vintage bottle. Pours a nice dark brown with limited head. Virtously no carbonation to begin with and the overall flavor on inpact is one of a strong punch of a deep fruity wine. One of the best Unibroue has to offer.

Pours very dark wih slight ruby rednes with large tan head. Aroma has definate hints of alcohol some sweetness (black currants). Taste  has nice yeastyness, hints of chocolate. Definate bitterness in the finish. Very nice.
Dark brown with red edges. Big fluffy off-white head. Plum and spice cake in the aroma. Flavor is full of spiced fruits and a bit of orange. Fizzy mouthfeel. Good stuff.

wow......this is a nice dark lager. really cant taste the booze at all either. nice thick head a bit fizzy though. kinda a sour/ sweet taste on the palate. overall a nice beer here guys. might have to get another bottle if its still on sale!

Sampled at the Newtown Brewfest 07 with Stegosaurus. These guys stole the show bringing the biggest variey of beer and they were awesome guys. Chocolately/ fruity aroma with a nice brown pour, Sweetness, spiciness alcohol  tastes very complex very good.
Good overall beer.  Very complete in many aspects, including full aroma and flavor.  Heavy presence of dark fruits and yeast.   Very drinkable.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: La Terrible makes me tingle all over. Its a dark, handsome beer that is incredibly rich and meaty. Some sour notes keep things interesting.

75 cl. bottle with a 09-09-2003 bottling date. Pours a dark brown hue with a tan head that fades quickly to a ring at the edge of the glass. Smells spicy sweet with black pepper and dark raisons. Medium bodied with a light, fluffy mouthfeel. Has a friuty sweet flavor of plums, raisons, and dates. Finishes with a sweet alcohol taste on the breath. Very drinkable, maybe too drinkable; this 75 cl. bottle did me in before I knew it. 

Note ; Ive bought two cases of this brew in the past year, one in Seattle and one in Dallas. " So far ", I ve found two bottles to be totally flat. The brewery is aware of the problem and blames it on some bad corks. None the less, at $7 to $8 per bottle thats some good beer money going down the drain. 
Oct 2004.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Its lively, bitter, thick feel, full body, chocolate, heavy cloying sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour. A typical Belgian style ale, but done very right. Head is feisty, be sure to treat it right when pouring.

750mL bottle, courtesy of Stine.  Thanks, Eben!  Pours a murky, dark brownish-black color; fluffy, light khaki head with great retention and lacing.  Yeast, esters, and white pepper in the aroma; very pleasant.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: excellent yeast and ester character; cloves, white pepper, and some mildly boozy dried fruits; excellent balance and drinkability.  Lengthy, estery and white pepper finish.

Poured from a 750.  Thick shade of charred sienna brown.  Nose suggests first a pungent italian salami, paired, with strange success, to bitter chocolate, thick grape juice and typical metallic overtones.  Cayenne and peat wrap around the edges.  Fully roasted, smoky flavor of bananas, dark chocolate, and red bell pepper.  Smooth and rich in the mouth, slightly dry and not hiding the rustic touch of grainy sugar.  Wet smoke and moss lead to a finishing reversal of sweet hazelnut essence and rye.  Warming, and spicy in a pleasant, quiet way.  Nothing transcendent, but very solid.

Pours hazy dark brown color with large beige head. The aroma is earthy and sweet with some chocolate, anise, and fruity alcohol notes. The flavor is chocolate, a variety of fruits, and a crisp almost mint-like herbaciousness. The middle has a distinct maraschino cherry twang to it. The finish is earthy and caramel sweet, with some prune and spice tones as well. Warm, yeasty aftertaste. This is a very satisfying beer. Good stuff.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 28 Sep 2007) Dark brown colour, almost black, with huge pale brown head. Malty, sweet nose with notes of dried fruit (prunes, raisins), spices and black-currant. Malty, clean taste with dried fruit, Christmas spices and wild berries. Sweet, vinous, warming and full bodied. Massive beer, but still balanced. Lovely!

Found a 2004 vintage of this at my local grocery store.  Discounted because it was too old.  Lucky for me.  Poured a deep brown color, the cork shot across the room and it started gushing out.  Almost hit my buddy in the head.  Smelled of apples, sort of like apple cider, with other dark fruits as well.  Taste was nice, beautifully balanced, apple notes again, champagne like bubbles, all flowing into a nice dry finish with lingering apple and dark fruit on the tongue.  I enjoyed this quite a bit.

Pours black, with a small, yet well-retained, creamy light tan head.  Huge, sweet, dark fruit aroma, sweet molasses, and yeast.  Lovely aroma.  The flavor was much of the same.  The sweet dark fruits and malts blend together nearly perfectly.  Traces of sweet cinnamon and yeasty residue are left on the palate, as the aftertaste is sweet with semblances of some funk.  Aged 3 years, so it has gotten a little funky, but I think in a very good way.  Drinking very good right now.  Probably my favorite Unibroue beer.

Bomber.  Pours a deep ruby color with a small off-white head.  Aroma is malt, candy sugar, and chocolate.  Taste is the same, with a nice hop characteristic, wonderful raisin flavors, and the syrupy consistency of a liqueur.  Alcohol noticeable at the end.  One of my favorite sipping beers.

Dark ruby color, small off-white head. Sweet, a bit chocolaty nose. A bit earthy liquerish palate, some toffee, toned alcohol and light hoppy notes. This is quite interesting "slow beer" and not terrible at all.

Bottled. Deep amber colour, mediumsized brown head,. Aroma is really strong raisiny and alcoholic (barley wineish) with caramel malts and some yeast in it too. Flavour is raisins, alcohol, some sweet malts and also vanilla & chocolate. Aftertaste is really vanillaish.

750ml from Rons.  Pours dark brown/black with just the slightest ruby-red highlights and about an inch of offwhite head that dissipates rather surprisingly quickly.  Smells woody initially, with raisins, chocolate, nut, banana, and burnt qualities all playing equally big roles, with just a hint of pith.  Tastes roasty, burnt, and raisony, with a good doses of chocolate, nut, banana, and citrus/pith playing huge roles too, with wood, nuts, and raisins playing bigger roles toward the finish and aftertaste  Wow, this tastes great.  Full rich velvety mouth-feel that makes this a relatively easy drinker for what a big beer it is.  Alcohol is oddly absent from the aroma, flavor, and mouth-feel, so its effects sneak up on you with this beer.  Wow.  This beer is amazing - leaps and bounds better than I remember it being.  Another slam-dunk for Unibroue!

750 ml.  thanks to the big man johnycorkscrew for this.  Pours a dark brown with ruby hints and a white head.  Aroma is spicy, plums and rasins.  Flavors is typical unibroue - overrated.  More of those dark fruits, carmels, alcohol, and as devon stated below that unibroue yeast.  Seriously Im waiting for these guys to not leave me disappointed.

Thanks Johnycorkscrew for bringing this one to the par-tay.  Hazy dark brown with medium white head.  Aroma was very spicy and typical unibroue with some dark fruit and maple syrup thrown in there for good measure.  Flavor is dark fruit, spice, quite a bit of alc, and ofcourse that unibroue yeast flavor.  Medium body with lively carbonation.  Very nice, thanks again for bringing it johny!!

sampled at a party hosted by xnoxhatex. pours brown with off white head. nose is very brown sugary with a touch of spicyness to it. flavor has sweet caramelly notes with some spice to it. fizzy full mouth feel. one of unibroues better beers but i still dont like their yeast or carbonation.

Wow. Its been a long time since a brew really hit me right between the eyes, but this one did. A tad on the sweet side, which is the only detraction from this wonderful beer, it pours a deep, rich coffee-colored near-black amber with an aggressive caramel colored head. The nose is an amazing blend of very light lemon and honey sweet goodness. The palate...ah, the palate. Lightly figgy, blended with cardamon and ginger, notes of honey and well-blended alcohol underlying it all to balance out the sweetness. Now mind you, it comes in a 750 ml bottle that cannot be recorked, so be prepared to drink the entire bottle upon opening. Thats my plan, and I am NOT sharing.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2010 Very dark, very creamy, very floral.  It takes Trois Pistoles and morphs it into this totally different beer. All of the good of TP and solves the maltiness issue. ON SECOND ANALYSIS: This is a Quad! Something akin to Westeverleten 12.  Nice.

Bottle - Dark brew with creamy head.  Malty nose with some floral hints.  Complex flavors - sweet malt, raisin, hops, caramel, fermented fruit - warming alcohol.  Medium to full bodied.  Id rather accompany this with food than comsume as a solo.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark amber colour. Heavy malty moderate hoppy aroma. Moderate sweet/bitter flavor. Lots of plum/rasin and week chocolate notes. Long complex nice finish. Creamy palate. Excellent beer.

Beer poured dark, dark brown with nice head and lacing. Aroma was nondescript, but the flavor sure wasnt. Nice fruity malty goodness with a lot of spices and a definite strong hint of cherries. Very sweet, but not overly so.  Mouthfeel was really carbonated, but it seemed to fit perfectly.  This could be the best Unibroue!  Good beer...go try it.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 Pours almost black, with a full creamy head. Aroma of dates, figs, malt, molasses. Flavor is immediately caramel, dried fruits, with almost no bitterness. Not very complex, but a solid tasting beer. Will have again.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2009 
Date: December 25, 2003
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Whole Foods Market, DC
Appearance: solid ebony with a frothy tan head
Aroma: sweet rich ripe fruit aroma
Flavor: malty flavor with lots of fruit character, hint of alcohol in the finish
Overall: a bit disappointing in the lack of complexity

Date: January 08, 2009
Mode: bottle
Source: Ale Atlanta
Score: ii to iii
a few years gives it a richer and fruiter flavor, nice sweet chocolate in the background, 

Date: November 08, 2009
Mode: draft brick store
a bit of tartness in the aroma and flavor, rich dark fruits, sweet esters offset by the tartness, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

Dark, ruby brown; linkering small amber head.  Rich, nutty caramel aroma.  Big flavor of dark roasted malts, molassas, carob, pepper, poppy seeds, alcohol, prunes and kumquat with a lingering aftertaste of smoke, burnt caramel, sweet cane syrup and white pepper.  I believe Im drinking a 2005 now, but have had many years worth, fresh and aged.  Always a treat.

The 750 ml bottle poured a very dark brown beverage with ruby highlights at the edges in strong light. It had a modest sized creamy off-white head that lasted throughout. The aroma is strong and complex with ample notes of coriander, orange peel, caramel and pepper with more subtle hints of aged leather. The body was moderately full with soft carbonation and a smooth, almost oily texture. The flavor starts out sweet, faithfully representing all the aromas mentioned above. The finish is still somewhat sweet accompanied by a very smooth alcohol warmth settling in the chest.

Brun ufiltreret øl.

Meget kraftig duft og smag af kryderier. Alcohollen er hæftig.

Super belgisk bryg, selvom den er lavet i Canada. Minder dog en del om trapisterne.

Wonderful brew.  This Unibroue is like a lot of the other ones out there, but it has a pretty wonderful spice hint to it.  Overall Id have to say its one of my favorites of theirs.  Slight smoky taste, with a nice brown sugar taste.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 2004 bottle. Thick, dark black pour, with creamy tan head. Carbonated well. I get bright apples in the nose, and a dash of caramel and other spices. Flavor is mostly cider and apple. Very smooth, watery, easy on the palate, with a good finish and aftertaste. Ill have to try a fresh bottle to compare.
My favorite from Unibroue, has a lively smoky taste.  Delicious beer to savor, dark color and taste jumping all over the place in the mouth.  Top notch!

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 22 oz bottle, burnt umber hue with light brown head, thick, lasting brown sugar characteristic of a begian strong ale, malty as well, nutty aftertaste, good one to split....Bottle marked 2004 and good until 2007...Very syrupy sweet ie. sugar and prunes, some malt backbone

Looks and tastes like Trois Pistoles to me. Purple black color. Lots of fruit aroma and taste. Medium head because I opened cold to avoid  a foam-over. No hops.  I see no need for this as Trois Pistoles is cheaper!
Flaske. Fantastisk farve og duft rammer dig når du hælder denne øl op. Komplekse noter af malt, krydderier og rørsukker. Disse fortsætter i smagen, der er sammensat og ideel. Brilliant øl.

Bouteille 750ml. De couleur brune foncée et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (raisins, figues, léger de cerises et de prunes, notes de pommes), de malt moyennement rôti, de sucre bonbon, dépices (léger de cannelle et de réglisse noire, notes de poivre et de clou de girofle), moyen dalcool (petites notes vineuses) et léger de chocolat noir et de pain avec des petites notes boisées. Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-fort et une texture moyennement crémeuse. Goût de levures assez fruitées (raisins foncés légèrement vineux, prunes, dates, léger de cerises vieillies, notes de pommes vertes) et accompagné dun goût plutôt épicé (moyen de réglisse noire, léger de cannelle, notes de clou de girofle) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté moyen-léger rôti, de sucre bonbon et de pain, léger de sucre brun, de caramel et de chocolat noir avec des notes de biscuits parallèlement à un moyen goût dalcool aux notes réchauffantes (présent toute la gorgée) puis en finale lon retrouve un goût moyen-léger amer et asséchant de levures épicées (léger de poivre) ainsi que des notes boisées. Post-goût long et plutôt sec, moyennement amer de rôti, de levures épicées (poivre), de fruits (moût de raisins vineux, dates) ainsi que léger de chocolat noir et dalcool.

bottle.  this one rocked me quick.    black pour with thin frothy tan head.  aroma is fruity, spicy, mild yeast, roasted malts.  nice body.  nutty and malty.  peppery, dark fruit and mild sugar.  dangerously smooth and very nice.
Pours a black brown and gives a sweet malt raisin aromas.  The notes of toasty malts and pernod show nicely in the palate and finsh.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2008 Bomber.  Pours dark brown/black.  Head dissipates quickly.  Smells of sugary licorice and raisin.  Tastes of toasted malt with sour blueberry and liquorice.   Finish lingers.  Wonderful.

Its an almost black beer with a nice head. The aroma is sweet with notes of burnt sugar and roasted malt. The flavour is sweet with notes of burnt caramel, a bit of fruits like tangerine and apple. Its OK, but need more complexity to make my day. 2422

Bottle. Pours nearly opaque with hints of light brown light coming through and a thin, creamy tan head with lacing. Smell is sweetish malt, some light spicey yeast aroma, doughiness, bannana and some  earthy scents. Flavor is some smokiness, grain spirit alcohol flavors, fruit - plum, bannana some sweet and sticky cherry flavors. Flavor and mouthfeel also have a distinct dark bread quality.
Dark brown, beige head. Aroma of spices, a bit creamy. Flavours: spicy, cinnamon, peppery and dark fruits. Alcohol noticable. Balanced bitterness.

Aroma has the typical Unibroue yeast with fruits, plums/raisins and malts. Dark brown coloured with a great looking beige head. Taste is sweet, unibroue yeasty, peppery, some cinnamon, dark and dried fruits, raisins and some peach. Great yesss.

Cloudy brown color, short creamy lasting head, perfect appearance. Aroma of Unibroue yeast, spicy, malty, plums, some alcohol. Strong taste of roasted malt, combined with lots of dried fruit and spices as well. Bit bitter finish. Very nice stuff.
One of my favorites that I enjoy regularly.   Belgian candi sugar, yeast, raisins, malt, and hints of alcohol.  Great beer.

Caged and corked.  Pitch black with a lightly active tilt around the edge, rising to a bright white ring of foam.  Nice rich flavor of licorice, dates, raisins and maybe some dark cherry.  Dances around in the mouth and goes down quite easily for a 10.5 ABV brew.  Superb.  (#3024, 7/15/2007)

pours cloudy dark brown with decent head that fades.  aroma is spicy with lots of phenol (bananas and other fruitiness) with some fig and ripe fruit.  taste is tart fruity with lots spiciness and a good amount of booze towards finish.  theres is good amount of dark fruit and toffee sweetness.  good stuff.

2004 750mL purchases at Beer World of Largo that pours deeply amber with one inch tan head. The aroma is fairly strong with crushed black grapes that have been backing in the sun for thirty minutes. Theres also notes of sour sugar candy, figs, raisins and yeast. The flavor is much like the aroma with black grapes, figs and raisins that slide into a bit of tartness about midway. Into the finish more fruity sweetness, yeast and more fruit dominate the palate. Very nice brew with no sense at all of the big ABV.

this beer is scary im not gonna lie. dark as hell with such a strong taste of alcohol you can barely tell whats going on till your like half way done the bottle and built up some tolerance  to it. then it becomes a little sweeter but still out of control. i like to be able to take a nice swig of my beer and be a lttle refreshed you know. but this is like wine to me.

Bottled.
Almost black with a small, beige head.
Sourish and yeasty nose. Some wood and alco-feel.
Sweet and frutiy flavour. Pretty sweet with burnt, dark sugar.
Bottle: Black colour,creamy head. Aroma of yeast,fruits,raisins,Dark Chocolate.Flavor almost the same as the aroma.Medium body.Medium finish.

Opaque dark brown, medium soapy head. Fruity malt aroma, slightly roasted, notes of cherries, yeast, and a clear touch of alcohol. medium bodied and smooth. Good balance, with sweetness, some acidity, and bitterness well integrated.

An excellent ale that pours a three finger, thick light brown head fades slowly leaving a good lace.  Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Nose is a malty alcohol.  Very deep amber, almost black color.  Starts smooth and malty and finishes with an alcohol overtone. Ages well, bought Sep 2006 bottled 2004, best by Aug 8, 2007. $6.22 for a 750ml bottle from Smileys Beverages Dover, NH.

Pours black with a large, beautiful brown head that clings to the glass and laces nicely.  Nose is complicated - initial molasses mixes with dark fruit and biscuity malts, with a hint of yeasty mustiness and phenolic spice towards the end.  Flavor is dates, Belgian candy sugar, smoke, chocolate, and cloves.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Lingering warm alcoholic finish.  Yum yum.
Now we are talking.  This still have a very cola like apperance, but it tastes pretty nice.  Some roast and chocolate, and an nice cherry spiciness.  Still, way thin.

750 mL bottle.  Dark brown with a creamy white head.  Aroma of berries, dark fruit, malt, and yeast.  Taste of black licorice transitioning to a nice fig taste and finishing with a lingering candy sweetness.  Pleasant alcoholic warmth in the back of the throat.  I havent always been a fan of Unibroues dark ales, but I figured anyone arrogant enough to name a beer, "terrible," must have made a good brew, and, indeed, I was right; this is quite good.
Another quality beer from the northern neighbor. I look at all the fancy descriptions, and I can only respond by saying that no North American brewers can do a strong ale like this.

This took me off guard, as I was expecting a beer not peroxide in a bottle.  Semi-transparent brown color with quickly diminishing, rocky, tan head.  Aroma was of apple cider gone bad which translated to the taste.  Will try again at some point in time, but Im not in much of a hurry to.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip.  This ale poured a deep brown color with a huge fizzy tan head that slowly faded away.  A bit of light lacing is left behind.  Some ruby highlights and active carbonation are visible when held up to light.  The aroma is made up of dark fruits, brown sugar, plums, and sweet malts.  The smell is very vinous.  The flavor consists of dark grapes, cherries, plums, light malts, and some bread.  The mouthfeel is thin and fizzy.  A bit of a dry finish.  The high alcohol is hidden perfectly.  A decent ale, but other examples of this style really overshadow this beer.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2007 Bottle at Volo. This is a beautiful beer, that was also presented in a very fancy way by the waitress. A very dark pour. The smell was pleasing and complex, with identifiable dates, black cherries and red wine vinegar. This tasted like heaven. Just a slice of heaven in a glass. Red wine, black cherries, cumin, black grapes, black plums, and a touch of various other spices and fruits that my palate simply cant keep up with. If you see this on the menu, you must try it!
Pungent aroma of soy sauce.  Nice color.  Tastes somewhat dry.  Taste is dark and comes in late.  Went well with a red pixie stick.

Niiiice! Aroma of dark fruits...plum, raisin mostly. Pour was a dark black with a nice 2 finger tan head that didnt lace at all. The taste was a heavy carbonated mix of dark fruits (again) plum and raisin with hints of chocolate in the background. The beer tastes agonizingly sweet upon first sip but bitters up in the end with a medium to strong alcohol burn. Lots going on in this beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Large bottle shared w/ my son. I made the mistake of drinking a whole bottle myself once and paid a gastronomic price for my folly. Pours a dark brown w/ a huge foamy head. Over carbonated like most beers this style. Mouthfeel is much like soda, again the over carbonation. This is a complex busy beer. Tastes run from raisins & plums to brown sugar & chocolate. Whenever i drink this brew I have visions of 3 old hags standing around a large black kettle. Eye of newt, toe of frog, etc. Anyway, I digress. This is a good but powerful brew. I will drink it again.
was in florida on vacation and enjoyed a corked bottle that was not terrible a thick sweet beer with a kick

Aroma of plummy dark fruits backed by yeast. Malt too. Looks black, but beautiful ruby color appears when placed before halogen. Beige head that didnt stay long. Medium bodied. A bit fizzy. The dark fruit is present, along with a slight hint of phenolic resin. Definitely sweet malt, though not syrupy. The finish is actually rather dry, and tends to pucker the mouth. The bitter is adequate to be noticable in the finish.
Bottle. Dark brown. Sweet aroma of dark fruits, liquorice, malt and yeast. Great flavour of malt, chocolate, yeast, dark fruits, liquorice, alcohol and spices.

Dark brown, smells of plums and cherries, malt, molasses, maybe maple syrup, something sweet thats hard to pin down but really good.  Tastes of chocolate, but not in the same way stouts taste like chocolate, its hard to explain this one but I like it a lot.  Mouthfeel is smooth, almost creamy but not too heavy.

Rated 5/13/06:  This is a great beer to get cozy with anytime of the year. The pour is an immense dark ruby red with a thin head and little lacing. Due to the high alcohol content this is to be expected. The aroma is unlike any other, awesome is an understatement. I drank from a red wine glass and an intense aroma of dark sweet fruits filled the air. I inhale and its as if I am drinking port, It is hard to explain how delicious the scent truly is. The beer is slightly thin on the palate but it works. The flavor is bursting with fruit flavors and sweet malts. Plums, cherries, figs, raisins, who knows what is all involved in this wonderful beer. Overall this is a must try. Not your typical brew, but exactly what I would expect from Unibroue. Absolutely Fabulous.

Black with a brown head that disapears quickly.  Rather fruity aroma. Fruity raisony taste that is creamy and not too strong.  Smooth. Taste is on the sides of the tongue and lasts just long enough. Fun to drink.
