2004 bottle - Pours almost black with a moderate sized head of large carbonation bubbles that quickly fade away.  The aroma is mainly of yeast and dark fruit.  The flavor is sweet malts with plenty of dark fruit.  High carbonation lends a lively mouthfeel to this medium to full bodied brew.  The 10.5% abv is buried and at 3 years on, the beer is still doing very well.  I expect it could hold up well for quite some time to come.
Bottle at Københavnske Øldage 2007.  Black - offwhite head. Licorice, yeasty, berries, sweetness, dirt, brown sugar, smooth, roasted. Alcho-burn. Typical belgian style !!

Bottle. @ Copenhagen Øl Festival. Large beige creamy head that mostly diminished. Dark mahogany color. Yeast, dry fruit, liquorish, apricot, hint of chocolate with some woodish like notes as well. Notes of brown sugar and chocolate. Full bodied with a soft carbonation and light alcoholic texture. Well balanced moderated sweet with some bitter alcoholic flavor. Nice linger sweet finish.

Dark Red/Brown colour. Too much bubbles and meduim head. A few seconds later the head dissapears.  Fresh and fruity aroma. Spicy. Taste is fresh as well with spices notes but yeast is predominant. Great beer but too much carbonatation for be the perfect beer. The sensation in mouth is like soda or coke (bubbles). The finish is OK, hume and wood. Great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 First rating750 ml bottle Dark deep red color, fluffy tan head. Almonds and marzipan alcohol scent, also fruity and Belgian ale yeast. A bit spicy as well, but lots of alcohol that is dominating. Spicy, yeasty and bitter taste, warming alcohol as well. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Alcohol, yeast and spicy aftertaste.7/4/7/3/15=3.6Rerate75 cl bottle on September 4, 2010I got this from Systembolaget, I think back in 2006 or so, just stored it in 12 degrees since then.Clear dark brown color, fluffy tan head. Sweet, milky, spicy scent. Cinnamon, apple, alcohol, spicy, pumpkin taste. Red berry aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.Round, tasty, nice, well hidden alcohol, very drinkable. Dangerous probably.7/4/7/4/14=3.6

2004 bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a ruby highlight and a big white head which fades fairly quickly to a ring. Aroma is quite fruity with notes of apple, pear, caramel maltiness,  typical Unibroue yeastiness, cookie dough.  Flavor is quite different from the aroma with some cherry, chocolate, a little bubblegum/banana esters, raisins.  Medium-full body with quite a bit of carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2007 Very dark mahogany with big, foamy head /   Medium body, spritely carbonated, with good finish / Mild, creamy flavors of sour malt, banana, chocolate, raisins, and dates / Very good, but a little too restrained in flavor and bit too boisterous in carbonation.

The beer pours a deep, dark mohagany, almost brown color.  The head is thick and deep tan color with very nice lacing.  The aroma was very fruity with hints of caramel, chocolate, coffee and candy.  The thing that hits you the most with La Terrible is the mouthfeel and palate.  Not at all what I expected from this baby.  The finish is so smooth and enjoyable.  What a great effort from Unibroque!

I am very suprised I liked this beer. Had in a 750ml. Corked and caged. Pours a very dark black, semi thick. A light brown head that fizzes then fades. Alot of fruit on the nose. Smooth mouthfeel. Hints of rasins, dates, slight roast, alcohol, figs, and sweetness. The finish is massive dates and rasins then a delayed date hint. Very, very good.

Bottled-cork & wire: Vintage 2004- Pours a very deep brown color; opaque with a nice ruby hint in the light. The very lively and bubbly tan head fades to a consistent film. Very fruity aroma. Light vinous qualities with hints of muscat grapes, prunes, figs, light citrus notes, with some chocolate & toffee in there as well. Has a very carbonated mouthfeel, almost harsh. The initial flavor is full of fruityness with elements of green apple, dark berries and fig. Theres also some light notes of oxidation and a wood hint, yet it has aged nicely. Theres a subtle sweetness in the middle reminiscent of brown sugar. The finish is the most impressive part of this Belgian Strong. It leaves with a nice roasty, almost earthy flavor, with light hints of tobacco, raisins, and roasted toffee. This is a nice Ale, and its a shame the mouthfeel is too abrasive. Other than that this is a very well crafted and enjoyable Belgian Strong.

750 bottle . . pours deep dark brown with a fizzy white head . . aroma is brown sugar, raisin, red wine, toasted marshmellows . . taste is dried fruit, cherry, sweet . . very cherry . . unique! . . good beer . . alcohol is well hidden

Complax brown Sugar/Raw Sugar aromas, pours with a thick brown latte like head, color is almost impenetrable black/brown.
Flavour is more dark sugar with some slight spice. 
The overall beer is good, it manages to conceal a ridiculous 10.5% with ease.
Poured a very dark brown with a very thick tan head. A very fruity and malty aroma. The taste was just as good as the aroma, alcohol was not too overbearing, very good overall
Dark  dark brown with thick off white head fruity and somewhat sweet with something else.. some say cloves some say anise i just say its good

Pours almost black brown with a ruby hue and a thick frothy tan head. Strong fruity aroma, notes of cherries, candy sugar, molasses, and a light hint of alcohol. Flavor has an overall cherry like tartness, a hint of candy sugar, notes of anise, and an alcoholic sweet finish. Palate is medium, lightly effervescent, tart, and dry, with some lingering anise.

Aroma: malty bread, grape, raisin, cherry, clove, alcohol
Appearance: large, creamy, cream colored head, mostly lasting, coffee colored
Flavor: sweet, fruity, cloves
Palate: creamy texture, medium bodied, lively carbonation

almost has the taste/feel of a wine. pours dark brown with medium head that lingers. hints of fruits in the aroma, the abv is well disguised in this one. easy drinking, light carbonation, smooth finish.

750mL thanks to sombeast!  Poured deeper brown with a dusting and a ring of off-white head.  Aroma was of deeper dark fruits, some peppery yeast and a hint of herbal hops.  Flavor found darker fruit and chocolate notes.. sharper, spicy accents were a tad too peppery to me.. quite enjoyable overall.  This was a bit high in carbonation, but not as grating as Unibroue often is for me.. some sharp notes detract from the feel, too.  Solid brew.  Thanks Chris!

I couldnt believe my charming and vivacious wife brought me home a beer that said right on the lable that it was TERRIBLE!     I gave her a terribly hard time about this, but shes a good woman.  I served the beer in a snifter glass and we rated it jointly as a training exercise.  An aggressive pour yielded a strong two-finger tan head, which diminished at a normal rate to an 1/8 inch. The head seems to hang around indefinitely, and can be easily replenished with swirl of the glass.  Aroma of carbonation, malt, and just a note of smoke and alcohol.  Color is a clear dark brown.  Carbonation is fairly high, typical of what I have come to expect of Unibroue beers, delivering both a smooth creaminess and a little pop on the tongue. Flavor is moderate dominated by toasted malt, a little nuttiness, some residual sweetness, and just enough bitterness to provide balance.  Finish is a mild and pleasant toasted malt bitterness.  A little lacing is left on the glass.  As usual, Unibroue has done well, this is a terribly good beer in my book.

Wow!! This was delicious!! Poured a loverly dark-brown into the goblet with a frothy light-tan head that laced nicely as it was drunk. HUGE fruity aroma with hints of malt, spices and light alcohol. Beer is full-bodied with a taste that is rich and satisfying with dark fruit, spices, roasted malt and a just-there-enough presence of alcohol. Wonderful beer!!

Nice very dark brown color with a frothy, large light brown head, which diminishes and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is amazing, with rich malts and fruits. Smells a lot like rootbeer. Flavor is good, very malty, a little sweet with a light fruitiness.
Bottle, 75cl. Dark brown colour with a large tan head. Sweet and fruity aroma, slightly spicy. Big flavour, fruity & complex, a little bit too alcoholic though.
lightly sweet start quickly goes dry, flavors of berries, spice, and yeast. ends a little sour and bitter.

Pour is a dark brown with some red and a nice head.  Some floaters.  Aroma of spice, yeast, and dark fruit.  Flavor of many complex dark fruits, caramel, yeast, spices, and some roasted malt.  An excellent dark belgian style ale.
Pours deep dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and caramel. Tastes are sweet, coffee, caramel and prunes. Very smooth. Light carbination. Alcohol weel hidden. Very Nice.

Bottle. Pours dark brown, lightly hazy. Head is quite fizzy and bubbly - not imrpressive looks. Aroma, though, is quite stunning. Roasted malts, some caramel. But especially, it has a lot of complex spices... it is difficult to discern them, but they smell terrific. Flavour builds on this. A little smoky, some caramel and spices en masse. Stuinning.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 Almost opaque brown-black with medium-sized khaki, lasting head. Aroma is Belgian yeast, bubblegum, spice and faint alcohol. Initial taste is similar but milder and less complex, with more bread flavor. Finish is strong and dry. Medium-light and smooth palate. Aftertaste is dry, vinous dark fruit and warms your insides. Alcohol is well hidden, yet something doesnt seem quite right about the flavor - slight metallic note maybe. Or maybe just too wine-like for my tastes. Still though, a nice beer.

Pours dark with a 2 finger fluffy almost tan head.  Aroma is dominated by dark fruits.  Dark and citrus fruits along with spices dance on the palate. A good amount of carbonation. Nicely coats the mouth and finishes dry. Great ale.

or a long time, just intrigued by the bottle. All in all, i found it fairly solid, and quite heavy, but not quite up to the internal hype that I had built for it. I wished it was more complex, and darker. I felt that it just wasnt decidedly dark or not dark. It floated along in the middle not really deciding which way to go. I wanted something super roasty, chocolaty and maybe even burnt. Had it just said "strong ale" on there, I might have been a bit more understanding of what it was trying to be. Still though, worth enjoying, maybe with a friend, for this is a mighty ale.

750ml bottle.  deep ruby brown glimmer with a nice little above avg head.  the first thing i want to say is..."best before 2011,"  damn!!!!!  thats a beer.  this could easily outlast some of the bottles in my wine cellar.  this brew has a nice thick aroma that is unusually high, even for a belgian (style) ale.  the aromas almost all cover the 4 major (legit) food groups.  major fruits all over, even tofu...and some herbs/light spice.  theres even a breath of fresh air in the aroma, that is, for the beer conessieur.  taste?  theres an overall fluffiness in the mouthfeel, and a crazy kind of cheese going on in the flavor, as well as some off-shoot vegetables.  this beer is crazy sweet.  A+ here, definitely a repeat buy, when i can find it.

The name scared me a little but I went with it and its very excellent as is expected from Unibroue. A pleasureful when you pour it. It has such a rich color and great head. Goes down amazingly smooth with a nice aftertaste. A truly great brew.

This beer had massif flavor. Alcohol content made me happy. A deep brown beer with thick head. Taste is sweet, fruity but also partially a mellow nutty chocolate notes are present. Drank it with some really good breads. Definately a solid beer.

2004 vintage that I have been cellaring since purchased in Montreal Sep 05.  I had heard that there had been problems with the 2004 corks so I was somewhat concerned opening this baby. I pulled the cork and pop!  Poured with great fizz and gusto! Relief
The color is a very dark- held up to the light the ruby comes through. Lots and lots of floaties with great lacing.  Smell is of sweet fruit and candy. Taste- damn that is smooth!  Much smoother than Trois Pistoles.  Dried fruits and bakers chocolate with a dry finish. No noticable hops. The house yeast isnt too noticable here. This is an awesome beer and would be exceptional with a fine meal (mine was experienced with chicken soup). This is the best Unibroue that I have experienced to date.

Pours deep, deep ruby, almost like coffee, with an off-white head.  Aromas of malt and provolone (yes provolone).  Besides the obvious, there are notes of sour cherry in the flavor.  Finish could be more clean.
Pours a dark brown with a large creamy light brown head. Good lacing. Very good beer.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a murky dark brown sandy color with a large frosty beige head.  Aroma is of fine dry chocolate malt, molasses,dates,prunes,plums,brown sugar and fresh yeast.  Taste of brown spicy sugars, molasses,fresh yeast,dates and a nice dry chocolate backbone.  Similar to other Unibroe offerings but still quite tasty.

I had this at the beer tasting at Barley Pop in Germantown, WI.  It was smoky in there so I may update when I get some.  This was one of the best beers Ive ever had despite being served colder that it should have.  A ton of rich flavors.  Chocolate and molasses stood out but Ill have to get some and check more closely.  It was also great mixed with their Quelque Chose (thx Chuck:).  It was by far the standout at the tasting yesterday.  It was a 2004 vintage too...

Bottle: Pours black with a small, light brown head that is mostly diminishing.
All I can say is Wow!  This is one of the best best beers I have had, right up there with the Chimay Grand Reserve I had in Belgium.  I has a rich, full flavor with a malty, molasses flavor with a hint of chocolate and some slight fruity overtones that are too complex for my amateur palate to detect.  A wonderful long finish that lingers in your mouth after you finish a sip.  Highly recommended to anyone who likes dark Belgian beers.
750 ml bottle. Pours dark brown with full foam brown head.  Little alcohol in the taste, taste of sweat malt with bitter after taste. Sweat aroma. Very good drinking beer.

La Terrible pours a deep dark brown, and is heavily carbonated, with an inch thick tan head. The head from this beer lasted longer than it does from my woman. The 10.5% is well hidden by the flavor of this beer.
Upon pouring, the carbonation and color reminded me of a cola.  The aroma was sweet and full of carmel.  The body was similarly sweet with heavy carbonation.

Pours a deep dark brown, topped by an inch or so of soft tan foam. Good head retention and lacing. Mild sweet grain and soft chocolate aroma.

Bold sweet flavors - chocolate malt, toffee, brown sugar, grain, and a fruitiness like Welchs grape juice concentrate. Very sweet in the finish and aftertaste. Medium full body, mild carbonation

Very nice.  Right off, the 10.5% is completely masked by the smooth, sweet taste of this beer.  Murky brown pour with a squatty off-white head.  Fruity aroma similar to a lighter cognac.  Dark fruits, malt, and sugar mix well with the malt.  Palate was enjoyably light for a change.  Its nice not to have every Belgian Strong be thick and syrupy.  Overall, a great beer.

lively, long finish,  i think its rare to find such a corbonated beed that doesnt just moisten the tounge but renders a chocolaty auroa about the mouth, not so much a lingering spice, but an assimilation of the tatse buds that leaves them like an addict, fiending for the next sip
Dark cherry red with huge head. Lots of sweet malt in the aroma. molasses. Slightly sour. Little bit of belgian yeast. Very carbonated.
22 Jul 2006 - Malty sweet spiritous hop aroma.  Dark brown-red colour, good lacing and reasonable head.  Sweet raisin, choc malt and hop flavour.  Tangy sweet roast fruit hop finish but a bit thin.

aged approximately 2 years - Semi-opaque brown pour with a small off white head.  Aroma of macerated fruits...relatively boozy aroma.  Raisin and plum aroma.  Chocolate covered raisins soaked in alcohol.  Sweet with some hints of alcohol present.  Very tasty.  Pit fruits, mellow flavors melded together...Delicious.

Like hte 15, this beer is focused on the alcohol content.  It is prominent in the flavor and aroma.  Fruity, but not as fruity as some higher quality Belgians.  Lots of malt as well.  Simple overall and lacking complexity.  The palate is good but not as thick as I would like.  Dark brown, I thought this was an abbot ale.

Pours a dark brown with a minimal head.  Aromas of dark fruit, toffee, and a little of the estery earthiness, as well as a hint of sweet banana.  Flavor is dominated by malt with very pronounced raisen, chocolate, and sweet.  A very nice beer.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: very dark brown, no much head to it. aroma has alot of malt in it. not as fruity as im used to from Unibroue. not one of my favorites.

Bottle Marked 2004.  Pours a very dark brown, with smaller tan head that dies rather quickly with stubble lacing.  Aromas of Chocolate, light coffee, yeast, faint hints of malt and fruits.  Flavor is nice, sweet, and smooth.  Hints of raisins and malt come through, with other dark fruits and caramel.  Finish is nice, fizzy, but smooth.
Fizzy flavor with a dark pour. Flavors akin to spiced cola in a strange way. Rather malty. Not a favorite from Unibroue.
Mlat hop aroma with spice. Black colour with great head and lacing. Smooth malt hop flavour with citrus aftertaste. Fizzy palate.

BB 06-11.  Dark brown, almost chocolate colored pour; head is beige, small, and fizzy with nearly all diminishing and no lacing.  Bold and nice nose; chocolate, plum, yeast, light coffee bean, raisin, and some definate notes of alcohol.  Flavor is very similar and very malty; chocolate, brown sugar, and yeast make up the malty base with raisin, plum, and light coffee filtering in to make it complex.  Palate is lively, medium, and almost silky in texture, despite the carbonation, with a fairly bold alcohol presence.  Finishes average length (for a Belgian) and sweet with chocolate and raisin and noticable alcohol presence.  Nice, very malty, unquestionably bold Belgian from Unibroue.  Definately great as a desert-type beer, but still remaining quite drinkable.  A little age might make this one much better, less carbonation and alcohol presence, but even still, a solid brew with lots of character.

2004: Dark brown pour, moderate head, above average lacing and retention. Aroma is very dusty yeast with sugars, lesser notes of dark fruits and malts. Alcohol well hidden, which is good. Sweet finish, fairly heavy beer. However, the flavors and complexity never jumped at me even with an older bottle. DO NOT DRINK WITH FISH!
One of my favorites from unibroue.  Leesy, sweet fruit flavor.  I wouldnt want it any sweeter, but its just about right..

Saw this beer and thought to myself "If beers like Pabst say they are wonderful but taste terrible, then a beer that says that it is terrible right on the bottle must be great."  It was pretty darn good.  Sweet is about the best description.  Most likely a bit too sweet for the style, but if you can deal with the sweet, it is a very nice beer to enjoy.

Thanks to BankerJoe for bringing along to a tasting to share.  Pours a dark brown with hints of amber and a bubbly off white head that left some lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, some Belgian "Unibroue" yeast, very fruity,  Flavor was candy sweetness, lots of carbonation, malty, dark fruits, caramel and surprisingly lingering hop bitterness despite the age.
Bottle. Dark brown, tan head. Aroma: Malt, yeast and alas cork. Flavor: Malty and yeasty. Low bitterness. Warming.

25 oz bottle, 2004 vintage, via Secret Santa Murphy (pdee), Christmas 05.  Pours a clear dark brown colored body under a fairly small very fizzy beige head that lasted forever due to the excess carbonation.  Aroma is classic Unibroue.  Lots of fruitiness, though with a slightly thicker malt presence than most of their beers, with lots of their characteristic yeast.  Notes of raison, plum, and coffee.  Flavor mirrors aroma, various dark fruits, lots of Unibroue yeast, even stronger on the raison and plum.  Lightly peppery on the finish.  Mouthfeel is identical to most of the other Unibroue beers Ive had.  Medium bodied with tons of fizzy prickly carbonation that makes for a foamy mess.  This is probably the beer that benefited more than any Ive had in a long time from being allowed to breathe for a long time.  Each of the three glasses I had out of this bottle were much better 45 minutes after pouring than directly after.  The extended time spent in my Chimay chalice really let alot of the carbonation blow off.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown from the bottle and appeared black and opaque in the glass with a huge almost soapy off-white head that was mostly lasting. There was beautiful carbonation and I could actually see the head building up from the bottom as it slowly disolved from the top. Lacing was fair. There was light malt aroma and some light yeast but plum, apple and red wine were the dominant odors. There was also a touch of alcohol. I loved the aroma, but it could have been a little stronger with less alcohol. There were heavy flavors of sweet, dark fruit (like figs) and a touch of chocolate with just a little bitterness and a short finish.  The flavor improved greatly as it warmed. The body was medium to full and both a little dry and a little syrupy with fizzy carbonation and a moderate alcohol finish. Great carbonation but not enough body. It was a little different than other Unis Ive had, but still had that special something that lets you know its a Uni.

750 bottle-This poured out to a dark,cola looking color with a huge tan head.The aroma was of malt mostly.The taste was also  malt,spices,like cloves,similiar to Aventinus with a slightly bitter finish.Great lacing for this beer.Good brew!

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 Dark pour with light tan head, larger than normal head.  Aroma of caramel and coffee with some faint fruit.  Taste of brown sugar, smooth for something with almost 11% alcohol.  Fantastic finish.

2004 bottle.  Poured dark.  No light come through.  HUGE head.  Slight tan head.  Calmed down quick.  Smells like Asti champagne.  Overly carbonated.  Tastes like dirty Belgian candy sugar.  Not a fan of this style or this beer.

750 shared with brie on christmas eve eve.  clove and apple flavors dominate... this is very sweet and the brown sugar flavor hides the 10.5abv... this is my kind of strong ale from a great fake belgain brewery in canadia

2004 Bottle.  Deep brown with a hint of red with a fizzy head.  Aroma of pineapple, cherry, and apple.  Taste has a lot of yeast to it with flavors of apple and cherry with some spices added in.  A tad thin, but overall a quality brew that I wouldnt mind having a bit more of.

Not as daunting as it would appear.  Smooth, and malty with a nice, clean finish.  Alcohol is well hidden.  I liked this a lot.  Unibroue always does me a solid unless its the 2006 Trader Joes beer, in which case they added nutmeg and ruined their perfect track record.  This was mighty fine though.
black with touches of red. beige head. smells like candysuagrs and yeast fruti very aromatic. taste of bread anise and fruit very nice

Pours a dark brown, thick liquid, and smells great.  Lots of malt, but a nice bit of fruit to balance out the dark malts.  Standard Belgian yeast flavors, with a tad bit more malts.  Not as extreme as you would expect based on the appearance.  Nice beer.

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with a massive tan head. Yeasty aroma with a bit of fruit. The taste and mouthfeel are interestingly close to Dr. Pepper. The taste is spicy with some licorice, plums, and the requisite Belgian yeast-imparted taste.

750ml Bottle. Good yeasty aroma with a slight currant hints around the nose. Pours a decent head that stayed with me till the end. Very smooth flavor with cherry aftertaste and full flavored. Goes great with steak. Good strong ale and one of the best Ive had from Unibroue.

licorice and plum on the nose.  Clean, full mouthfeel with significant effervescience.  blackcurrent and raisins on the finish.  pronounced sourness, but not unpleasant.  nice, but not up to the mark set by trois pistoles and la fin du monde.

[Bottle from Beermouth tasted with the hop-bros at Jess cosy inn.]

A little dissapointing beer, maybe the bottle was infected or just we have had to many beers at that moment. As Cab says, its sweet and dry in a boring way!

2004 750ml bottle, tasted on Nov 22, 2006.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a thick tan head.  Aroma of yeast and pretty strong alcohol, perhaps a hint of nutmeg.  Flavor is a bit maltey,  maybe nutmeg and cinnamon, and the alcohol is, shall we say, not too subtle.
Bottle from Beermouth. This one is not a balanced beer, it is sweet and dry and that is not in a nice way.
Deep amber/brown with nice slightly tan head. Caramel, malt, cane suger, toast and herbal. Nice body, but not very well balanced.

Brown with red notes. 
Aroma of roasted malt, molasses, chocolate, licorice and some acid.
Rocky flavour with notes of berries, spices, alcohol and almonds. Sweet with dry finish.

Bottled, 2004 vintage. Poured brown, with a thick, foamy medium-tan head, leaving lots of lace on the glass. The nose had notes of oak, spice, and cherries and the flavor was woody, fruity (cherries and apples), with a bit of spice (cinnamon?), and a hint of alcohol. The mouthfeel was soft and smooth and the finish slightly dry with just a hint of hops.
Sampled at an American Beer Tasting Event but unfortunately I forgot my notes. Some (very) dark fruits and a lot of spices (cardamom). Should be excellent for cellaring.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a small off-white head. Sweet malty yeasty aroma. Sweet malty yeasty flavor with hints of dark fruits and honey. Dry malty finish.

DBF 2005. Deep chestnut, low off white head and low condition. Low malt with a background iron tartness in the nose, gently fruity in the mouth with a gentle iron tartness and a lingering malty balsamic sub-Rodenbach finsih.

poured a very dark brown, almost black with a thick white head that disapated quickly.  aromas of dried fruits, spice, and sweet malt.  sweet and spicy taste that coats the mouth.  good finish with a nice bite.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: one of the fav uni beers . love the first time i had it 4 guys came to my bar drank it straight from the bottle ooh soo fun
Dark brown pour with small tan head. Aroma of plums and other fruits, including cheeries. Vinous. Some malts. Very complex. Slight alcohol burn. Dry, bitter finish. Very good.

I LOVED this beer.  i poured beuatifully.  It had a nice dark color.  The aroma was amazing, very sweet.  Once I drank this, it had the most amazing taste, sweet with fruit and yeast.  Very nice finish.  If I had 5 bottles of this stuff, theyd all be gone by now.  BTW, the high alcohol (10.5% ) is a little noticeable.  But this is an amazing beer.

750 ml bottle 2004 vintage  poured a hazy dark reddish brown with a large lasting amber head. Aromas of dark fruit, brown sugar and pepper. Palate was medium bodied. Flavors of plum, grape koolaid, pepper and a hint of spices with a warming finish.

Dark brown lasting head.  Aromas of nuts, malts, molasses, toffee, french vanilla but very well maintained.  Black berries, cherrys, brown sugar makes this dark beauty a rollercoster of fantastic flavors.  Bottles in 2005, this beer can age for a good 10 years...

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2009 Rerate; despite my previous rating, I have been wanting to rerate this one for a while.  Color was a dark brown color with a medium to large frothy head.  Nice Unibroue aroma; yeast, dark fruity, with some sweetness and molasses.  Well it definitely isnt terrible for me anymore; palate has definitely changed a bit.  Fruity, roasted malt, sweet malt, caramel and yeast; some nice spice in the finish.  Happy to have had this one again.

I really didnt like this. That is not too say that others will not like it alot.  Poured a dark brown, fairly large whitish head.  Carbonation was very evident.  Aroma was very strong of fruit, and also of malt.  Very strong taste of fruit and malt.  I couldnt put my finger on a taste that was very prevalent until I read some of the reviews.  The flavor was fig.  Not a huge fan.  Wouldnt drink again.

sampled from a 750, thanks Dan.  Pours dark brown with a big off white head.  Medium to high carbonation level, not as high though as a De Dolle.  Aroma is light chocolate, caramel malts, and lots of yeast.  Taste is a small amount of dark fruit, chocolate and caramel malt, earthy yeast, with a smooth finish.

Bottle. Very dark bown color with nice brown head. Woody, malty aroma, oak, fruits, figs, some yeast and vanilla. Smooth malty flavor, turning hoppy and a bit more aggressive after a while. Fruity notes, pepper and other spices.
Very nice, more than any others from this brewery perhaps. I like it very much, Maybe it is a little underrated. With a distiguishible sweet flavour, great malty aroma and good foam.

Pours extremely dark with somewhat of a medium head that disappears rather quickly. Flavor consists of malts and a fruity palate. Palate lingers just enough with a smooth finish. I was surprised by this one, didnt expect it to be so well rounded.

2005: Pours dark cola brown w/ medium spritzy froth. Aroma is malty. Full nectar w/ ample residual effers that explode on the palate. Strong flavors of fig, roasted coffee bean, dried stone fruit, easy tobacco tar, vanilla, ripe plumb and black cherry, stewed carrots, wood, cassis, old leather, iodine, cola. The strong oaky wood character overwhelms the other flavors and leaves you w/ fruity iodine and oak on the finish. Finish is long w/ slight bittering. Overall: a very complex brew with strong flavors that will improve with some age. Highly recommended.
Aroma: spiritous, malty and stone fruit. Appearance: cola black/brown, small flat patchy head. Flavour: spiritous, malty, complex fig and vitamin C. Palate: medium lingering malty and coconut.

Bottle. Dark brown color with off white head that didnt leave any lace. Smelled of dried fuits and malty molasses. Flavors included molasses, green apple, soy, and alcohol. Not a huge fan of this one.

Dark muddy brown, massive head. Yeasty and vaguely fruity aromas. As dark as this is, Im getting no chocolate/coffee flavours or aromas, so Im assuming there is no (or very little) roasted malt in here. Its all big bready yeast and dried fruits like raisins and prunes. Again, a nod to craftsmanship, but Im not the biggest fan of the style.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: In the bomber bottle at the Huber Haus Unibroue tasting. Pours a dark brown nearly black color with a fleeting tan head. Spicey, with a wine-like aroma. Strong alcohol burn to the palate. Raisins, dates, and plums add to the fruity wine flavor. Has a definite drying finish. Good stuff here.

A nearly black color, some purple-red highlights... had a head that lasted (literally) for hours.  Had the characteristic Unibroue aroma... a nice rich yeastiness with elements of fresh fruits (apples, pears, grapes, blueberries, blackberries), some light spiciness.  Dark, rich flavors of fresh fruits (blueberries, cherries, apples, pears), dried fruits (cherries, plums, raisins), yeast, citrus, spices, cooked fruits (apples, pears), malts, dark chocolate and something like fruit-flavored candy.  Absolutely amazing.  Very dense, very rich, definitely at the top end of the Unibroue line.

Great looking bottle, marked 2004.
<!-- p -->
Pours a dark brown with an off-white bubbly rocky and large head. Beautiful aroma of vanilla, prunes, whiskey and banana. The first mouthful was a little overcarbonated, but as the beer settled and warmed (even more than the serving temp of about 13degC)  a sweet alcoholic bouquet of oak, more vanilla and dried fruits came through. There was little hop flavours and the finish was remarkably clean and lacked any alcohol burn as Ive felt in so many belgians before. Overall, its not an amazingly complex beer, but gives enough to be interesting, whilst still maintaining an incredible balance. Fantastic

This beer LOOKS like coffee in the glass once the head and bubbles disperse.  Aromas of champagne, yeast, and dark fruit (figs, raisins).  The dry finish is substantial, but leaves a substantial amount of fruit on the tongue.  Rough, but light, mouthfeel.  Tastes of earth, brown bread, wine, raisins, plums and soda.  Maybe is bit too much carbonation prevents this great ale from being as smooth and flavorful as it could be.  Otherwise, no complaints.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2006 Pours dark brown almost black with a large effervescent white head that immediately dissapates to almost nothing.  Aroma focuses on dark fruits, with yeast notes, some sourness, very small amount of coffee.  Flavor focus on dark fruits, with a nice yeastiness and sourness in the finish.

2004 bottle and a perfect pick for rating #400 - Pours very dark brown, almost black - when held to the light there is a bit of a crimson hue.  There is a deep tan head that appears fizzy, but has some lasting to it.  Aroma has an emphasis on dark fruits - plum, fig, dark cherry.  There is also the Unibroue yeast, and some sharp vinious qualities that compliment the rich smoothness of the other flavors.  There are also some caramel and toffee notes as it warms.  The beer is medium bodied, lighter than expected, and smooth with semi-sharp carbonation.  The taste has a tone of dark fruit as described in the aroma.  Very smooth taste.  The mouthfeel gets thicker the warmer it gets as well as the carbonation taming down.  Lots of Belgium earthiness.  The malt is very dark and creamy.  Finish adds a bit of spice.  The spice and earthiness linger around for quite a while.  For 10.5% the alcohol is very well hidden.  Excellent beer.

dark, coffee-brown in color. head is off-white and quite fizzy. aromas: coffee, prune, raisins, yeast, vanilla. tastes like caramel, malt, coffee, pepper, prunes, plus a bit sour. body is a little bit thin, but leaves a pleasant warm feeling in my throat. quite enjoyable for sipping.

2004!..not as spritzy as most unis..more full if u will..------.i had seen this in a bar in austin for $18,i looked it up and put it in the back o my head.------- payday and me and a terrible showdown, just in new to my bottleshop.-----.well, $9.80 later and me winding down from my day.------.a 750ml with my name on it..-------.well, tight cork...good hard pop.-----..disappointing pour, but constent cocoa like head, puddle o foam if u will..------.solid in the aroma, uplifting berry like smell..-----.is quite a larry..------.it is a pleausure, a tad warm, the throat glows like a furnace, well, the complex flavours are abundant.-----.ThiS is a TOPDOG in the unibroue pound, it has bite, yet it is shiny and well trained and a clean bill of health, the things that make em up are tasty and clean.----.fruity and intoxicating ------...adult and merry...well, i think i like it..a good offering from the kuenks, and worth the money, in away, better than the 15 and more complex than most horses in the unibroue glue factory...--!

This beer is a real treat every chance I get to taste it. Ive had it several times now but still never a whole bottle to myself. Still I decided to review it because it always leaves an impression on me.

Appearance: Served a dark burgundy - black with hints of plumb purple color.

Smell: Dark fruits and port with lots of sweetness in the nose.

Taste: Red wine like a Cabernet and Port with loads of spices and fruits, plumb on the top. More sugar sweetness and caramel. Plenty of toastyness. There are also hints of woodiness and fusel alcohol coming through to warm the belly. A nice dry finish.

Mouthfeel: Solid mouthfeel, creamy and spicy. 

Drinkability: This is a perfect nightcap beer. Certainly a sipping beer but boy is it nice!

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

75 cl bottle. Very dark bown color, nice brown head. Woody, malty aroma, oak, fruits, figs, some yeast and vanilla. Smooth malty flavor, turning hoppy and a bit more aggressive after a while. Fruity notes, pepper and other spices. Sour but also malty in a quite strange mix. But its good, I liked it...
This poured very dark, with the appearance of a cola. Spicy and sweet, quite an array of flavors here. Not what I typically think of as a belgian strong ale, fantastic nonetheless.

750 ml bottle....sampled with my family after dessert.  Went well with some brownies.  Poured purplish/dark brown with a pepsi-like head.  Very sweet on the nose. Somewhat of a light to medium palate. Although I am not well-versed in these types of Belgians, I felt it was very well done.

A rich palate, loaded with so many flavors that I had trouble even beginning to name them. Chocolate, red wine? That just seemed like the tip of the ice berg. Alcohol was well hidden. Overall, a fantastic drink.

750 ml (2004)-  Poured very dark brown with a frothy tan head that fell quickly.  Sweet and spicy (like a ginger snap cookie)  with a slight hint of fruit.  The flavor throughout is good but the finish is "terrible", too pungent of an alcohol tastes that lingers a bit to long.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 Frothy tan head over a dark brown body.  Aroma typical of Unibroue, spicy and fruity.  Taste is almost port-like, with some additional medicine qualities (not in a bad way), very soft.  Smooth ending, nice spice with some light fruit.

Dark dark brown color with a large creamy light brown head. Sweet spiced aroma with some fruit shining through. Sweet fruity flavor, some molassas and spice in the end, somewhat warming from the high alcohol.

75-cl 04. Pours gorgeous dark brown with a big falling tan head. Overbearing pears and green apples on the nose. Almost caustically fizzy. Ginger, molasses, dried fig, and prunes on the mid-palate, with a puckery long sour finish.

75 cl bottle - 2004. Yeast at the bottom. Very dark reddish brown colour with a nice head. Lovely aroma of wheat, dried fruit, sourness, yeast and spices. Complex flavour with notes of dried fruit, spices and yeast. Ends up with a warm feeling from the alcohol.

(05.13.06) Sampled at DiCarlos Spring beer tasting event. Bottle.  10.5% ABV. Poured hazy brown with small white head. No discernable carbonation. Spicy sweet malt aromas. Medium bodied ale that starts with moderate malt sweetness and caramel, spicy (coriander?), fruity (dried orange peel?) flavors. Complex flavor character. Finished dry with light malt fade. An excellent drinkable Belgium-style ale.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2007 Found the notes, finally.
Aroma: malt (sweet), candisugar, chocolate caramel, dates, vinous, yeast.
Appearance: darkly reddish brown, halfclear. Thin, light beige yellow foam that sets quickly.
Flavour: bitter, foodish (dont know the right word), soylike, sweet, very full-bodied, vinous.
Palate: rough, thick.

opaque, black body with small off-white head...aroma is somewhat lambic and flemish in style (the three styles (including bel strong ale) seem very reminiscent of eachother sometimes...nice spice and citrus aroma with a kriek lambic backbone...flavor is of dark fruits (namely black cherry), spices, vinegar, figs, plum, and raison...nice bready aftertaste
Brown with light head.  Light spice intermixed with the malts.  Slightly sweet.  Alcohol taste bites a bit.  Needs to be thicker although not sweeter.

dark brown, w/ small head.  Aroma is good with malt, spices, and some fruit. Alcohol is noticable but not overbearing.  Flavor is sweet with spices, molasses undertones.  Rosted malt becomes more apparent as the bottle warms.  Definatly should be drank at room temp.

2004 vintage. I am impatient.

Dark brown, damn near black and completely opaque. Small brown head. Is this a stout? 

DEEP odor. Alcohol throughout, ripe fruit and a pile of herbs I will never know the proper names of. Black licorice is somewhere in there, along with allspice.

Alcohol. Wood. Spice. The flavor is even throughout and these three notes permeate everything. Intense. The aftertaste is sweet and dry, makes you crave for more.

Easily the strongest Unibroue Ive had. For as wicked as it is its pretty easy to drink, too.

Bottled in 2004. Poured a really dark brown-black with burgundy edges. Nice initial head that turned to a thin covering in minutes. Lacing was uniform (carbonation generated) and slid down the glass quickly. The aroma was yeasty, spicey (coriander in a beer this dark?), and mildly oaked. The the flavor featured oak, candi sugar, some dark fruits, and a bit of chocolate. First sip nailed me: the alcohol, very warming. Mouthfeel was moderately bodied but not thick. Enjoyable.
This is a great Belgian style brew.  Rich and fruity aroma, dark chocolate appearance and a rich and creamy head.   Would definatly buy again.

2004 Vintage. Despite it being overly carbonated, I enjoyed this one quite a bit. This is the most aged sample Ive had, and I wouldnt mind seeing what a few more years do to it. Its a rich, clove and allspice note on the nose leading into caramel and molasses. Lots of dark fruits, and then Belgian funk on the finish. I think this is the best of the Unibroue series.

This is my favorite brew produced by Unibroue. Pour a dark brown with an authentic Belgian style head which is hard to control. Typical Belgian style dark fruits rule this beer, but definitely done very well. This is a lip-smackin brew that will make you wish you had more once you finish your bottle. I highly recommend this beer. Again, as far as Unibroue beers go, this is my favorite.
Definitely belgium strong ale type, with a bit stronger alcohol finish than St. Bernardus or Chimay Blue.  Somewhat quickly disipating head, nice aroma.

This beer pours dark brown and entirely untransparent with a tan fizzy head thats persistent.  The aroma is sweet and bready with a taste thats malty with a very bready after-taste and that sweet spice taste that makes those unibroue beers so good.

Does Unibroue craft a bad beer? I mean everything Ive tasted from them has been top notch. This was no exception either. Exquisite in aroma and flavor. Malty, dark fruits, spice, and peppery. This is an exceptional beer. Im glad Ive got a few stashed away because in about 5 years this is going to be phenomenal.

This dark brown ale poured with a short tan head. This is a typical Belgian-style strong ale, with a full body and some alcohol taste. There is a slighty herbal finish, making it seem like a digestive, as the brewer suggests.

Bottle. Dark brown color with a large frothy brown head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Moderate tart fruit and spice aroma with an alcohol tone. Medium body with a sticky texture. Solid sweet roasted flavor with a sweet smooth finish of long duration. Solid well balanced strong brew.

Bottle.  Dark brown with mahogany highlights and a thin off-white head. Aroma of spices, malt and dark fruit. Medium creamy syrupy palate with very lively carbonation and a nice alcohol warmth. Flavor is mostly sweet and vinous, with notes of spice, dark fruit, anise and  molasses. As it warms up, chocolate and roast notes become more apparent.

i thought the other unibroues were much better at masking the alcohol than this one.  served a bit too cold, and a little too carbonated for the style i felt.  i thought this was boring, but the quality was nonetheless apparent.
A very fine strong ale.  Very yeasty flavour complemented with a hint of spice and very fruity.  As with all Unibroue beers very cloudy in the glass and very heady, but head disappears quickly.

Cloudy apperance.  Smells very fruity and a powerful alcohol aroma.  Can smell grapes and prunes too!  Carbonation tickles the top of my mouth.  Very sweet and fruity.  Dry, bitterness at the end.  Nice beer

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2008 (08/08... The latest issue of All About Beer rated this as a Biere de Garde, which I have to admit, mystifies me)  From a caged cork 750ml. brown bottle with a best before date on the back, 08/08/07, served at cellar temperature in a chalice. 

Made a good appearance, poured a opaque rudy/purple blackish brown with a fluffy tan head that settled into a thin foamy lacing, well carbonated, as you expect from Unibroue product.

Had a dry fruit, plums and raisins, and Maderia wine with whiffs of yeast and spice.

A dry, crisp from the malts, carbonated smooth medium bodied mouth feel, above average drinkability.

Very dry wine tasting, dry dark fruits and Maderia wine, a light spiciness from the hops and a dry yeasty and winey finish. The alcohol warmth is subtle, like in a decent wine.

A decent Belgian Strong Dark Ale, but no a great one, because of the high carbonation, a Unibroue trademark, I can see why some reviewers remark on the soda-like quality. Overall, dry tasting, which I like, with wine characteristics, along as you dont have to pay more than $8 a bottle, recommended for anyone exploring Belgian ales.

2004 bottle.  Pours a very dark amber.  Large and lasting tan head.  Aroma is very much like Trois Pistoles.  Unibroue house yeast, fruit, some sweet malts.  Flavor has a tinge of sourness, lots of fruit and yeast, spices, and just a hint of chocolate in there.  I find the chocolate to be a real nice touch.  Alcohol is barely detected.  This stuff is nuanced and subtle, yet powerful and richly fulfilling.  This would be a fantastic drink with or after a nice dinner.

Thin creamy, coffee coloured head. Dark brown in colour. Thick, high powered nose of raisened malts, classic Belgian strong ale in style. Good lift and power. Follows up very well in the palate with excellent malt action (heavy, rustic, sweet, authentic) but never gets heavy going despite the 10%. A very good effort from this solid Canadian marque.
2004 Bottle shared w/ John & Elisa.  Dark fruit alcoholic aroma.  Nice fine tan head - tight.  A like-brown beer.  coriander heavy-sweet. Common belgian brown, easy going.

750ml - 2004 vintage - Aroma is slightly mettalic.  Yeast, milk chocolate, candi sugar, some dark fruit and spice.  Pours deep dark brown with a medium off white head and good lacing.  Flavor is chewy yeast with some dark fruit, grape, and spice.  Hides the 10.5% very well.  Palate is sticky and tart but gets smoother as it warms.  Another solid Unibroue brew.

Pours a very dark, almost black amber  at first glance it looks like a stout with a good sized tan head that dissipates into nothing rather quickly.  What immediately jumped out at me was the very lively carbonation that was audible from a few feet away.  The aroma, while not overpowering is hints of chocolate and light fruit. Taste is VERY distinctive, immediately I thought oak and more oak.  This really tastes like a carbonated port with hints of grape and a well placed spicyness..  The carbonation is so intense as to be annoying, as the flavor is much more reminicent of port than beer.  Okay as it warms, the carbonation dissipates a bit.  Really, Im shocked more ratebeer descriptions dont mention port and oak.  Also, a well aged burgandy.  Really one hell of an impressive and unique tasting beer.  Mouthfeel is light, and as I said, lively carbonation.  Ive gotta say, as a wine fan, I love this stuff.
2004 bottle here.  Thick brown head of small bubbles with a dark but not cloudy color.  It drinks more like a wine, giving a nice warm hug to the brain of the imbiber.

2004 bottle  dark pour , looks like coke with a big tan head that lasts and good lacing. aroma of sweet grapes. flavor is sweet, spicy ,malty with a  dry finish.
very smooth with a  medium mouthfeel and a slight alcohol burn  good stuff

Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. This beer has a bite, but goes down so smooth as the bite dissolves in your mouth, its appearance is compareable to coca cola, dark fat tan lasting head, good healthy body & flavor, this is very drinkable ( i mean sipable) another good Unibroue beer.

bottle. Deep brownish plum with a lasting tan head. The aroma is vinous, sweet, with clove, grapes, various spices. The flavor is robust and complex. Great spiced character with a juicier body and even some slightly roasty coffee-esque notes. Wonderful balance all around.  Unibroue seems to have brews of this style down to a science.
Good Belgian style beer with a fuiity chocolate taste with some spicy after taste. It pours nicely with a thick tan head.
A great beer. Dark brown. Fine big head. Flavor is sweetish, malty and perhaps a bit spicy. Flavor mainly sweet and malty.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2006 2004 bottling.  Pours a rich reddish black with a good white-tan head settling to something rather thin in a minute or two.  The nose on this beer is unlike most things Ive drank.  It has a dry fruitiness (perhaps raspberry?) that reminds me more of sparkling wine than beer.  I also pick up chocolate, yeast, raisins and a good deal of bread.  No alcohol, but a touch of vinegar?  The palate is smooth and creamy, borderline luxurious.  There is also a very interesting alcohol heat in the back of the throat up to the sinuses sort of phenomenon, rather than a alcohol in the mouth to the stomach... weird, but nice!  This is the major selling point of the beer, to me.  The flavor is intense and complex.  First that dry fruity champagne alcohol flavor with a bit of sweetness.  Theres a bit of roast upfront that increases in intensity into strong charcoal as the flavors develop. This beer is also rather sour, which I generally dont find becoming of a brew, but I tried to keep this out of my flavor rating and channel it into overall.  This beer being unlike anything Ive yet to try, I just dont know how to rate this beer fairly.  I will definitely revisit this one.

Dark red brown color with a tan head.  Nice aroma- mostly chocolate and raspberries.  Flavour has a bitter fruitiness- grapes, plums.  Some caramel.  Spicy.  Very rich flavour.  The fruitiness lingers.  A unique flavour- I wasnt blown away at first, but now Im really a fan!

Exquisite bouquet of yeast, bread & raisins.  As inviting nose as Ive ever come across, very much in the Belgian style.

Nice dark brown, clarity excellent good head retention.

Very rich, malty plum & raison with bitterness to balance but very much in the background,

Way too easily quaffable, people could hurt themselves with this one. 

Compared Unibroue La Terrible with a three year old Rochefort 10 and very surprised the Terrible was more to my liking, go figure!  The key factor was its Belgian characteristics, aroma, flavour, presentation and sheer enjoyment of brew in perfect balance & proportions.

2004, 750 ml bottle. Dark brown pour with thin, quickly disappearing head. A host of aromas greet you  sweet plums, raisins, malts. The flavor starts with a hint of moldy earthiness that gives way to sweetness  figs and sugar  and then a slight bitterness. The alcohol is hidden everywhere but at the end and even then it is a subtle warming. Lively carbonation in a medium body.

750ml bottle.  Thich, black opaque hue.  Thick tan head.  The nose has notes of roasted coffee, plums, raisins, bittersweet chocolate and a slight alcohol burn.  Full and sweet with a bitter finish.  Initial is lively carbonation with a sugary sweet malt caramel flavor.  Thick and cola, vinuous, cloying, port and shery, raisins, whiskyish...Third glass, and still lively with a hissing carbonation.  More burn in the nose.  Cane sugar note.  Bready and yeasty.  Heavy yet silky.  Full yet smooth.  Elegant and alcohol.  Its a sipper.  Sweet and bitter.  Cloying and delicious!
Damn, this is a complex beer to analyze. Nice spicy, dark chocolate, caramel taste, great dark appearance, 10.5% alcohol but easy to drink, drink it in a Baron glass, you wont regret it.

2004- 750 mL bottle corked and caged. Smells and tastes kind of like a wine. Aromas of coriander and cloves spice it up a bit. There are also aromas of plums and other fruits. The taste is of spices, fruits, and still has a malty flavor. This is my first belgian ale and I have to say I was pleasantly suprised by the complexity.

Poured a very dark brown, almost black.  Rather fizzy, medium sized off white head.  Aroma has lots of malt in it. Taste is also very malty with the slightest bit of fruit in the finish. Im not sure what kind it is, possibly apples. Somewhat dry, hoppy finish. Wonderful beer.

2004 bottle. Pours dark brown/mahogany into a trappist glass.  Medium sized bubbles quickly recede to receive small constant flow from the bottom.  Fig and bread aromas. Tangy, fizzy and medium bodied with a dry lasting finish.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2011 Plastic sample cup at the Penn Museum.  This was very good.  Rich brown with yummy fruits.  More ooomph than I remember from the Trois Pistoles.  Will need to secure a specimen for dissection.  3/18/11 - 25.4 oz bottle, 2004.  Nose is dates, figs, mushrooms and damp forest floor, but in a good way.  Body is medium but feeling thin with dull carb.  Taste is kind of like the smell but more earthy, musty with just a hint of burnt caramel and bitter clove.  It would be unfair to change my rating for a brew 4 years past the suggested drink by date.  This would have fallen to a 3.4.  I can however state that this is not one i would cellar for more than a few years.
Dark like a good porter.  Has a lot of flavor but still very smooth.  Hint of chocolate and coffee would make it a good after dinner drink.

Many thanks to my good friend Beerblockaid for this 750 bottle (2004 version).  What a wonderful treat to enjoy on St Pattys day and rate for my 300th brew.  The pour was dark and thick and foamed up a huge fluffy tan head which dropped away to a thin skim, and later disappeared completely.  The aroma was sweet and inviting with apple and dark fruits.   The flavor was yummy, each sip makes you want another..  dark fruits, banana, and cola  a bit of sweetness but not overly so..   Full, rich flavor, almost chewy but not quite.  Clean finish with a bit of spice (clove) and dryness.   You get the Unibroue yeast flavor but not over the top as in the Trois Pistoles.  Its fairly complex but this is not the notable characteristic.   The most notable thing about it is that its absolutely delicious without being too sweet or bitter or anything else.  Beautifully balanced.   The alcohol will sneak up on you in a hurry but you wont notice until you are already buzzed.  It doesnt taste like 10.5% ABV.  World class and awesome.  Another truly spectacular brew from Unibroue!

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2006 Pours a deep dark brown color, fully sedimented and cloudy with a giant light brown frothy head that shows medium retention.
Aroma is strong and spicy with predominant malt and yeast and notes of coffee, caramel, coriander and cask wood. Very complex.
Flavor is moderately sweet and strongly bitter with a bold initial attack and an awesome and powerfull finish. It develops new flavors with warming. Taste is as complex as the aroma.
Good thick mouthfeel with a syrupy consistence and a long finish. Well disguised alcohol. Overall its a great, complex and well balanced example of a Belgian Strong Ale.

750 ml Corked Bottle shared with  <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/View-User-31163.htm&g

Corked and caged bottle with a best before date of 08-08-2007. Poured a large sized tan fizzy head with sparse lacing, carbonated, opaque, and a dark brown hue. Malty, caramel, sweet, spices, clove notes, alcohol, and some banana notes. Flavor was sweet, malty caramel, spicy, and vinuous but not overly so. Tingly mouthfeel. Medium body. Another fine brew from this brewer and IMO worth a try.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2006 Beautiful beer. Reddish to dark brown (from bottom to top) crowned with a big and frothy light brown head. It smells of malt, yeasts and spices, berries and coffee hints and also a veiled alcohol presence. It tastes initially sweet but ends more bitterly and alcoholic.  It has a light to medium body softly carbonated with a sirupy texture. The aftertaste is of alcohol (though soft) and yeast. I preffer the Trois Pistoles. <FONT SIZE=1>Bottle shared with <a href = http://www.ratebeer.com/View-User-30044.htm> Panzerfaust  </FONT>

This beer offers an aroma consisting of wheat and malt with a hint of cherries and dates in the background.  It is a brown solution that resides under a good sized opaque colored head and has good lacing.  The taste is of wheat, malt, yeast, dates, and toffee.  The aftertaste is of yeast and alcohol.
Dark red-ish brown. Huge head, doesnt last long, though. Sweet, malty aroma. Malty, somewhat dry flavour with notes of alcohol and berries.  Will probably improve with age.

Bottle. Dark brown, rich tan head. Fruity and yeasty aroma of prunes, black currant, blackberries, almond, nut- shells, chocolate and anise. Nice. Yeasty flavour of dried plums,  fresh baked white bread, nuts and berries. Yeasty arftertaste with notes of alcohol, spices and black berries. Tasty, but I expected more.

Strong, fruity and yummy aroma, though apple juice was a bit too prevelant. A touch of yeast and spice. Pitch black pour with a huge head. Very burgundian in flavor with thick molasses and grapes, spice. Palate was a bit obtuse and in your face. Tone the palate back a bit and this would be a real world class beer. Just falls short, but still great ;)
2004 on cage, 750 mL: Pours a decent-sized head, tan-brown, diminishing.  Black in color.  Mild aroma, sweet, slight perfume, coffee.   Taste of sweet thick molasses, very fizzy, alcohol.

Pours a very dark reddish hue, with quite a bit of head. Smells fruity, and sweet. Reminds me of a fruit wine, also a bit sour. Thinner body, goes down smooth. Strong concoction as well, tho not so noticeable whilst drinking. An outstanding brew.
Deep brown color, large tan head. Champagne aroma, molasses and strawberry flavor. Smooth texture but the alcohol comes through.
a great beer! wonderfully canadian. a bit strong but in a good way. recommended highly for the beer enthusiast!
"2004. Poured a dar dark black with slight red edges. Nice head. Aroma was of yeast and spices not sure which and some oak. The flavor was of oak dark fruits and some chocolate. Nice beer. "

dark slightly sweet barley wine flavor. strong intense chocate with an intense alcohol lingering. smooth. this is the best unibroue that i have had. a world class ale. wow. this is the opposite of terrible. try it. amazing.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2006 From bottle.  Pours a dark, dark brown, with just the faintest hints of red when held up to the light.  Foamy tan head leaves some lacing on the sides.  Nose is very sweet, with dark fruits and yeasts abounding.  Flavor has some dark fruits, with raisin and pear showing up as well.  Great mouth feel and a little alcohol in the finish.

Dark, opaque brown-black color with a medium tan head.  Sweet aroma of champagne, alcohol, candy sugar, and fruit.  Flavor of dark malts, alcohol and dark fruit.  Medium bodied with excellent carbonation that tingles the tongue.  Chocolate coffee finish.  Very nice.

Bottle, 2004 edition.  Dark brown body with medium off white head.  Beautiful champagne-like bottle.  Aroma of champagne, peaches, strawberries.  Flavor of biscuits, strawberries, molasses, and alcohol.  A bit tingly in the mouth.
Bottle, 2003 edition.  Pours dark brown with big beige head.  Aroma is complex with dark fruits, caramel, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor much the same.  Well balanced and with good body.  Fine beer.

bottle, 2004 edition. very good, pours dark dark brown. nice active head. aroma of plum and raisins with a hint of alcohol. taste is similar. flavors such as apricot and plum and such predominate, very nicely balanced. has an almost wine-like character. some alcohol is present in the flavor but its not bad at all. makes your warm very qickly, one bottle will put a nice smile on your face.

Thanks to winkle for this fine gem.
750ml corked bottle.

Dark ruby brown iin colour with small white head, aroma of malty choclates. Flavours of rasin and honey. Warm mouth feel, lmost port like.
Very pleasant.
Very very dark - aroma of plums and dark malts.  Flavor is moderatley sweet with some complex flavors - raisins, yeast & candy sugar.  Fairly thick body.  Finish is just a hint sour.

Terrible pours to a very deep brown, to black color with a thick and creamy white head and a lively carbonation. When held to the light, deep mahogany hues shine through this dark and wonderful ale. The nose on this beer is fantastic, with big aromas of fruity and spicy yeast, roasty dark malts, sweet malt, and peppery alcohol. The palate is firm on the tongue with lots of big sweet malty and fruity flavors, paired with roasted barley notes, and most spicy yeast flavors that dance on the tongue. Terrible finishes with more sweet malt, fruit, and yeasty spice up front, then ends with a soothing, warming, peppery burn that lingers. 

Yet another world class brew from Quebecs Unibroue. Clearly this brewery is one of the best on the planet, and they truly rival the Belgians, when it comes to brewing up styles like Terrible, which is based on a Belgian Abbey Ale. It can be enjoyed young, or cellared like a fine wine, and can be aged for a number of years. Terrible is marketed in corked 750 ml brown bottles that retail for $6-$7, in the good beer stores where it is sold. It is a perfect dark ale to sip and enjoy on a cold winters night, and works very well with hearty dishes, or strong and sharp cheeses. Try it with a Montreal classic, a "Smoked Meat" sandwich, or perhaps roast beef, or prime rib.

Another at the tasting...I was a bit buzzed by the time I drank this.  Pours much more dark and creamy than any of the other unis Ive had.  Much more malty and heavy than other unis as well.  Didnt have quite the character of some of the aged bottles I had last night...but I did enjoy the heavier taste.

750 mL corked bottle; stored for an estimated 3 to 4 months sitting on top of the refrigerator in a light-exposed wine rack, sideways.  Pours a deep, dark purple/ruby with a large but quickly dissipating light brown, creamy but fizzy head.  Aroma is suspectly Unibroue-ish like every one of their beers Ive had to date; yeast, dark fruits, dark malt, and detectable alcohol.  Flavor is similarly dark but with some sharp, bright sweetness; alcohol is not present in the flavor, but it warms the throat and stomach and the nose during exhale; finish is just a tough flat (kind of like Diet Coke) with a lingering, slightly bland aftertaste.  Like every Unibroue, its too fizzy and it froths up in the mouth to create a huge but thin mass of bubbles; this makes it feel too thin, yet the sugariness makes it too sticky.  Overall, this is a solid beer and a good Belgian; much better is available, however.
750ml bottle-pours a light tan head with cloudy dark brown color.  Aroma is malt.  Taste is malt, slightly sweet, nutty.

Great.  THis has tons of flavour, body, mouthfeel, just really complex things that dont happen in normal beer.
It has nice balence between the malt and the hops, its smooth, but has a nice lingering bitterness, it also has a rich complexity that isnt available in most beers.

from the bottle served at cellar temp. date stamped september 9th 2003. poured deep mahogany with a light tan head that left some lacing. aroma musty a sourness, malts, caramel, chocolate, strong presence of alcohol, woody. flavor wow had a hard time just picking the 1st thing I tasted got so many differant thing, caramel, honey, dark fruits, raisins, alcohol, malts, chocolate toffee. got some sourness and bitterness all in a good way. this aged very well.

Cage stamped 2004
Deep, syrupy brown with a fizzy, tan head that held as a soft film. Aroma is sour & woody as a Belgian brown with bready yeasts and cola. Creamy & bitter with woodsy sourness, the flavor occasionally erupts with a sugary sweetness. Entertaining.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462<font size=-1>
Meilleur que La Fringante, elle est plus chaleureuse et plus savoureuse. Comme La Fringante, elle est pas facile à trouver car elle est disponible à S.A.Q.

Bottle purchased at Wine Warehouse, Charlottesville. Pours nearly black with a small head. Malty nose, some sourness in there, some alchohol present as well.  Flavor is sweet maltiness and alchohol. Lots of both. Too much of both for me.

another great one from unibroue. i could drink this for breakfast, but then i could probably not make it to work. had this at the end of a night of drinking other tasty brews and it really put the cherry on top i hate to be so cliche, but...who am i kidding, i love it! alcohol hidden well like all unibroues.

Bottle: Pours dark black with ruby tones when held to the light. A medium foamy off white head fades to a thin cap.
Aroma- sour burnt malt smell. Fruity, yeasty,  alcohol  tones come through upon closer scrutiny. 
Excellent balance in the alcohol flavour.
Flavour is dominated by a sourness with a raisin/plumy fruit flavour underlying that. Some linger alcohol comes through in what is otherwise a pretty clean finish.

Pours deep and dark with a small, tan head that fades quickly. Nose is fruity, vinous and plesantly sour. Flavor is muted; slightly tart and wine-like at first, then a rush of malty backbone. Malty, fruity lingering finish. Slight alcohol warming but very well hidden overall.

Bottle date 9/9/03: Poured a very dark brown with a small cream colored head.  Aroma was sweet and malty.  Caramel, raisins, some chocolate, yeasty and estery.  Flavor was malty and semi-sweet.  More fruityiness and chocolate notes.  Soft carbonation.  Starts with a medium body but finishes a little thin.  nice warming sensation.
Robe noire surmontée dune mousse blanche persistente. Arômes de porto, de levure et de fruits rouges. Saveurs de porto, de boisé, de fruits rouges et de levure.
Full sweet maltiness to the max. Unfortunately, I think too much so. Could be a bit more balanced, imo. Alcohol is hidden very well. Good beer but probably one I wont buy again.

750ml corked bottle. Black, thinning to reddish brown at the edges, with a dense tan head. Aromas of dark fruit, dry dark molasses, burnt toast, coffee, and yeast. Flavor mimics all of these well, with an overall dryness and alcohol warmth in the finish. Medium body and not as thick a mouthfeel as I expected. "... a pleasant alternative to coffee."-- Agreed, especially after dinner, though I cant see it replacing my morning java!

Bouteille-Une ale de type belge brun foncée aux reflets rougeatre avec une mousse consistante et restante. Bon goût fruité ainsi que quelques nuances subtiles.Bottle-A brown strong belgian ale with some reddish reflections. Strong consistant head and fully lasting. Good fruity taste with some subtily in the after taste.

Bottle. A small milestone: my 500th rating! I think this is a worthy beer for this occasion. Pours a brownish-black with red hues and a huge slowly diminishing fizzy light-brown head. Looks perfect. Nice aroma of yeast, fruit, malt, brown sugar, spices and alcohol. Fantastic flavour of caramel, dark fruit, yeast, malt, spices, some chocolate, a touch of alcohol  and more -- so complex and delicious. Alcohol is extremely well hidden, it goes down sooo easy that its almost dangerous. Medium to full bodied. My favourite Unibroue and an amazing beer!

bottle from bryan. thanks cuz. drunk on thanksgiving. dark brown color. sweet and carbonated. tastes of dark fruits like plum and currant. commercial description is right, it would be nice as an after dinner drink if it came in a normal size instead of the bomber that it is.
UPDATED: JAN 5, 2006 Pours a very dark brown with a creamy head. Aroma of malt a dark fruits. Tastes malty with hints of cherry and fig.

Not sure Ive ever really had something quite like this.  Pours dark brown with a large off-white head.  Aroma of dried fruits like grapes and figs.  Tastes a lot like Trois Pistoles but with a little more kick.  There was some noticeable wine flavor.  Interesting, to say the least.  Dont think I could stand to drink the whole 750 ml botle.

The blackened mahoganey body is a cautionary prelude to this beast of a Belgian.  The aroma has a real red grape juiciness, quite sweet and esthery.  A layer of rich maltiness supports the fruitiness, which at times gets out of hand in the body.  More grape and cherry sweetness saturates the body, which also notes some woody, earthy tones.  I could have handled a bit more malt to balance the fruity sweetness, or maybe some aging would smooth this out and make it near excellent.  Yet another original brew from this great brewery.

nice, light yet full-flavored.

An easy to drink variant of Unibroues other fine beers, not as intense as trois pistoles, not as light as chambly

Pours very dark, almost opaque with some faint ruby highlights. Do not recall any other Belgian Dark Ale this black in color. Fizzy, big-bubbled head thinned out to a nice durable whispy cover. Somewhat restrained, but pleasant aromas of dark fruits, cherrys and yeast. Even with the typical lively carbonation for this style, the beer presents a full body and chewy mouthfeel. Rich sweet flavors of dark figs, raisins, cherries, dark rum and yeast make a presence. The 10.5% is well balanced and unobtrusive but quite warming and stealth. Finishes sweet and slick, but in no way cloying. Ive read previous reviews where this release from Unibroue is somewhat hit or miss, but I think I got a nice hit with this one.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2008 [bottle - corked and caged 750 ml - 2004 vintage] Dark in color. Almost black. Some red highlights and a fizzy head. Nice and pleasant aroma of yeast, citrus, malts and some fruits. The taste has lots of citrus and tang in the beginning with a yeasty and malty middle and a warming alcohol finish. The finish even has a little bit of cherries and apples at the end.

2004 vintage.  This beer had a moderately malty and yeasty aroma, with some definite cherry.  Poured a decent creamy light brown head that completely disappeared.  The body was dark brwon, almost black.  Initial flavor was very sweet with a moderate, average finish.  Taste was dry and syrupy with lively carbonation.  Didnt really taste the alcohol until the finish.  I dont think this bottle changed for the better after a year or so in the cellar.

2004 bottle.  Pours to a huge fizzy, loud sounding tan head that disapates rather quickly.  The body is a dark brown/red with a visible hue from the light source in the room.  The aroma is cherries, amaretto, plums, green raisins, and grape juice.  The flavor is an earthy port wine that got some powdered sugar spilled on top.  Plums, light chocolate, pre-ground (not fresh) pepper, light decaying wood.  The palate is sweet, hugely carbonated.  As it warms up, the palate is more tolerable.  This is a well-made brew, however.
Good strong beer.  Less forceful than other strong ales Ive, but less alc.  Get a couple, 1 is just getting started.

750 ml bottle.  I didnt care for this beer at all.  Pour very dark brown with virtually no head. Very light aroma of cherry and other fruits. I noted cherry and other fruits in the flavor.  With the high alcohol content, this really reminded me of the liquid cough medicine I had as a kid.  I realize this beer is rate very highly, but this one is definitely not to my liking.

Pours ruby red with a thin tannish head.  Smells of figs, plums, raisins, light notes of sherry and grapes.  Taste is buttery with nice autumn berries and local fruits.  Finish is warming with a nice tinge of tanginess.
Bottle at The Map Room.  Pours a nice dark, rich looking reddish brown.  Lots of dried fruits in the aroma.  It came off a bit too sweet for me.  A good brew none the less.

2004.  Pours dark brown/black and comes out a lot like sparkling wine with a bubbly head that settles thin to non existent.  Sweet and fruity aroma, raisins and plums comes to mind.  More fruitiness in the taste, cherries and reminds me of apple juice a little.  There is a little roastiness in the finish similar to coffee.  Thin and carbonated mouthfeel. Im getting that warm alcohol feeling in my stomach.  Overall a pretty easy to drink Belgian Strong...just wish it wasnt as carbonated.

Man, this is a special brew.I think this one was a 2003?? Didnt have 2004 on it. Pours a reddish brown and the aroma is amazing.Tons of raisins and other dark fruits.Some spices also.I have had some Belgian Strongs that were absolute shit but the flavors here were outstanding.I have been saving this for this rating # 500.
Bottled. Pours a dark brown, with a tan head. Aroma is sweet, roasted and fruity. Taste is roasted malts, sweet and spicy.

Beautiful, muddy and nearly black in color with a deep tan hued and actively bubbling cloisters for the head.  Intoxicating aroma of concord grapes, plums, shiraz, cloves, pepper and chocolatey Fruity Pebbles.  Flavor impresses with plum skin and pressed raisins.  Spicy pepper and cloves coalesce with a vinous chocolate body.  Hearty, rich and spicy.  Mildest hint of whole wheat banana bread and sweet cherries.  Substantive, tingly and far reaching palate feel, actively effervescent, but well in-tune with the other elements.  Finishes with dark chocolate covered raisins, peppered grain and dark cigar unfoldings.  Quel formidable.

Sweet, tart fruit smell.  Berries, raisins, and other fruits.  A very complex nose to go along with a complex taste.  Let me tell you this one aint Terrible at all.  The flavor was crisp at first then we got into all the complexities if the taste.  It was sweet and fruity, mainly grape with what I thought was a hint of mocha.  The two flavors complimented each other very much.  It was black in color and glowed red in the light and was topped off with a chocolate colored head that faded quickly.

Pours black with a thin head. Aroma is weak, but the aroma that does exist is of dark fruits. Initial taste is very fizzy, then the beer settles down and you can taste some dark fruits like plums and the like. Oveall a good beer, however I am not a big fan of fizzy beers so its not really for me.
Complex aroma, with hints of figs, cloves, cherries and rasins.  Dark body, thick head.  Sweet, fruity tones with a hint of chocolate.  Clean finish.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2010 100th rating. Pours brown/black with a redish tint. Head is initially large and bubbley, but quickly dies off. Aroma is fruit and clove, I also can pick up the ABV. Flavor is licorice, dark fruit (prunes, raisins), clove, sweet and malty. Body is medium. Nice mouthfeel, light and sparkling, long finish. Very clean, 10.5% is well hidden.
not the best name in the world; the beer is a bit better than the name.  dark brown, lively carbonated.  aroma of raisins, chocolate and alcohol.  sweet and bitter, cloying.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2007 A beer or beer maker must be extremely arrogant to give his product an insulting appellation and expect it to sell well.  Isnt there something in the Bible about God raising the humble?  I chose to engage in a bit of sacrilege and raised this arrogant bottle of blackish brew from my fridge instead.  I thought that I could, perhaps, force it to repent its wicked ways.  Not only did this Unibroue beer seem arrogant, but its neck was a dark gothic spire and its attitude dark and brooding.  It was harboring a secret, rubbing its hands around a bloody knife or binding its mouth from telling secrets.  An uncorking cum exorcism did nothing but serve my nostrils adumbration of the flavor.  Nothing to do then, but serve myself a generous cup of this devilish liquid and make what I can of it.  The liquids edges (if such things are real) glow with a bloody red when held to light, and relax when brought back to shadow.  The smell performs a slow and mournful twist, intimating vegetables and dark fruits.  Inside the beer itself lies a supine collection of deep flavors like, raisin, molasses, malts, and wood.  Most comforting among these tastes was a lone hero, a glimmer of yellow light in a cubic sea, a cavalier apple-wood taste that shone through when the sheer weight of the darker flavors threatened to mass together and bury me.  These flavors, even when pushed away by the chivalric apple-wood, hardly move.  The beer is macabre by its personality, and any vibrant displays on its part could be interpreted either as a brewmasters fluke or an odd case of an undead beer  curiously still, but characterized by episodic fits of bright, shining flavor.

[22 oz. bottle] Pours a creepy black color, with barely any carbonation at all. At first, I was wondering if something was wrong. Then, once I tasted it, I was greeted with strong malt and alcohol flavors, along with raisins, cloves, coffee and dark chocolate. One hardly gets overpowered by the 10.5% ABV. This is definitely an interesting beer from Unibroue. Im glad to have it as my 100th rating.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2005 The ominous darkness of this bottle promised an exciting reviewing session. I was not let down by the pour: a sinister black hue topped of a fizzy tan crown that dissipated quickly into the void. A foreboding atmosphere accompagnies the first whiff. Many aromas intertwine and interact as you inspect the nose. Dark malts and fruits echo each other and call for a sip. I resisted as I could, and tried to analyze all these sensations. Roasted coffee, dark chocolate and oak dominate the background while blackberries, raspberries and apples mingle with salted butter, biscuits and toast. The first taste was surprisingly uneventful. Very few of the fragrances I had recognized were noticeable and a large malt profile seemed to quench all pretenders. Roasted sugars and coffee reign terribly over the flavor of this brew giving it a stout-like quality. The mouthfeel is slightly redeemed by the velevety smooth palate that finishes dry and salty. I was a bit disappointed by the second part of this beer - maybe I was expecting too much. Not my favorite Unibroue.
750. Nice dark brown in color. Light bubbly head, went down fast. Aroma of dried fruits such as plums, raisins, and chocolate. Taste of plums a bit sweet but finishes creamy.

This reminds me aof a trappists ale.  But its dark plum fruitiness is excellent.  VERY smooth - to point of almost no carbination.  This is a great drinking beer.  Its barely a beer - but its good.

Ver dark brown pour, aroma of dark fruit, yeast and alcohol. Very smooth mouthfeel, some plum, pumpernickel, toffee and quite yeasty. Sweet finish with alcohol punch. I thought this was an elegant creation, when sipped as intended it serves the purpose very well.

Bottle with 2003 on the cork.

Pours an opaque dark brown, bordering on black. Thin tan head, no lacing and quickly no head. Smells of dark fruit. Oaky and vinuous.

Taste is fruity, blackberry and ripe plum. Oaky and vanilla underneath. Licorice and caramel. Rich caramel malt. Sticky but a refreshing finish takes that away. Yummy.

Saved this badbwoy for my 200th (2005) rating!!! Chocolate covered dark fruits and bananas baked over a soft, chewy loaf of bread. Clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, you name it, its got it.
