The alchohol is pretty big on this one, but its complexity really hides it well. Terrible would be Mugato covering a Chic song...this shit is fantastic!! Unibroue must have got a hold of some disenchanted monks from Pomeral, switched them over to beer, and the rest is history.
750. Pours a dark brown color with a light off white head. Nose is yeasty, bit of funk, some light dried fruit notes.  taste is malty, sweet, bit of dough. Fizzy palate.

Bottle (750ml).  Poured dark brown-black with an average foamy light brown head that lasted for a little while.  Aroma of bread-dough yeast, spices (cloves, cinnamon), apple, raisins, sweet roast malt, wee bit of alcohol.  Taste is stewed prunes, spices, roast brown sugar malt, alcohol, other dark fruits, bready yeast, maybe a hint of chocolate - lovely.  Mouthfeel is very lively yet creamy, cant fault it.  Another home run from Unibroue - note to Sleeman: DONT CHANGE THIS BEER!

Dark, dark brown body with bubbly light brown head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity, slightly smoky, just a little yeasty and touch of alcohol.  Sweet, fruity (plum), and sugary flavor, with a sugary aftertaste and a very small hint of alcohol.  Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2007 750 ml bottle of 2004.  Expensive it was, but worth every penny.  This may be one of the best beers I have ever tasted.  Black as the inside of a cave, rich with a moderate, but long lasting head.  The rich flavor and aromas are like nothing else I have ever encountered.   I am not sure what is there it is integrated so well. Fruit, caramel, spices? This is the one all craft beers should aspire to be like.    

Update: Just opened a bottle of the 2005 edition.  Just as good as ever.  I am sorry it is gone and will have to try to track down some more.

Fantastic Belgian-style beer. 2005 bottle. Pours almsot as black as a stout, with a large but quickly dissipating head, and in my case, a lot of lacing. Smells to me like all the Beligian beers basically smell like, but with a darker/smokier hint. Tastes just great, like a strong Belgian crossed with a sweet stout (if that sounds great to you...). Some harshness fades as it warms up. I could drink this all day, but then Id be dead, cuz its strong, or at least broke, cuz I think this was about $10/750 ml bottle at the "discount" store at Foster and Clark.

Added note: Im drinking this tonight to prove/disprove my theory that really good, strong beer/wine can wipe away a cold if you drink it early on in your cold with lots of water. To see how my experiment turned out, send me a message....

2003 bottle.  ive had this one for more than a year, and i could no longer resist the temptation of trying it.  pours out almost black in color with a small head that goes away really quick leaving almost no head at all.  taste is sweet, malty, smooth, and refeshing.  since i saw this one of the beer that NC will be seeing soon, i had to go on and drink it, and damn this is a really great beer.  one of my new favorites for sure.

Bottled, sampled at Ölbaren during the RBESG -05. 
Almost black in colour. "Dark flavours" - vineous, tidbitty, prune, and peppery. Full body, with sweet malt but very balanced.

750 ml bottle.  Poured a very nice brown with red tints.  Head was fizzy and lasted quite a while .  Lacing was minimal however.  Aromas of plum and currant.  Flavors were a little more complex.  While the plum and currants were there, there was also some pepper, and some caramel.  Added were a bit of roastiness, which surprised me.  Dry finish, and I usually dont like dry that much.  Definitley the best dry beer I have had.  Pretty darn good.

Mmmmm....very much like a friend of mine likes his tea (or was it women?). God I love my Duvel tulip, shows this beer off to perfection...deep black with a huge tan head which slowly dimishes leaving plenty of lace. Vinous, fruity, funky aroma giving a subtle hint of things to come. Flavour is oak, dried fruit, plums, port; very well balanced, not too sweet not to dry, very little bitterness, and almost no evidence of the 10.5% ABV. I am a big fan of high ABV beers that hide it well. Palate complements the flavours, but is not quite to De Dolle standards. If I was capable of drinking this all night, I would! Another excellent broue from Unibroue (especially after consuming a 750ml bottle by myself).

Pours a clear deep red with a small fizzy brown head. Earthy brown sugar aroma with cocoa , marzipan, some sour cherry, nut cake. Big in body. Slightly chalky. Well balanced flavors reflecting the aroma and a perfect bitter finish. I like.
Bottle: Brown with no head. Nice dark fruits in the aroma. Flavour starts with cocolate, raisins and other dark fruits. Spicy esters in the finish. Nice stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2006 I have only managed to try this beer a couple of times but will have to get around to having it more. Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer pours a very dark black color with a huge dark brown head that lingers. The aroma is sweet, richly malty and has that bready yeasty nature that is found in many Unibroue products. The flavor is strong with sweet dark malts and has lots fo ripe fruits, light chocolate and brown sugar elements. There is a bready - yeasty undertone. The mouthfeel is nicely smooth.

You should always try a beer twice. This time I didnt chill it... I just summoned the courage to have another go at my dreaded Bomber Number Two. The cork resoundingly revealed a still very lively beer at 9 months, maybe the ample carbonation was now smoother. This time Terrible had nice underpinnings of wine-like flavor, sort of a young Moulin-A-Vent like sugariness and an almost Pino Noir-ish grapey/dark berry thing going on. Powerful and integrated, not astringent but quite more-ish. I was impressed.

I wonder if the temperature had a big effect, or the slight extra ageing, or if the bottles were not equally good... or if my expectations got in the way. I will grab a few more to gauge consistency.

OLD RATING 7/4/5/3/13 Bomber cellared 6 mos. Pours yeasty dark brown with nice, fine head activity. Yeast and soft spice aroma. Flavor profile is undefined and odd to me, perhaps b/c alcohol does assert itself where rich notes of fruit are fighting to express - they seem a bit defeated. Hints of lemon rind and cola emerge and vanish. Long off-dry malty finish. Slightly peppery feel from carbonation. This brew has a sweet body but slightly astringent feel, I cant quite get it. Hmm... noteworthy but not a standout Uni-Belgian for me.
Great dark pour with frothy head that reminds me of rootbeer....settles nice.  Raisens and plums....sugary sweetness. Tastes a little like baked prunes.
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2006 Rerated.  Dark Dark brown you cant see through. Not enough bubbles a very flat brown ale.  Acidic throughout the taste with some chocolate slivers.

Dirty mahoganey, Thin creamy white head, fades to almost nothing.
Strong grassy and sugary dark fruit aroma. 
Fruit liquor. Banana brownies. Sweet grapes and apples. Almost too sweet at times. Slight chocolate hints.
Thick, full flavor. I appreciate the smoothness.

Aroma is like raisins and plum with brown sugar. The appearance is like dark chocolate with a nice foamy head. The flavor is very nice with all the qualities of the aroma plus some spiciness. The finish is a nice warming from the alcohol.
This is a seriously wild beer. smells of raisins and other sweet fruit, taste of malt and dark fruit, with carmel and brown sugar, this is the type of beer you want for dessert, enjoy!!
Dark brown colour. Candysugar nose with some woddy hints. Sweet, malty flavour with notes of dried fruits. A little chocolatey. Some residual sugars here. Absolutely no alcoholtaste. Somewhat acidic.

Very much like the other Unibroue beers Ive tried.  Tastes a bit heavy on the corriander or some spice they use.  Much too heavily spiced anyway.  Very fruity aslo, Im not sure maybe Ive just grown tired of the belgian style.  Im glad my roommate only shared a bit of this with me.
Bottle. Dark brown with beige head. Liquid chcolate, madeira, roasted notes and some fruity tartness (berries, green apples), alcohol hid well. Short finish.

2004 Bottle, in my cellar for about 10 months I guess.  Spice and dark malty sweetness in aroma.  Slick dark tan head, very dark brown pour.  Lovely sweet dark malt taste - spiciness is in the background at first; first few sips are dominated by a sweetness not usually found (by me anyway) in strong Belgian ales. Medium to full bodied as well.  Tons of spicy flavours come out as it warms, all with absolutely no hint of the alcohol - amazing.  No classic Unibroue yeast taste or aroma either.  What a wonderful beer, a decent choice for 666.

Poured dark brown with a modest head and durable surface lacing. Aroma-complex and perfumy, dried fruit, chewing gum, light smokiness, lime. Medium bodied, old, malty and oaky, raisins and slight sour vinous note. Medium finish, dryish and warm. Sep 9 2003.

2004 vintage, 750 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown and opaque with slight orange highlights, and a large foamy tan head that diminishes leisurely and leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is yeasty brown bread with brown sugar, herbs and lots of spice.  Flavor is sweet, earthy and and spice with hints of molasses, dark rye, floral hops and clove - the alcohol is very well hidden I must say.  Medium body and gentle carbonation.  Very enjoyable.

Very dark brown with reddish hues. Two fingers of head even with a gentle pour. Rich candied malt aroma with hints of cherry and spice. This beer is sweetly complex without being overpowering and made me think of cherry pie. Perfect carbonation throughout and a dry lingering finish. Im liking Unibroue more and more for hitting the sweet spot in quality and price.

Oooooh man.  One of the finer things.  Poured from a bottle, into a dark brown-tan color with a thin brown-black head. Like most Unibroues theres a defined sweetness and spiciness in aroma and taste and here its somewhat subdued and accompanied by a hint of roast.  Sorry, I just didnt taste the "salty rocks" here.  Slick, minimal packaging, corked bottle.  Quality, people.

Medium body & mouthfeel, somewhat low carbonation.  Alcohol blends well with malty sweet and semi-fruity taste.  The taste starts sweet & finishes malty, but theres a hint of tuna or salty rocks in the middle.  Im not sure how to describe better, but it just flattens out and brings the whole taste down for me.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2005 Lustrous deep black / brown color, contrasted against a fairly well kept laced head, good body, coffee flavor with a bitt too much over-riding alcohol in taste and on the nose, but while solid good, just lacking something to push it higher in the ratings.  Hey thats just me.  My fellow tasters did not enjoy this brew much as measured against others in the sampling.

From a bottle. Aroma is sweet and slightly frutiy - almost a raisin-like smell. The appearance dark dark brown, with light tan head that quickly dissapated. The flavors are complex: light and sweet up front with a heavy malty finish, almost like a brown ale (huh) to my amateurish taste buds. Overall I like the flavors better than a brown ale - much more depth. A slight alcohol bite is present although for 10.5%, it is not intrusive. The palate for me left a little to be desired for such a complex flavor and aroma.  Medium body, almost-flat carbonation, and a quick finish. Overall Im fairly impressed with this beer. While Ive had other Unibroue brews and Im pretty sure there are others I like better, this is only the second Ive rated.

Terrible indeed...I suppose I should start with the positive and say that it really is a beautifully presented bottle. In terms of a score the beauty of the bottle certainly evens out the ugliness of the beer itself. Theres barely any pressure to push the cork out and I have to pour from quite a distance to get it to form any head, which doesnt last at all anyway, quickly reducing to some fine white wisps like cirrus on an otherwise clear day (oh dear, am I turning into MartinT?) The liquid is a weird black colour with more browny-grey highlights than red, though in a wine glass it looks a whole lot like red wine from a distance. Aroma? Theres surprisingly little for a beer thats 10.5%. Obviously the toasted sugar, pears and stinky esters of the house yeast is there but even that is restrained. It vaguely hints at both a red wine and Flemish sour ale character but never really delivers on either. Some vanilla, but really the only thing that makes it seem like its 10.5% is the alcohol. Surprisingly thin and lifeless body - I usually dont complain about beers being on the low end of carbonation but I reckon in this case it would have given the beer a bit of vibrancy and brought out a little more character. Lightly sugary-sweet, milky flavour with more toasted sugar notes. I like how they get it dark without any dark malt character, but theres just not a lot else there. Its headily alcoholic too. Its not bad beer as such (though it did have some elements I didnt like), but for a beer of such a reputation (not to mention $18) this really should at least have more flavour, and preferably good flavour. I really should have learned my lesson with Unibroue by now...

Poured dark brown with a hint of red.  Malt and mild sweetness and spice in the aroma. The flavors are a mix of yeast/malt and some cherry-like sweetness, but I felt this needed more of a spicey aftertaste, clove or all spice and this just didnt deliver. It was almost too smooth.

Definately drinkable, but after having tried quite a lot from Unibroue, I fell that the difference between them are not too big and that they never have what it takes to get up there among the greatest. Pours dark brown almost black with a fine beige head. Dominating roasted malt and yeast aroma with a touch of spices and pepper and a nice sweetness. Biding spicy flavor with plenty of roasted malt and some herbs and hops and tones of liquorice. Nice, but the Unibroue yeast is too evident, like in many of their beers. Warming from the high ABV.

Aroma of black cherry over horse-blanket.  Appears a dark brown; like root beer.  Flavor is of bret with caramel and a noticeable taste of alcohol.  Palate is both medium-thick and appropriate.  Overall, I was not as excited about this beer as others may have been, however I do believe that I will give it another shot after aging.
Really strong, dark beer, with many layered flavors that accentuate each other nicely.

This beer has a bite, but goes down so smooth as the bite dissolves in your mouth, its appearance is compareable to coca cola, dark fat tan lasting head, good healthy body & flavor, this is very drinkable ( i mean sipable) another good Unibroue beer.

A deep dark brown with a ruby tint to it. A light tan head with aromas of sweet fruits and a yeast tang. Tastes very fruity but with a nice hint of roasted malts underlying it. Similar to Trois Pistole.

750ml bottle:  This one pours an opaque brown, with tinges of ruby.  There was a small tan head that dropped down quickly.  The aroma has a sweetness to it.  There are hints of some fruits, possibly raisins and plums.  Some yeastiness and breadiness also.  The taste is quite good.  It has many tastes of a good belgian strong, but there are hints of roastiness and coffee also.  This was really good!

03-03-2003
Pitch dark brew. Small beige head and some laces. Nose:typical Unibroue yeast signature and faint smoke notes, perhaps cold tobacco.  Definetely on the sweet side with subtle sour notes. Flavors of plums, raisins and berries. Alcohol content very well hidden. Laid down for 2 years, very well preserved but did not gain in complexity. Not my favorite Unibroue but still a very good Belgian Ale.

(Bottle 75 cl) Very dark and opaque, very small, lacing head. Pronounced alcohol in the nose. Very malty with notes of dried fruits - especially raisins. Odd underlying sourness. Ive had this stored for six months - I think I should keep the remaining bottles for a couple of more years. 310505

This one poured a solid black with a beige head. The aroma is rather smoky with some charcoal and chocolate. The flavor has a charcoal and tobacco presence with some dark fruit and coffee. Overall I liked this one.

Bottle: (2004) Dark Brown, nearly black, HUGE frothy beige head, appears honeycombed from outside the glass, huge empty caverns thoughout the head, sporatic lacing.   Wonderful aroma, quite candyish, sugary sweet, light dark pitted fruit.   Sweet malty start, picking up more sweetness as it finishes.   Subtle dark pitted fruit, quite subtle.   Seems not as complicated as I once remembered it.   Body and mouthfeel also seem fairly average, down a bit from a year ago (roughly).   Raisins, plums, and a smidgen of plum on the finish.   Still remains sweet, malty, and slightly bready.   Just seems to have thinned out a bit.   Not very complex, good otherwise.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle and shared with friends. Pour dark pitch in color. Fluffy head stuck around until beer started to get warm. Noticed a light sour smell when first poured. Coffee & chocolate tones came forward as beer started to warm. This is a belly warmer and you can taste the higher alcohol content however it is not over powering. A good beer to drink on a cold day.

Beautiful dark color and rich aroma of sour fruits and malt.  Thin gold head with a mild carbonation throughout.  A diverse flavor mixed with burnt coffee, chocolate and brown sugar.  I hardly noticed the alcohol as it was perfectly balanced with the other flavors in the beer.  Another great beer by Unibroue!

Nose of dark fruits, spicy, has a distinct yeasty Unibroue aroma. Very muddy dark brown body with a small tan head on top. Malty flavor, with some dark fruits, candi sugar, some alcohol presence. Good one, but not as good as Trois Pistoles.

Love the big black bottle.  Dry, dark boozy ale.  Fantastic carbonation, some of the finest bubbles Ive ever savored.  Crisp and clean, however, missing some of the sweetness, chocolate and fruit that you find in Trois Pistoles and Maudite.  A black champagne.

This was very dark in both flavor and color.  thanks to shag for bringin this down.  strong apricot and raisin flavors.  undertones of walnuts, allspice, and brown suga.  :)  i still love this brewery and everything i have had from them seems to be top notch.

Bottle 750ml - Shared with friends - Pours black not much light gets through but what does shows ruby red highlights.  A very fluffy offwhite head at first drops down to about 1/4 inch.  Aroma was sweet candies, plums, raisins.  Smelled very rich.  Flavor is plums, raisins, some smokyness lingers in the background.  Very sweet, complex, and delicious.  The 10.5% is covered quite well but can be felt with the warmth this gives you on the back of each sip.   It finishes with enough bitterness to offset the sweet taste.   This is a fantastic brew!

Black. Huge, bubbly, light tan head. Smells belgian- sweet malt, dried fruit, candy sugar, also some yeast. Same flavor with a bit of roastedness and warming alcohol. Full body, nice level of carbonation. Excellent. Try opening one room temperature.

Nice dark brown beer with a great big tan head. Intens malty and caramely aromas with fine hints of dried fruits, flowers, coffee, and spices. The taste is round and has a mild caracter. There is a good malty presance with fine sugary accents and with a fine spicey elegance. It has also a sexy fruity accent that brings a nice balance in this brew. It end with a well integrated coffee bitterness and some hints of dried fruits. At the Copenhagen Beer Festival.

Came in a 750mL bottle with a cork.  This beer pours a dark body with a tan head that sticks around.  The aroma was spicy, but also had some caramel and a sweet fruityness.  Very nice body on this brew.  Spicy and malty with flavors of chocolate, brown sugar, and some spices and fruits.  Extremely good Belgian style.  Love this beer.
Deep mahogany body, off white head.  Yeast aroma with a yeast taste and weak palate. The alcohol also came foward on this one.
Malty nut aroma on the nose. Black body and brown head that left lacing on the glass. Rich sweet coffee flavor that went down smooth on the palate. A good beer.

Bottle poured Dark red brown with a nice big head and lacing.
Aroma of yeasy and spice.
Flavor is malt,spice, light roast with the alcohol well hidden.
Very good beer. Thanks horseys!
Opaque brown with a thin white film of a head.  Spicy and yeasty aroma.  Cinnamon. Rich and aromatic.  Flavor is also rich and spicy.  Nutmeg?
Poured dark brown with a tan head. The aroma was yeast and metal. Flavor: yeast, spices, metallic, and cloves. Very thick almost chewy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation tickles the tongue.
Black with ligth brown head. Yeast in tha aroma. Spicy taste with a hint of sourness and yeasty spicy aftertaste.
Bottled. Deep brown color with an off white head. The taste is sweet with yeast and spices dominating the body.  The yeast has some slight sour notes. Quite warming on the palate.

Bottled. Brown colour with a beige head.
Acidic fruity aroma with notes of bread.
Nice flavour with lots of chocolate and dried fruit.
Well hidden alcohol.
Dark brown, with  an offwhite head. The nose is cinnamon, cardamom, malt, fruit and spices. The taste is sweet, with sourness and yeasty finish
Deep reddish colour with a big light brown head. Malty yeasty aroma with dark fruit and alcohol. Malty flavor with hints of dark fruit and yeast. Palate is a bit thin.
Bottle. Dark red brown colour with a big baige head. Light wheaty banana fruity aroma and taste, like a dunkel weisse. Medium body and a sweet light alcoholic finish.
(on bottle) Smells like coughsyrup; medical and liqourice. "As-you-where-unibroue"-yeasts in the flavour. Warms nicely up in the finish, with malts and alcohol. Full and warming beer.

Dark brown color, thick colored tan foamy lacy head, sweet roasted malt, dark fruits of raisins, prunes, dates, sweet chocolate, nutmeg follows through on a medium-bodied palate, with burnt brown sugar, dark fruits, nutmeg, chocolate pralines, molasses in roasted malt character, towards a malty dry finish in an alcoholic warmth.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2005 9/9/2003 750ml bottle.  Pours a dark brownish-burgundy with a huge fizzy tan head that quickly dissipates.

The aroma is rather reserved - vinous berries and a little vanilla woodiness.

The flavor is also vinous and sherry like with a sweet malt backbone underneath.  Theres some plums, woodiness and pepper.  The finish is tart fruity alcohol.  It is medium to full bodied, not much carbonation but what there is is rather harsh.

Overall, I was a little disappointed with this.  It is well made (nothing offensive about it) but a little too wine-like for me.  It is surprisingly drinkable and hides the alcohol well (until it kicks you in the butt later).

Sweet malt base with spiced adjuncts: dried fruits and caramel mainly.   Big alcohol presence start to finish; or is it because I drank this instead of breakfast?  The lively carbonation was somewhat distracting this early in the morning, but I appreciated the warming finish.  Very nicely done!

Had been keeping this for a special occasion and ended up drinking it after a big  session on homebrew. Gained a very favourable impression despite being rather pissed. Oh well Ill have to buy another one and rate it properly - bummer.
Pours a deep brown with a slight reddish tone with a large tan head.  Aroma is very cidery.  Taste is malty sweet, with a slight tartness.  This is a nice beer which hides its alcohol well.

Drinking this in my brand new crystal - a great beer for a great goblet.  Looks, smells and tastes fantastic.  You can definitely feel the alcohol but you cant taste it too much.  Reminds me of Dogfishhead raison detre, just better - a big claim i know. Also reminiscent of barleywine ales.  This is probably my favorite beer from my favorite brewery. Top Notch!

The beer immigrates from the 750ml brown cork and caged bottle a deep brown color with ruby high lights, the head dinosauric in size, creamy in texture and a nice tan color, and after decomposition, the residual lace forms a fine curtain to drape the glass. Nose is cotton candy sweet, a touch earthy, hints of over ripe fruit, plums I think, spice, woody, maybe even a touch of fusel alcohol, fresh and inviting, start is lightly sweet with a nice grain presence, the top is middling in its affect on the taste buds. Finish is ferine in its acidity, the hops pleasant and spicy, quite dry aftertaste with a nice bit of tummy warming from the 10.5 percent ABV, a nice drinking beer and from what Ive heard and read, you either Love It or Hate It, I like it.

2004: Pours dark chocolate color with medium head. Aroma is yeasty with some orange peel and vanilla notes. Flavor is unique and I cant really put my finger on it. Definitely some plum and spice in there. Sweet on the tongue with a creamy finish. Alcohol not at all apparent. Though it does warm the stomach. Well done.

Dark brown with foamy tan head. Aroma is some yeast, malt, and distant fruity esters.  Taste is malt, candi sugar, definite alc presence.  SOme dark fruit rounds it out nicely.  I am enjoying this one 10 am sunday morning, and its anything but terrible  "Its five o clock somewhere"

alcohol was certainly not well hidden.  Mainly malts to tis beer, aroma was mainly sweet with some fruit like notes.  Taste was also sweet but slightly over-carbonated which made it heavier on the palate.   A warm alcoholic finish.

Afine showing from our old Belgian Canook friends.  This rating is about my 4th attempt at this brew and I think that I am finally starting to get what every else sees.  Pours muddy with a dark, rocky head that looks vaguely pinkish in the light I subject it to.  Nice sweet aroma with plenty of those Belgian tweaks and twangs.  Wow this stuff is warming, but not bad, the resiny plum hits and forewarns of impending alcohol.  The finish is moist initially but eventually the mouth dries.  Nicely done.

Pours super dark brown.....only strong light will show. Has a initially big head that shrinks to a thin layer....almost cola in color and medium lace. Aroma is light fruit, light brown sugar, malt and yeast. Flavor is sweet plum, spice, yeast, and what I assume to be black malts. There is a hint of alcohol in the finish. Also, there is something I cant place no matter how hard I try to think of a way to describe it.  This is great stuff, but way too expensive in my area. I am happily working my way through a bottle, but at almost 10 bucks Im taking my time.

The pour is almost opaque, but very strong light will reveal a dark brown body that has a deep ruby hue in the edges of the glass. Brilliantly clear after 10 months in the cellar.
It forms a  reserved, fleeting head which easily laces the glass.
Heavy malt aroma, even when first opened and cold. Heavy caramel with raisins and dates.  Rich and complex. 
Not overly sweet, but rich and smooth. Not quite Trappist but makes you think youre close.
Just Terrible.

Poured a brown color with a redish hue with a large foamy head.  Aroma was of sweet caramely malts and a bit of yeast.  Flavor was semi sweet with a heavy yeast flavor.  Medium mouthfeel with a yeast aftertaste.

How funny that this should rate so much higher than the 2005.  Like the edition 2005 this works better as a cordial or after  dinner drink than it does as a beer.  Jet black, foreshadowing the intensity of the beer.  Less complex than the edition 2005, with a slam of sweet malt and chocolate, and a hint of fruit.

Pours a nice almost black color.aromas of dark fruit and malt.Flavor has a wonderful blend of the dark fruits and chocolate.i felt the alcohol was making a slight presence, but didnt affect the taste in any which way.Unibroue never seizes to amaze me.They are great brew and hopefully will be around a long time.

I have had this beer 4 times so far. Once when it was young and I was greatly disappointed,once at a beer taste and was impressed(go figure). Twice at home since. Usually Unibroue is pretty consistant,this one was not. Mild chocolate and dark fruits,but initially served at 50 F the Unibroue yeast strain was dominant. As it warmed to 60 F + it improved hitting me with some spice. This review number is based on all 4 tastings .IMO,this one is hit or miss,something that I have found to be unusual from this usually consistant brewery.
Carmelized pecan aroma, crackerjacking into a full candi noseball, reeking of top-ferment.  Palate crisp, creamy, malty liquor back-of-mouth hum.  Floral adenoid burp.  Well done.
wonderful beer with a wonderful nose of Plums toffee raisins and apricots. chocalate spice overtones and a wonderful full mouthfeel.

2003 bottle. Dark brown color with minimal head and lacing. Typical Unibroue all around, lots of yeast, black cherry aroma. More of the same in the body, plus coconut, alcohol, very sweet, medium body. Has a fizzy body, reminiscent of cola. Good but not at the same level as some of their other brews.

Bottled.  Pours very dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is sweet with chocolate, light vanilla, and a light fruitiness.  Taste is also sweet with  chocolate notes again, distinct yeasty flavors, raisins, caramel malts, and more than a tinge of alcohol giving way to a serious alcohol warming.  Some choco-fruitiness in the end....tasty.

Pours very dark with a fizzy light tan head that dissipated, leaving a small film on the beer.  Aroma is yeasty fruits and apples, similar to other Unibroue offerings, but somewhat richer and maltier.  Taste is very similar to Unibroue, as it follows from the aroma:  dark fruits, some spice, with a bone-dry finish.  There are small hints of chocolate or coffee in the flavor as well.  The alcohol is very well-hidden.  The body unfortunately felt somewhat thin for a beer this dark.  It is also very carbonated... tastes forced, even.

Dark brown hue and thick tanned colored head that retreats to flat nothing.  A earthy and wood aroma that also smells like some root beer.  I love Belgian strong ales but this one is a strange brew. Somewhat unripe fruit flavor and scoop loads of sugar. Even though this is my first Unibroue, i got a bad first impression already.

Almost pitch black pour, a little scary at first, and not a very thick head. Aroma is outstanding, a lot of fruit, classic Unibroue, maybe a little chocolate on the nose. Highly carbonated, and pretty fruit forward, which contradicts the appearance. Perfect balance, more fruit on the finish, followed by smooth chocolate.

Poured a reall dark brown with almost no head, aroma was spicey and malty, with some yeasty hints. Flavor was interesting, for the strength of the alcohol it was hidden pretty nicely. I felt it had some spices, maybe some liquorish flavor in there as well, but overall very tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2005 Pours a dark brown/reddish color. Sweet aroma of yeast and apples. Powerful flavor right up front. Some bitterness with alot of spice and some kind of fruitiness. Finish seems to be fairly tart. As I got down to the last third of the bottle it got alot warmer and the alcohol taste became terrible.

Dark brown liquid, strange for a belgium style brew in my expirence. Nose is malty with Unibroue yeast. Similar in body to Trios Pistoles, the difference being La Terrible leans more on the malty side compared to the Fruit found in the Trio of Pistols brew. Dried fruit and a quite a bit of caramel are found in this one.  The body is dry and yeasty goodness. Overall a complex wonderful brew. The 10.5% alcohol is so well hidden youll find yourself quite toasted before the last sip, you might want to find a valued friend to share this one with.

Just about as good as it gets for me.  Incredibly light body for the high alcohol but still full enough to keep me interested.  Dark cherry aftertaste, very lively yeast flavors.  Tart, sweet, dark, bubbly and wonderful.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2005 dark brown with a very bubbly, but quickly gone head. Very yeasty, dark malt and brown sugar. Some plum and raspberry. Sweet and spicy, but lacking in the hop area and finishes smooth.
bottled. a bit of a struggle. dark brown, brown sugar aroma, plenty of alcohol, standard unibroue yeast, candi sugar, a little stale homebrew nastiness lurking behind some chocolate flavour, i dunno

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2005 I had this beer while I was snowed in in College Park, Md. after the presidential inauguration.  Pours very dark brown with a light tan head that was slightly thicker than I expected, but that disolved fairly quickly.  Very spicy aroma.  Soft, full mouthfeel.  The flavor was overpoweringly sweet at first, but I usually drink hoppier beers.  After a few sips, I was able to taste the cinnamon and other spices in it.  Not a beer I would necessarily enjoy again.  I see the appeal, but dont like them this sweet.
Belgian strong nose qualities. Dark dark amber. Very nice flavor. Smooth alcohol presence. There is nothing terrible about this beer.
Brown colour, decent tan head. Fruity yeast, with some hints of alcohol. Fruity belgian taste with some interesting spices. nice malty belgian!

Pours a dark chocolate brown with a modest tan head that doesnt last as long as Id like.  Fruity, alcoholic aroma with a touch of spice.  First impression of the flavor is of grape juice? Odd, I know. As it warms the beer becomes much like a winter warmer. A plethora of spices I feel are well masked in this ber.

Ive drank several of these in the past couple months,  had a few bottles with bad corks that werent drinkable.  But when theyre good,  theyre damn good.
Great looking beer,  yeasty, clovey,  and a bit fruity with alcohol presence.. really sovour every sip,  my fave Unibroue and I like em all.

Yummy. This comes through the LCBO but once a year and never disappoints. Its a dark, dark burgundy-brown, with a pile of yeasty, malty flavour base that has a plethora of spice, fruits, cloves, et cetera. Classic Unibroue.
This one has so many spices going on inside, you can practically hear the strains of "Ill tell you what I want, what I really, really want..."  Awesome.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Very dark mahogony.  Champagne head.  Unibroue nose w. plum, clove, fruit.  Typical unibroue yeast flavor with lots of clove and apple.  Tart appley finish, some alcohol

cork read 03 - 1 (ok im gonna skip the terrible jokes)
this b.s.a. poured a black body with a white head.very pleasing to the eye.the frist sniff gave me cherries,prunes,yeast,chocolate,and malts.i was very happy with the flavor as well.it was a nice mixture of,molasses,yeast,cloves,spice,and malts.this is my favorite unibroue so far.

Rich malt aroma along with some fruit, grain and alcohol. First sip comes across a bit too strong, but then it smoothed out well with tastes of caramel, soft spice and rich fruit. Medium to full body but at times it seemed that it was thin as it slipped down the throat so easily. The colour of the body to me is a deep dark brown with some red tawny tinges, the head was a good size light tan head. It lasted reasonably well and left some good brussels lace. Alcohol in this beer was nice and warming and as I got into this 750ml bottle the better it got. Syrup, a little bit of coriander and cloves and maybe some soy sauce are mixed in with the taste.

Ruby black ale with a thicl off white head. Sharp coriander and aniseed in aroma, with notes of chocolate. Sweet caramel, anise, coriander, with fruity prunes and warm alcohol finsih. Almost porto like in quality, rich in body and aroma. Bought at LCBO.

Bottle courtesy of Pailhead.  Deepest brown color.  Long lasting off-white head.  Nice malt rich nose.  Medium to full bodied.  Pleasant malty and yeast flavors.  Somewhat typical of Unibroue but still very pleasant.

750ml brown bottle, corked.  Aroma is raisins, brown sugar dark fruit, vodka like alcohol . Cola coloured beer, white head fades quickly.  Touch of sourness, lots of dark malt and alcohol flavours, tingly mouthfeel. Big alcohol notes in the finish with warming effects.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2005 Pours out a deep, dark brown with a nice lacing white head. The aroma is somewhat fruity with some alcohol on the nose. The taste is typical of a Unibroue beer, but is still a nice drink with notes of fruit, caramel and  maybe a note of syrup.....decent brew

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2005   This beer is like Chimay Bleu except it has even more kick to it.  Chimay Bleu has a much better taste.  The first sip was great and then the beer went down hill.  The taste was bitter like maple syrup.  The aroma is good.  The taste was not bad, but it wasnt really worth drinking.

A great winter ale - dark, dense and fruity.  Still, didnt make that strong an impression - until an hour later when the 10.5% ABV became quite obvious. 

Not great, but Ill be Terrible again in the future.

Corked 2004 served in a Duvel Tulip 55f
Pours dark almost black with a  1.5off white head
Aromas of Fruity esters with raisins and plums
Roast malts are subdued by the almost cloying sweetness of this brew
I  really enjoyed this beer.A very drinkable Belgian Strong. If you like
Big sweet malty beers with little hops this is a winner

75cl bottle, Sept 9, 2003 on the back of the bottle.  Uncorked completely flat.  No carbonation at all.  This really ruined the beer.  It ended up tasting like a Bourbon and soda made with old, flat diet pop...very sweet, and syrupy.  Just terrible...maybe it could have been good, I dont know.

Pours a semi-lucid mahogany with a small mocha-colored head.  Aroma of fruits, clove, and alcohol.  Flavor is very complex, moderately sweet, dominated by ripened fruit, yeast, and alcohol.  Finishes dry and bitter.

Perhaps its me but this is the worst Unibrew Ive ever tasted.

Unibrew products all tend to be somewhat sweet and I dont mind that much but this seemed just too close to the title on the bottle(Terrible).

The best this brewery has to offer (IMO) is La Fin Du Monde which is available in most larger Govt Liquor Stores.

Appearance: pours out plummish, but when I look at the results, its an unmitigated, solid black, fully opaque, with a finely fizzy, buzzingly carbonated, toasty-tan head. 
Aroma: sadly, I mostly get a cola-ish impression, something I like to avoid in beer, but also with dark fruits, and a bittersweet coffee-ish impression.
Taste: heavy, dark, and quickly weighing in with the alcohol component. A well-inegrated collection of flavors, for none truly stands out over any other, all blending terribly well....spicy, sparkly, dark, fruity, roasty, toasty, ...well-rounded, but extra-abominable in its overwhelming flavor and alcohol. This is one rich, delicious, dark, and rewarding ale. I cant quite place it above Maudite or Trois Pistoles, who have their own unique charms, which could never be overshadowed or eclipsed by this ebony delight, but this particular Belgian-style black ale is in a class of its own. Wow! "Terrible" in only the best way. Yum ,yum, yum, yum!!!

Took some effort to get the cork out of the bottle, I was worried this would be a flat beer. But alas, there is plenty of carbonation and a pillowy tan had forms. Dark brown color. Slightly musty, earthy aroma. Fruity - plums, raisins. Nice big, sweet malty flavor profile. Sweet raisins, wood, alcohol. A warming, long lasting finish is perfect for a chilly December evening.
I am continuily impressed with Uniboue and its line of affordable Belgians. I found this one complex and a definate alcohol presence.

This beer can now be bought in Florida, but this particular bottle was sent to me last year by rater Snoot. 
Bottle dated: 11/03
 Pours a dark roasty chestnut colored body, with edges of amber and a short lived light tan head. The aroma holds a cosmic maltyness. roasted grains, toffee, a chocolaty sweetness, a hint of coffee, dark wheaty breads, and a small note of clove. The flavor has a robust spicy note of maduro wrapped cigar and black pepper, and again, that clove hits you in the finish. There is a nice light smokiness to the beer, a sweet fruity note of raisins, the bravado of brown sugar, and the mysterious smoky company of molasses. This has turned out to be a very nice treat! Im ampped that I can now buy this locally! The palate is sticky sweet, with a tiny tart lemony yeasty character, and a full velvety palate. Im impressed! Id love to drink a bottle of this with a nice cigar; theyd compliment one another rather well!

Very deep dark mahogany brown color.  Surprising amount of carbonation - almost like a soda after 30 minutes in a glass - which killed any significant head.  Startlingly clean taste for such a dark brew though the flavor didnt match the fruity/berry/sage aroma.  I couldnt get past the carbonation and its possible that I let that color my opinion of the taste.  This was a 2004 bottling and it may have been a bit immature.  Im going to get another bottle of 2 and find a nice cool corner for them until next year.

Dark brown in color with a tan head. Aroma is sweet, chocolate and berries. Flavor is sweet caramel, alcohol and yeast. Finish is pleasant and warming. Does hide the alcohol well considering its 10.5%.

incredibly dark beer, very crisp at first, then a mealy thick body with a very slight taste of ginger and vegetables. also a very slight iron taste. it ends very smoothly. i thoroughly enjoyed this beer

Bottle:  Pours a blackish brown almost opaque body, with very little head.  Aromas of caramle malts, and alcohol.  Slightly nutty aswell.  Tastes is lightly sweet, but bitter as well.  Can taste the alcohol slightly.  Somewhat spicy.  Leaves a slight bitterness in mouth and surprisingly does not have a storng alcohol aftertaste.  Very enjoyable.
Nice blackish- brown and dark ambery color.   Slightly fizzy going down, somewhat sweet from start to finish. Nice mix of flavors, syrupy, sweet, hint of maple and malty.
Black color with almost no head.  Dark flowery aroma.  Plumby and burgandy-ish flavor.  A surprising good beer from a normally sub-par brewer.

Pours dark transparent brown. Nice head that lasts awhile. Aroma is apple cider and some sour/tart cherry. Taste like rotten apple/apple cider with some banana and cherry. Very smooth mouthfeel with some alcohol bite at the end. Very nice overall.

Bottle. Pours very dark (only a hint of ruby where the glass is thin) with a huge head. Very fruity aroma. Flavor is complex--very sweet in spots, sharply bitter in others, very dry. The alcohol lets you know its there when you swallow. Excellent.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2006 Bottled 2004 version. 750ml. Dark amber. Large tan head. Fruity/Floral aroma. Well Carbonated. Medium bodied. Spicey and bright. Good lingering taste. I feel this is by far the best Unibroue beer. Multiple tastings.

odeur tres fruite,levure.
Bon gout de caramel et de casonade,fruite.
Rondeur de casonade et de sucre en bouche.
Jadore le melande du sucre casaonade et du fruite de cette biere.

Bottle dated 9-9-03.  Reddish brown color out of the bottle in my snifter.    Bubbly beige head.  Sweet plum and alcohol nose.  Very warming alcohol sensation without the harsh taste.  Candied fruit sweetness with apples, pears, orange and grapes.  Really delicious and a surprisingly delicate beer for the ABV.  Very good with a smoked gouda.

Ok, so this beer doesn?t live up to its name (which is a good thing), but it really is nothing special.  Taste like a bad cross between a Belgian Strong and a stout.  Drinkable, but won?t toss the money on this beer again.

Pours a very dark brown fluffy white head. Aroma of fruitsnacks, malt, banana, and cloves. Flavor is strawberries bananas, grapes, and spices/herbs. A truly "terrible" brew ;) Thanks to Heemer for this one.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2005 Very dark brown body with a little hint of red highlights showing through. The head is thin and tan colored. The aroma is apples, pears and nutmeg spice. The mouthfeel had a fair amount of carbonation, but my tongue was also tired. The tastes were apples, cinnamon and pears. A very nice and relatively subtle version of the style. I wonder what is this one like when it gets a little age.

pours a very dark rich color with a thick dark tan head ... smells of a fruity blend w/ light scents of alcohol and hints of bubble gum..palate has some great carbonation good reamy swallow.. the flavor finishes w/ a little spice and a very light easy alcohol taste that lingers in my mouth and feels nice and warm after I swallow in addition to this I get some sweet fruity flavors in the taste w/ maybe a malty flavor as well.  This was a great beer and I enjoyed it thouroughly.

Thick tan head that takes sometime to fall.  Very dark garnet color.  Spiced blackberry aroma.  No apparent hop aroma.  Slightly tart with a spicyness that hits the back of my tongue and lingers.  Maybe nutmeg?  Smooth drinking with little after taste.  Alcohol is very carefully hidden in the malt backbone.  Hop bitterness is subdued and balanced beautifully.  This is a very easy drinker at 10.5%.  I would prefer a little more complexity but beggers cant be choosers and theis is an exceptional bier.  Well worth the price.

Very dark borwn color, with almost a hint of purple.  Aroma is typical Unibroue: apples, currants, clove, pepper, alcohol.  Maybe smokey.  Flavor is as complex as the bouquet as quite similiar.  Despite the rich color and high alcohol, very drinkable.  A whole body warmer.  Very good, but Unibroues spice flavors do not do it with me.  I want black pepper in a Zinfandel, not a beer.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2006 This poured a deep brown color, very carbonated, with a frothy tan head.  Theres some sweet malt aromas in the smell, but mainly spices, apple, and alcohol.  The flavor is fairly sweet with an underlying tartness, some caramel and fruit, a lot of spices and pepper.  Also much alcohol.  This is a nice warming drink.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL<font size=-1>

Bottle:  Malty fruity aroma.  Definite apple.  Pours a dark brown with a red tinge.  Okay off-white head.  Reminds me of a livelier carbonated version of Trois Pistoles.  Lots of raison. Some caramel and apple in the flavor.   Alcohol covered up very well.   Not quite as good as TP, but reminds me of it.

Deep bronze color with the antithesis of a head, slippery alcohol legs.  Smells of sassafras, malt, caramel, tart wine, alcohol and spices.  Flavor is sweet with dark fruits a tart middle with a light peppery finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with no co2  watery.  I would have to say that even though this beer has no carbonation, it still has some nice qualities.  Looks as if I got a bad batch.

Dark brown with a very small tan head.  Aroma of yeast and caramel with a fruit-hop nose.  Taste is creamy caramel and malt with a fizzy feel and yeast aftertaste.  Warm refreshing, creamy, and fizzy palate.
Pours brown with a tan colored head.  Slight fruitiness mixed with the malt but not overly sweet.  Big, Belgian yeast character.

bottled on 9-9-03.Very nice nose of the Unibroue yeast strain,raisin,caramel,bubblegum,spices.Nice dark brown>black,crazy head,nice lace.The palate could use some more body but this is a very nice beer.Very nice warming alcohol that you dont really encounter in the taste.

2004 printed on the cage, best before 08-08-2007 on the bottle.
Pours a dark iced coffee color with a quickly dissapating tan head. no lacing left behind. 
Aroma is sweet, fruity, (black cherries, plums, raisins) Malty (dark bread) with rum like notes.(Mollasses, brown sugar)
Alcohol is clearly visible floating on top as a well as coating the glass when swirling.
Flavor is chocolate, raisin/prune, and a little bannana bread in the background.
A little alcohol warming in the belly
Very tasty. I plan on getting another to cellar for a year or two.

092303 on bottle:  Foamed up decently when I poured it, but it quickly dissapated to looking like a flat coca cola but a bit darker.  Yeasty, bready aroma with dark fruit to it.  Tastes kind of like Coke with dried black cherries.  Along with that I get Belgian yeastiness, raisin, molasses, anise, and a touch of spice.  Alcahol comes out a little more as it warms, but it is very well hidden.  Body is a little thin, but it works for me.  This is one of the best if not the best Unibroue Ive had.

Date on bottle: 9/23/2003. Dark brown, about the color of coke. Aromas of dark fruit, malt, spice, yeast, and even a little bit of licorice. Flavor is dark fruit, malt, brown sugar, some spice and chocolate.  Body is on the light side. Another really good Unibroue.

Very dark brown color with a small tan head. Nice dark malt aroma with a lot of spices and dark fruit in the nose. Very
dry, malty flavor with a peppery finish.
Most Unibroues Ive sampled have a very similar aroma and flavor(not that i mind because I love them all)but this one 
is very different. It definitely isnt Terrible.
Deep Dark brown with a Nice sized Tan Head.  Yeasty aroma with hints of Dark Fruits.  Taste is of Dark fruits, earthy malt and some mild spice. Full bodied and quite tasty.
Very dark, with a tan head.  The aroma is great; yeasty, fruity and full. However, the flavor just wasnt quite as powerful. Nice spicy notes, but just too thin.

Poured a dark brown color with a tan head. Aromas and tastes of spices, brown sugar, molasses and some dark fruits. On the sweeter side. Alcohol content well hidden. It is good beer, but I still felt I wanted a little more out of it.

The darkest Belgian Style Abbey I have ever seen. Nearly black, but it cant be called black cause it was nearly black. More like a very dark brown. A nice sumptous head floats above the ale.  The nose was full of dark fruits, roasted malts, yeast, alcohol and bananas. 

The flavor was rather dull and the low point in the beer. I was expecting much more. Dark fruits in the flavor, grapes mostly, but some raisins and plums as well. A slight woodiness and very yeasty. Not as full bodied as I expected.

Born on date : 2003-03-03. Intriguing, inviting aroma of licorice with malty caramel notes, dark fruit and spices too. Dark brown color with a ruby shine, very fugaceous light brown head, it became a ring around the glass in a matter of seconds. Subtle, gentle and caressing flavor of licorice, dark fruits and spices with a bitter finish. As the beer warms up some chocolate notes appear.  Light body, soft carbonation, liquorous texture. Its good but the body is much too light, with a fuller body this beer would be awesome.
Very dark, thin head. It has a pretty strong, sweet taste with a little spice bite. Easy to drink, but not quite as good as I thought it might be.
Black with a thick, off-white head. Tastes like melted candy with lots of licorice and bubblegum flavors. Not very well balanced unfortunately and far too sweet.

bottle from 207th street warehouse,
has a pitch black appearance almost cola-like. tastse malty, spicy. decent alcohol finish easy sippin although t the fist sip really was bad.
Black Coloring.  Good Head.  Definitly a Belgian.  Yeast Comes Out Towards the End, Some Warming From the Alcohol.. For the Hype, A Bit of a Let Down, but Definitly a Very Good Beer.

Disturbingly brown or black.  It looks as thick as a marsh.  Medium head.  Sweet malts on the nose.  More malt and mostly alcohol in the taste.  Maybe some nuts?  Im not too sure.  A little spice too.  Not the greatest Belgian Strong by a long shot, but good enough.  I have another bottle relaxing for a few months; well see if that changes anything.

dark brown with tan head. coffeeish nose, couldnt get much else nose because I was at a beach burn at ocean beach.  dark malty flavor, some licorice and alcohol.  lively carbonation.  must have been the environment but I didnt get any of the fruit nose or flavors.

Pours an extremely dark brown with a large amount of tan head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with a hint of alcohol and spice.  Flavor is of fruits, spices, alcohol and malt.  A very warming finish as it goes down.

Pours a jet black with a small tan head.  Aroma is very spicey.  Just taking a wif you know this is a good one.  Flavor is apple, cherry tartness.  Very smooth as it goes down.  Lots of fruityness and mustyness going on here.  This is good stuff.
Wonderful dark fruits in the nose and on the tongue. Perfect when served in a nice Cabernet glass. A real winner form the brothers up north. Lets see if Sleeman screws this one up.

Pours dark brown and sits black with a fairly quickly dissapearing brown head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruits and a hint of alcohol.  The beer has a very nice full aroma that really draws you in and gets you ready for the taste.  Its malty and sweet with a little bitterness in the taste.  There is some spiced flavor at the back and it hides the alcohol nicely.  Very smooth, big, and bold.
Another keeper.  Black and sweet aroma. Ginger and root beer flavours are tremendous.  Wonderful!

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2004 Bottled: Black brown coloured. Not much head. Light brown. Spices, alcahol, caramel in the aroma. Flavour is dominated by the alcahol. Malts, fruits, spices and yeast present. Is sharp alcaholic and very warming in the end. Thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 for this.

Sweet spicy aroma. Ginger, cola, root beer, malts, bubblegum. Dark brown black with no head. Medium watery body with light medium carbonation. Light warming. Starts with medium malty sweetness, musty, Belgian yeast. Bubblegum and herbal notes, light carbonic acidity. Watery finish, but sweet and clean. Light bitterness, raisin. After is sweet malt and yeast.

Yeasty hoppy  coffee alcohol aroma. Almost black sparkling appearance with beige head.  Fruity  black cherry, prune yeasty  alcohol flavor with fine carbonation. Mild hop finish. Yeasty fruity aftertaste.

ohhhhh, yummy....one I definitely look forward to revisiting.  Georgeous pour....like motor oil with a tan head, very attractive (more lacing would have really done me in though, thus the 4).  Smooth inviting maltiness with a floral bouquet.  And my nose did not let me down in the taste....sweet maltiness with a citrusy tartness and the alcohol is amazingly well masked.

I enjoyed this beerr.   This beer poors a very dark brown to almost black with an average tan head.(if the head was longer lasting it would have been a five of five)  Aroma of dried fuit and malt.  Flavor is complex and nice.  Sl sweet initial taste with a nicely balanced sl bitter finish.  Alcohol is well masked.  Overall a nice effort by Unibroe.  A repurchase on my list for sure.

Dark body, black in colour, with a slight head making an appearance. Strong malt and caramel aromas, accompanied by some sweet alcohol aromas. Taste is sweet and sour. Some spicy hints with some hoppy bitterness. Floral as well. very complex. No alcohol aftertaste, which is good. WELL DONE!!!

Pours almost opaque dark brown-black with thin brown head...smells of raisins, plums, prunes, caramel so complex...tastes malty, earthy, citrusy, also so very complex...warm fruity finish...this is delicious...

Bottle. this raring is from notes that i took at Lumpys house. Thanks, Brother. Bottle. POurs a solid black with a thin light brown head.  has a yeasty earthy aroma. flavor is bitter and earthy with a dried plum/raisin taste. this has a malt finish of sweet caramel. finish is very warming.  the overall taste of this is a warming sweet citrus, this also has a touch of citus as it warms. there are also developing flavors of spice to this. My opinion to people trying this is to give it two chances, one when first opened, another about thirty minutes later. You will experience two different beers this way. They are both good.
Bottle. Flavors of alcohol, rasins, malt, carbonation, currant, and dried cherry abound. Finish is dry with a perfect alcohol warmth. This is good stuff!

Pours burgundy/dark brown.  Fruity, spicy aroma with a taste of fruits, mead, cognac, spice, molasses, and soy.  Wonderfully complex.  As it warms the alcohol becomes more noticable, but at the same time additional flavors peek out like cherries, nuts, and chocolate.  This is a great beer.
Deep brown/black with a lot of carbonation but tan head fades rapidly. Bready aroma. Flavors of dark fruits with strong yeast finish.

Pours a black color with a nice off-white head that leaves thick lacing on the glass. Spicy aroma, with a nice belgian style, dark fruits, and a good hopped backing. The taste was very sweet at the start, hints of dark fruit and fig, lots of spice and a mildly bitter end. Great brew.
Black like night with thick head. Aromas of cream chocolate, sweet prune/raisen, spice and a cherry quality. Molasses, cherry, honey, fig, melon?, flavors erupt on the palate. Fun beer to drink.
Nice Dark Brown in color and malty aroma. Liked it alot but not my fav. Unibroue.

Dark dense brown appearance, moderate short-lived foam. Malty, roasty aroma with mint leaf and coriander spice. Sweet clove palate, minty fresh, dries out mid-palate to a coffee roastiness. Malt and spice linger throughout.

This was outstanding.  I only managed to get a small sample of this but wow, it was incredible.  The aroma was that of dried fruits, maybe raisens or figs, and the appearence was dark brown without a head.  The flavor followed with the dried fruits and a nice balance of malts.  This is an incredible beer and one definitely worth trying.  Highly recommended.

750ml- Bottled Sept 9, 2003: Pours with an adequate, frothy head that in an instant is history......it looks and pours like Pepsi in my glass. The Unibroue yeast gives such great  aromas: in this one dough, berries, plums, and prunes?;  smooth, sweet and full bodied, with flavors that include dark fruits (plum, dates, raisins) chocolate, coffee, tobacco, and cola; it has a slightly medicinal and pleasant phenolic quality; its feels rather flat on the palate, though theres certainly carbonation going on. This is easily one of the most drinkable Belgian Strongs Ive had.  The complexity, flavor profile, and well hidden alcohol makes this an outstanding brew with the main flaw being its (perceived) flatness that subtracts from the appearance and palate scores (this could be in the top 5 for me, otherwise). Outstanding!

Bottle-In the vaults of HI International. Pretty malty, sweet, candy sugared Belgian style ale. Yeasty, with lots of syrupy candy sugar, bit too sweet and sticky for me, definite over the top one dimensional sweetness, which i find in a lot of Unibroue beers. Didnt really dig it too much to be honest, but theres some OK flavour.

Brewtopia04.  Hey, why not drink it while its free!  Big, heavy, sweet, and pruney.  The Unibroue guy (forgot his name) told me this joke while I was tasting: "when is a car no longer a car?  when it turns into a garage!"  No doubt a keen dose of Unibroue yeastiness in this beer.  Reminds me of Christmas.  Orange(?) corriander, pepper, grass, coffee.  Awesome.  This beer is all over the place yet so together.
Slightly spiced aroma.  There is a weird blend of spices in this one that I cant quite put my finger on.  Finishes dry with a slight aftertaste.
I told my roommate to bring me back something "terrible" from the store, and he did.  Only it wasnt terrible, it was amazing.  Beatiful in so many ways

Lovely bottle. Unibroue is great man.
Cork pops and love ensues. So pretty. Black like coal in my chalice. Black like death in my mouth and black like night in my stomach. So black for a belgian strong. So good as well. Pours like an oreo cookie. Black as night with a brilliant white head. Head dies and nose is of chocolate. Really I feel ike someone took Chimay bleu, added chocolate and Unibroue yeast. So that means notes of Chocolate, deep malt, carbonation and jock straps. Does it get any better!?
Flavors of red peppers chocolate, lemon and yeasty love. However this guy needs about a year or two to really develop. Now flavors meld rather than assert.
Go get this NOW. Buy three. Drink one now and save the other two for when your children are born. 
Grat

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2005 Bottle: From Julios. Good nose  Bit of a red wine with fruity hints as well. A familiar yeast scent too. Nice reddish brown color. Good head that disappeared to a ring. I get sweet fruity flavors. Cherry, plum, brown sugar, some ABV and like sethdude said some hefe in there. Nice finish flavorful yet very not thick or no ABV overwhelming. Im just starting to apreciate this style. Well see where it goes.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Poured very dark, almost opaque, with a medium head that settled down quick.  Sweet and spicy armoa, much like a wine.  First taste is sweet, fruity.  Plums and cherries spring up but do not dominate, light spice, very little alcohol burn.  Wonderful warmth and depth, marvellous aftertaste.  Outstanding.

Pours a rich almost black color with some caramel glints. Unfortunately, its light brown bubbly head faded quickly in my trappist glass. The aroma is definitely fruity (berries, dark cherries, banana), carries some spicy and yeasty hints, and hides the alcohol wonderfully. Taste is surprisingly sweet for a 10,5% alcohol beer. Its long bittersweet final gives you the warming effect you need after a cold winter afternoon spent outdoors. Dangerously drinkable, and perfect before going to bed...
Bottle at the Winking Judge.  Very dark redish colour with a litt bit of foam.  very well balanced for a 10.5% beer.  A good beer to relax and sip.
Shared 750 bottle. Good beer. Had a tripel smell at the first sniff. Tasted like a tripel with some dark malt to it. Alcohol was hidden very well.

Pours a deep cola color, with a small tan head resting atop.  This head quickly dissipates, leaving just a ring of tan around the edges of the glass.  Smells of dark fruit, sweet malts, and hefeweizen-like spices.  Flavor is again dark fruit and hefeweizen tones of banana and coriander, but with the addition of coffee, chocolate and yeast.  Hops leave a pleasant, grassy flavor and a bit of bitterness on the end.  Alcohol is not very evident for a beer of this ABV, and all in all I was quite impressed.  Hopefully Unibroue will not lose this treasure under ownership of Sleemans.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a very dark brown, cloudy liquid with a small amount of caramel colored head that dissipates quickly to near nothing.  Aroma is of malt, plum, raisin, fruity, maybe a faint whiskeyish character.  Flavor is of plum, raisin, fruit, but also has a faint grassy-whiskeyish that isnt pleasant.  Liquid has a very thin and watery mouthfeel, but goes down easily enough.  Not bad taken in mouthfuls, but stay away from sipping this one.  Also not very effervescent.  Sampled at 68 degrees Fahrenheit.

Very dark color in beautiful bottle. 750 ml too much, a smaller bottle would be just right. Can taste the alcohol, and bitterness. Alcohol not as masked as other Unibroues. Can substitute for an average wine earlier in the meal.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2005 Dark, ruddy purplish coloured beer with a thick tan-coloured head that lasts to the bottom of my glass.  Aromas of plum, raisin, and cherry with that characteristic Unibroue yeastiness.  A faint hint of black pepper.  Incredibly smooth with a faint fruity flavour, strong sweet maltiness, plum and cherry, yeasty Unibroue spice, sherry character, with a nice slightly bitter finish.  As it warms you get some chocolatey notes, more pepper, and a leathery dryness.  Very warming finish. Excellent brew with a rich creamy texture.

Outstanding beer. I can never make up my mind as to what my favorite Unibroue is but this is certainly up there. Strong malty flavour with  a destinctive hop bitterness and aroma poking itself out just enough to offer an interesting balance.

Pours dark opaque brown, with light quickly dissappearing foam.Fruity, floral, aroma. Spicy, syrupy, hints of carmel, chocolate, and a touch of coffee, mixed with a strong fruit and yeasty lees finish. Its an ok beer, but I don't like lees very much.
raisony malt and chocolate, light roast in the nose.  black with light brown commign through.  sweet carmel, raison, smokey, chocolate.  sweet, light signs of alc and loads of the Unibroue yeast
What a beer! Everything from the appearance of the bottle to the aftertaste of the beer is near perfect.  It's a dark beer that doesn't fill you up like other dark beers seem to do. Try it today!
NICE DARK BEER, ALMOST BLACK, WITH CREAMY HEAD,HINTS OF BURNT HOPS, AND A BITTER AFTERTASTE. NOT BAD AT ALL!

No head, dark brown. Suffered from being a little too sweet, which didn't mix well with the funkiness of the yeast. Didn't care for the balance, which just lacked bitterness in the end. Overall, good but not as good as I expected based on the other Belgian styles from Unibroue.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2004 Pours brown with almost no head. Aroma is almost entirely of straw/horse blanket. Flavor is straw/spice followed by a nice dark fruit background. This beer is soft in flavor and is more the type in which you have to actively search out the subtlies to find any real depth of flavor. The alcohol is almost undetectable. The palate is medium but fades to thin on the finish. Many of the less apparent flavor levels only come out at true room tempature, my first sip was chilled and left much to be desired so let it warm.

I tend to agree with "PushEject". Maybe my bottle got hot in transport or something. For some reason there was not alot to be desired. I had great expectations, but was a little let down with the almost mustiness, lack of carbonation and the overall sweetness. color was very dark and consistencey was thick. It did have some nice spices floating in the nose.
Clear dark brown big light head. Medium bodied a bit fruity and earthy, a very light but pleasant malt flavor. This is a real winner

750mL corked 03-1.  Impressive head that lasted a few minutes, white. This is a sexy brew! Deep mahogany ruby. Thin lace holds to edge of glass.  Slightly fruity, earthy, and some what leather like in scent. Taste is very fruity with an alcohol warth. Similar to sweetened pineapple juice, pear, and a slight linger of banana. The malts are superb! Very enjoyable and somewhat similar to wine. Wish this was more available in my area!

Pours nice deep brown with slight head and nice lacing.  Aroma is slightly fruity, some malts, and a hint of leather and musk (similar to what you get from Duvel)  Nice malty flavors with a complex finish.  Some plum, and a hint of chocolate in the flavor.  Nice finish.  High alcohol is hidden very well.

Aroma is of Dried Apricots, Malt, Dark Cherries, and I caught a slight coffee note.  It had a big head that went down very quickly.  Got much better as it warmed.  Smoot on the palate and had perfect carbination.  Was very sweet and a good Belgian.

750ml corked caged from July 02. Pours a dark brown almost black with a thin head. Aromas of toasted malts Unibroue yeast and some coffee. Somewhat stout like in the nose. The flavour is good, yeast, malts, sweet, slight alcohol kick also some mild hops I hadn't noticed before. This beer is much better at cellar temp. (53f-58f) than at a  refridgerated temp. The carbonation softens when it warms making it possible to pick up the complexities of the nose and flavour profile. Damn I love this beer!

Excellent Belgian-style beer, very dark brown in color, very little head, of what head was there was tan-ish & very subtle, very complex & fruity flavors although very subtle, overall balance was very excellent, very similar to Chimay Bleu if I may say so, very strong, very up-front, very excellent

Ignorant Texan lacks cognitive skills and general perception to enable subtle complexities to register. Was quite underwhelmed initially and gradually gravitated to plateau whereby some semblance of superior beer stared me down. Finding a certain sameness in Uni-product. Cherry aroma - not qulque chose, but still ... and speaking of still - not overly carbonated. That in and of itself is really not an issue or a problem. I just find this a good beer, but not one hat intrigues me enough to want to try it all too often.

This is one bold and beautiful belgian. Complex flavors of dark fruit- mostly bing cherries.  The bubbles are champagne like giving this a smooth mouthfeel.  Very classy and meant to be served in a fine crystal goblet.  Wonderfully coupled with the R.E.M. album "Reveal".
This was hard to rate (and drink).  Very thick, dark and malty with hints of soy-sauce. Overly carbonated and musky.  This beer tastes like an attic.

750ml Corked woth a 08-1 Stamped on the Cork Poured a a dark brown and possibly the darkest Belgian Strong Ale I've had as of yet. There is not much of a head on this one, just a very subtle thin film. Aroma is fruity with notes of cherries, some clove like spices as well as a peppery spice. The body is quite smooth and rounded with a carbonated crispness. The flavor I find similar to Trois Pistoles. It has the fruity malt and sugary sweetness as well as a spiciness that may be more dominant than the Trois. Overall this is a very nice Belgian style with a very spicy profile.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottled. Dark/deep ruby red with little head. Great fruit and spice nose.  Full body that has notes of fruits(apple, pear, apricot)  and spice(black pepper).  Hot  spice/alcohol finish.  I have been putting a few of these beers "In the cellar"  It be very nice to see how this beer mellows and develops.
Dark mahogony with a tan head. Sweet caramelly aroma with lots of fruitiness, also some chocoaltea and spice hiding out back there. Sweet, thinner than I expected. Some alcohol going down.
2004 SE gathering: Flavor is quite fruity with a cloying sweetness. Strong alcohol presence that is quite warming. Somewhat lacking in body.

Bottle: Dark brown almost black, pours heavy with a nice head. Chocolate & fruity aroma and taste with a distinct malt flavour. Alcohol content well balanced, makes a great beer to be enjoyed with respect.

This ones got it all. Pours brown with a huge head that lasts quite some time, aromas of earthy fruits and flowers. Flavor swirs about nutty with the same earthen fruit finishing with a long rasiny sweet aftertaste. Wonderful brew...
Dark and lovely to look at with a creamy tan head.  dark fruits strongly represented in this one.  Huge malts great beer

Sample glass, RateBeer Southeastern Gathering.  Lots of molasses, coffee, and chocolate.  Very dark brown color.  Very sweet throughout with a little bit of acidity in the finish.  Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: how unique, a Unibroue beer that isnt yellow and fizzy!
Poured dark brown with an offwhite head. Fruity, lightly malty taste. Finishes sweet. Good.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2006 Re-rate
A solid couple samples three years later reveal a wonderful winter warmer. As rich andcomplex as many classified as Quads.
Potent alcohol in the nose, nice ruddy brown color.  Mostly nutty, with minimal fruitiness.  More malt is required to carry the stiff ABV.  Strongly acidic and dry.  Lots of mouth action.

A deep rich toastiness to the aroma; dark roasted, black cherry-ish maltiness.  Strong presence of yeast.  Complex and very satisfying.  A terrific beer by one of the best breweries out there!  (Although, the Unibroue 11, in my opinion still reigns supreme!)
Malty and spicey. a sweet taste and a good aftertaste. A dark color. A really good beer. I'm a huge fan of Unibroue, and this may be their best.
Excellent and interesting beer.  Spices and dark belgian flavors shine in this one.

Expected a little bit more - but still a damn good brew. Dark brewed tea appearance, tight off-white head. Candy-sweet aroma with a bit of waffle syrup thrown in for good measure. A little too carbonated for my tastes which seems to be a Unibroue characteristic. Flavor has lements of dates, sweet chocolate with a intriguing back end of spiciness. Very complex - does not fall apart - just not melded together as well as most Belgians.

Great appearance.  Yeasty, standard Unibroue aroma -- which is good. If I closed my eyes, I wouldn't have know that it was dark, except for a slight syrupy twinge.  I was a bit disappointed in this for being a 98 percentile beer.  On balance, I'd buy the Don de Dieu instead.

Dark murky brown pour.  Big lasting tan head. Malty sweet yet slightly spicey aroma.  Big inital sweet taste that is washed away by a complex mix of flavors and mouthfeels.  Alot of dark fruit and spicey phenolic things going on.  A little yeasty Belgian flavors on the finish.  Fizzy dry palate with a good alcohol warming.  I liked it.

Dark brown body topped by a cream-colored head that fizzes, but doesn't seem to get any smaller very fast. The aroma is nicely spicy, a little alcohol. Nice spicy belgian character in the flavor, but a nice clean maltiness (almost like the malt in a pilsner) rides underneath keeping it from being overbearing. The alcohol is really only felt, not as much tasted or smelled. Good beer.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2005 Bottle - Poured a pitch-black beer with a nice huge dark head. Carbonation is excellent and aroma is really vinous with alcohol also perceptible. Complex flavor that includes spice, raisin and a bit of roastiness. Overall, this is a great beer that could rival some of the great strong Belgian ale but the alcohol flavor is bit too strong and should have been subtler.
Re-rate Spet 2005: Shared a 4 year old bottle with my friend Stephane and this beer has aged perfectly. The alcohol sharp taste as completly disapeared and has been replaced with more raisins notes. Wow!!!
(Bottle) Pours a bark brown color with a thin white head.  Has a banana aroma.  Flavors of raisins, figs, bananas, and plums.

Light banana ester in the aroma, and holy ethanol batman, this guy throws a huge alcohol aroma wrapped around the signature house spiciness.  Dark and sweet, some phenolics, and huge huge alcohol flavor that's rather distracting.  I'm not getting alot of malt complexity.  Well made for sure, but not my cup of beer.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 Excellent Belgian! Murky yellow/orange color. Beautiful banana fragrance, and a creamy brown head. Tastes like banana, raisons, figs, chocolate and several other things too. Complex flavors that overwhelmed my novice pallet. (In a most excellent way!) Ill be stockpiling this, and I know it will age and become even better, if thats possible.

Toasted malt aromas with bananna and alcohol coming through also. Large light brown head that lasted a while, dark brown almost black color. The up front flavor was moderately sweet with a light sweet finish with some phenolic flavors. Very complex and a very good Belgian Ale.
Good dark beer but has that certain underlying flavor which is a chraracteristic of all Unibroue beers.  I just noticed this: Unibroue=one brew?

clingy little tan head, velveety brown body.  nice lace.  yeasty, winey, ripe sweet fruits, nice alcohol presence.  woody notes hit with a leathery sweetness, more chocolatey as it warms.  big full mouthfeel, foams up a bit then astringency leaves some dry grainy malt character.  a steadily building warmth. malt profile and alcohol of a dopplebock, aroma and mouthfeel of a dubbel.

Okay, so I was trying to think of a clever way to say that the name directly implies how this tasted, then I find out that it is rated quite high. While this doesnt change my review in any way, I just think that now I am missing something, or (more likely) you guys are all crazy. This stuff is near black in colour. I am getting TONS of yeast and wheats in the nose and taste. Right there is where this goes wrong with me. I just dont like that flavour. There is some currents but that yeast just doesnt do it for me.

750mL bottle.  A near-black ale with mahogany highlights that pours with a fizzy, mostly diminishing head.  Full aroma of fruit, spices, and yeast.  Moderately lively palate holds rich flavors of plums, black currants, stewed fruit, and port wine.  Some roasted bitterness in the background, along with some slight pepperiness from the alcohol that is otherwise hidden.  Increasingly mellow as it warms.  An accomplished beer, just lacking that little bit extra.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2004 I cannot say enough about this beer. I've had it on many occasions and it is always great, sometimes amazing... A little tempermental and nicer if it has warmed a little. Beautiful bottle. Great name. Powerful. Cork, 750ml bottle conditioned. Nice caramelly nose of dried fruit. Off white small bubble head. Opaque. Complex fruity, burnt sugar, plummy/fig flavour. Some coffee. Yeasty. Many Port-like characteristics. Great mouth feel. Stunning. Extremely well crafted beer. It's funny I've yet to see a five out of five. Easily one Unibroue's best. I'd love to do a vertical tasting. Great for aging.
Awesome!  Riche Belgian-like brown-sugar, plum, raisen in the nose and the palate.  A most enjoyable beer....putting a few down to age, we'll see in a year....

Dark brown with a small off-white head that rims the glass.  Lots of fruit and yeast in the aroma.  Plums and cherries.  Flavors are rich and complex.  Malt and yeast followed by a decent alcohol tingle.  Body is smooth and perfect.  A good offering.

Deep brown with a lacy off-white head.  Hot alcohol aroma compemented by pronounced yeast with subtle malts and mild dark fruit notes.  Full-bodied with a definite malt accent.  Not chocolatey or roasted - just malt.  Yeasty up front, dry through the middle and finish.  Fun and drinkable, but not overly impressive.

Extreme Beer Fest Boston 2004:  Has a dark brown color with a good amount of carbonation and fruity smell.  Taste is fruity/malted and a slight alcohol finish.  Overall one of the better offerings from this brewery.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2004 Extreme Beer Fest '04: Color is dark brown with big foamy head.  Aroma is very fruity and sweet.  Flavor is full and malty with fruit.  It's smooth and warming.  Damn good beer.  My favorite from Unibroue so far.
Wow, what a beer. I really enjoyed this. Never saw a belgian so dark in color. Malty flavor, with some roastiness. Really yummy.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2004 Just a bit too alcoholic for me. Pours black with a tan head. Roasty Belgian like aroma. Malty flavor, with some subdued roastiness. If they would just unleash the dark malts on this and make it more in the open....YUM
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Beautiful dark roasted color which had a roasty yeasty aroma.  The flavor comprised wheat, cornfields, and dried fruits.  left a slight burning on the back of my throat from the alcohol. excellent beer

Damn.....this stuff is good.  I'm not as eloquent as the previous raters...but suffice it to say that I pretty well agree.  Complex is the one adjective that comes to mind.  Malty...sweet...dried fruits... damn....

Complex and unique sweet, spicy, estery aroma, with clove and banana characteristics from the yeast, along with some licorice, flowers, nutmeg, sandalwood, red grape,  plum, dark bread and very faint chocolate.  Deep, dark red-black color, some light tinges of mahogany when they are  searched for, and with a fine, creamy, lasting off-white head.
